Harlin climbs back onto the cart, the boards creaking under his weight. “Right,” he says.

“You’ve got steel of a sort, we’ve got water, and the bridge isn’t getting younger. Let’s

move.”

You fall into step again, sword at your side, buckler hanging a bit awkwardly on your arm

until you adjust the straps to a tolerable angle. The iron has that faint metallic chill that

seeps through the canvas; you can feel its weight every time your step jostles it.

Crossing Proxim Bridge feels different now. Earlier, it was scenery from a game you’d once

played. Now, with forty-odd inches of old Hylian steel at your hip and a shield-biscuit on

your arm, it’s a thing you’re actually staking your life on. If something came out of the river

right now, it would matter very much how well those knots hold.

Nothing does. The Hylia just keeps sliding under the stone span, wide and calm and

relentless. A frog plops off a rock and vanishes into a splash of rings.

Halfway across, Harlin raps the haft of his spear against one of the bridge’s low stone rails.

“You hear that?” he says. The tap rings off the stone, then dies quick. “Solid. Calamity

didn’t crack it. That’s why this post still matters. Monsters can skulk all they like in the

trees; as long as we hold the bridges, the roads stay open.”

On the far side, the road climbs gently away from the river, the ruins of East Post thinning

into scattered stones and the first hints of wild scrub. Ahead, the Dueling Peaks rise taller,

their twin blades cutting the horizon. Somewhere beyond them, Kakariko waits, folded into

its valley.

You’ve got sun on your back, a sword that might not disintegrate at first hit, a shield that

might keep one blow from your ribs, bread in your stomach, water not too long behind

you, and two living, breathing Hylians who’ve tacitly decided you’re their problem for at

least one more stretch of road.

For a man who woke up with nothing this morning, it’s not a bad start.

I fall back into the rhythm of the road for a while, looking at the sword in my hand more frequently than was necessary. It had no scabbard, no home, needed to be carried--much like myself. I'd never actually handled a sword in my life before--although amusingly I had built a few shields, for show--but somehow I felt like I knew how

to use it. I could imagine the--hypothetically--correct way to swing and pull and turn it, almost like it was muscle memory. Another mystery to throw on the pile. Not that Harlin or Mera needed to know that. I felt good thinking that maybe, if something untoward were to happen, I might be slightly more of a help than a burden.

As we walked the miles away, I asked my own questions of Harlin and Mera and made my own observations, few as they were. Returning the favour from earlier. I realise I'm not really sure how old they are. They looked to be in their thirties, same as me, but I wasn't really sure how that translated to Hylian years. Maybe it was 1:1, but I don't really know. They both also felt...parental, somehow. Could be they were simply world-weary and mentally mature for their age. Are they married? I don't know that either. I do my best to be discrete in my questions as the day wears on.

Thought for 13s

Road east of Proxim Bridge • Early afternoon • Sun warm, clouds thin and high

The road settles back into its steady song: boots on dirt, hooves on stone, cart wheels

creaking a lazy rhythm. The Hylia falls behind you, its hiss fading into the general hush of

wind in grass and the occasional birdcall.

The sword rides strangely natural in your hand.

You don’t need to look at it as often as you do, but your eyes keep dragging down anyway

—rust-pitted, edge dull, canvas-wrapped hilt sitting in your palm like it belongs there.

When the road bends and the cart slows, you give it the lightest test: a small half-cut

through empty air, a shift of grip, a turn of the wrist.

The blade moves clumsily, sure—its balance is all wrong—but your arms and shoulders

know how to correct for that in a way your brain insists you never learned. You don’t

overextend; your feet shift to keep your weight under you. The motion ends with the point

down and the flat resting near your shoulder, like you’ve been shown that finish a hundred

times.

Whatever brought you here didn’t bother to give you a wallet, but it seems to have

installed “basic sword literacy” as a consolation prize.

Harlin notices, of course. He notices everything.

“You hold it like you’ve swung steel before,” he remarks at one point, not accusing, just

observing. “Maybe whoever dropped you here had the sense to give you more than a

pretty face.”

Mera snorts softly. “Goddess knows we have enough pretty faces who don’t know one end

of a hoe from another.”

You talk as you walk.

You tell Mera more about carpentry “back home”—the way metal sneaks into everything,

not just hinges and nails but hidden inside walls, carrying power you never see. She listens

with a sort of fascinated horror at the idea of houses that hum quietly with energy.

“So you make buildings that are half lightning,” she says, shaking her head. “And you think

our shrines are strange.”

Harlin chimes in with comments about Hyrulean construction—how the old stonework

from before the Calamity holds together better than anything the newer masons throw up,

how Zora bridges last longer than Hylian ones but are murder to haul carts over.

In return, you ask your careful questions: how long they’ve known each other, whether

they have family, what “normal life” looks like when you’re not hauling bread and water

along half-ruined roads.

It comes out in bits and pieces, like you’re sanding through layers of finish.

They’re not married, as it turns out—though they share the sort of shorthand that makes it

easy to assume. Harlin is, in his own words, “on the downward side of thirty”—which, from

everything they say, matches your own age more or less one-to-one.

“Hylians who live quiet lives make it to their seventies, eighties,” he says. “Farmers and

townsfolk, anyway. Knights and hunters…” He tilts his hand in a wobbling motion.

“Depends on how many monsters they decide to annoy.”

He has a sister at Outskirt Stable, a pair of nieces who think his cart is the most exciting

thing in the world, and a father who used to ride with the guard before a Guardian beam

took his leg. The old man now spends his days sitting on a bench by the paddock,

hollering unasked-for advice at anyone who puts a saddle on wrong.

Mera is indeed “parental,” but in her case it’s practice, not potential. She had a husband

once, she mentions in a low, offhand way—one of the guards on these same roads. He

didn’t come back from a run during the worst of the Calamity years. There’s a son too,

grown and restless, gone north to see if rebuilding in Akkala is “really as busy as they say.”

“You remind me of him a little,” she says at one point, after you thank her again for the

bread. “The way you look at things like they might still surprise you.”

She doesn’t say “and the way you hide how scared you are,” but you hear it in the spaces.

The miles unfold. The land shifts slowly from river-slope to broader, flatter fields, then to

bumpier ground as the road skirts low hills. The Dueling Peaks grow from distant blades to

looming stone colossi, their split now very obvious—the narrow, cleft valley between them

hinting at the river and road that cut through.

Your body hums along under you, in that pleasant “used but not abused” way. Your feet

are beginning to feel the miles, a warmth building in the balls and heels—nothing dire,

just the reminder that boots and skin haven’t fully made their pact yet. Your throat goes

from comfortable to “could use another drink,” and the hollow under your ribs deepens

from “bread was nice” to “a proper meal would be even nicer.”

Harlin reads the road and the sky like it’s his second language. As the sun tilts toward

afternoon, shadows stretching just enough to change the color of the light, he squints

ahead and lifts his spear toward a rise.

“Once we crest that,” he says, “you’ll get your first look at Dueling Peaks Stable. We’ll stop

there for the night. Kakariko’s another stretch yet, and there’s no sense walking into a

Sheikah village footsore and starving. They’ll think we’re trying to guilt them into feeding

us.”

Mera chuckles. “They’d feed us anyway. They just like doing it on their terms.”

When you do crest the rise, the world opens up.

The twin mountains dominate the view, close enough now that you can see the waterfalls

spilling down their cleft, white threads against dark rock. At their feet, on a flat patch near

the road, sits Dueling Peaks Stable: a big, round, tent-roofed structure with the familiar

horsehead crest on its sign, surrounded by a scatter of fences, cookfires, and smaller tents.

Horses graze in a corral; smoke curls from the stable’s chimney; you can see tiny figures

moving about, working, talking, living.

Between you and the stable, the road drops into a broad valley. You can already smell faint

hints of woodsmoke and cooked food on the wind, weaving in with wildflower and dust.

Harlin’s shoulders loosen a fraction when he sees it. “There,” he says. “Roof, walls, hot stew

if you’ve got coin, lukewarm if you don’t. We’ll see about the first part for you, Zeth.”

He doesn’t say “we’ll see about coin,” but his tone makes it clear he’s already thinking

about how to present you to the stablehands in a way that gets you a bowl anyway.

Your sword and shield feel more real with every step toward that cluster of light and life.

They’re not much, but they’re yours. And as the stable grows from a painting into a place

with smells and sounds and people, the sense that you might actually carve out some kind

of existence here—stranger from a far realm with a half-ruined blade and a head full of the

wrong world’s history—sharpens into something like possibility.

I smile at the landscape ahead. How could I ask for more?

"Sounds great," I say. "Much appreciated." I purse my lips slightly in thought. "I thought the stable was on the other side of the peaks. Did it relocate recently? Or was my map outdated?" I shrug. "I guess I could just be remembering wrong."

Thought for 9s

Road above the Dueling Peaks valley • Mid-afternoon • Warm sun, woodsmoke on the

breeze

Harlin huffs a little laugh. “Depends how you’re holding the map,” he says. “Dueling Peaks

Stable’s always been on this side—west of the split. Folks coming from Hateno and

Kakariko pass through the gap, follow the river north, and hit the stable right about where

we’re heading now.”

He taps the side of his head with two fingers. “If you were looking at a chart drawn from

the east, might’ve flipped it in your mind. Happens. Half the travelers I meet swear the

Peaks moved on them between visits.”

Mera smiles. “Or perhaps your ‘maps and books’ are older than you thought. A lot of the

ones from before the Calamity are… let us say ‘optimistic’ about what survived.”

As you descend into the valley, details swell up out of the view you first saw from the rise.

The stable’s great round roof dominates its little cluster of buildings, patched canvas

stretched over wooden ribs, the horsehead crest hanging from a tall central pole. Around

it, life arranges itself in messy circles: a corral where half a dozen horses graze or drowse; a

cookfire with a big iron pot bubbling over it; a line of laundry snapping in the breeze.

You can hear voices now—snatches of talk, a burst of laughter, someone calling for more

feed. A dog barks twice, the sharp sound bouncing off the stable’s curved walls before

resolving into excited yips as your cart gets close enough to be interesting.

The smells hit you in layers: horse and hay, woodsmoke, something stewing with root

vegetables and a bit of meat, the faint acid tang of leather being worked. Your stomach

tightens in earnest this time; bread has officially slid down the priority list.

A pair of stablehands come out to meet the cart: one lanky Hylian teen with straw stuck in

his hair, the other a middle-aged woman with a bandana and the kind of forearms that can

lift hay bales like pillows. They greet Harlin like a familiar piece of furniture, trading quick

updates about road conditions and who’s come through lately.

When their eyes land on you, they go straight to your sword and cobbled-together

buckler, then up to your face.

“Picked up a stray?” the bandanaed woman asks, not unkindly.

“Zeth,” Harlin says, voice easy. “Walked out of nowhere near Gatepost with nothing but his

good manners and a headache. Helped keep an eye on the road, pulled an old blade and

shield out of the riverbank. Heading for Kakariko when the road allows.”

He doesn’t mention “not from this world.” He does angle you as someone who’s trying and

not just leaning.

Mera adds, “He’s a carpenter by trade. Not afraid of work and says polite things about

bread.”

That earns you a faintly amused look from the woman. “Well, that’s two points in your

favor. I’m Pella. This is Jorin.” The teen gives you a quick, awkward nod, clearly cataloguing

you under “new and interesting but probably not dangerous.”

Pella jerks her chin toward the stable. “Harlin’s right, you look like you walked farther than

your boots are used to. You’ve coin of your own?”

The question is practical, not accusing. You can feel Harlin’s glance slide your way—

checking how you’ll handle being put on the spot.

The sword suddenly feels heavier at your side; the buckler’s weight tugs at your arm.

Behind Pella, the stewpot gives a lazy bubble, steam curling up with the rich smell of fat

and herbs. Someone inside the stable shouts about fresh hay. A bird flits across the yard

and lands on the horsehead crest, flicking its tail.

You are at a place where roads meet and stories cross, with just enough gear to be taken

mostly seriously and absolutely no money to your name.

I stick my sword point in a patch of soft earth and put my hand out to shake hands as Harlin and Mera introduce me. "Nice to meet you."

I feel my face redden just the tiniest bit at the question of money, and bob my head side to side slightly as a I give a friendly laugh. "Ah ha, I am...afraid I don't have coin of my own. Ready to make some though," I eye the stables and horses as we talk. Secretly I would rather do about

anything but take care of the stables, but I try to keep myself humble and unentitled. I'd do whatever they asked of me if they offered. *Beggars can't be choosers,* I remind myself. "That is, of course, if you've got anything that needs doing. Can't say I'm very familiar with horses or stables, but wherever you need some help, I'm your man."

Thought for 16s

Dueling Peaks Stable yard • Mid-afternoon • Warm sun, smells of hay and stew

Pella takes your hand in a grip that says she’s hauled more than her share of feed sacks.

Her eyes go to the sword stuck in the dirt, then back to your face as you admit you’re

broke but willing.

The tiniest smirk tugs at one corner of her mouth. “That makes you the most honest

stranger I’ve met this week,” she says. “And the bar’s not as low as you’d think.”

She glances past you to Harlin; they exchange a quick, silent conversation in looks. Harlin

gives the barest nod, like someone vouching for a tool that’s rough but sound.

“Walked guard, didn’t complain,” he adds aloud. “Pulled that blade out of East Post,

wrapped it up himself. Says he’s a carpenter.”

At carpenter, something in Pella’s expression shifts. She looks past you toward the stable

proper: one of the fence rails is visibly bowed where a horse has leaned on it too often,

and the corner of the main door hangs a little low in its frame.

“Can’t say no to that,” she mutters.

She hooks her thumbs in her belt and fixes you with a practical look. “Here’s how it is,

Zeth. We don’t turn folk away hungry if we can help it. But stable space and stew don’t

grow on trees either. You put in work, you sleep under a roof and get a full bowl. You slack

off, you sleep under the stars with half a ladle and we wish you luck with the night bugs.

Fair?”

Jorin, the straw-haired teen, snorts. “He can start with the south fence,” he says. “Bay

mare’s been leaning on it again. And that trough plank’s about ready to kick out.”

Pella nods toward the fence. “You know your wood from your elbow, you’ll see what needs

doing soon as you look. We’ve spare boards and tools in the shed.” She jerks her chin at a

low outbuilding near the corral. “After that, help Jorin with the hay and water. If there’s

light left and you’re still standing, I might ask you to look at the door hinges.”

Mera, standing by the cart, gives you an encouraging little smile. “Told you he wasn’t afraid

of work,” she says to Pella, then adds to you, “We’ll see you at the pot when it’s ready.

Don’t let Jorin bully you into carrying all the buckets.”

Jorin rolls his eyes, already moving to unhitch the horse from Harlin’s cart. “C’mon, sword

man,” he calls over his shoulder. “Fence won’t fix itself, and Pella gets mean when the rails

start sagging.”

The stable yard bustles around you as you step into it properly. A woman at a table

outside is mending a bridle, leather creaking under her awl. Two travelers lead their horses

toward the corral, chatting about monsters near the Peaks. A pair of kids chase each other

around a hitching post, one using a stick as an imaginary spear. The stewpot sends up

another rich plume of steam; your stomach answers with a sharper, more insistent growl

now, low and hollow.

At the south fence, the problem announces itself quickly: one rail bowed outward, another

split along the grain where something heavy pushed too hard. The trough beside it is held

together more by habit than structure, one plank bulging, nails working loose. There’s a

neat stack of scrap boards and a bucket of rusty nails nearby—someone’s “we’ll get to it”

project, waiting for the right pair of hands.

Tools in the shed are familiar in shape if not in finish: hammers, saws, a rough chisel, even

a hand plane that’s seen better sharpening. Wood is wood, nails are nails. The smells—

sawdust, old linseed oil, sun-warmed pine—hit memories in a more direct way than

anything else today.

Harlin leads his horse off toward the hitching posts, Mera disappearing toward the stable’s

back entrance to negotiate bread and deliveries. Pella peels away toward the corral,

shouting at someone about mucking a stall properly.

For the first time since you landed at Gatepost Town, you’re standing in front of a job that

looks almost normal: broken boards, a fence that needs squaring, a trough that needs

shoring up. Behind you, on the edge of the yard, an old Hylian sword stands in the dirt like

a flag marking where your day changed.

I grab my sword, not wanting to lose my currently most prized--nearly only--possession, and put it near the carpentry supplies. Then I get to work.

The fence board is easy. Practically child's play. Definitely the result of procrastination, not difficulty. A quick saw through the two bad rails to remove them, then getting two new ones from the lumber pile and cutting them to length. I'm not used to doing these tasks without power tools, but it's not a problem. The pine is a soft wood and the saw is sharp. Turning the planks flat I slightly taper the ends of the new rails so they'll actually go into the slots of the fence posts, and then go about slotting them in. First a little too far on one side, and then pulling the other end into the opposite post's slot. I could leave them at that, but I want to make a good impression, so I take a chisel and gently slit the tapered ends of the new rails, then slice multiple small wedges of wood from the old, sawn rails. A wedge goes in the split of either end of the two new rails to widen the taper and disable them from slipping out either side, then the remaining wedges get hammered into the post slots to prevent the new rails from rattling.

I glanced at the door hanging low its frame as I went to work on the fence, since the fence repair was relatively mindless, and mulled on how to fix it while I worked. I had a few ideas, but it would depend on the hinges whether or not any of them would work. I don't know what type of hinges or joining to expect from Hylian carpentry, to be honest.

Before I get to that though, I need to tackle the trough. This task is trickier for me, and it takes me a bit to wrap my

head around it. I give it a good look-over, examining the trough for more detail about what I'm working on.

Dueling Peaks Stable – south fence & trough • Late afternoon • Sun lowering, shadows

longening

The fence goes from “accident waiting to happen” to “serviceable” in that deeply

satisfying, almost meditative way.

The saw bites cleanly through the bowed rails; pine dust feathers onto your boots. The

smell is instantly familiar—resin and sun and work. Cutting new rails to length without a

miter saw feels weirdly nostalgic, like stepping back into someone else’s childhood, but

the hand saw pulls true, and the wood is soft enough that your arm only complains a little.

The tapering feels like cheating in the good way. You shave the ends down, test them in

the post mortises, then knock them home with that heel-of-the-hand-and-hip pressure

that every carpenter learns. When you wedge the splits and hammer in the little shims,

everything tightens up with a quiet, gratifying thunk. The fence line straightens. Give it a

shove and it flexes like one piece instead of a bundle of excuses.

You catch Jorin watching you once from the corner of his eye while he hauls a bucket.

When the fence settles and doesn’t groan, he gives a small, grudging nod and goes back

to work.

The trough is another beast.

Up close, it’s obvious why they’ve been ignoring it: it’s not one simple break, it’s an

accumulation of sins. The thing is a long, rectangular box of joined planks, stained nearly

black near the bottom from years of water. One of the long side planks has bowed

outward, bulging like a swollen belly. The end joints are gapping, nails pulling free in a way

that says “I will fail at the worst possible time.” There’s a hairline crack running along a

knot, just waiting for a hard kick from a thirsty horse to open into a leak.

You circle it, crouch, run your fingers along seams. Whatever they used for sealant—some

kind of pitch or resin—is flaking away in spots. If you were doing this “properly” in your

old world, you’d probably tear it apart, plane everything true, reseal, reassemble with

proper hardware.

Here, you have: scrap boards, old nails, basic tools, and a yard full of animals that would

really prefer their water to stay in one place.

You take a breath, do the mental math, and settle on “triage, not surgery.”

First you drain it. There’s still a shallow pool of water in the bottom. You wrestle it to a

slight tilt and let what’s left slosh out onto the packed earth, earning a mildly offended

look from a nearby chestnut mare. Then, with the weight gone, you can properly lean into

the bulging side, feel how much give there is.

More than you like.

You brace one boot against the outside, hands on the rim, and push. The bow creaks,

complaining, but slowly eases back toward straight. You don’t force it all the way—you’ve

seen what happens when you overcorrect old, tired wood—but you coax it into “mostly

true.”

While you’re holding it there with hip and shoulder, you mark out positions for a couple of

cleats—short crosspieces you can screw or nail over the outside to hold the planks in line.

No screws here, so nails it is. You cut a pair from a reasonably sound board in the scrap

pile, pre-punch nail holes so you don’t split things further, then, still using your body as

the clamp, you start hammering.

The first few blows ring up your arm in that satisfying way. Wood bites around metal,

everything tightens. By the time you’ve sunk the last nail and stepped back, the bulge has

become a mild curve. Not perfect, but miles better.

For the ends, you knock the worst of the nails out, drive them back in at slightly new

angles, and reinforce the joint with another pair of external cleats, creating a crude but

sturdy collar. Anywhere you see a gap that looks like it wants to be a leak, you work in

some of the intact old sealant with the tip of your chisel, smearing it like putty. It’s ugly. It

will probably need a proper re-tarring in the near future. But for now, it’ll hold.

By the time you’re finished, sweat is sticking your shirt to your back, and your hands have

a couple of new blisters starting where unfamiliar tool handles have rubbed skin. They’re

small, hot points of complaint, but nothing dramatic. Your legs feel pleasantly heavy. The

sword leaning near the tool shed has picked up a dusting of sawdust and dirt, as if it

approves.

You tip what water you spilled back into the trough from a bucket, watching carefully. A

few drops seep where you expect them to, then stop. No steady leaks. No sudden splits.

The chestnut mare nudges your shoulder, then leans in to drink, as if giving it her own

field test. The trough creaks but does not explode. Good enough.

When you straighten up, Pella is standing a little way off, arms folded, watching with that

evaluative stable-master look.

“Rail looks solid,” she says. “Trough’s not bowing like a drunk anymore. I’ll have words with

the next fool who lets a horse kick it for fun, but for now? That’s decent work.”

There’s a glint of approval in her eyes that wasn’t there earlier.

Mera reappears from the back of the stable, dust on her skirt and a smear of flour on her

cheek like she’s been bartering and baking simultaneously. Harlin’s over by the hitching

post, rubbing down his horse, but he glances your way and raises his brows in a silent

“well?”

Your body answers before you do: you’re tired in the honest way, thirst sharpening again

at the back of your throat, hunger now a steady, insistent pull. Your shoulders have that

pleasant ache that promises they’ll be a bit stiff tomorrow. But under all of it, there’s a

quiet, solid satisfaction: you did work, real work, in Hyrule, and it held.

Above, the sun has dipped a little lower, warm light taking on a hint of gold. The air cools

just a touch. Someone stokes the stewpot; the scent of onions and herbs rises thicker,

almost dizzying.

Pella jerks her head toward the cookfire. “Go wash up,” she says. “You’ve earned a bowl.

We’ll talk more about that door once you can stand straight without wobbling.”

Jorin ambles past with an armful of hay, muttering, “Not bad for a guy who didn’t know

one end of a horse from the other.”

It’s not quite praise, but it’s close.

You collect your sword, its canvas-wrapped hilt rough and reassuring in your hand, and

head toward the bucket and ladle set out by a rain barrel for washing. The water splashed

on your face is cool and clear. When you look up, Dueling Peaks loom in the distance, and

the stable yard hums around you with quiet end-of-day energy.

In the span of one Hylian afternoon, you’ve gone from “strange man with nothing” to

“strange man with a job, a sword, and a spot by the stew.”

I do my best to wash up without too many distracting thoughts. I've never been big on stews, but I don't hate them, and right now it wouldn't matter anyway. It was both a welcome meal, a chance to rest my aching feet, and I'm looking forward to actually experiencing the food itself for what it is. Seeing Link drop random raw food items into a mysterious pot and a fully-prepared meal popping out was never my idea of an engaging cooking mechanic in the game, but it had left me with an earnest and sincere curiosity about what exactly Hylian cooking actually tastes like. Mera's bread was certainly wonderful, no lie there, but it was also bread. I know what bread--even delicious herb bread--tastes like. I have no idea what this upcoming stew might be made of or taste like.

Dueling Peaks Stable – cookfire circle • Late afternoon sliding toward evening • Air cooling,

stew steam rising

The wash water is cool enough to sting in a good way. Dust and sweat smear off your

forearms, your face, the back of your neck. Blisters on your hands twinge when you flex

your fingers, the skin stretched thin and shiny in a couple of spots, but nothing’s torn. You

look like a man who worked, not a man who lost a fight with a tool rack.

By the time you make your way toward the cookfire, the stable yard’s rhythm has shifted.

The daytime clatter of work has softened into end-of-day noise: a last round of hay tossed

in the stalls, a couple of travelers rubbing down their horses, someone laughing too loud

at a joke that probably doesn’t deserve it. Somewhere, a dog is making very persuasive

arguments about scraps.

The stewpot sits in pride of place on a tripod over the fire, a dark iron belly bubbling

gently. Whoever’s tending it is doing so with the seriousness of a priest at an altar—a

broad-shouldered Hylian with sleeves rolled up and a ladle almost as big as your forearm.

Beside him, a low table holds stacks of wooden bowls, spoons, and a basket of bread that

smells suspiciously like Mera’s handiwork.

You slide into the loose queue forming around the pot. Mera spots you first and lifts a

hand in greeting from a sitting log, where she’s talking quietly with another traveler. Harlin

arrives a moment later, falling into line behind you, spear set aside for once.

“Careful,” he murmurs. “You make too much of a face when you taste it and they’ll decide

you’re one of those ‘just bread and salt for me, thanks’ types.”

When it’s your turn, the cook gives you the standard rapid-fire assessment: clothes, build,

sword, tired eyes, calloused hands. He doesn’t bother with small talk; he just dips the ladle

and fills your bowl nearly to overflowing, then gestures with his chin toward the bread

basket.

Up close, the stew is… intriguing. The broth is a rich brown, flecked with green and red.

You can see chunks of root vegetable—something like carrot, something like potato,

maybe a bit of turnip—softened but still holding shape. There are ribbons of some leafy

green that’s gone deep emerald in the heat, and, to your cautious delight, actual meat:

small cubes of something that looks like beef, but given the world might be from a goat or

some hapless monster slaughtered earlier in the week.

You grab a heel of bread from the basket. It’s Mera’s style again: crusty outside, soft inside,

with herbs baked through. Between that and the steam from the stew, the smell hits you in

a wave: savory, earthy, brightened by something sharp—maybe wild onion or a local herb

you don’t have a name for yet.

You find a spot on a low log near Mera and Harlin. When you finally get the spoon to your

mouth, the stew lands on your tongue like somebody’s memory of a perfect autumn.

The broth is deeper than it looks, layered with flavors: fat rendered from whatever meat

they used, the sweetness of long-cooked roots, the slight bitterness of greens, salt just this

side of too much in exactly the way road food often is. There’s a hint of something smoky,

as if they browned the meat first or used a stock made from bones roasted over this same

fire.

The meat itself is tender but still has a bit of chew, not the stringy punishment you’ve

sometimes gotten from “stew” back home. The vegetables break under your teeth without

turning to mush. Every so often you get a bite where the herbs hit harder—a tiny

explosion of brightness that cuts through the richness.

It does something to your brain besides just “fill hunger.” There’s this weird layering: your

real-world experience of stews you’ve tolerated, your game-world association of “throw

food in pot, get buff,” and then this actual, physical bowl in your hands that is neither

abstraction nor afterthought. This is someone’s Hylian Tuesday-night special, and it tastes

like comfort and survival and “we made it through another day.”

Your stomach, which has been playing polite all afternoon, decides it has thoughts. The

first few spoonfuls go down almost too fast, and you have to deliberately slow yourself so

you don’t scald your tongue. The warmth slides down your throat, settles in your belly,

radiates outward. Your aching feet feel less important. The throbbing of your new blisters

recedes under the general wave of “fed, finally.”

Mera watches your face as you eat, a little amused, a little curious. “Well?” she prompts.

“Does it match your maps and books, or have we disappointed you terribly?”

Harlin tears off a chunk of his own bread, sopping up broth with the casual efficiency of a

man who’s eaten this exact recipe a hundred times. “Careful how you answer,” he says

around a mouthful. “Call Pella’s stew anything less than a blessing and she’ll make you

muck stalls till morning.”

The cook snorts from across the fire but doesn’t contradict him.

Around you, the stable’s small community eats and talks. A pair of Sheikah travelers

discuss monster sightings near the river. A merchant complains about prices in Hateno.

Jorin demolishes his bowl like it’s running away from him, then eyes the pot in a way that

says he’s considering a cheeky second serving.

Your sword leans within arm’s reach against the log, the canvas-wrapped hilt catching

stray flecks of firelight. The buckler rests near your feet, a scuffed iron circle that somehow

now qualifies as “your shield.” Your body is heavy in a good way, full of food and fatigue.

The sky overhead is shading from bright blue toward softer tones; a faint coolness sneaks

into the air as the sun dips lower toward the Peaks.

For the first time since you arrived, you’re not moving, not scrambling, not explaining

yourself. You’re just a tired worker at the end of the day with a bowl of stew, a bit of bread,

and people on either side who know your name.

"It's great," I say sincerely. "I'm not exactly a poet, so I don't know if I can really say anything worthy enough to praise it..." I eye Harlin, "Harlin puts it best I think. A blessing." I follow his lead on sopping up the stew with my bread as well, though before I finish it I take a quick peek around for something I've been watching since we arrived at the stable: a dog. I don't know what breed or gender it is, but it reminds me of a border collie, and I absolutely adored it from the moment I saw it. It's sitting begging silently as a dog does for food from some other tired stable hand not too far away. I wave the little bit of bread I have left just far enough for the dog to notice it in its periphery, and that does its job. The dog comes over and accepts the bread. I look at Mera.

"Forgive me for the bread." I tousle the dog's fur, "But I just had to meet this fella. I love dogs."

The dog clocks the bread bait like it was born for this job.

It abandons its previous mark with only the faintest hint of guilt, pads over with that brisk,

businesslike trot collies have, and parks itself in front of you, tail doing a low, hopeful

sweep across the dirt. Up close, you can see the breed is more “Hyrule mutt” than

anything pure: long-legged, medium-sized, black and white with a splash of brown over

one eye, fur going shaggy around the neck. The eyes are sharp, bright, and very focused

on your hand.

When you offer the scrap, it takes it with careful teeth, lips barely brushing your fingers.

No snatch, no drool, just a polite “thank you, yes, I will be taking that.” The tail shifts gears

from “hopeful” to “victory wag.”

You tousle its fur and it leans into it like you just hit the exact right scratch spot on the first

try. The coat is dusty but healthy, with that slight oiliness of a dog who spends more time

outdoors than not. Its tongue lolls for a second, then it sits, pressed lightly against your

shin, as if you’ve been part of its territory for years.

Mera watches, amused. “Forgiven,” she says, pretending to sigh. “We all tithe to Tavi

sooner or later.”

Harlin snorts. “Stable’s true master,” he adds. “Pella just thinks she’s in charge.”

At the name, the dog’s ears perk. Tavi glances between each of you, as if taking

attendance, then flops down at your feet with a soft whuff, front paws stretched out, head

resting on one of them. Tail thumps twice against your boot.

Pella, ladle in hand at the pot, glances over and shakes her head. “Traitor,” she calls to the

dog. “You barely know him.”

Tavi’s only answer is to close her eyes halfway and lean a little heavier against your leg.

Harlin gives you a sideways look over his spoon. “That’s it, then,” he says. “You’re officially

part of the furniture. Tavi doesn’t cozy up to just anyone. Either you smell like spare food,

or you’ve got good bones.”

“You smell like sawdust and rust,” Mera says. “So I vote bones.”

The teasing lands light. Underneath it, there’s a small shift in how people glance your way:

a stranger is one thing, but a stranger endorsed by the dog and the work and the stew is

starting to edge into “one of us, for now.”

You finish the last of your bowl, bread and all. The warmth settles in your belly like a small

hearth. Your muscles keep sending low-level complaint about the day’s work—feet hot

and sore, shoulders tight, hands slick with the beginning of callus—but the food blunts the

edges of it. Your head feels pleasantly muzzy, the way it does after a long day that was

actually worth the exhaustion.

Around the fire, the conversations slowly thin as people drift off to tasks or rest. The sky is

tilting into evening now; the light has gone from gold to a softer, cooler wash, and the

Peaks are dark silhouettes against it. Someone lights a lantern by the stable door. Another

hangs a small, caged flame near the corral.

Pella finishes serving the last few bowls, then wipes her hands on a rag and wanders over

to your log. Her gaze travels from your empty bowl to your sword, then to the fence you

fixed and the trough in the near distance.

“Not bad for a first day in Hyrule,” she says. “You keep that up, we’ll find more things for

you to break your back on. In return, you get a place in the loft tonight.” She jerks her

thumb toward the stable. “Hay’s clean, roof doesn’t leak much. You can thank Harlin and

Mera for vouching you in.”

Tavi chooses that moment to roll onto her back and present her stomach, legs in the air in

shameless invitation. You oblige with a belly rub; her back leg kicks a little in bliss.

Mera stands, stretching with a small groan that betrays her own miles. “We’ll be heading

toward Kakariko in the morning,” she says. “You’re welcome to fall in with us again or see

what the stablemaster can offer longer term. Depends how much you like horses and

fences.”

Harlin pushes himself to his feet, bones popping. “Either way,” he adds, “you’ll want sleep.

Tomorrow looks longer than today, and you’ve got that new-body shine about you that

says you’ve forgotten what real tired feels like.”

The fire crackles softly. Someone starts plucking a simple tune on a stringed instrument a

little ways off—just a meandering melody, something to hum to. The air carries the mixed

smells of hay, animal, smoke, and cooling earth. Your eyelids feel heavier than they did a

half hour ago, helped along by a full stomach and a day that started with cosmic

dislocation and ended with carpentry.

Tavi, having secured both bread and belly rubs, settles herself firmly at your feet as if to

say: wherever you lie down tonight, expect me there too.

*/ The previous response was very good, but makes the mistake of attributing knowledge to both Pella and Harlin that they shouldn't have; Pella shouldn't know that it's my "first day in Hyrule" and Harlin shouldn't be make

reference to "new-body shine". Please revise the response to fix that before we continue. /*

Good catch, nicely spotted. Here’s a revised version of that last scene with those bits fixed

so everything stays fully in-world and diegetic:

Dueling Peaks Stable – cookfire circle • Late afternoon sliding toward evening • Air cooling,

stew steam rising

The wash water is cool enough to sting in a good way. Dust and sweat smear off your

forearms, your face, the back of your neck. Blisters on your hands twinge when you flex

your fingers, the skin stretched thin and shiny in a couple of spots, but nothing’s torn. You

look like a man who worked, not a man who lost a fight with a tool rack.

By the time you make your way toward the cookfire, the stable yard’s rhythm has shifted.

The daytime clatter of work has softened into end-of-day noise: a last round of hay tossed

in the stalls, a couple of travelers rubbing down their horses, someone laughing too loud

at a joke that probably doesn’t deserve it. Somewhere, a dog is making very persuasive

arguments about scraps.

The stewpot sits in pride of place on a tripod over the fire, a dark iron belly bubbling

gently. Whoever’s tending it is doing so with the seriousness of a priest at an altar—a

broad-shouldered Hylian with sleeves rolled up and a ladle almost as big as your forearm.

Beside him, a low table holds stacks of wooden bowls, spoons, and a basket of bread that

smells suspiciously like Mera’s handiwork.

You slide into the loose queue forming around the pot. Mera spots you first and lifts a

hand in greeting from a sitting log, where she’s talking quietly with another traveler. Harlin

arrives a moment later, falling into line behind you, spear set aside for once.

“Careful,” he murmurs. “You make too much of a face when you taste it and they’ll decide

you’re one of those ‘just bread and salt for me, thanks’ types.”

When it’s your turn, the cook gives you the standard rapid-fire assessment: clothes, build,

sword, tired eyes, calloused hands. He doesn’t bother with small talk; he just dips the ladle

and fills your bowl nearly to overflowing, then gestures with his chin toward the bread

basket.

Up close, the stew is… intriguing. The broth is a rich brown, flecked with green and red.

You can see chunks of root vegetable—something like carrot, something like potato,

maybe a bit of turnip—softened but still holding shape. There are ribbons of some leafy

green that’s gone deep emerald in the heat, and, to your cautious delight, actual meat:

small cubes of something that looks like beef, but given the world might be from a goat or

some hapless monster slaughtered earlier in the week.

You grab a heel of bread from the basket. It’s Mera’s style again: crusty outside, soft inside,

with herbs baked through. Between that and the steam from the stew, the smell hits you in

a wave: savory, earthy, brightened by something sharp—maybe wild onion or a local herb

you don’t have a name for yet.

You find a spot on a low log near Mera and Harlin. When you finally get the spoon to your

mouth, the stew lands on your tongue like somebody’s memory of a perfect autumn.

The broth is deeper than it looks, layered with flavors: fat rendered from whatever meat

they used, the sweetness of long-cooked roots, the slight bitterness of greens, salt just this

side of too much in exactly the way road food often is. There’s a hint of something smoky,

as if they browned the meat first or used a stock made from bones roasted over this same

fire.

The meat itself is tender but still has a bit of chew, not the stringy punishment you’ve

sometimes gotten from “stew” back home. The vegetables break under your teeth without

turning to mush. Every so often you get a bite where the herbs hit harder—a tiny

explosion of brightness that cuts through the richness.

It does something to your brain besides just “fill hunger.” There’s this weird layering: your

real-world experience of stews you’ve tolerated, your game-world association of “throw

food in pot, get buff,” and then this actual, physical bowl in your hands that is neither

abstraction nor afterthought. This is someone’s Hylian Tuesday-night special, and it tastes

like comfort and survival and “we made it through another day.”

Your stomach, which has been playing polite all afternoon, decides it has thoughts. The

first few spoonfuls go down almost too fast, and you have to deliberately slow yourself so

you don’t scald your tongue. The warmth slides down your throat, settles in your belly,

radiates outward. Your aching feet feel less important. The throbbing of your new blisters

recedes under the general wave of “fed, finally.”

Mera watches your face as you eat, a little amused, a little curious. “Well?” she prompts.

“Does it match your maps and books, or have we disappointed you terribly?”

Harlin tears off a chunk of his own bread, sopping up broth with the casual efficiency of a

man who’s eaten this exact recipe a hundred times. “Careful how you answer,” he says

around a mouthful. “Call Pella’s stew anything less than a blessing and she’ll make you

muck stalls till morning.”

The cook snorts from across the fire but doesn’t contradict him.

You talk, you praise the stew, you share the bread with the dog—Tavi—and win instant

canine allegiance. She takes the scrap neatly from your fingers and flumps against your leg

like she’s known you for years. Pella calls her a traitor from the stewpot; Harlin mutters,

“That’s it, you’re furniture now. Tavi doesn’t cozy up to just anyone.”

Mera smirks. “You smell like sawdust and rust. That’s an honest smell. Dogs like honest

smells.”

The teasing lands light, and something subtle shifts: glances toward you have less wary

curiosity and more matter-of-fact inclusion. You’re still “the odd man who turned up on

the road,” but now you’re also “the one who fixed the fence” and “the one Tavi likes.”

You finish the last of your bowl, bread and all. The warmth settles in your belly like a small

hearth. Your muscles keep sending low-level complaint about the day’s work—feet hot

and sore, shoulders tight, hands slick with the beginning of callus—but the food blunts the

edges of it. Your head feels pleasantly muzzy, the way it does after a long day that was

actually worth the exhaustion.

Around the fire, the conversations slowly thin as people drift off to tasks or rest. The sky is

tilting into evening now; the light has gone from gold to a softer, cooler wash, and the

Peaks are dark silhouettes against it. Someone lights a lantern by the stable door. Another

hangs a small, caged flame near the corral.

Pella finishes serving the last few bowls, then wipes her hands on a rag and wanders over

to your log. Her gaze travels from your empty bowl to your sword, then to the fence you

fixed and the trough in the near distance.

“Not bad work for someone we just met at noon,” she says. “You keep that up, we’ll find

more things for you to break your back on. In return, you get a place in the loft tonight.”

She jerks her thumb toward the stable. “Hay’s clean, roof doesn’t leak much. You can thank

Harlin and Mera for saying you were worth the trouble.”

Tavi chooses that moment to roll onto her back and present her stomach, legs in the air in

shameless invitation. You oblige with a belly rub; her back leg kicks a little in bliss.

Mera stands, stretching with a small groan that betrays her own miles. “We’ll be heading

toward Kakariko in the morning,” she says. “You’re welcome to fall in with us again or see

what the stablemaster can offer longer term. Depends how much you like horses and

fences.”

Harlin pushes himself to his feet, bones popping. “Either way,” he adds, “you’ll want sleep.

Tomorrow looks longer than today, and you already worked yourself right up to the edge.”

The fire crackles softly. Someone starts plucking a simple tune on a stringed instrument a

little ways off—just a meandering melody, something to hum to. The air carries the mixed

smells of hay, animal, smoke, and cooling earth. Your eyelids feel heavier than they did a

half hour ago, helped along by a full stomach and a day that started with cosmic

disorientation and ended with carpentry.

Tavi, having secured both bread and belly rubs, settles herself firmly at your feet as if to

say: wherever you lie down tonight, expect me nearby.

"Thank you all, I appreciate it. I'd like to continue on to Kakariko if you'll have me," I say, nodding to Harlin and Mera as I haul myself up. Turning to Pella, "Again, thanks so much. I don't know if I'll have time before Harlin wants to set out to fix it, but I'd at least like to take a look at your door tomorrow morning. I'm not sure what kind of hinges

its using, but if it's a certain kind it may not be as big a deal to fix. No guarantees, just want to, you know, try."

Thought for 11s

Dueling Peaks Stable – cookfire circle • Early evening • Air cooling, first stars peeking out

Pella listens, eyes narrowing in that practical “what can I get out of this” way that’s

somehow not exploitative, just honest.

“Door’s been hanging low for months,” she says. “If you want to poke at it in the morning

before we hitch up the teams, I won’t stop you. We’re usually moving by the time the sun’s

comfortably above the hills. You’re up before that, you’ll have time to look and still catch

your cart.”

Her mouth crooks. “And if you make it worse, I know where you’re sleeping.”

Harlin snorts. Mera hides a smile behind her bowl.

Pella claps you once on the shoulder, solid but not unfriendly. “Loft’s that way,” she adds,

nodding toward a side door. “Ladder just inside. First-come, first-claimed on the bedrolls,

but there’s plenty of hay.”

Tavi thumps her tail against your boot as you stand, then scrambles up as if of course she’s

coming too.

Dueling Peaks Stable – loft • Night • Cool air, soft rustle of hay, distant river murmur

The loft is a world of its own above the stable.

You climb the ladder with a body that’s just this side of wobbly, arms and legs protesting

now that they’re off duty. The smell hits you first: hay, old wood, warm animal, and the

faint, clean tang of night air slipping through gaps in the boards.

Moonlight filters in through a pair of small windows, laying pale rectangles across the

floor. Bedrolls and blankets are scattered in loose clusters where travelers have staked out

spots. A couple of them are already asleep—bundles of cloth and breathing. Someone

near the far wall coughs once, then goes quiet.

You find a patch of hay that hasn’t been completely flattened, drag a spare blanket over it,

and ease yourself down. The hay crinkles and shifts, then settles around you, poking in a

few places but overall more forgiving than bare boards. Your feet sigh with relief when you

get your boots off; the skin underneath is hot and a little tender, but not wrecked. Your

new blisters pull when you flex your fingers, but the sting is manageable.

Tavi circles once, then twice, then flops down with her back against your shins like she’s

been sleeping next to you for years. She sighs, the dog-equivalent of “this’ll do.”

Through the floorboards, you hear the muffled sounds of the stable settling: horses

shifting, a soft snort, a hoof scraping once, twice. Somewhere below, someone hums a few

bars of a tune as they finish up one last chore. Outside, the wind brushes against the

canvas roof, a gentle, side-to-side hush.

You stare up at the shadowed rafters for a while, mind doing its usual trick of trying to

rewrite the day in order.

Gatepost. The Guardian. The road. The sword in your hand that shouldn’t fit so well.

Harlin’s questions. Mera’s bread. The trough taking shape under your tools. Stew. A dog’s

weight against your legs.

Eventually, tiredness bulldozes the second-guessing. Your thoughts blur, then dissolve.

Sleep takes you in the crunchy warmth of hay and the smell of horse and smoke.

Dueling Peaks Stable – yard • Early morning • Pale light, thin chill, mist clinging low

You wake to a rooster’s crow that sounds like it’s trying to outshout the sun.

For a moment, there’s that mild, familiar shock of where am I—wood, hay, dog, not your

old ceiling, not your old bed. Then yesterday slots back into place, and the disorientation

ebbs, leaving a quieter, dull ache where your body complains.

You’re stiff. Back, shoulders, hands, even the arches of your feet. Not broken-stiff, just “you

did more than your usual quota of reality yesterday” stiff. You roll your ankles, flex your

fingers; things loosen gradually with the promise they’ll forgive you as long as you don’t

ask them to lift a cart today.

Tavi is a warm, curved weight behind your knees. When you shift, she groans theatrically

and stretches, front paws forward, back arched, tail giving a half-wag before she shoves

her nose against your arm in greeting.

Down below, stable life has already restarted. You hear voices, the clink of buckets, the low

murmur people use around animals. The air up here is cold enough that you can see the

faintest hint of your breath when you sit up.

You pull on your boots with only a small argument from your feet, gather your sword and

shield, and climb down.

Outside, the yard is washed in that pale pre-sunlight that makes everything look a little

unreal. Mist hangs low in the dips of the ground. The Peaks are blunt silhouettes.

Someone’s started a small morning fire; the smell of porridge and weak tea floats on the

air.

Harlin’s cart is still where you left it, though now the horse is half-harnessed and Harlin

himself is checking a wheel, cloak already on. Mera is talking quietly with Pella near the

stable door, a small cloth bundle—probably bread—passing from one to the other.

You catch Pella’s eye and nod toward the big front door.

“Got up early for your hinges,” you say. “If you’re still all right with me poking at them.”

She snorts, amused. “If you’re mad enough to look at carpentry before breakfast, I’m not

stopping you. Door’s right where it was last night. Try not to have it fall on your head; I

don’t have time to dig anyone out from under it before noon.”

Dueling Peaks Stable – main door • Early morning • Light strengthening, air damp and cool

The door’s size hits you now that you’re approaching it with “fixing” in mind instead of just

“passing through.”

It’s a big, double-leafed thing, thick planks banded with iron straps, built to withstand

bored horses, careless carts, and bad weather. One side is usually kept bolted and the

other swung; it’s that swinging leaf that’s dragging, bottom corner scuffing the packed

earth just enough to leave a groove.

You crouch and inspect the hardware.

The hinges are strap hinges, big iron tongues bolted through the door and anchored into

the frame with stout pins. Nothing exotic, nothing magical—just chunky, overbuilt

hardware that’s tired. The bottom hinge’s pin has worn in its socket, allowing the door to

sag. There’s also a hairline gap where the hinge plate has started to pull from the frame,

two of the old wooden pegs holding it having loosened over time.

You test the swing gently, lifting under the latch edge. When you raise it a hair, the

dragging stops. That tells you what you already suspected: you don’t need to rebuild the

world, just give gravity a slightly different path.

You raid the scrap pile again, find a bit of hardwood that isn’t completely ruined, and

shave it down with chisel and knife into a thin shim. Then you fetch a mallet and a spare

peg, loosen the lower hinge plate just enough to tuck the shim behind it—between iron

and frame—lifting the whole door a finger-width at that corner when you tighten it back.

It’s fiddly work, made more fun by the chill making your fingers clumsy at first, but once

the blood gets moving, your hands remember what they’re doing. You drive a fresh peg

through the plate into sound wood, then tap the old ones deeper, snugging everything

up.

When you test the swing this time, the door moves smooth, the bottom edge clearing the

packed dirt with a satisfying fraction of space. No grind, no groan. It doesn’t catch in the

frame. It doesn’t swing wild; it stops where it should.

You step back just as Pella comes over, a mug of something steaming in hand. She nudges

the door with her hip. It moves. No scuff, no drag.

Her brows go up. She pushes it open, then closed again, more deliberately. The motion is

clean.

“Well,” she says. “You weren’t boasting.”

She hands you the mug. “Here. Warm tea, and there’s porridge by the fire if you move

quick. You keep making yourself this useful, and we might have to start fighting over who

gets to claim you.”

Harlin calls over from the cart, “Not before Kakariko, you don’t. He owes me at least one

more day of road-watching.”

Mera, already securing a bundle at the back of the cart, adds with a small smile, “Eat first.

Fix the world afterward.”

The steam from the mug smells faintly of herbs and something like mint. Your stomach,

which had been content to let your hands have their fun with the door, pipes up again

with renewed interest.

Harlin’s horse flicks its ears as if impatient to be gone. The Peaks stand ahead, cleft

gleaming where the first real light of morning catches the waterfalls. Somewhere beyond

them lies Kakariko, and perhaps—if this world is feeling generous—a Sheikah who can put

a name to “very, very far away.”

For now, though, you have hot tea in your hands, a working door at your back, and a cart

waiting to take you further into Hyrule.

*/ No need to rewrite it, but in the future do remember the rule of the simulation for not speaking/writing for the player. The line "'Got up early for your hinges,' you say. 'If you’re still all right with me poking at them.'” should not have been allowed under that rule. /*

I accept the mug gratefully--I've never been that good at dealing with the chill, and that's still true--and acknowledge both Harlin's readiness and Mera's admonition to have a bite. I head over to get some of the offered porridge.

The porridge is fine. Not as world-defining as the stew last night, but still a decent breakfast. I've always been an oatmeal kid, and this porridge was fairly similar. Where the real delight of the morning was, though, was in the tea. I

love tea, and had many different varieties on hand back in my old home. I don't know what kind of tea this is, but is great. I make sure to ask Mera is she knows what it is as we get ready to head out.

Thought for 20s

Dueling Peaks Stable – yard • Early morning • Mist thinning, sun just touching the Peaks

The porridge does exactly what porridge is supposed to do: sits heavy and warm in your

stomach, takes the edge off the hollowness, and gives your body something honest to

burn. It’s simple—oats or some local cousin, a bit of goat milk, a pinch of salt—but it lands

comfortably close to “oatmeal back home.”

The tea is another story.

The steam curls up under your nose as you walk, carrying a mix of scents: something green

and herbal, something sharper like mint, and a faint, almost floral note underneath. The

first sip sends heat down your throat and out through your fingers, chasing the stable-

yard chill out of your joints. There’s a mild bitterness at the back of the tongue, but it’s

rounded by the herbs, not harsh.

When you ask Mera about it while people start making ready to leave, she smiles into her

own cup.

“Hyrule herb and a bit of Necluda mint,” she explains. “Pella keeps bundles of both

hanging in the rafters. The herb clears the head, the mint chases the cold out of your toes.

Old stable trick—keeps hands working when it’s too early for the sun to do its job.”

She tilts her cup toward you in a little salute. “If you pass through Hateno someday, look

for the dried bundles in the market. Every household makes its own mix. This one’s more

mint than most.”

Harlin finishes checking the cart, slaps the horse’s flank lightly, and comes over to trade his

empty mug for a coil of rope. He gives you a once-over—sword, shield, the way you’re

standing after yesterday’s work—then nods, apparently satisfied that you’re not about to

fold in half.

“Cart’s ready,” he says to Mera. “Road should be clear this time of morning. If we’re lucky,

we’ll hit the pass before the wind starts shouting at us.”

Pella joins you long enough to eye the stable door, give it a testing swing, and grunt in

approval when it moves without dragging.

“Door swings right, fence stands straight, trough didn’t explode in the night,” she says.

“You did good. If Kakariko doesn’t snatch you up, there’ll be work for those hands here.”

Tavi hovers at your side, clearly trying to decide whether “new friend” is a permanent

fixture or a soon-to-depart traveler. When you move toward the cart, she pads along, tail

making uncertain half-wags.

Pella snaps her fingers twice. “Tavi. Yard.”

The dog freezes, looks between you and Pella, then trots back to her spot near the

hitching posts with a put-upon sigh, sprawling where she can still watch the gate.

Mera climbs up onto the cart’s bench beside Harlin. There’s a brief shuffle as they shift

bundles to make a bit of space for you to ride or walk at your preference. The morning

light is sharpening now, burning the last of the mist off the ground; the cleft of the

Dueling Peaks glows faintly where the rising sun catches spray from the distant waterfalls.

Harlin clicks his tongue, and the cart lurches into motion, wheels crunching over packed

earth.

Behind you, the stable is already folding this morning into its long memory: another

traveler, another repair, another bowl of stew. Ahead, the road bends toward the split in

the mountains, and somewhere beyond that, Kakariko waits in its green valley, full of

Sheikah eyes and questions you haven’t asked yet.

The tea’s warmth lingers in your chest and fingers as the cart rolls out of the yard and back

onto the road.

As we make our way out, I decide to continue getting to know my gracious hosts, hoping they weren't getting tired or annoyed by questions. "So, you guys work with the stables. Do you work *for* the stables? There isn't one actually in Kakariko, though, right? What's actually taking you there?"

Thought for 11s

Dueling Peaks road, leaving the stable • Morning • Sun climbing, air crisp in the pass’s

shadow

The cart rattles back onto the main road, the stable shrinking behind into a cluster of

canvas and wood. The Peaks loom steadily larger ahead, their cleft now a deep shadow

with silver threads of waterfall glinting inside it.

Harlin walks for the first stretch, leading the horse by the bridle while Mera rides on the

bench. When you ask your question, he angles a look over his shoulder, then back to the

road.

“‘For’ the stables is a strong way to put it,” he says. “They’re not some Grand Stable Order

with banners and oaths. More like a family that got stretched too thin across the map.”

He adjusts his grip on the reins, sidestepping a rut.

“I haul for Outskirt most seasons,” he goes on. “They pay me, I haul for the others when it

makes sense. Grain one way, tools the other, letters stuffed in every spare gap. Dueling

Peaks, Riverside, Wetland, even down to Highland if someone bribes me hard enough.

Stablehands talk to each other more than the royal post does, half the time.”

Mera leans an elbow on her knee, smiling faintly. “The stables trade news as much as

goods. Travelers talk there. Hunters, merchants, guards, the odd Sheikah researcher who

forgot what sleep is. Harlin makes sure the stories that matter don’t get stuck in one

place.”

Harlin snorts. “I drag sacks, she drags compliments. Don’t listen to her.”

He shifts the topic back toward your actual question. “Kakariko’s different. No stable there,

true enough, but it’s the biggest knot of people between here and Hateno, and the

Sheikah like their supplies regular. We take them flour, salt, cloth, odds and ends the

merchants don’t want to haul over the pass themselves. Bring back herbs, ink, medicine,

things the village has more of than the stables do.”

Mera taps the side of the cart with her cup. “And I go because flour sitting still at the

stable doesn’t turn into coin,” she says, amused. “Kakariko’s market days are good for

business. They appreciate proper bread. Stable folk will eat anything that doesn’t move

fast enough.”

“Lies,” Harlin mutters. “We’ve just learned not to argue with Pella about crusts.”

She ignores that, continuing more quietly. “There’s the shrine, too,” she says. “The old

priest will light candles for the dead when I ask. My husband’s name is on that list. I take

him fresh bread when I can afford the time.”

The cart hits a flatter patch; Harlin swings himself up onto the bench beside her, making

room if you want to ride or keeping pace if you stay walking. The road has begun to tilt

downward toward the river that threads out from between the Peaks, the air gaining a

slight dampness. Rock outcrops rise on either side now, scrub and low trees clinging to

their faces.

Harlin gestures ahead with his chin.

“And the guard captain in Kakariko likes to know how the roads feel,” he adds. “Soldiers

can’t be everywhere. Teamsters see more of the in-between. I tell him where the monsters

thickened or thinned, where the bridges complain, where the ditches aren’t draining right.

He grumbles, sends a patrol or two, pretends it was his idea.”

A bird wheels far overhead, riding a thermal. Closer, the sound of water grows: the river in

the gorge, constant and low.

Mera glances sideways. “And you?” she asks mildly. “You’re not bound to the stables, not

yet. After Kakariko, do you want to keep chasing their wagons, or were you thinking of

something else? Carpenters don’t stay idle long in a village that keeps rebuilding itself.”

Harlin doesn’t press the question, but his eyes flick between you and the narrowing road

ahead, weighing how you’ll fit into whatever shape this day takes as the path dives toward

the shadowed throat of the Dueling Peaks.

I'm tempting to take a seat and ride for a while after yesterday's work, sparing my feet for later, but I stubbornly turn down the offer for now and continue walking. If Harlin thinks I can do any good helping to keep watch then I should try to live up to his expectations. Better to have at least one person not riding on the cart. I might have a chance later in the day.

"Mm, I don't know yet. Guess I'm like that guard captain: I just need to get a feel for things. After yesterday the thought did cross my mind like you said," I nod at Mera, "I could probably do okay for myself in Kakariko as a carpenter if someone was willing to take a chance on me. Granted, I know what the architecture there is like, and it's a *little* different than the stables. Not sure if I'd live up to their standards or not."

I mentally chew on the discussion a bit. "Ultimately, while I would love to know more about my situation, truth is I simply find Kakariko a fascinating place and would like to experience it. You mentioned Hateno...gotta be honest, I always thought Hateno was one of the nicest places in all of Hyrule. If I were going to settle down somewhere for good, Hateno would be a serious contender. Is that Purah woman still based there?"

Thought for 23s

Dueling Peaks road, approaching the gorge • Late morning • Sun higher, air cooler in the

mountains’ shadow

Harlin seems quietly pleased you’ve chosen to walk. He lets you pace a little ahead and to

the side of the cart—good sightline, easy to step clear if the horse spooks—while he keeps

the reins loose in one hand.

When you talk about Kakariko architecture and maybe finding work there, Mera smiles

down at you over the cart rail.

“They do like their angles and their neat lines,” she says. “Sheikah houses are…part home,

part puzzle box. Hidden spaces, clever joins, everything just so. But wood is wood. A

steady hand and a straight eye matter more than where you were born.”

Harlin grunts his agreement. “If you can fix Pella’s door, you can fix a Sheikah’s gate. The

old ones will frown at you for a week, then pretend it was their idea to hire you.”

Talk of Hateno draws his gaze eastward, toward where the land eventually rolls down to

sea you can’t yet see.

“Hateno’s kind to folk who want quiet,” he admits. “Good fields, good rain. Dye shop that’ll

turn your clothes any color you can name, an inn that doesn’t water the soup, kids

underfoot everywhere.”

Mera’s smile turns softer at that. “And the sea,” she adds. “You hear it before you see it.

Smell the salt in everything. Hateno folk walk like they know where their next meal’s

coming from.”

When you bring up Purah, both of them react—Harlin with a slight raise of the eyebrows;

Mera with a little puff of laughter.

“‘That Purah woman,’” Mera echoes. “Yes, she’s still there. Up in the lab on the hill above

the village. Hateno Ancient Tech Lab. Hard to miss—big strange house with a furnace that

burns blue when she’s busy.”

“Sheikah researcher,” Harlin adds. “Old as the hills by the stories, looks like a child by the

eyes.” He rolls one shoulder. “Plays with ancient machines and doesn’t sleep enough.

People say she helped the knight and the princess, back when the Calamity still had teeth.”

Mera nods. “Some villagers adore her. Some cross the street when she’s coming because

they’re afraid they’ll get turned into frogs by accident.” There’s fondness in her tone, not

Zelda Wiki

Zelda Wiki +1

malice. “Her assistant, Symin, is easier on people’s nerves. He’ll explain things slowly if your

head starts to spin.”

Harlin gestures with his chin toward the distant east. “Word is, she and folk like her are…

arguing with the rest of us about what to do with all the old Sheikah ruins. Towers, shrines,

Guardians that didn’t get smashed. Some say pull them apart before something nasty

learns to wake them up again. Some say we’re fools to throw away tools that saved us.”

He squints ahead as the road begins to drop more steeply, rock walls shouldering closer

on either side. “Either way, Purah hasn’t stopped tinkering. If anyone’s still lighting up

strange stones and muttering about ‘guidance’ and ‘runes,’ it’ll be her.”

Mera tilts her head, studying you. “If you’re set on Hateno someday, you could do worse

than knocking on her door,” she says. “Carpentry and a curious mind might both be

welcome. Just… don’t touch anything on a table without asking first. Or second. Or maybe

third.”

The road narrows as you enter the throat of the Dueling Peaks. The river’s voice grows

louder, echoing between stone walls; cool, damp air brushes your skin, a contrast to the

sun on your shoulders earlier. Up above, the sky is a bright strip framed by sheer rock, and

somewhere ahead you can hear the distant, constant rush of waterfalls spilling through the

cleft.

Behind you: a night in a stable, a warm meal, people who’ve chosen to keep you in their

orbit another day. Ahead: Kakariko’s hidden valley, and, farther still, the sea-washed hills of

Hateno and an eccentric Sheikah scientist who, by all accounts, delights in impossible

questions.

For now, the cart creaks steadily forward, hooves ringing on patches of exposed stone, and

the three of you move deeper into the shadowed pass, carrying your questions with you

like extra, invisible luggage.

Zelda Wiki

Sources

Sources

*Ah, so Purah is still as mad scientist as ever,* I think to myself. Their mention of her still being in the form of a

little girl rings true in regards to my Breath of the Wild knowledge. I know that by the time the events of Tears of the Kingdom that issue had been rectified though, so I'm curious at what point Purah will figure out her age rune conundrum and age up. I suppose I will find out one way or another.

I make a face at the mention of Purah's disagreement with the Hyrulean consensus to dismantle the Sheikah tech around the kingdom, though. "I have to be honest, I can't say I disagree with her. If a child is led astray you don't kill the child. You discipline and you teach, so they don't do it again. Plus, from a less extremist perspective: just seems like a horrible waste." I look toward the crashing waterfalls and the beautiful moss hanging on the stones around them, sprayed by mist. Then I remember Harlin and Mera's comments about Guardians when we were still near Gatepost Town Ruins, and felt the need to soften and qualify my opinion. "I guess my 'perspective' might be skewed through. Technology where I come from may not actually be as sophisticated as Sheikah tech, but it is far, far more plentiful. And we've never had a corruption like you had to deal with. Suppose it has made me a bit dull to the danger."

Thought for 12s

Dueling Peaks gorge • Late morning • Cool mist, stone walls close

Your words bounce a little off the rock around you, softened by the rush of water.

Harlin is quiet for a few steps, boots scraping on patches of bare stone. The cart wheel hits

a shallow rut and thumps; the horse tosses its head once, then settles.

“Discipline and teach instead of kill,” he repeats. “Nice idea. Harder to swallow when the

‘child’ in question burned half your fields and carved lines of fire across the plains.”

He doesn’t say it angrily, just with that flat, tired honesty of someone who’s seen too much

of the aftermath.

Mera looks up toward the dark mouth of the cleft where the main waterfall is hidden. The

spray drifts down in fine mist, beading on her shawl and hair.

“I do not like the waste either,” she says. “Those shrines—the ones still standing—feel…

sad, in a way. Like ovens with no bread in them.” She smiles faintly at her own metaphor.

“But I was in Kakariko the night a corrupted Guardian came too close to the village. It

never got through the walls. The knight and the princess saw to that. But its beam hit the

outer fields. We watched our crops catch fire like dry parchment.”

Harlin nods once, eyes on the road. “My father was on the walls by the Castle when the

Guardians first went wild,” he adds. “He says he still dreams of the way they moved—like

spiders that’d learned they were bigger than gods. You see that once, you don’t blame folk

for looking at any glowing Sheikah stone and thinking, ‘Maybe not again.’”

The path squeezes narrower for a moment, the gorge walls leaning in. Moss hangs in

sheets from the rock, dripping. Ferns cling to cracks. The river is a constant presence to

your right now, foaming white where it slams against boulders, then smoothing into glassy

stretches where it can breathe.

Mera glances down at you, thoughtful. “Where you come from,” she says, “if you had a

thing this dangerous, and it turned against you—what would your people do? Lock it

away? Argue about it until you forgot why you built it? Or keep it shining and tell

yourselves ‘this time will be different’?”

The way she says it, she genuinely wants to know—not as a challenge, but as if she’s trying

on another world’s logic for size.

Harlin scratches at his jaw. “You say there’s more of your kind of machines,” he adds. “That

makes it easier to risk keeping the bad ones, maybe. For us, this is… what we have. We lose

a field, we go hungry. We lose a village, there’s nowhere to send the orphans but another

village that’s already full.”

There’s a beat of silence, just river and cart and footfalls.

Then Harlin huffs a breath through his nose. “I’ll say this much, though. A kingdom that

tears down every old thing out of fear never builds anything worth singing about. If Purah

and her lot can find a way to make the machines safer—or build new ones that don’t listen

to monsters—we’ll be fools if we don’t listen. I just don’t want another Ganon having an

easy time of it.”

Mera nods at that, the mist catching in her lashes. “Balance,” she says quietly. “We are bad

at balance. We go from ‘depend on the machines for everything’ to ‘smash them all and

hide in caves.’ Maybe your dullness to the danger is not all bad. It lets you see the pieces

we throw away.”

The gorge begins to widen again. Shafts of sunlight spear down through the opening

above, catching the spray and turning it into drifting veils of gold. You can see, ahead,

where the road will soon bend out toward the Dueling Peaks Stable’s eastern cousin: the

little way-stops and camps that sprout near the mouth of this pass.

Harlin shifts the reins, giving the horse its head for a moment on an easier stretch.

“Either way,” he says, “Purah will do what Purah does. The rest of us will argue about it

over stew. If you end up in Hateno, you can tell her about your world’s machines and see if

she glows at you or throws you out.”

Mera smiles. “If she glows, that is good. If she starts muttering about ‘experiments,’ run.”

The cart creaks on. The waterfalls thunder politely in the background. The conversation

settles into a companionable lull, your thoughts and theirs weaving around old scars and

new possibilities as the three of you walk the knife-edge between fear of the past and

curiosity about what might still be salvaged.

I don't have to think much about Mera's question. "Oh you pretty much hit the nail on the head. Where I come frim they would most certainly argue about it until it is too late. Honestly, people are so obsessed with doing what they want to do that no ody ends up doing much at all where I come from. I won't miss that all. People are doers here, for better or for worse."

I let their other insights settle in mind as we continue to

walk. They were all valid points. As the conversation and trek continue, I'm content to see what happens next.

Thought for 22s

Dueling Peaks gorge, eastward • Late morning • Cool shade, water roaring below

Harlin huffs out a short breath that might be a laugh, might be agreement.

“Arguing until it is too late,” he says. “That sounds familiar enough. Maybe your world and

ours are not so different. We just do our arguing with fewer books and more shouting

across fields.”

Mera’s smile is small but genuine. “Doers can be just as foolish as dreamers,” she says. “We

just make our mistakes louder.”

The conversation thins after that, not awkward, just… settled. The three of you fall into a

quieter rhythm: boots, hooves, cart, water.

The gorge breathes around you.

Rock walls press in close, then ease apart. The river, a constant white-noise rush at your

right hand, alternates between furious rapids and smoother, glassy stretches where you

can see fish flickering like shadows beneath the surface. Moss and ferns drink the spray;

every so often, a small side fall spills down from high above, leaving dark, wet trails on the

stone, beading into threads that join the main flow.

The cool keeps the worst of the sun off you, but it also sinks into your clothes. The tea you

had at the stable lingers as warmth in your chest and fingers; without it, the pass would

bite a little harder. Your legs remember yesterday’s work—nothing dramatic, just that dull,

constant ache that says you’ve reintroduced yourself to “manual labor” after too long

away. Your feet are the loudest complainers, hot spots blooming where blisters started last

night. Still manageable. Still well within “push through” territory.

At one point, Harlin slows the cart and nods toward a ledge up on the right-hand wall.

“See there,” he murmurs.

Three bokoblins are perched on a shelf of rock well above the road—blue-skinned, pig-

snouted, armed with rough spears and a rusty club or two. They’re arguing noisily over

something in a torn sack, too engrossed in the dispute to pay much attention to the road

below. One boots another in the backside; the kicked one staggers, windmills, almost
