pitches off the ledge, then catches itself at the last second with a furious squeal.

Harlin steers the cart to give the wall a little extra distance, keeping half an eye on them,

half on the path. Mera slides a hand to the bow beside her on the bench but doesn’t draw.

The bokoblins never look down. Whatever’s in the sack is apparently more important than

three humans and a horse. The road curves; the ledge slips out of sight behind a shoulder

of rock. The moment passes, leaving behind a faint echo of their bickering howls.

“Fewer of them than a few years back,” Harlin says quietly. “Still enough to keep things

interesting.”

As the gorge widens, the sound of the water changes—less trapped thunder, more open

river. The air warms by degrees. Light broadens overhead until you’re walking under a full

sky again, clouds thin and white, sun bright but no longer directly overhead.

Eventually the pass lets you go entirely.

The land opens into a softer valley. To your left, the river meanders out from the

mountains, calmer now, its banks green with reeds and wildflowers. Ahead and to the

right, the road forks around a rocky outcrop.

Straight on, the main road continues east toward Fort Hateno—wider, more worn, the

obvious trader’s route.

To the right, a smaller path peels away and climbs gently toward a gap between wooded

hills. Someone has planted lantern posts along it at intervals, simple wooden poles with

hanging, glass-shielded lamps. In daylight, they’re unlit, but they still mark the way like a

string of beads leading into the hills.

A signpost stands at the fork, weathered but legible. The main road’s arrow reads “Hateno

Village.” The smaller path bears a simpler carving: just the Sheikah eye, stylized and

watching.

Harlin draws the cart to a halt long enough to glance back at you, then at the right-hand

way.

“There,” he says. “Kakariko road. Lanterns all the way to the ridge. They say the Sheikah

started putting them in after the Calamity, so folk wouldn’t be afraid of the dark on the

climb.”

Mera adjusts her shawl, eyes following the line of the hill path. “And to make it easier for

the village to see who’s coming,” she adds. “Light works both ways.”

Harlin guides the cart onto the smaller road without fuss, the wheels crunching onto more

compacted earth, stones set with deliberate care. The climb is gentle but steady. On either

side, the land folds upward into slopes dotted with trees and brush; you catch glimpses of

farm plots tucked here and there, small terraces clinging to the hillsides.

Your body notices the incline—calves waking up a little more, breath deepening—but the

change of scenery helps. Birds chatter in the branches. A lizard darts across the path and

vanishes under a rock. Somewhere distant, a cucco lets out a disgruntled squawk.

As the lanterns tick past—unlit, glass catching bits of sunlight—you feel an odd déjà vu,

like walking through a screenshot into a place you’ve studied from too many angles. The

broad strokes match your memory: the curve of the road, the way it bends around a stand

of trees, the shape of the hills framing the sky. But there are new details, too. A small stone

cairn someone’s built beside one lantern. Fresh cart tracks. A child’s carved wooden toy,

forgotten and half-kicked into a ditch.

After another steady stretch of climbing, the road crests a low ridge and the world drops

away on the far side into something that is very definitely Kakariko and also very much its

own thing.

The valley is a tucked-away bowl of green, ringed by steep hills and cliffs. Terraced fields

step down from the slopes like giant stairways: rice paddies gleaming with water,

vegetable plots in careful rows, small orchards of fruit trees. Houses are scattered among

them and clustered near the valley floor—wood and plaster, steep roofs, banners bearing

the Sheikah eye fluttering softly.

Smoke rises in thin lines from chimneys. You can hear the faint thock of someone splitting

wood, the murmur of voices, a cucco’s furious clucking at something only it understands.

A narrow stream winds through the village, crossed by little arched bridges. At the far end,

on a raised promontory, the chief’s house stands with its distinctive upturned rooflines,

banners snapping in the breeze.

It is familiar, and it is new, and it is real in a way no game map ever quite was.

Harlin lets out a slow breath beside Mera.

“There she is,” he says. “Kakariko. Village of old secrets and nosy aunties.”

Mera’s eyes soften, taking in the terraces, the houses, the shrine’s simple gate visible near

the village center. “And good tea,” she says. “Do not forget the tea.”

The cart starts down the slope toward the valley floor, wheels rattling over the first set of

stone steps deliberately worn into the road for traction. Lanterns continue all the way

down, marking the path into the heart of the village.

Whatever questions you brought with you—from “can I work here?” to “who can explain

the impossible?”—this is the first place in Hyrule where the answers might be more than

guesses.

I walk slightly slack-jawed for a moment as I take in the abrupt sight. The elegant architecture, the beautiful scenary, the breathing history of both Kakariko and, really, Japan from my old world. Playing the game, I did indeed find myself enchanted by the aesthetic of the Sheikah people and Kakariko Village, though its isolation and idiosyncracies had always put me off frim spending an excessive amount of time there. My intuition tells me that Harlin would probably agree.

I make sure to politely keep my mouth closed and expression closer to neutral as we descend the slope and enter the village, not wanting to draw undo attention by being a gawker.

"Yes," I agree with Mera, who was obviously hinting at her approval of being with a fellow tea-appreciater. "I don't know that I ever thought about tea feom Kakariko. Now you've gone and brought it up and it's all I want."

For the first time I find myself keeping my eyes peeled for something specific amongst the village houses, farms and people. I never found myself liking the most narratively important Sheikah people in the games. Impa, Purah, Robby, etc. But there were a number of minor characters in the game that I adored being around that lived in the village. Dorian, Paya and Lasli spring to mind. I keep a discreet eye out for them as I follow Harlin and hia cart.

Thought for 23s

Kakariko Village – upper road • Late morning • Soft sun, valley air warm and green

The cart rattles down the stone-cut track into the bowl of the village, lanterns ticking past

as you go. Up close, Kakariko is less postcard-perfect and more lived-in: laundry flaps on

lines between houses, cuccos strut with ridiculous self-importance, and somewhere a baby

is wailing with the vigor of ten.

You rein your expression in, keeping your jaw from hanging while your eyes do the work.

The architecture lands exactly where your memory said it would and then keeps going—

steep roofs with layered tiles, beams exposed and neatly joined, paper screens glowing

soft where sunlight hits them from behind. Banner cloth rustles in the breeze, each painted

with the Sheikah eye in different styles: simple and bold over a shop door, intricately

patterned outside what’s clearly a family home.

Mera hums approval at your comment about tea, a conspirator’s little sound. “You’ll have

your chance soon enough,” she says. “The inn keeps a good pot on. And the elders could

brew sarcasm into steam if they wanted.”

Harlin guides the cart along the main lane that snakes down through the terraces, hooves

clopping on carefully placed stones. Villagers glance up as you pass—measuring looks, not

hostile, just taking stock. Travelers are common enough here, but you’re a new

configuration: familiar cart, unfamiliar face.

You keep a discreet scan going as you walk alongside.

Near a stand of bamboo and the little pond at the village’s center, a man in Sheikah garb

stands vigil-still by the path up to a large house with upturned eaves and heavy banners.

Broad shoulders, hair pulled back, Eightfold blade at his side. His eyes track the cart as it

passes, steady and weighty. Dorian, by every line of stance and steel.

At his back, on the raised veranda, a young woman is sweeping, motions careful and

precise. Her hair is bound up in that familiar swooping bun, a small paper charm tucked

into it; freckles dust her cheeks. Even at this distance you can see her chewing nervously at

her lip as she glances between the lane and the house door, as if expecting someone

important to appear at any moment. Paya, without question. She clocks the cart, you, your

mismatched sword and shield—and then drops her gaze back to the broom in a flurry of

flustered focus.

Farther down, near a bright splash of color that resolves into the Enchanted armor shop’s

awning, a younger Sheikah woman stands just off the path, calling out about fine cloth

and sturdy gear to a pair of passing farmers. Her voice is bright and sing-song, but

underneath there’s a tiredness in the eyes, a hollow that game-text never quite captured.

Lasli, drawing attention to her sister’s shop with practiced lines, even as her gaze drifts for

a heartbeat toward the fireflies glassed in a jar by the doorway.

All three are exactly where the shape of the village says they should be, and yet they’re

also more—more weight in the shoulders, more life in the small, idle gestures between

tasks.

None of them rushes you. You’re another stranger on Harlin’s business, and that’s not rare

enough to tilt the world.

Harlin steers the cart toward a flat, open space near the base of the valley—something

between a square and a widened bit of road. A couple of other carts are already there, one

loaded with pumpkins, another with sacks of rice. High Spirits Produce and the general

store crouch nearby, signs out, doors open.

zelda.fandom.com +1

zelda.fandom.com +1

Zelda Dungeon +1

“Here we are,” he says, drawing the horse to a halt. “Kakariko’s belly. We unload here, then

let the elders and shopkeepers argue about who gets which sack.”

Mera hops down with the ease of practice, already knotting a cloth bundle tighter under

one arm—probably bread orders wrapped in linen. She gives the village a quick,

appreciative once-over, then looks your way.

“You’ll see more of it before the day’s done,” she says. “Tea, gossip, and at least three old

women telling you what you should do with your life.” Her eyes glint with humor. “If you’re

lucky, only three.”

Around you, Kakariko goes on being itself. Dorian resumes his quiet, watchful stillness at

Impa’s house path. Paya sweeps, stealing glances you’d swear are more habit than focus.

Lasli sings out another line about armor that will “suit you perfectly, traveler!”

You’ve made it from a ruin at the foot of the Plateau to the heart of the Sheikah’s hidden

village with a cart, a dog’s friendship, a battered sword, and a half day’s work under your

belt. The map in your head and the village under your boots are finally the same place,

and the difference between seeing Kakariko on a screen and feeling its air in your lungs is

about as subtle as a Guardian beam.

Harlin thumps the side of the cart. “Right then,” he says. “Let’s see who wants their flour

first. After that? You can start seeing what this village thinks of men who fix doors and ask

too many questions.”

I do my best to make myself useful to Harlin and his unloading, thoughts beginning to simmer in my head as I work. It had been almost exactly a day since I suddenly *was in* Hyrule, and while the wonder of experiencing it in all its real glory was still a metaphorically intoxicating drug, the more rational and logical side of my mind was beginning to cry a little louder.

I wasn't sure if I should be actively chasing a chance to return to my old home or not. Maybe it could happen.

Then again, it could be that this just was my life now. And that wouldn't necessarily be bad. I could make myself anything I wanted to here, and that meant something, even if it came with sacrifice.

But regardless, it seemed only logical that whether I pursued returning "home" or conceded to remaining in Hyrule, I was going to need to find a way to subsist for an indeterminate amount of time. And that could not simply mean following Harlin and Mera each day and doing oddjob carpentry each evening forever. I was going to have to find a real niche.

I continued to help with the unloading process as I spoke to Harlin. "How long do you think you'll be here in the village? Make this transaction and immediately hit the road again, or are you here for a day or two before you move on?"

Thought for 12s

Kakariko central terrace, cart square • Late morning • Sun mild, valley air smelling of earth

and smoke

Sacks thump, boards creak, your shoulders start that familiar warm ache again as you fall

into Harlin’s rhythm: he hauls from the cart, you pivot and stack where the shopkeepers

indicate, Mera slips in and out with her cloth-wrapped bundles, vanishing into doorways

and reappearing lighter each time.

By the third trip your palms are protesting yesterday’s blisters; the skin stretches and

complains, but the callus underneath is already thinking about growing. Your feet don’t

love the stone steps, but the rest from straight-line walking helps in its own way.

Harlin listens to your question as he hefts another sack of flour onto his shoulder. He

pauses just long enough to answer, shifting the weight with a practiced shrug.

“Not a hit-and-run this time,” he says. “We’ve got half the valley’s pantry on this wagon.

Shopkeepers will want to count and complain, elders will want news, and Mera’s got

orders to fill.” He nods toward where she’s already being buttonholed by a woman in a

patterned shawl, who is clearly talking about bread in the tone of someone discussing

statecraft.

“Today for certain,” he adds. “We’ll sleep under a roof here if the inn’s got room or in the

cart if it doesn’t. Tomorrow depends on how fast folk make up their minds about what

they want hauled out.” A faint smirk. “Kakariko’s good at thinking. Less good at deciding.”

He sets the sack down inside High Spirits Produce with a solid whump. The shopkeeper

immediately starts untieing the mouth to peer inside, muttering about grain quality.

Back out in the square, Harlin wipes a forearm across his brow and glances your way again.

“You’ve got daylight,” he says. “Once we’re unloaded, I’ll need you less. Mera and I know

this dance.” His gaze flicks around the village: the inn with its fluttering curtains; the path

up toward Impa’s house, Dorian a steady presence at its base; the shrine gate; the bustle

around the general store. “If you’re going to sniff around for a niche, this is as good a

place to start as any. Plenty of old wood, old questions, and old people who like the sound

of their own advice.”

Your stomach reminds you that porridge was a while ago and unloading flour is a cruel

kind of irony. The smells drifting on the air don’t help: someone frying something doughy

near the inn, the faint tang of pickled vegetables, the green, clean scent of rice paddies

just beyond the houses.

Mera reappears at your elbow long enough to slip a small cloth-wrapped lump into your

hand—a heel of bread, still faintly warm. She doesn’t comment, just gives you a knowing

little nod and dives back into negotiations over her next delivery.

Around you, Kakariko goes on breathing: Paya sweeping nervously at the path to the

chief’s house, stealing another anxious glance down at the square; Lasli’s sing-song voice

pitching armor to a new arrival; Dorian’s watchful eyes never quite leaving the flow of

strangers.

Harlin turns back to the cart for another sack. The edge of the day ahead feels open in a

way that’s both daunting and promising: a whole Sheikah village full of work, questions,

and whatever passes here for opportunity, with at least one night’s safety guaranteed and

tomorrow not yanking you away just yet.

I pause briefly to thank Mera for the bread and wolf it down before getting back to it. "And where will you be headed once you leave here?"

Kakariko central terrace, cart square • Late morning • Sun higher, village humming

Harlin shifts another sack of grain down from the cart, settles it against his shoulder, and

answers between steps.

“East, if the road’s kind,” he says. “Back through the pass to Dueling Peaks, then out

toward Riverside and Wetland stables. They’ll be waiting on herbs, ink, whatever medicines

the elders spare us. After that, probably swing north if there’s coin in it. Monsters don’t eat

themselves and hunters need arrows.”

He drops the sack inside the shop, straightens, rolls his shoulder once to work out a kink.

“Hateno’s a maybe,” he adds. “If someone here shoves a letter or a package in my hands

and swears it can’t wait for the next merchant. Or if the guard wants word carried to the

fort. I don’t go there on every run. Too many hills for an old cart.”

There’s a wry edge on old, but his hand runs over the cart rail in that unconscious

possessive way that says he trusts it more than he lets on.

One more round of loads, and the wagon bed starts to show actual gaps instead of a wall

of sacks and bundles. Shopkeepers are already sorting, counting, complaining cheerfully

about weights and measures. A couple of kids have materialized to stare at the horse and

ask Mera questions about bread that are really just excuses to stand close to someone

interesting.

Harlin dusts his hands off on his trousers and squints at what’s left.

“Another hour or so to finish here,” he says. “Then I owe the guard captain a cup of

something bitter while I tell him where the road’s rough. After that?” He nods toward the

village at large. “We’re just folk underfoot until morning.”

Mera reappears from a side door, purse a little heavier from sales, sleeves floured again.

She glances between you and Harlin, reading the shape of things.

“We won’t drag you back to the cart when we leave,” she says. “If Kakariko feels right

under your feet, you plant them here. If not, there’s always another run, another road.”

She gives the square a meaningful little look—the inn, the shrine path, Impa’s house

watching from its height, the shops with their doors propped open.

“Daylight’s good,” she adds. “If you want to speak to anyone important, better before the

old aunties decide it’s nap time.”

Your stomach is appeased for now; your hands and shoulders are definitely aware they’ve

been working two days in a row, but nothing’s gone from ache to injury. The village’s

sounds and smells press in: rice paddies wet and green, woodsmoke from cooking fires,

the faint tang of dye from a shop up the lane.

Harlin turns back to the last of the cart’s cargo. For the moment, you’re free to either keep

lifting alongside him or step out of the rhythm and start testing where, in all this carefully

terraced life, a displaced carpenter with a battered sword might fit.

I make my thank yous and excuses to Harlin and Mera and double check that leaving my sword and shield in the cart is all right before striking out on my own for the time being. Could be that without any gear and not even a weapon I might get a tut-tut from someone thinking I was weird and crazy vagrant, but I find that scenario more appealing than lugging an unsheathed sword around a safe and lawful village and being taken for a threatening barbarian.

Truthfully, it would be enough to simply sight-see, but I know I have things that need doing. If Hateno was a only a maybe--and it seemed like an unlikely maybe--for Harlin and Mera, then it might be that I needed to be ready to

fend for myself. Before I just start walking around begging for a job though, I want to start building a rapport. Establish a support system. And I've already mulled over how I might do that. And perhaps also establish a little bit of leverage. It isn't necessarily a plan I feel good about, but it is one that I think could get me somewhere, and it's mostly harmless. And it needs Dorian.

I start wandering over in the direction I saw him, still on duty at his post outside Impa's house. I wave and smile as disarmingly as I can as I approach. "Hello! You uh, you don't know me, but are you Dorian?"

Thought for 19s

Kakariko – path before Impa’s house • Late morning • Quiet, shaded, banners stirring

The climb up toward Impa’s house is steeper than it looks from below. Stone steps lead

past small gardens and hanging lanterns, up toward the broad platform where the chief’s

home sits like a watching bird.

Dorian is exactly where you saw him before: at the base of the final rise, between two

banner poles, Impa’s house looming behind him. Eightfold Blade at his hip, hat casting a

bar of shadow across his eyes, back straight in that particular “nothing gets past me” way.

He clocks you well before you’re close enough to speak. His gaze flicks over you—plain

clothes, no sword in hand, calloused but not yet fully Hyrule-worn—and then past you,

automatically checking what you came from. When he sees Harlin’s cart below and

recognizes the teamster, some of the tension drops a fraction, but not all.

When you greet him and use his name, his brows tick up, the only real giveaway that

you’ve caught him off guard.

“I am,” he confirms after a heartbeat, voice low and even. “And you’re… new.”

His eyes narrow just a little, not hostile, just sharpening.

“You came with Harlin’s wagon,” he adds, more observation than question. “I do not know

your face, and that means you are not from this valley.”

He shifts his weight, not quite blocking the path but very much occupying it. One hand

rests near the guard of his blade in a casual way that is not actually casual.

“I will ask your name,” he says, “and your business at the elder’s house. Outsiders are

welcome in Kakariko, but not all of them need to trouble Lady Impa.”

Behind him, up on the veranda, Paya has stilled in her sweeping. She’s trying, not very

successfully, to look like she is absolutely not listening.

"My name is Zeth," I think about raising my hand to shake, but decide not to, not sure if that was really even customary among Kakariko denizens. Instead I give a weak wave and smaile at Paya, just to let her know that I noticed her. I'm sure that will absolutely throw her into some sort of quiet chaos. But I keep my focus respectfully on Dorian. "My business at Lady Impa's house is actually to see you. It is an honour to make your acquaintance. I know you're on duty right now...um...is there a policy about unnecessary chatter while on duty?"

Thought for 7s

Kakariko – path before Impa’s house • Late morning • Breeze soft, paper charms rustling

Your wave and smile toward the veranda land like a bomb.

Paya jerks as if you’d shouted. The broom squeaks against the boards; she fumbles it,

nearly drops it, recovers, and then becomes intensely focused on a single imaginary speck

of dust that absolutely must be swept right now. Her shoulders are a little too straight. Her

ears are a little too red.

Dorian tracks that with the faintest flick of his eyes, then brings his attention squarely back

to you.

“Zeth,” he repeats, testing the name, filing it somewhere. “No policy against words while

on duty. Only against being distracted.”

His gaze sweeps the lane below—villagers going about their business, no one else

approaching the house—then up the hill, then back to you. Satisfied that nothing

immediate is about to explode, he eases his stance by a hair. Not relaxed, but allowing

space for a conversation.

“If your business is with me,” he goes on, “we may speak. Here is as good as anywhere, so

long as I can see the road.”

He shifts half a step to one side so he can keep both you and the village in his peripheral

vision. One hand still rests near the hilt of his blade, but the grip has loosened.

“What is it you want, Zeth?” he asks. “News from the roads? Work? A warning? Or are you

simply curious enough to trouble a guard at his post?”

Behind him, Paya’s sweeping slows just enough to be obvious. The broom head moves in

small, careful arcs that cover almost no ground at all, the classic pattern of someone

eavesdropping with every part of their body that isn’t an ear.

I am pleased that Dorian, ever the professional, makes such an allowance for me, and I bob my head respectfully. I try to keep my mindset in a way that I think would make a culturally traditional Japanese person feel better. I know that Kakariko is very heavily inspired by my old world's Japan, but I've never been to Japan and and hardly any kind of an expert. I also have no idea if it even matters at all. Kakariko is still certainly not Japan, and the Sheikah are definitely not Japanese. It just seemed like a good way to start, and I hope I find my social footing as I go. The real problem, which I foolishly didn't consider...was Paya. What I wanted to say to Dorian I didn't really want other people hearing. More for his sake than my own.

"Thank you, sir. I promise I won't distract you from your duty. If I am, please tell me and I'll remove myself. As to my business with you...I'm not exactly sure how to put this..." I wring my hands with some genuine nervousness. "Let's put it this way: If someone were to tell you that, even though you had never met them, they know you well, and respect you, and *trust* you...and needed your help, what would you say?"

Thought for 10s

Kakariko – path before Impa’s house • Late morning • Air still, paper tags ticking softly

Your words land like a thrown stone.

Dorian’s gaze sharpens, all the little allowances he’d given you pulling tight again. He

doesn’t move, but his presence hardens; the easy half-slouch of a village guard becomes

the quiet coil of someone who has been other things.

For a heartbeat he says nothing.

Up on the veranda, Paya’s broom actually stops. It hangs mid-sweep, bristles hovering over

the same spot of floor they’ve been worrying for the last minute. She’s not even

pretending anymore; her shoulders are angled toward you both, eyes wide.

Dorian does not look back at her. He keeps his attention pinned to you, searching your

face like he’s trying to decide whether you’re dangerous, unwell, or both.

“That,” he says at last, “is a very strange way to begin.”

His voice is still low and controlled, but there’s a new edge under it. Not anger—wariness,

old and deep.

“Most people who tell me they ‘know’ me without having met me are drunks, fortune-

tellers, or liars,” he goes on. “Sometimes all three.” A beat. “None of those are welcome at

Lady Impa’s door.”

He glances down the path, then up toward the house, making a decision.

“Paya,” he calls, without turning. “Inside.”

There’s a small, startled noise from the veranda—half squeak, half “yes!”—and hurried

footsteps. Paya all but vanishes through the sliding door, broom clacking against the

threshold in her rush. The paper panel slides shut with a soft whff, leaving you and Dorian

in a bubble of relative privacy under the banners.

He exhales once, slow, then returns fully to you.

“If this is some joke, drop it now,” he says. “If it is not…”

His hand settles more deliberately near his blade, not threatening, but making the line

clear.

“If someone I had never met told me they knew me and trusted me and needed my help,”

he says, answering your hypothetical, “I would say this: trust is earned, not declared. And I

would ask them how they know what they claim—and what they think they know that

gives them such confidence.”

His eyes never leave yours.

“So,” he adds quietly, “consider the question asked.”

The village hums below: cucco noises, distant chatter, the crack of someone splitting

wood. Up here, it’s just the two of you in the shade, wind tugging at the corners of the

banners, Dorian’s suspicion and curiosity held in careful balance.

I am relieved for half a moment as Dorian sends Paya away. But I also feel my stomach turn in a knot. If you had told me a week ago that I could meet Dorian, I would have not believed it, but would have thrilled at the concept anyways. Now that I have set the large, skilled warrior on edge, I feel myself wanting to wither somewhat under his intimidating facade.

I speak softly, privately, but deliberately. "It is a strange way to begin, but then, what I have to tell you is strange.

And I believe honesty is the best policy. It is not a joke, and I assure you I am not here to antagonise you. Or anybody for that matter. I am...a rather helpless person in the here and now; I am telling you the truth when I say I need help. However..." I let my gaze fall to the side briefly, "The reason I need help is for a very...not...believable reason. I will tell you why I feel I know you well, but first, just one thing, if I may be so bold: you say you don't know my face and that I am not from this valley. How far away from this valley would you say I came? In your professional opinion."

Thought for 8s

Kakariko – path before Impa’s house • Late morning • Shade cool, village sounds muted

below

Dorian listens without interrupting, jaw set, eyes never leaving your face. The more you

talk about honesty and unbelievable reasons, the deeper the lines at the corners of his

mouth get.

When you finish and ask your question, he tilts his head a fraction, considering you like

you’re an odd blade he’s deciding whether to trust.

“How far?” he echoes. “Far enough that you do not know how to stand in front of a guard

without looking like you want to apologize for breathing.”

There’s the faintest ghost of humor in it, but it’s wrapped in steel.

He takes you in more deliberately now, piece by piece.

“You are not from this valley,” he says. “You are not from Hateno or the Necluda coast—

the accent is wrong, and you do not smell of salt or dye.” His gaze flicks over your clothes.

“You do not dress like a Sheikah, or a Hylian farmer, or a soldier. Your hands know tools,

but not a hoe. You speak of our elders and scholars as if you had read them on a page

instead of hearing them from a gossiping aunt.”

His eyes narrow slightly.

“And you come to the chief’s house empty-handed, with nothing to bargain, and talk

about knowing me and trusting me before you’ve earned either.”

He lets that hang there for a beat.

“In my professional opinion,” he says at last, “you come from too far away. Somewhere that

does not fit neatly on any map I have seen.”

A tiny shrug of one shoulder.

“But that is an opinion, not proof. Words are wind. If you want me to believe anything

stranger than ‘lost traveler with more questions than sense,’ you will have to say more than

that you feel you know me.”

His tone hardens again, just a touch.

“And you should know: if your ‘unbelievable reason’ threatens Lady Impa or Paya, I will not

care how helpless you claim to be. I will act first and regret later.”

He doesn’t say it loudly. It doesn’t need volume. The promise sits there between you,

matter-of-fact as the sword at his side.

“Now,” he finishes quietly, “you asked your question. I have answered. It is your turn.”

2/2 2/2

I inhale and exhale slowly. I was really deep in it now. Some people have told me I have a certain charm about me in the past, but I am definitely not a diplomat.

"I know you because I come from so far away in both space and time that I have observed Hyrule like an audience may observe the theatre. I have no power or ownership over this...metaphorical "play", but I do feel a connection to it. To the people in it. The locations. I know you and I respect you and I trust you because I have watched you." I nervously rub my nose, preparing to drop my bombshell. I make sure that I keep my voice as low as

possible so that nobody hears but Dorian. "You are Dorian, formerly of the Yiga clan. You abandoned the Yiga and devoted yourself to the Sheikah when you fell in love with a woman from Kakariko, with whom you had two daughters: Koko and Cottla. But the Yiga do not accept leaving their clan, and so they killed your wife." I immediately take a step back and lower my head, ashamed that I had to bring up something so personal and painful to the man.

"Please forgive me for bringing this up, but it is something that I should not know--something that nobody should know but you...and maybe just a few others. But it is the only way I know to convince someone that I am not where I should be, and need help." I keep my eyes downward to show respect. "Please forgive me."

Thought for 17s

Kakariko – path before Impa’s house • Late morning • Wind gone still, banners hanging

heavy

The words pour out of you, and for a moment Dorian is a statue.

Not the relaxed kind. The drawn-bow kind.

When you speak his daughters’ names, something sharp flashes across his face—too fast

to read, too raw to be anything but pain. By the time you reach “killed your wife,” his hand

is already moving.

Steel whispers halfway out of its sheath before he checks himself. The Eightfold Blade

hangs there, bared a handspan, catching a thin line of light. His other hand fists in the

front of your shirt and slams you back a step into the wooden post of the banner.

The impact is not enough to truly hurt, but it gets your bones’ attention.

Up close, his eyes are fierce. Whatever calm he usually wears is gone; what’s left is

something much older and much less forgiving.

“Quiet,” he hisses.

It’s not a shout. If anything, the lowered voice makes it worse.

The village sounds below are suddenly very far away.

He scans the path, the houses, the veranda above—checking for witnesses. The paper

screens of Impa’s house stay closed. Paya does not reappear. A pair of villagers down-

slope walk past without looking up; from below, you’re just two figures under the banners.

Satisfied, he turns his full attention back to you.

“How do you know that name,” he says, very softly, “and those things?”

He doesn’t wait for an answer.

“Do not say them again,” he snaps, the words clipped. “Not here. Not anywhere in this

valley. If you ever speak of my daughters in the same breath as the Yiga Clan where they

might hear—”

The blade twitches in its sheath. He shoves it home with a hard, decisive push.

“—we are finished speaking.”

His grip on your shirt tightens once, then loosens by a fraction, enough that you can

breathe without feeling the post grind between your shoulder blades. He doesn’t let go.

“You say you are helpless,” he murmurs, “but you carry knowledge like a knife to my

family’s throat. That is not helpless.”

He holds you there for another couple of heartbeats, searching your face for any hint of

mockery, deception, malice. Whatever he sees—or doesn’t—tempers something in him.

The rage doesn’t vanish, but it pulls back from the edge.

When he speaks again, the words are still hard, but more controlled.

“You could not have learned those things in this village,” he says. “Impa knows. I know.

One other knight who is not here knows. The Yiga who killed my wife knew, for the

moment it took him to strike.” His jaw tightens. “None of them would have put those

truths in a stranger’s mouth.”

His eyes narrow.

“So you either come from very far away indeed… or you are a Yiga trick I have not seen

before.”

He finally releases your shirt, but only to seize your upper arm in a bruising grip instead.

“Either way,” he says, “this is no longer a conversation you and I have alone.”

He jerks his chin toward the house behind him.

“You want help? You want someone to believe your impossible story? Then you will tell it

to Lady Impa. Every word. You will stand before her and repeat what you said to me, and if

she finds truth in you, then perhaps I will believe you are lost and not a knife.”

His hand tightens on your arm, making it very clear this is not a suggestion.

“And until she says otherwise,” he adds, “you will not speak my past aloud again. You will

not speak my daughters’ names in that context again. Not to me. Not to anyone.”

He steps sideways, still holding your arm, guiding you firmly toward the steps.

“Walk,” he says quietly. “Do not run. Do not try to pull away.”

The banners creak softly above you as the wind stirs again, like the village itself exhaling.

Below, life goes on—cucco noise, distant chatter, the thunk of a chopping block.

Up here, Dorian escorts you up the last stretch of stone toward the chief’s house, jaw

clenched, shoulders squared, your arm in his grip and your bombshell still ringing in the

air between you like a struck bell.

I wordlessly do what Dorian asks as compliantly as I can. Nobody likes being man-handled, but he is justified in his actions. I am not proud of my actions, and I hope I can make right with Dorian, but he was right when he said that the knowledge I have is the one that might make me not so helpless. And this was literally the only way I could think of to start gaining traction in this world.

Thought for 10s

Impa’s House – entry platform • Late morning • Cool shade, faint incense on the air

Dorian keeps his grip firm but not brutal, steering you up the last flight of stone steps. Up

close, Impa’s house looms larger than in any game cutscene: carved beams dark with age,

paper screens yellowed slightly with smoke and time, banners heavy with stitched Sheikah

eyes watching the valley.

At the top, he releases your arm with a final squeeze that feels very much like a warning,

then steps ahead to slide the door open without ceremony.

Inside, it is dim and cool.

Light filters through paper screens, soft and diffuse. The smell of old wood, ink, and a faint

trace of incense hangs in the air. Tatami mats sigh quietly underfoot. The interior feels

bigger than the outside suggests, in the way of houses built with more thought than

bravado.

At the far end of the room, slightly elevated on a low platform, Impa sits.

You’ve seen this image a hundred times framed by UI and quest text; reality strips all that

away and leaves a very small, very old Sheikah woman whose presence nonetheless fills

the space. Her hair is piled up beneath her hat in its familiar knot, white as paper; her back

is bowed but not frail. The lines of her face are deep, but her eyes are sharp, dark, and

absolutely awake.

To one side, a low brazier glows faintly. To the other, a writing desk with carefully stacked

papers, brushes washed and bristles wrapped to keep their shape. The Sheikah Heirloom is

not here; a simple stand where it once sat now holds only a folded cloth.

Dorian kneels at the line where wood meets tatami, bowing his head.

“Lady Impa,” he says, voice low. “There is a matter that cannot wait.”

Impa studies him for a heartbeat, then lets her gaze drift past him to you. It lingers longer

than is comfortable, taking in your clothes, your posture, the exhaustion in your shoulders,

the way you’re holding yourself after being dragged here.

“Dorian,” she says at last, her voice dry but steady, “you look as if you have bitten into

something sour.”

He grimaces faintly. “Sour and sharp, my lady.”

“Mm.” Her attention returns fully to you. “Well. Bring it here, then. My old teeth can still

chew.”

Dorian rises, gestures you forward, then speaks without embellishment.

“This man calls himself Zeth,” he says. “He came with Harlin’s wagon from Dueling Peaks.

He claims to be lost—from somewhere beyond any road I know. He also knows things he

should not. Personal things. About my past and my family.”

Impa’s gaze does not leave your face.

“Does he now,” she murmurs.

Dorian’s jaw tightens. “He knew of my… former allegiance,” he says carefully. “And of my

wife’s death. Of the manner of it. He spoke my daughters’ names in the same breath as the

Yiga.”

Impa’s eyes narrow just a fraction; that, more than anything, tells you you’ve stepped

square into something sacred and raw.

“And yet he is still breathing,” she notes mildly.

“For the moment,” Dorian says.

A ghost of wryness touches her mouth. “You are learning restraint.”

Her attention settles on you like a weight.

“Step closer, Zeth,” she says. “My eyes may be sharp, but the rest of me is still an old

woman’s. I will not chase you down if you run.”

The line is dry, but there’s iron under it.

Up close, you can see the fine tremor in her hands, the way her breathing is a little shallow.

You can also see the absolutely unshaken steadiness in her gaze.

“This village stands because of secrets kept,” she says quietly. “And sometimes because of

secrets shared at the right time. If you truly come ‘from so far away you watched us like a

play,’ as Dorian says you claimed… then you are either a liar, a spy, or a very specific kind

of fool.”

She folds her hands in her lap.

“I have lived a long time,” she continues. “I have seen heroes pulled from shrines, monsters

poured from shadows, ghosts given form by malice and memory. There are not many

stories left that can surprise me.”

A beat.

“Not many,” she repeats. “But some.”

Her eyes don’t waver.

“So,” Impa says. “You will tell me your story, Zeth-who-knows-too-much. Where you say

you came from. How you came to know things buried in my family’s grief. Why I should

not have Dorian drag you from this valley and leave you on the road with a warning not to

return.”

A faint, almost amused exhale.

“And if your answer is that you are helpless, choose your words carefully. Men who cross

mountains with nothing but their clothes and their tongues are rarely as helpless as they

think.”

She falls silent then, giving you space. The only sounds are the faint crackle from the

brazier, the distant murmur of the village below, and Dorian’s controlled breathing at your

side as he stands like a drawn line between you and the rest of Kakariko.

I bow my head again like someone who cannot count high enough to reach the number of "I'm sorries" needed.

"Yes ma'am. I, of course, apologise for my poor choice of

words to Dorian. I am absolutely incorrect to label the wielding of such information as 'helpless'. I merely mean to say that, as lacking as I am in skill, possessions and experience, even a child in this village could most certainly do me great harm. I have only made it here to the two of you by virtue of the kindness of strangers," I motion outside the building to Harlin's cart. "I approached Dorian because I know he is someone who understands both loss and resilience, and that he is a good person. I appreciate greatly you being willing to listen to me now.

"I am, as I have said, Zeth. Yesterday morning I suddenly found myself west of here, in Gatepost Town Ruins. And that...is simply all there is. There was no great show, no explanation, no expectation for my arrival there. I was at home, minding my own business one moment, and the next moment I was standing with nothing but the clothes on my back in the middle of the road through the ruins. I have told my benefactors, Harlin and Mera, that I where I come from is so very far away that I do not know the nature of the relationship between here and there. And that is the truth I really don't. I did not tell them what I have just told Dorian, about how, when I was back there, I was able to observe Hyrule in a small and limited way, as I did not want to cause panic or seem threatening.

I stop for a moment, unsure of whether I should continue speaking or not.

Thought for 10s

Impa’s House – main room • Late morning • Dim light, ink and tatami

Silence settles for a long moment after you stop. The brazier pops once; a tiny ember drifts

and dies.

Impa watches you the whole time you speak, eyes almost hooded, but not with sleep. She

is listening the way an old tree listens to wind: feeling for which gusts are real and which

are only noise.

When you trail off, she lets the quiet linger a breath longer, then two.

“That,” she says at last, “is a beginning. Not a story.”

Her hands shift in her lap, fingers lacing.

“You appeared at the Gatepost Ruins with nothing,” she recaps, “and the first thing you did

was attach yourself to a wagon and walk a road, instead of running into the woods

screaming.” A small, dry huff that almost passes for a laugh. “This already makes you more

sensible than some heroes I have known.”

Dorian makes a low, disapproving sound in his throat at the word heroes. Impa ignores

him.

“You say you come from… elsewhere,” she continues, voice careful, “a place where you

watched us as if we were on a stage. Where Hyrule was story, and I”—her mouth quirks

—“was something like a character in your ‘play’.”

Her gaze sharpens again.

“In all my years,” she says, “I have heard of other realms. Shadows beside ours. Echoes. You

are not the first to speak of them. You are the first to stand breathing in front of me

claiming to have crossed from one.”

Her eyes flick briefly to Dorian.

“And you knew which stone to throw if you wished to prove you were not simply

guessing.”

The line hangs there, heavy with what you invoked.

Dorian’s jaw clenches, but he stays silent, hands at his sides, shoulders tight.

Impa exhales slowly.

“If you truly observed us as a story,” she says, “then you know things that never left this

room. Things the knight did beneath the castle. Things the princess saw under the

mountain. Things about this village that are not for wandering ears.”

She leans forward a fraction, the motion small but intent.

“So I will ask you three questions, Zeth. Answer them, and I will decide whether you are a

liar, a fool, or something rarer.”

Her fingers raise, counting off.

“First: in this ‘theatre’ of yours, did our Calamity end as it truly did? With the knight

waking, taking up the Sword that Seals the Darkness, and the princess binding the malice

of Ganon at the castle? Or did your telling go… differently?”

Her eyes do not leave yours.

“Second: what do you remember of the Sheikah shrines and towers after that victory? In

your world, did they vanish as ours are beginning to, or did they remain like bones in the

fields?”

The question has the tone of someone cross-checking your story against the debate

already simmering in Hyrule.

“And third…”

She hesitates the barest moment, as if choosing between many possible blades, then

selects one.

“Third: when you watched, what became of this village?” Her voice softens, but it does not

grow kinder—only more precise. “Were we still here, tucked in our valley between one

disaster and the next? Or did your ‘story’ carry on far enough that Kakariko’s name was

spoken in another context?”

The questions are not shouted. They don’t need to be. Each is a thread tied to something

real and heavy outside this room.

Dorian shifts beside you, the fabric of his trousers whispering. His eyes flick between you

and Impa, wary but forced, now, to listen.

Impa settles back again, the effort small but visible.

“You may speak,” she says. “Slowly. Clearly. You have already thrown one boulder into my

guard’s heart; do not throw more stones than you must.”

Her gaze stays on you, but there’s a new glint in it now—not belief, not yet, but the faint

light of genuine curiosity struggling past old caution.

“After that,” she adds, “we will speak of what help you think you need—and what price

Hyrule might pay if you scatter your… knowledge… without care.”

I recall the neat symmetry of Impa's words with Harlin's three questions near the Forest of Time and the old Guardian.

"Insomuch as I have observed...yes. Everything--that is to say very little--that I have seen since my arrival is how I remember it. However, my memory is not fresh, and without anticipating ever being in this time and place, I did not take special note of all events and outcomes. I am afraid that at best I am a flawed and unreliable narrator to this play."

I like my lips, feeling uncomfortable at a truth that Impa was pushing to the surface that I had not anticipated. "I would address your third question next: Kakariko, to my knowledge, fairs very well after Link--" I realise the name Link has not actually been used at all since I arrived. Nor Zelda. People always refer to them by titles or epithets. I correct myself, "The Knight ended the Calamity Ganon. I am not aware of specifics, however I believe this village was spared any great disaster from those events, and remained largely unaffected."

I bite my lip. "Your second question, moreso than the first and third, puts me in precarious position should I answer truthfully. But as I've said before: honesty is the best policy. And as you have said: there may be a price to pay for knowledge scattered without care." I dare to lift my eyes from the floor for the first time since I was brought into the room. Impa doesn't even appear as if she needs to

blink. "If I answer your question, seeds of knowledge will be sown, to continue your metaphor. I will do whatever it is you ask of me. Do you wish me to answer?"

Thought for 12s

Impa’s House – main room • Late morning • The quiet feels thick

Your answer hangs there, honest and uncomfortable. The symmetry with Harlin’s earlier

three questions doesn’t seem lost on Impa; one corner of her mouth tugs, very slightly.

When you ask if she wants the answer, her eyes finally blink.

“Mm,” she says, a soft sound that could mean many things.

Her fingertips tap once, twice, against the back of her other hand. The only other sound is

the faint crackle from the brazier and the low murmur of wind outside.

“You are not wrong,” she says at last. “Seeds, once scattered, cannot be un-scattered. I

have spent a lifetime weighing when to speak and when to hold my tongue.”

She glances past you, toward where the shrines and towers would be, invisible beyond the

walls.

“These machines of ours already stand on a knife-edge in the hearts of my people,” she

says. “We fear them, we owe them, we argue over them. One more story—about what

might become of them—could shift that balance toward wisdom… or panic.”

Her gaze returns to you, sharp again.

“But you are also not wrong that you owe me an honest answer,” she adds. “You did not

choose to drag your strange knowledge here, but now that it is here, we do not get the

luxury of pretending it isn’t.”

She breathes out slowly through her nose.

“So,” Impa decides, “we will walk the middle path. You will answer—clearly—but only

about what you say you saw in your own ‘telling.’ You will not dress it as fate. You will not

say ‘this will happen,’ only ‘this is what happened in the story I watched.’”

Her voice hardens a notch.

“And you will not speak of how or when the shrines and towers changed there. No details

that could tempt some fool into trying to force our world to match yours. Only whether

they remained, or were gone, or became something else entirely.”

She leans back again, settling her weight.

“If you cannot manage that restraint,” she says dryly, “then you are not ready to swing

knowledge like the blade you think it is.”

A beat.

“As for the first question,” she adds, “you will answer that as well when you are done. How

your ‘play’ showed the end of the Calamity. That is not a seed we have not already planted

ourselves.”

Her eyes soften just a fraction, though they don’t lose their focus.

“Speak, Zeth,” she says. “Tell me what your distant eyes saw of our shrines and our ending

—only that, and no more. Then we will see whether your truth is a curse, or simply another

burden I am old enough to carry.”

I nod, accept Impa's judgement and glance briefly at Dorian, uncertain of what the man may be thinking. Then I refocus on the floor as I continue. "There are many stories- -many plays--about Hyrule and its people. I am...just a man. I have a job, I have hobbies, I go about my life. I have friends, they have jobs, they have hobbies. I hear things without actually having witnessed them. My knowledge is incomplete. I have no desire to swing incomplete knowledge like a child who has found their parent's sword. What I know about Dorian, what I know about the Calamity: I saw those things with my own eyes. What I know about the Shrines and Guardians and Towers...the Divine Beasts...it is both secondhand, maybe thirdhand,

and it is...from a different story. A different play.

"I told Dorian that where I come from is someplace removed in both space and time. This space, this time, that I now occupy, does not correspond directly in either way. The other play was from the perspective of what would be, here and now, considered the Future. In *that* future, I observed that while the Sheikah and Kakariko continued proud and healthy, all aspects of Sheikah technology such as what you asked about were completely erased. It is easy for me to follow your admonition not to say how or when, because I don't know those details. All I know are what I can infer from what Harlin and Mera have told me." I think back to the old Guardian alongside the road with the wooden wedges jammed into it, waiting to be destroyed. "What I have seen since I arrived."

Thought for 6s

Impa’s House – main room • Late morning • Light thin, air still

You lay it out as cleanly as you can, and the room feels like it tightens around your words.

At the mention of “many stories” and “different plays,” Impa’s eyes half-close, not in

dismissal but in concentration. Dorian’s jaw works once; he stares at a point somewhere

just past your shoulder, hands flexing open and closed at his sides.

When you finish, the quiet that follows is not empty. It’s full of someone thinking very

hard.

Impa breaks it with a soft, wry exhale.

“So,” she says, “in one of your futures, we live. The village stands. The Sheikah endure. And

the machines are gone.”

Her fingers drum once on her knee, a tiny, dry patter.

“That is… not the worst future I’ve heard described,” she admits. “I have been told worse

endings for my people than ‘old and alive without their toys.’”

A thread of tension you didn’t realize was in her shoulders eases by a hair.

“You are wise to know the limits of what you saw,” she continues. “Secondhand stories are

like copies of copies: each one loses a little ink. But even smudged ink can point at the

shape of the words.”

Her gaze shifts, finally, to Dorian.

“You see, Dorian?” she says, mild on the surface. “Even in the stranger’s distant tales,

Kakariko is still here, being itself. Your daughters grow in a village that outlives gods and

ghosts. There are worse comforts.”

He doesn’t quite relax, but some of the rawness in his expression dulls. His eyes flick to

you, less like a blade and more like a measuring tool now.

Impa returns her attention to you.

“As for the Calamity,” she prompts gently. “You said you saw that yourself. Tell me how

your ‘play’ showed it end. Leave nothing out that your eyes truly watched, but do not gild

it for my sake. I am too old for flattering lies.”

You give her the short version of what you saw: the knight’s long road back to strength;

Divine Beasts reclaimed; the storm over Hyrule Castle; the last battle with Ganon’s

monstrous form; the princess stepping forward, light gathering in her hands as she binds

the Calamity’s malice and finally, finally, speaks freely with the knight in the quiet after.

Impa listens with her eyes closed this time, as if comparing your words against memories

she already keeps: reports from Sheikah scouts, her own sense of the world’s malice

loosening.

When you finish, she nods once, slow.

“That,” she says, “matches what my own spies and my granddaughter’s letters told me—

allowing for your theatre’s… flair.” There is the barest hint of a smile at that. “If you are an

agent of falsehood, you are at least diligent with your research.”

A longer breath leaves her, almost a sigh.

“All right,” she says. “Here is what I think.”

She straightens as much as she can, the motion small but authoritative.

“You are not a Yiga trick. They prefer knives and masks to long, wearying explanations. You

are not a simple liar; liars do not hand me their doubts and ignorance as readily as their

‘secrets.’”

Her gaze sharpens.

“You are, I suspect, exactly what you claim to be: a man dragged from a distant elsewhere,

carrying half-remembered tales which match our lives too neatly to dismiss and not neatly

enough to rely on.”

Her eyes soften just a little, though the weight of them doesn’t.

“That makes you dangerous, Zeth,” she says. “Not because you wish harm, but because

you do not yet know where your knowing cuts deepest. You are also… potentially useful.

To this village. Perhaps to Hyrule.”

She lifts one hand, two fingers raised.

“So we will set two rules.”

The first finger crooks a bit.

“Rule one: you do not scatter details of these ‘other stories’ in the streets like grain. If you

must speak of them, you speak in terms of ‘I saw in another telling,’ not ‘this will happen.’

Seeds, not chains. You will not name Yiga in the same breath as Dorian’s family again. If

someone demands more of you than vague shapes, you send them to me.”

Dorian’s shoulders loosen a fraction at that, tension narrowing into a more manageable

knot.

“The second finger:”

“Rule two: until this village has decided what to make of you, you are of this village. You do

not drift rootless. You will not chase every rumor about ancient machines or lost shrines on

your own. You will eat our rice, fix our doors, and let our aunties decide whether they trust

your face.”

Something like amusement ghosts through her eyes.

“In plain words: you will stay here in Kakariko for a time. Work if you can find it. Listen

more than you speak. When you speak of futures, you do it carefully, and preferably only

when asked.”

She settles her hands back in her lap.

“In return,” she adds, “this village will not cast you out onto the road as a madman. I will

tell the guard captain and the elders that you are under my eye. Dorian will not gut you for

what you know—though he is allowed to scowl at you as much as he likes.”

Dorian makes a quiet sound that might almost be a reluctant snort.

Impa watches you a moment longer, like she’s making sure all of that has landed

somewhere solid in your head.

“You came here seeking help,” she says more gently. “You have it, of a sort. Harlin’s wagon

got you to our gate. My name will keep you from being chased off it. The rest—work,

place, purpose—you will have to earn yourself.”

A pause.

“If, in time, you still wish to seek out Purah in Hateno, or the princess herself, we will speak

of it again,” she finishes. “For now, let your story catch up to its setting. The world has

waited a long time without you; it can spare a week while you learn where the streets are.”

She inclines her head, just a little.

“Do you understand these terms?” she asks. “You do not need to like them. You only need

to decide whether you can live with them—for now.”

I look up sharply, surprised, then bow my head again. I did not expect to effectively be put under house-arrest. But I swallow the feeling. It is both a gracious and wise ruling. So long as I am here, Impa maintains the control over me that she fears could cause disaster if she didn't. I, on the other hand, while not able to continue traveling--at least

for now--have something resembling a home.

"I-I understand. And thank you very much." I turn to Dorian and put my hands to my head. "And I apologise to you again, sir. I deserve for you to neither trust nor like me. But please I know that I always spoke truthfully. I admire, respect and trust you. I hope that in time I can earn some small positive thought from you as well. I will never speak of what I said to you to anybody again so long as I live. That is a promise."

Thought for 13s

Impa’s House – main room • Late morning • The air finally moves again

Dorian takes your apology like he takes everything else: straight on, without flinching.

There’s still anger in his face—for what you said, for the fact that you could say it—but it’s

cooled from white-hot to something harder and more controlled. When you promise,

something in his shoulders loosens by a finger-width.

“The promise is to Lady Impa first,” he says quietly, “but I hear it.”

It is not forgiveness. It is “I will wait and see.”

Impa makes a soft sound that might be approval.

“Resentment is heavy, Dorian,” she says. “Do not carry more than your back can bear.”

He gives her the ghost of a bow. “I will carry what I must.”

She lets that stand; she knows better than anyone what he hauls around.

Her attention comes back to you, the weight of it gentler now but no less firm.

“Good,” she says. “You understand more than some who were born under this roof. That is

a start.”

She adjusts her seat, small motions betraying the stiffness in her joints.

“Here is how this will be,” she continues. “You will stay in the village proper. Not the

outlying farms, not the hills. If the inn has space, you will sleep there; if not, someone will

find you a corner and a mat. You will speak with the village watch—Cado, at the main gate.

Tell him I have named you guest, not prisoner. He will see that the guards know your face.”

A faint smirk. “And if they forget, Dorian will remind them. Politely.”

Dorian’s expression says his definition of “polite” has edges, but he doesn’t argue.

“You are free to seek work,” Impa adds. “The carpenters, the shopkeepers, the farmers on

the terraces. Kakariko has more rotting beams than pride will admit. If you make yourself

useful and keep your tongue from outrunning your sense, you will eat.”

Her eyes narrow, just a little.

“Every few days, you will come back here,” she says. “You will tell me what you’ve seen,

who you’ve spoken to, and whether any of your… half-remembered tales were stirred by

what you learned. If I judge that you can walk farther without tripping over your own

knowledge, then we will speak of Hateno, or of the castle, or of anything else your

curiosity drags you toward.”

She inclines her head, the gesture tiny but formal.

“For now, Zeth of Nowhere,” she finishes, “you are a guest of Kakariko. Under my eye.

Under Dorian’s glower. Welcome to the village you already knew too well.”

There’s something almost kind in the last line, buried under the dry delivery.

She lifts one hand in a small, dismissing motion.

“Go,” Impa says. “Rest your tongue. Put your hands to something that does not involve

fate.”

Kakariko – outside Impa’s house • Approaching noon • Sun high, valley warm

Dorian slides the paper door open and steps aside, letting you pass out first.

The light on the veranda is almost shocking after the dimness inside. The village sound

rushes back in—voices, cuccos, the distant rush of the waterfall beyond the terraces. You

can feel your heart still beating a little too fast from being under Impa’s gaze, the way it

does after narrowly avoiding a fall.

As you step out, Paya is there, kneeling beside the doorway with a tray she clearly wasn’t

just bringing by accident: a teapot and two cups, hands tense on the wood. She must have

arrived sometime during the conversation and waited, not daring to interrupt.

Her eyes flick from you to Dorian and back, wide as lanterns.

“O-oh! I—um—welcome back, Father, I was just, ah—tea, I thought Lady Impa might—”

Her words tangle themselves, then collapse into a tiny, strangled noise when she realizes

you’re close enough to actually see her panic.

Dorian spares her the ordeal of finishing.

“Lady Impa will drink if she wishes,” he says, voice softer than it was with you, but still

carrying. “For now, she has given our guest her word.”

The word “guest” hangs there.

Paya blinks, surprise flickering over her features, then some warmer, more complicated

relief.

“A-ah,” she manages, clutching the tray. “Th-then… welcome, um, to Kakariko? Properly. I

mean. If you need… if you get lost, you can ask, and, um, the villagers will… usually… help.”

She uncurls a little as she speaks, finding refuge in something like routine hospitality.

Dorian glances at you, then down the steps.

“I will be at the path or with the patrols,” he says. “If someone treats you badly, they

answer to me. If you treat them badly, you answer to Lady Impa first and me after.”

It’s as close to “we have your back” as you’re going to get today.

He gives a short nod, then moves back to his post at the path, posture resuming its

watchful stillness. The Eightfold Blade rests easy at his side again, though his eyes cut to

you now and then, recalibrating “threat” into whatever new category you’ve earned.

Paya, still pink in the ears, bows her head in a quick, earnest dip before sliding the door

open with her shoulder and disappearing inside with the tea.

You’re left on the landing, a few worn steps between you and the main lane.

Your body reminds you of mundane facts: your back is stiff from standing so long, your

palms still tender from sacks and saws, your stomach not quite full but no longer

complaining. The village below is busy but not rushed, a living thing going about its late-

morning tasks.

You have Impa’s protection, Dorian’s suspicion, Paya’s flustered courtesy, and a vague

mandate to become part of this place instead of a problem for it.

Below, Kakariko spreads out like the version you remember and the one you don’t:

terraces, shops, shrine, inn, people. Somewhere down there are loose beams, creaking

steps, gossiping elders, and perhaps the first threads of the niche you were wondering

how to carve.

The path from the chief’s house back to the village is the same one anyone walks.

Now you get to see what you do with it.

I try to smile reassuringly at Paya, but I'm certain it fails, still shaken from my encounter with Dorian and Impa. As she scuttles away I nod to Dorian with a small "yes, sir" and then just...sort of stand there for a minute. I got what I wanted, actually, more or less, though I may have also had my safety net torn away from me in the process. Harlin and Mera wouldn't wait a week for me to be able to leave Kakariko, nor would I expect them to do so. I decide that the next time I see them I'll simply let them know I'll be staying in Kakariko for a while, and leave it at that. At least odds were I could still spend the night with them at the inn or in the cart like we did yesterday. It could be a good goodbye tomorrow.

For now I make myself focus on Impa's first stipulation: make myself known to Guard Captain Cado. I start making my way to the Main Gate to do so.

Thought for 4 seconds

Kakariko – path from Impa’s house to main lane • Near noon • Sun warm, stone steps cool

underfoot

You stand there a beat longer than is strictly necessary, letting the adrenaline drain out of

your hands. Your legs feel a little wobbly—not from the climb, but from the emotional

whiplash. Audience with Impa, almost stabbed by Dorian, accidentally nuking someone’s

tragic backstory… that’s a full morning by any standard.

Focusing on Cado is a mercy. It’s a task. Tasks are good.

You take the steps down from the chief’s house carefully. The village opens below you with

every few strides: the shrine gate, the paddies, the narrow lanes between houses where

laundry flaps and cuccos patrol. Familiar-but-not.

By the time you reach the main lane your breathing has evened out. The way to the gate is

obvious: follow the path down-valley, past the general store and High Spirits, past the little

bridge over the stream, toward the lower terraces where the houses thin and the world

starts to fold back into hills.

The gate is more symbolic than fortified—Kakariko’s not a walled city—but the Sheikah

have made it very clear where “inside” ends and “outside” begins. Two sturdy posts, a pair

of banners, a small guard post tucked to one side with a bench and a rack for spears.

Cado is there.

You recognize him from the game’s mental file: the other half of Dorian’s watch rotation,

the one with slightly less baggage and slightly more visible nerves. In person he looks…

tired, but earnest. A man whose entire job description is “worry professionally.”

He’s sitting on the bench when you arrive, polishing the head of a spear with a rag. His

hair is tied up in the familiar Sheikah topknot, and he’s got that perpetual faint frown of

someone who’s always expecting trouble, even on a nice day.

He spots you approaching and is on his feet before you can second-guess yourself, spear

haft planted, shoulders coming up into proper posture.

“Ah—hello,” he says, blinking once. “You’re… new. I don’t recall seeing you enter the

village with the merchant caravans.”

He looks you over the same way Dorian did, though with less lethal weight: clothes, hands,

weapon calluses, empty belt.

“Is there something I can help you with?” he asks, tone polite but wary. “If you’re looking

to leave, the road is clear at the moment. If you’re looking to come in—” he realizes how

that sounds, since you’re obviously already inside the village, and flusters a little, clearing

his throat. “I mean, ah, if you’re looking for lodgings or work, the inn is up there on the

left, and the shops are—”

“I’ve already…seen Lady Impa,” you manage, voice coming out quieter than usual. “She

told me to report to Guard Captain Cado, so he’d know my face.”

That lands like a stone dropped into a pond.

“Y-you…” His eyes widen. “You’ve already… seen Lady Impa?”

He straightens another half-inch, somewhere between impressed and rattled.

“Right. Ah. That’s me. Cado.” He thumps his fist lightly to his chest, almost as if reminding

himself. “If Lady Impa told you to speak with me, then—”

He reins himself in and actually focuses.

“What name did you give her?” he asks, a little more official now. “And what did she say

about… your status here?”

You explain, straightforward: you’re Zeth, you came in with Harlin’s wagon, you’re to

remain in the village for now as a guest under Impa’s eye, looking for work if you can get

it. You don’t repeat any of the details about Dorian or Yiga or other-world stories. “Guest,

not prisoner” is the line you hit.

Cado listens, lips pressing into a thoughtful line. When you drop Impa’s exact phrasing, he

exhales slowly and some of the stiffness leaks out of his shoulders.

“A guest of Lady Impa,” he repeats. “Right. All right. That… clarifies things.”

He glances past you, up the lane toward the chief’s house, then back.

“In that case,” he says, “consider yourself formally noted.” There’s a hint of pride in the way

he says it, like this is the sort of small bureaucratic ritual he’s been entrusted with and he

intends to do it perfectly.

He gestures toward the gate posts and the village beyond.

“You’re free to move about within the village,” he says. “Terraces, shrine, shops, fields. If

you want to go further afield—up into the hills, toward the Great Fairy’s spring, that sort of

thing—tell either me or Dorian first so we know where you’ve gone. If something…

happens, it helps to not be guessing.”

He fidgets with the spear a second, then adds, more quietly:

“Some of the elders will be suspicious. Don’t take it personally. We’ve had… a lot of visitors

the last few years. Not all of them kind. But if Lady Impa says you are a guest, then you

are. I’ll make sure the watch knows that.”

He clears his throat again, trying for brisk.

“If you need a place to sleep and the inn is full, speak to Lasli or Mellie. They’ll know whose

nephews have gone traveling and left a mat empty. If you get in trouble, come here. If you

cause trouble…” His eyes sharpen, Dorian-style for just a heartbeat. “Don’t.”

The moment passes; he softens with an awkward little half-smile.

“And, ah… welcome to Kakariko, I suppose,” Cado says. “Properly. We don’t get many…

what did Lady Impa call you? ‘Guests of nowhere’?”

He seems amused and a little spooked by that idea in equal measure.

A breeze comes up the valley, tugging at the gate banners. Somewhere behind you, a

cucco loses its mind over some slight. Down the lane you can see the cart square where

Harlin and Mera are undoubtedly nearing the end of their unloading work.

You’ve now got three pillars holding your situation in place:

Impa’s rule: stay, work, be careful with what you know.

Dorian’s watchful, very personal stake in whether you’re a threat.

Cado’s more procedural protection: you’re noted, you’re “in the book,” so to speak.

You are, for better or worse, part of Kakariko’s mental furniture now.

From here, the village is yours in a much more practical sense: the inn to check on your

friends, the shops and houses to scout for carpentry work, the shrine and terraces to walk

when your brain needs catching up with everything that just happened.

The big, cosmic questions—going home, Purah, the princess—have been politely shoved

onto the “later” shelf.

For the moment, the world is small: one valley, one village, one day where you get to start

proving you’re more than a walking spoiler.

Cado's demeanour causes me to measurably relax, and I appreciate the man whom, before now, I had never really paid much attention to. I make an attempt at a familiar gesture for myself, and stick out my hand for a handshake to see how he would react. "Thank you, sir. I appreciate it."

Kakariko main gate • Just before noon • Sun bright, faint breeze under the banners

Cado blinks at your outstretched hand like it’s a puzzle piece he half-recognizes.

For a heartbeat he looks like he might bow instead out of sheer muscle memory—but then

something in his face says no, this is how travelers do it, and he shifts the spear to his other

hand and takes yours.

His grip is careful at first, then firms up when he feels the work in your palm—blisters over

older callus. He gives a single, earnest shake.

“You’re welcome,” he says. “And, ah… you don’t have to call me ‘sir.’ Just Cado is fine. If

anyone here is ‘sir’ it’s Lady Impa, and she’d probably throw her cane at you for saying it.”

There’s a small, crooked almost-smile with that. It doesn’t quite erase the wariness in his

eyes, but it adds another layer: you’ve moved from “unknown variable” to “person he’s

going to worry about specifically,” which is progress in Cado terms.

He releases your hand and plants the spear again, back in his familiar post at the gate.

When a pair of farmers trundle past with a handcart, he nods them through, then glances

back to you.

“I’ll let the others know,” he says. “If anyone gives you trouble about being new, tell them

Cado already fretted over you and they can save their breath.”

The breeze kicks up the smell of wet earth and rice from the terraces. Down the lane, the

square where Harlin’s cart is parked is visible between houses; you can see the wagon bed

is mostly empty now, Harlin a moving shape beside it, Mera’s headscarf bobbing as she

talks with a shopkeeper.

Behind you, the village stretches up toward the shrine and Impa’s house; to either side,

lanes and stairways thread between homes, laundry lines, and the occasional sagging

beam or crooked door that a carpenter’s eye can’t help registering.

You’ve shaken the village’s gate captain’s hand, you’ve got Impa’s word around your

shoulders like an invisible cloak, and somewhere down there are two friends finishing the

work that brought you here in the first place.

Kakariko, for the first time, feels less like a level and more like a neighborhood—with all

the mess, noise, and possibility that implies.

I ponder what to do next. The obvious choice to go to the inn and ask about work. If there's actually work to be had...maybe I could fenagle my way into reserving a room now. Especially if I might be needing it for a few nights.

While I'd be happy to at least busy myself with a trade I know something about, I'm aware of a few problems presenting myself as a carpenter. First of all, I had no tools.

Right off the bat that made me a fairly worthless carpenter. I can't expect potential clients to just have tools laying around that I can help myself to all the time. Second of all, I had no materials. A village would need to have some way of procuring lumber whether they intended to grow or simply maintain, but I'd need to either purchase the materials myself or arrange for the client to pay for materials directly. Which means I'd have to try and get my materials margins *spot-on*. Which leads to problems three and four: I know how to do carpentry, but not how to sell myself or run a business; I know how to do carpentry...western carpentry. cuts may be the same pretty much everywhere, but I have no idea how to go about fixing a broken folding fan door or securing a traditional Japanese house beam.

So...I guess I'd be doing unskilled labour. Maybe I'd be working for food and not money. I don't like the idea, but I suppose I'd just have to se what happens. If Kakariko really is as full of gossip-mongering aunties as I kept hearing it was, maybe people would start to pity me. Not that I particularly like the idea of being pitied by a bunch of old Japanese grandmas. But I might need to be.

I start making my way to the inn, the name of which I couldn't remember, and allowed myself to finally take in some sights as I walk along. I notice Enchanted in particular, curious of what might be inside, but knowing it would be a fruitless endeavour given my lack of funds.

Thought for 22s

Kakariko main lane → Shuteye Inn • Near noon • Warm sun, breeze off the paddies

You peel away from the gate and head back up the main lane, letting your pace fall into

something easier. Now that “report to Cado” is checked off, the village has room to be a

place again instead of just a quest marker.

Enchanted sits like a lacquered jewel box on the right as you pass: steep roof, fabric

awning, the Sheikah eye painted crisp on a hanging sign. Inside, you catch flashes of color

—deep blues and blacks of the Stealth set, sturdy browns and reds of the Hylian gear—

arranged almost theatrically on stands. Claree is at the counter, posture immaculate,

speaking to a traveling farmer with the cadence of someone who has curated everything in

her life. Lasli hovers just outside, calling a cheerful greeting to a pair of passing youths,

then glancing up the lane toward you with mild curiosity before duty pulls her attention

back.

It’s all very tempting and completely theoretical without a single rupee to your name. You

move on.

Past Enchanted, the Goddess Statue’s little pond glints to your left, the stone figure

watching over the village with her usual unreadable calm. Opposite it, across the way, sits

the inn: Shuteye Inn, its signboard hanging slightly crooked, as if too relaxed to stand

perfectly straight.

The building is modest compared to Impa’s house—two beds’ worth of width, front wall

broken by a wide sliding door currently propped open. A couple of tables sit just inside,

with stools pulled up; this close to midday, one is occupied by an older man nursing a

bowl of something and muttering appreciatively at the taste.

The air inside is cooler and dimmer, tinged with the smell of old wood, straw, and a hint of

simple food—rice, maybe, and some kind of broth. It feels less like an establishment and

more like a slightly cluttered living room that has decided to charge rent.

Behind the low counter at the back stands Ollie.

He is every inch the nervous innkeeper you half-remember: lanky, shoulders a little

hunched, dark circles under his eyes. At the moment you step in, he is… not exactly asleep,

but very much in that slack-faced drift where his eyes are half-lidded and his weight has

settled onto his elbows.

Your foot scuffs the threshold; his head jerks up like you fired a bow.
