“A-Ack!” He nearly drops the rag in his hands. “Are you… a g— a g-guest? I mean—of

course you’re a guest, sorry, you just— I didn’t hear you, um, come in…”

Zelda +1

Zelda Wiki

zeldadungeon.net +1

He visibly tries to pull himself together, straightening as much as his spine will allow and

giving you what is, objectively, an attempt at a professional smile.

“W-welcome to the Shuteye Inn,” he says, voice wobbling but earnest. “I’m Ollie, and, uh…

if you’re looking for a bed, we, um, have two kinds. There’s the… regular bed and the soft

bed and—”

He trails off, eyes flicking over you the way everyone’s have: clothes, empty belt, no visible

gear.

“…but, um, you don’t look like you’ve, ah, just come in from the road with the others,” he

finishes, a little lamely. “S-so, if you’re not here for a bed right now, that’s— that’s fine too!

I mean, you can be, but you don’t have to be, I just—”

He cuts himself off, swallows, and tries again.

“Wh-what I mean is: how can I help you?”

Behind him, you can see the two beds through an open doorway—simple frames, neatly

made, one with slightly plumper blankets that must be the fabled “soft bed.” A single

cucco feather has escaped from somewhere and is wedged under a table leg near your

foot, because of course it is.

Your stomach gives a small nudge at the smell of food; your feet ache in a way that makes

the idea of claiming a future place to sleep feel suddenly very practical. Ollie, meanwhile,

clearly expects some combination of “room inquiry” and “random traveler weirdness” and

is braced for either.

2/2 2/2

I give my head a slight little bow in greeting. "Hi, yes, well, I'd like to reserve a room, but I have to admit I'm a little hard up right now. I'm embarrassed to admit it, but I need to find a way to make some rupees, I think. Get back on my feet, so to speak. Was thinking I could stay here in Kakariko for a while. I thought, maybe, with the inn being such a central place to the village, you might be able to

point me somewhere..." I feel like I'm babbling a little.

"Sorry, I'm not very used to this."

Thought for 10s

Shuteye Inn – front room • Near noon • Air cool, faint smell of rice and tea

Ollie’s shoulders slump a little in visible sympathy as you explain yourself. The nervous

sales patter dies off; you get the feeling he understands “hard up” on a personal level.

“A-ah, no, it’s all right,” he says quickly, flapping one hand. “We, uh, we don’t exactly live

on piles of rupees here either. You’re doing better than most just saying you’re short

instead of pretending you aren’t.”

He rubs the back of his neck, thinking, gaze bouncing around the room as if answers

might be hiding under the tables.

“Well,” he starts, “the usual way is: traveler comes in with coin, pays for a night, eats,

leaves. Simple.” A tiny grimace. “But if you don’t have coin yet…”

He glances at the doorway, as if expecting a stern auntie to materialize and object, then

leans in across the counter a fraction, lowering his voice.

“I can’t just… give you a room forever on a promise,” he admits. “Oils don’t buy

themselves, and my mother would rise from her grave to smack me if I started running a

free hostel.”

A beat; then his expression softens.

“But,” he adds, “if you’re planning to stay and work here, people will notice. Kakariko

doesn’t let hungry hands go too long if they’re willing to be useful.”

He ticks options off on his fingers, more comfortable now that he’s talking about other

people’s business.

“Mellie up on the terraces always needs help in the fields – planting, weeding, hauling

water. It’s backbreaking, but she pays fair, and if she likes you, she’ll feed you until you

swear off pumpkins forever.”

Finger two.

“The carpenters near the lower paddies have been grumbling about sagging beams since

the last big rain. If you know anything about wood that isn’t just ‘it burns,’ you might talk

to them. They’ve got tools; they just don’t have as many backs as they used to.”

Finger three.

“Claree at Enchanted sometimes pays in coin or clothes for someone to haul crates or

clean the storage. She’s picky, though. You’ll have to convince her you’re not going to

sneeze on the silk.”

He hesitates, then adds, almost shyly:

“And, um. I can let you leave your name for a room. If—when—you get some rupees

together, the regular bed’s cheaper and the soft bed is…” he makes a face like the very

idea of luxury makes him itchy “...well, soft. For today, if you end up with Harlin and Mera

again, they’ve got first claim on whatever I’ve got open anyway. They always send word

ahead.”

Your stomach twinges faintly at the lingering smell of broth from the back; your feet are

grateful you’re standing on tatami and not stone for the moment.

Ollie fidgets with the rag in his hands, then seems to reach a decision.

“Tell you what,” he says. “If you find anyone who’ll vouch that you’ve worked a half-day for

them—Mellie, the carpenters, even Cado if he’s desperate enough to make you haul

spears—I’ll knock something off the price and we’ll call it ‘working toward your stay’.” His

eyes dart away, then back. “Just… don’t tell everyone I said that. I’ll have every layabout in

Necluda suddenly discovering their love of ‘honest work.’”

He attempts a conspiratorial smile; it comes out lopsided but genuine.

“And if you can’t find anything today,” he adds, “come back before nightfall anyway. We’ll

see what Harlin’s doing and whether there’s floor space left. A guest of the village

shouldn’t be sleeping in the ditch.”

He clearly doesn’t know how official your “guest” status is, but the instinct is there.

Outside, through the open door, you can see a slice of village life sliding by: somebody

carrying a bundle of firewood, a kid chasing a cucco, the distant flash of Lasli’s sash as she

pitches armor to a passerby. Up-slope, the terraces wait in layered greens; down-slope, the

square with Harlin’s cart is still alive with movement.

You’ve got a rough, social credit line now: work somewhere, get vouchered, start clawing

your way toward a bed that isn’t a cart or a hayloft. How you earn that first nod of

approval—and from whom—is the next knot to pick at in this newly “home-adjacent”

village.

"Oh, that's, very helpful of you," I say, honestly surprised at how outgoing and generous Ollie is. I suppose life in my old world has made me rather pessimistic and cynical in a way I never really realised I was until now. "My name's Zeth, but yeah, for sure I would not want to get in Harlin or Mera's way. They've been very good to me. I'll uh...I'll check out those leads. Sounds like there's actually quite a bit what needs doing around here." I tap on the counter, ruminating. "I won't go spreading it around, I promise. I hate to take you up on that, actually. I'd feel better paying you the full, fair amount. But..." I finally shrug, "I might just need to. Thank you Ollie."

Thought for 5s

Shuteye Inn – front room • Just before noon • Quiet, cool

Ollie ducks his head, almost like he’s trying to hide a smile.

“Zeth,” he repeats, as if committing it to the inn’s invisible ledger. “Right. I’ll, ah… keep an

ear out. If anyone comes in mumbling about ‘some out-of-towner who fixed their fence’

I’ll know who they mean.”

He fidgets with the rag, then sets it down with a little decisive pat.

“And, um… between you and me,” he adds, voice dropping conspiratorially, “most people

don’t want to be in debt. The ones who say they don’t mind never pay it off. You sound

like the other kind. That goes a long way here.”

The compliment is awkward but sincere.

He straightens, back to his “trying to be an adult” posture.

“Go see what you can find,” he says. “If the day goes badly and no one’s got work, come

back and we’ll… improvise. I can at least get you a bowl of something and a corner that

doesn’t leak.”

He gives you a small, earnest nod, then jolts as the kettle in the back room starts to hiss.

“O-oh—excuse me—water!”

He vanishes through the doorway in a small flurry of half-panicked motion, leaving you

with the quiet front room, the smell of tea coming on, and the soft creak of the building

settling around you.

Kakariko main lane, by Shuteye Inn • Noon • Sun bright, paddies glittering

Stepping back out into the lane, the light feels sharper after the inn’s dimness. The village

has shifted into its midday rhythm: voices are a little louder, kids a little more underfoot,

the air warmer and thick with the smell of wet earth, rice, and cooking fires being coaxed

into life.

From here, you’ve got a good view of your immediate options:

Down-slope, the square where Harlin’s cart sits is still active—though the wagon looks

much emptier now, bundles redistributed into shops and storerooms. Harlin’s

unmistakable profile moves beside the horse; Mera’s scarf is a bright knot of color as she

finishes up a conversation with a shopkeeper.

Up-slope, the first terrace fields spread out, green and flooded, Mellie’s broad-brimmed

hat easy to pick out among a few bent backs working the paddies. Beyond them,

scaffolding and half-repaired beams frame a couple of houses, the carpenters’ worksite

obvious even at a distance by the stacked lumber and the rhythm of mallets on wood.

Across the way, Enchanted’s awning flutters in the breeze, Lasli’s voice drifting faintly

down the street as she pitches armor and fabrics to a traveler you don’t recognize.

Your feet still carry the dull echo of two days’ work and walking; your stomach is hovering

in that “fine for now, but don’t forget me” zone. The village hums quietly around you,

unaware that its newest almost-resident spent the morning discussing hypothetical futures

with its matriarch.

The big questions are on pause. Right now, it’s simpler: where to point your hands first,

and which corner of Kakariko you’ll start weaving yourself into.

*Order of operations time,* I think to myself.

I don't have any spare clothes and washing is...something I'll have to figure out. So the fact of the matter is that I'm just going to be more tired, more dirty, and potentially more "beat up" with each job I take. Odds are that someone working in fabrics and clothes isn't going to want somebody covered in sweat and mud dealing with their wares, so I should probably hit up Enchanted first. Frankly, a condition I don't mind anyways, for several reasons. Second is a hard choice between the farming and the carpentry. Farming is dirtier, but carpentry on a *beam* specifically might be harder. Granted...Ollie did describe Mellie's work as "back breaking". Might need to save the farm work for last.

I only have half a day to work, and I don't know the full extent of each job, so there's no saying if I'll even get to more than one today. For a moment I have my first twinge of disappointment since arriving in Hyrule: It would have been nice to explore more, rather than wear myself down labouring. But then...this was a real world. The necessity of hard work cannot be dismissed.

I walk over to Enchanted and rap lightly at the entrance to announce myself. "Hello?"

Thought for 9s

Enchanted – doorway • Noon • Light bright on dyed cloth, air cooler inside

Your knuckles tap the frame and the sound disappears into fabric and wood. A half-beat

later, Lasli’s head pops around the edge of the awning like she’s been spring-loaded for

“new person.”

“Hi there!” she chirps. “Welcome to Enchanted—fine clothing, sturdy armor, and… um…

everything else that makes you look like you actually meant to come to Kakariko today.”

Her eyes flick over you, quick and curious. Not judging, exactly—just cataloguing: single

set of clothes, travel-scuffed, no belt pouches, no visible weapon at the hip.

She seems about to launch into a standard sales pitch when a voice from inside cuts

across her.

“Lasli. If you’re going to herd customers, herd them in, not leave them at the door.”

Claree, of course.

Lasli winces like a kid caught half-doing a chore. “S-sorry, Sis! He just knocked, I wasn’t—”

Claree appears in the doorway with the smooth inevitability of tax season.

In the game she was “the serious one.” In person, that reads as “owns exactly one

expression and it is called Business.” Hair bound up neatly, apron spotless despite the dye

smells in the air. Her gaze does the same quick, efficient sweep Lasli’s did, but with more

calculation behind it.

“Come inside or stay out,” she says, not unkindly, just practical. “Standing in the entrance

lets flies in and rupees out.”

Lasli steps aside to give you room, and when you do step in, the shop folds around you

like a jewelry box.

Racks of clothing line the walls: the familiar dark, tight-weave Stealth pieces on one side,

Hylian tunics and trousers in neat stacks, a couple of sturdier, padded sets hanging higher

up where they catch the light. There’s a faint tang of dye and treated fabric in the air,

undercut by something herbal—moth-repelling, most likely.

A wooden counter dominates the center, with a ledger, a tidy little box of rupees, and a

pair of folded measuring tapes laid with military precision.

Claree plants herself behind the counter and steeples her fingers lightly.

“You don’t have a merchant’s pack,” she notes. “And you’re not wearing anything I sold

you, or I’d remember. So unless you’re here because you got lost on the way to the inn,

you’re either looking to buy with money you don’t have, or to ask for something else

entirely.”

Lasli, hovering by a display of belts, winces again. “Sis…”

Claree doesn’t look away from you.

“It’s not an insult,” she says. “Just saving everyone time. If you’re hard up, say so. We still

talk to people who aren’t buying.”

Her eyes narrow, but more in curiosity than suspicion.

“Ollie sends me the occasional stray,” she adds. “People looking for work ‘for a while.’ Are

you one of his?”

There’s space there for you to explain what you’re after: rupees, not charity; willing hands,

not expectation. She waits, letting the silence do the work.

Lasli, not nearly as patient, blurts in the gap:

“We do sometimes need help, you know. Carrying crates, sweeping, dusting, folding—

someone has to do all the boring bits while Claree is in her, um, ‘consultations.’”

Claree’s eyes flick sideways. “Lasli.”

“What? It’s true!”

Claree’s attention returns to you, measuring again.

“If you’re looking for work,” she says, “be clear about what you can actually do. This is not

a barn; I am not handing the fabrics to someone who’ll treat them like grain sacks. But I do

need someone with a back who won’t collapse after two crates and who can remember

which shelf things came from.”

Her gaze drops briefly to your hands—blistered, roughened, already moving toward “I use

tools” rather than “I hold quills.”

“Start talking, Zeth-or-whatever-your-name-is,” she says. “What are you after, and what

can you offer that doesn’t end with dye all over my floor?”

I let myself be whisked inside without restraint, glancing around the business quickly so as to not keep Claree or Lasli waiting on me. I don't want them to think I'm stupid or a waste of their time. If I'm being honest with myself, I take particular note of Lasli while making sure it isn't obvious. Of all the characters in Breath of the Wild, there were two that I was rather...more attached to. Both happened to be working in their families business as someone you'd be the first to meet, and one of them happened to be Lasli. Even as a cartoonish game character she seemed pretty, amicable and fun. I was interested in seeing how she was as a real person. But that could wait. Had to wait. I note that Claree already knows my name, though she tried to back-pedal as soon as she said it. *Wow, gossip does travel fast here.*

"Yep, sorry, I'm afraid I *am* one of those. I haven't got a rupee to my name and Ollie said I might stop by here. I know I'm not the picture of business management, but I made sure I don't have anything on me that could sully or stain your cloths, and I pride myself on my organisational skills. I can certainly haul crates. I don't want to be a bother or a charity case though, so don't make an exception to what you actually need done just on my account." I make sure to smile and make appropriate eye

contact, my composure having largely returned after having a chance to cool down and recentre while dealing with Cado and Ollie.

I give a small bow of my head abruptly, having forgotten to actually introduce myself. "My name is Zeth, by the way. Sorry. Forgot to introduce myself. I guess you already know that though."

Thought for 7s

Enchanted – shop floor • Noon • Dye-scented air, light slanting through the doorway

Lasli’s face brightens at your explanation; Claree’s goes… flatter, but not in a bad way.

More like she’s moved you from “unknown” to “column B: usable.”

“Ollie talks too much,” Claree mutters, then corrects herself with a sigh. “Ollie talks just

enough, I suppose. Zeth, then.”

She listens to your little pitch, eyes on your face, then on your hands again when you

mention organization and hauling. When you finish, she nods once, curt but satisfied.

“Good. You’re at least honest about what you don’t have,” she says. “Most people who

walk in here broke try to pretend they’re not.”

Lasli bounces a step closer. “We do actually need crates moved,” she puts in. “The new dye

came in and the storeroom is a mess and Sis keeps re-folding everything I fold and saying

‘this isn’t a pile, it’s a landslide.’”

“That is because you fold like a Bokoblin stuffs its mouth,” Claree says dryly, but there’s

sisterly exasperation in it, not cruelty. She flicks her gaze back to you.

“All right,” she decides. “Half-day’s work. No promises beyond that. You’ll haul crates from

the back to the side room so I can sort them properly, sweep the floors, and do whatever

Lasli tells you that doesn’t involve touching stealth fabric or anything with embroidery.”

Lasli makes a tiny wounded noise. “My folding isn’t that bad.”

“You may demonstrate on the discount rack,” Claree replies smoothly. To you, she adds: “If

you truly have an eye for order, help her put some sense into that heap. Tunics by size, not

by whichever color she thinks is cutest this hour.”

Lasli looks both affronted and weirdly relieved to have backup.

“As for pay,” Claree continues, businesslike again, “I can spare a handful of rupees at the

end of the day, or I can speak to Ollie and count it against a night’s stay if that’s more

urgent. You will not make a fortune sweeping and carrying, but you will not be working for

air.”

She leans on the counter slightly, studying you one last time.

“Two conditions,” she says. “One: if your hands start to shake, you stop before you drop

anything breakable. Pride doesn’t replace shattered dye jars. Two: if some gossip-hungry

auntie asks what you’re doing here, you say ‘helping at Enchanted’ and leave it at that. I

don’t need my shop turned into a story-bench.”

Lasli edges over to your side, already half in “coworker” mode.

“Storeroom’s this way,” she says, gesturing toward a beaded curtain at the back. “The

crates aren’t that heavy, but they’re awkward, and mind your head on the beam—Sis keeps

saying she’ll fix it and then ‘forgets.’”

“I am not a carpenter,” Claree says, unbothered. “If you are, you can add that to your list of

services after you have proven you can sweep.”

The beaded curtain clicks softly as Lasli holds it aside for you. Beyond, you can see the dim

outline of stacked crates, the faint smell of fresh dye and old wood, and a floor that

absolutely needs a broom taken to it.

Your shoulders still remember yesterday’s fence and trough; the blisters on your palms

protest even at the sight of another day’s lifting. But your body also knows the rhythm of

this kind of work, and the promise of coin—or a bed—sits at the far end of the afternoon

like a small, solid reward.

Claree has already turned to her ledger, pencil scratching. Lasli waits, bright-eyed, ready to

induct you into the sacred rites of “moving boxes so my sister stops yelling at me.”

Kakariko wanted you to put your hands to something that doesn’t involve fate. This

definitely qualifies.

I think about chiming in with a "actually I do know a thing or two about carpentry," but I decide against it until I've worked with the local tradesmen first. I might learn a thing or two. I want to make a good impression, but showing off typically backfires. For now say "thank you" and do as instructed. I thought maybe we'd start with the discount rack--the name of which intrigues me and I wonder exactly *how discounted* it may be--but Lasli escorts me to the heavy lifting first, and I comply.

"Right, so, I can probably make these easier to navigate for your sister if I have a hint at what's in them," I say to Lasli. "Is there an inventory or are the crates labelled in some way..."

Thought for 12s

Enchanted – storeroom • Early afternoon • Dim, close, smells of wood and dye

Lasli lets the beads fall closed behind you, and the sounds of the shop muffle: Claree’s

voice drops to a hum, the street beyond to a distant murmur.

The storeroom is a rectangle of controlled chaos. Crates and boxes are stacked in two

uneven rows, leaving a narrow aisle that’s clearly been walked a lot and swept not quite

enough. The air is cooler than outside but thicker—old wood, packed cloth, the sharp

mineral tang of powdered dye.

Some crates are rough pine, roped shut; others are sturdier, banded in metal. Chalk marks

scrawl across more than a few.

At your question, Lasli brightens. This is territory she knows.

“R-right, yes, labeling,” she says, patting the nearest stack. “These ones—” she taps a row

marked with a simple triangle “—are cloth. Mostly base-layer stuff. These”—she indicates

another stack with a circle-with-a-dot symbol—“are dyes and treatments. Don’t tilt those

unless you like blue knees.”

She moves sideways, pointing as she goes.

“Square is buckles and bits. And the ones with the, um, eye and two dots are for special

orders. Don’t touch those unless Claree says so. She gets this”—she scrunches her face in a

fairly accurate imitation of her sister’s most disapproving glare—“if anyone even looks at

them too hard.”

Closer up, you can see the chalk marks aren’t half-bad as systems go—just… executed with

the enthusiasm of someone who loses track halfway through.

Some symbols are smudged; a couple of crates have two conflicting marks, one crossed

out with an irritated swipe.

“I tried making a list,” Lasli admits, lowering her voice like she’s confessing a crime. “But

the paper got wet and then I spilled some purple and it looked like… um… a monster ate

it. So now I just, sort of, remember where everything is? Mostly?”

Your hands itch in that particular way they do when you see a system that almost works.

You run your fingers along a crate edge; the wood is rough but solid. When you lift, your

palms flare in protest—yesterday’s blisters reminding you they exist—but the muscles in

your shoulders fall into line. It’s awkward more than heavy, the kind of load that demands

attention to your feet and to the low beam Lasli warned you about.

You shift the first “triangle” crate out into the side room she indicated: a narrow space off

the main storeroom with an empty wall and a couple of unused shelves. You set it down

where Claree will have a straight line of sight from the counter when the curtain’s drawn

back.

Behind you, Lasli keeps up a running commentary as you work, half to be helpful, half

because silence apparently makes her itch.

“Claree likes things in straight lines,” she says. “Rows, columns, everything matching. I try,

but then someone comes in and touches something and then I can’t stop seeing where it’s

wrong and then I have to fix it and then she says I made it worse. So if you make it look

neat enough she doesn’t have to redo it, she’ll probably pay you in more than just scowls.”

You fall into a rhythm: she points out which crates are safe to move together, you test their

weight, adjust your grip, and ferry them into more sensible groupings. Triangles nearer the

door, circles further back, squares stacked where they won’t cave in softer boxes. You call

out markings as you shift them; Lasli confirms or corrects, occasionally catching a

mislabeled one with a triumphant little “Ha! I knew that wasn’t just buckles.”

The floor underfoot leaves dust on your bare soles through thin shoes, gritting slightly as

you pivot and step. The low beam dings your shoulder once when you misjudge; it’s more

insult than injury, and Lasli winces in sympathy.

“Sorry,” she says. “We keep saying we’ll get someone to shave that down, but then there’s

always… something else.”

You remember Impa’s words about “put your hands to something that doesn’t involve

fate” and file that beam under future problem you might fix—after you’ve earned the right

to offer.

After a few crate trips, your palms are a chorus of sore spots, but your body starts to find

efficiencies: carry two smaller boxes instead of one big one, slide rather than lift when the

floor allows, nudge with a hip instead of twisting your back. Sweat prickles at your neck;

the storeroom is still cooler than outside, but exertion turns any air thick.

When you pause long enough to wipe your forehead, Lasli peeks past you into the side

room and lets out an appreciative little “oooh.”

“That already looks better,” she says. “She won’t say it, but she’ll think it. That’s how you

know you’ve done well: Claree’s eyebrow doesn’t do the thing.”

She demonstrates “the thing” with an alarmingly accurate impression. It’s… not entirely

kind to her sister, but it’s very funny.

You get through another stack, enough that a clear path exists from the storeroom door to

the back wall for the first time in what looks like weeks. Your arms are getting that pleasant

heavy feeling of “in use but not yet betrayed,” and your breathing’s a shade deeper.

At some point, Claree calls through the beads: “If you’ve broken anything, I haven’t heard

it yet. That’s mildly promising.”

Lasli sticks her tongue out in the general direction of the curtain, then immediately looks

guilty about it, as if the house itself might tattle.

She glances sideways at you as you heft another box.

“Thanks, by the way,” she says, a little more earnest than before. “Most people who come

in looking for work want to be seen working. You’re actually… doing it.”

She toes a bit of dust on the floor.

“And, um. The discount rack is real,” she adds, catching the direction of your earlier

curiosity. “It’s mostly things that got a spot or a loose stitch or were made in a size no one

here fits. Not trash. Just… shy clothes, I guess.”

There’s a tiny, fond smile at that.

“When we’re done moving these, if you have any clever ideas for making it look less like a

laundry avalanche, I’d be grateful. Even if you can’t afford any of it yet, it’d be nice to not

feel like it’s going to fall on me every time I walk past.”

Another crate thumps down into a new, orderly row. The storeroom is starting to breathe

—aisles wide enough for two people to pass, stacks that look like they might stay stacked.

Your back is warm, your hands sore, your shirt sticking to your shoulders in spots—but the

work is straightforward, the expectations clear, and the immediate reward structure (don’t

drop, do stack, maybe eat and sleep later) is refreshingly simple compared to the

existential weirdness of the morning.

Outside the storeroom, Kakariko goes on: Aunties gossip, cuccos plot, the waterfall

murmurs beyond the hills. Inside, you and Lasli excavate order from clutter one crate at a

time, laying the first, very literal groundwork of the place you’re starting to call home-

adjacent.

Despite the rough job the crates do to my hands, the work doesn't feel all that bad once I get into a rhythm, and organisational matters always feel cathartic to me. After a little while, I only half-take Lasli's advice, and make little tweaks to her directions in ways I hope she doesn't notice, improving the efficiency of the space used and making sure that in the future, when Claree needs to go through these items herself, she will be able to hit what I hope is a steady workflow without having to stop and search for things.

I also steal a few discreet glances at Lasli here and there as she's distracted by things during the work. I'm interested in how she appears in reality, and I pay attention to details about her appearance. I already knew she was pretty, but I want to see how, in the flesh.

I smile warmly at her as she thanks me for the honest work. "Compliment accepted. I can't help notice there seems to be a lot of that sentiment floating around. I hear a lot of talk about how people are taking advantage and exploiting others--but I have to be honest, I must be having a very good time of things. I've almost only been surrounded by goodwill since I met Harlin and Mera yesterday," I pause for explanation, "I came in with Harlin's cart." I reorganise a few small crates I found a better way to stack. "And thank you for the tip on the discount rack." I hold up my hands, "I think right now my priorities might be a pair of gloves when I can get to it."

Thought for 16s

Enchanted – storeroom & side room • Early afternoon • Dust motes, steady work

Lasli falls into your rhythm without quite realizing it. You start nudging her “put it there”

choices a little—angling crates so labels face out, stacking by weight, leaving clear lines of

sight from the doorway—and she just… goes with it, chatting as she adjusts.

More than once she reaches for a spot, pauses, and then mirrors what you’ve just done

instead, brow knitting for half a second like she’s filing away a new trick.

Up close, in the dips between trips:

Her hair is that pale Sheikah white with a faint blue cast, pulled up in a high tail that sways

when she moves. A few wisps have escaped and cling to her cheeks where the humidity’s

gotten them. The red markings under her eyes are softer in person—less “painted on,”

more like something that belongs there. Her eyes themselves are a warm brown, bright,

and they crinkle at the corners when she smiles, which she does often enough that the

lines are already well-practiced.

She has a smudge of dark blue dye along one jaw like she forgot it was there, and her

tunic’s sleeves are rolled up to the elbow, forearms dusted lightly with cloth fibers and

chalk. Pretty, yes—but also busy, hands constantly in motion, adjusting, straightening,

gesturing.

When you talk about all the goodwill you’ve met, her expression tilts from cheerful to

interested.

“Harlin and Mera, huh?” she says, shifting her grip on a crate so you can squeeze past with

another. “That tracks. They have a nose for strays. They brought a Zora here once who’d

gotten turned around and ended up halfway to Hateno before realizing they didn’t like

mountains.”

She laughs softly at the memory.

“And… it’s not that people aren’t kind,” she adds, more thoughtful. “It’s just… we’ve had

rough years. People are tired. When you’re tired, work feels heavier, and anyone who looks

like they might make it heavier again…” She trails off, shrugs one shoulder. “You’ve just

gotten lucky and landed near the good ones first.”

She glances at your hands when you mention gloves, winces in sympathy at the state of

your skin.

“Ow. Yeah, that’s… that’s a real ‘welcome to Necluda’ handshake you’ve got going on.”

She nudges open a smaller crate with her foot, nudging aside straw to check the contents,

then shakes her head.

“We do get gloves now and then,” she says. “Mostly climbing or archery ones. Good

leather, dyed, nice stitching. We keep them out front because they sell fast when travelers

pass through. Not exactly cheap.”

A beat; her face brightens with that “idea forming” spark.

“But the discount rack might have something,” she says. “Every so often we get a pair with

a stitching flaw or one cuff shorter than the other. Claree marks them down instead of

throwing them out. No one here wants to look ‘crooked’ at full price, but if you’re more

worried about blisters than fashion…”

She grins.

“And if there aren’t any right now… well. You’re helping us today. I can keep an eye on new

stock. If something comes in that’s ugly but tough, I’ll try to steer it toward ‘needs a home’

instead of ‘perfect match for some noble from Hateno.’”

She says that last part with a tiny, wicked lilt that suggests she’s been on the receiving end

of exactly that kind of customer many times.

You shift another crate into place—cloth symbols all in one row now, dye crates grouped

where a spill won’t cascade over everything. The path from door to back wall is clean and

straight enough that even in a hurry, Claree could grab what she needs without playing

obstacle course.

By the time you’ve worked through the worst of the stacks, sweat’s dampened the collar of

your shirt and your blisters have gone from protest to dull, steady ache. But your

breathing’s even, your back’s holding up, and the room looks different: less like storage,

more like a system.

Lasli wipes her forehead with the back of her wrist, then peers into the newly cleared side

room again.

“Claree’s going to hate how much she likes this,” she says. “That’s her favorite state.

‘Annoyed but secretly pleased.’”

From the shop side, you both hear her voice: “If you two are done rearranging my entire

livelihood, bring yourselves and a broom out here. The dust under the front racks has

begun a rebellion.”

Lasli jumps, then snickers under her breath.

“She did say half-day’s work,” she reminds you. “You’re safely past ‘charity’ and well into

‘gainfully exploited.’”

She steps aside to let you lead the way out, beads clicking against your shoulders as you

push through.

Out in the main shop, it’s brighter; your eyes need a blink to adjust. Claree has one

eyebrow very slightly raised as she looks past you toward the storeroom—the eyebrow

Lasli mimicked earlier—but the corner of her mouth betrays the verdict.

“Shelves visible, labels facing out,” she notes. “Remarkable. Perhaps Ollie’s gossip is

occasionally worth something.”

Her gaze drops to your hands again, spots the reddened patches and fresh dirt.

“Gloves are on the want list, then,” she says. “Do not buy them from me until you can

afford to do it without flinching. Discount rack or a carpenter’s castoffs will do for now.”

It’s the closest she’s going to come to “don’t spend your first handful of rupees in my

shop,” and it lands as rough-edged kindness.

She nudges a broom toward you with her toe.

“Sweep front to back,” she says. “Lasli, you take the discount heap and try to convince it to

behave. If our guest here truly has ‘organizational skills,’ let him suggest where tunics

should go. If it ends with fewer avalanches, I may even pay him.”

The broom’s worn smooth where hands have gripped it over and over, the bristles splayed

but still serviceable. The floor under your feet is a patchwork of scuffs and stray threads.

It’s work, but it’s simple, concrete, and it’s buying you a foothold in the village one stroke

and one rearranged tunic at a time.

I take the broom, but pause before starting as Lasli makes her way to the discount rack. I softly follow over to the rack to see what state it is currently in.

Enchanted – front room, discount rack • Early afternoon • Light striping the floor, dust in

the air

The discount rack squats in the front corner like a small fabric landslide.

It’s one of those freestanding wooden frames with crossbars, meant for neat rows of

garments. Instead, it looks like at least three people over several weeks have each had a

different idea of what “discount” means.

Tunics of different cuts hang bunched together, some half-off the hangers so their sleeves

drag the floor. A pair of trousers is looped over the rail instead of hung properly. A short

cloak has gotten itself twisted almost inside-out. There’s a small wicker basket at the base

that clearly started life as “for loose items” and ended up as “for anything we don’t know

where to put right now.”

You notice:

Some pieces still have their price tags, with amounts scratched out and rewritten

lower in a quicker hand—Lasli’s, you’d bet.

A few have visible issues: a dye blotch near a hem, a misaligned seam at the shoulder,

a tiny burn mark near a cuff. Nothing crippling, just enough to make a perfectionist

wince.

One pair of leather gloves does exist, half-buried on the rail: good stitching, but one

cuff clearly trimmed shorter to “fix” a bad cut. Someone tagged it down to a more

forgiving price because of that.

Lasli is already there, hands hovering, torn between wanting to dive in and not knowing

where to start. She glances sideways at you, clearly a little self-conscious now that she’s

got an audience for her “problem corner.”

“So, um,” she says, lightly hooking a fallen sleeve back onto the rail. “This is where the ‘shy

clothes’ end up. Wrong size, wrong season, wrong… personality.”

She makes a face.

“Claree says it looks like a cucco nest. I say it has ‘character.’ She says ‘so does a pile of

laundry,’ which is very rude.”

Up close, you can see that in between the chaos there is a sort of logic: similar colors tend

to clump, lighter pieces drift to one side, heavier ones to another. It just never quite made

the jump from “pile” to “system.”

The broom feels wrong in your hand here; this is about vertical order, not dust. Lasli shifts

her weight, waiting for a cue, clearly open to being told how to improve things if you’ve

got an angle that doesn’t involve just “make it neater somehow.”

The gloves, lopsided cuff and all, hang there on a warped hanger near your shoulder—

practical, flawed, and very much in line with the rest of your life right now.

I roll the broom handle playfully in my hands as I survey the wreck.

"Weelll, let me ask you this: does Claree already have a-- hang on," I turn around and simply address the elder sister directly.

"Claree, do you have a preference on how the discount rack *should* be organised, or is at Lasli's discretion? I assume you want to lighten the stock here and not be sitting on lower priced stuff."

Enchanted – front room, discount rack • Early afternoon • Sunlight slanting in, fabric smells

warm

Claree looks up from her ledger when you call, pencil pausing mid-stroke. For a heartbeat

she just studies you and the corner you’re standing in, eyes flicking between the rack and

the broom in your hands.

“I do have a preference,” she says. “My preference is ‘not like a Lynel charged through it.’

Beyond that, I care about two things: people can see what they’re buying, and they can

find their size without tearing the whole thing apart.”

She sets the pencil down, comes around the counter a few steps to get a better look at the

situation.

“Right now,” she goes on, “anyone who touches that mess makes it worse. So: tunics

together, trousers together, cloaks together. Lighter things to the front, heavier to the

back. Small to large, left to right. Tags facing out so I don’t have to guess.”

Her gaze slides sideways to Lasli.

“And everything on an actual hanger, not ‘folded artistically’ over the bar.”

Lasli makes a tiny injured noise. “It looks nice that way.”

“It looks like your laundry,” Claree counters. “You’re welcome to organize your room

however you like. The shop has to sell things.”

She turns back to you, one eyebrow ticking just shy of “doing the thing.”

“If you can make that corner look like something a sensible person would want to browse,

I will be… satisfied,” she says. “If you can do it in a way that means it stays neat for more

than a day, I might even be impressed.”

Her eyes flick to the broom, then back up.

“Sweep after,” she adds. “No point cleaning the floor under a collapsing mountain.”

She starts to turn away, then pauses, gaze snagging briefly on the lone pair of gloves with

the uneven cuff.

“And if you happen to find anything usable for yourself in that pile,” she says, voice a

shade drier, “remember you have not been paid yet. Don’t ‘accidentally’ organize it into

your pockets.”

There’s the faintest ghost of humor at the edge of her mouth as she says it. She trusts you

just enough to tease you about it.

Lasli waits until her sister has gone back toward the counter, then leans closer and

murmurs:

“She says that, but she did put the gloves there instead of sending them back to the

tannery. That’s her version of being nice.”

She plucks a hanger upright, straightening a tunic shoulder.

“So… you heard the boss,” she says, more brightly. “Type, weight, size, all in a row. How do

you want to start? I can wrangle tags and sizes if you do the… uh… ‘spatial magic’ thing

you did with the crates.”

The rack creaks faintly as you touch it, garments shifting. Up close, the flaws in each piece

are clearer—off-color cuffs, wobbly seams, slightly mismatched panels—but so is the

workmanship beneath. These were all meant to be “perfect” once; they’re just… human

now.

Your palms complain as you start lifting hangers, but the work is satisfying in the same way

the storeroom was: there’s a mess, there’s a set of rules, and there’s a visible path from

“before” to “after.”

That pair of crooked-cuff gloves waits on the rail, very much part of the puzzle—and, if all

goes well today, a potential first, small investment in the hands you’re building this new

life with.

2/2 2/2

I roll the broomstick again. I had actually expected Claree to not care so much so long as it looked clean, tidy and could move. Time to pivot. "Okay, so here's the thing: have you got any more of these tags?" I indicate the price tags, hoping for a simple answer.

Enchanted – front room, discount rack • Early afternoon • Fabric whisper, muted street

noise

Lasli looks at the tags you point to, then over at Claree.

“We’ve got extras, right?” she calls. “From when you re-priced the Hateno shipment?”

Claree doesn’t look up from the ledger. “Second drawer under the counter,” she says. “Left

side. Don’t take the ones with the red ink unless you like having to explain why.”

Lasli pads over, slides the drawer open, and returns with a small bundled stack of tags

threaded on twine, plus a stub of pencil.

The spare tags are simple: stiff paper rectangles with a little hole punched in one end,

blank on one side, faintly lined on the other. A few already have tiny numbers on them in

Claree’s precise handwriting; most are clean.

Lasli offers them out to you, palm up.

“We use these when something changes price or needs a note,” she explains. “If you’re

thinking of some better way to mark the ‘shy clothes’ so people actually look at them

instead of just seeing a pile… I’m listening.”

She glances at the rack, then back at you, eyes brightening with curiosity.

“Just don’t write anything like ‘cheap because ugly,’” she adds, lowering her voice. “They

may be discounted, but they still have feelings.”

From the counter, Claree makes a quiet, long-suffering sound that somehow still carries

amusement.

“Clothes do not have feelings,” she says.

“They do if you treat them nicely,” Lasli shoots back, then gives you a conspiratorial little

grin, cradling the remaining tags. “Anyway. We’ve got tags, we’ve got a rack, and we’ve

got… well, this.”

She gestures at the current heap.

“Show me what ‘organized’ looks like where you come from.”

I look at the tags quickly and start picking out the ones that already have writing on them and setting them aside. We wouldn't be needing those. I hand the truly blank ones to Lasli and temporarily lean the broom against the wall.

"I'll start hanging and organising by type and size. While I do, take notice of what garments of matching size could form a complete outfit. Mark a complete outfit with matching tags. This way we'll still get this done with time efficiency, but when it's all said and done, you'll also have somewhere to point someone who is in a hurry." I look Lasli in the face. "I know you get plenty of travellers, and I'm sure at least some of them need to grab something before heading out somewhere else. Even something out of season might be able to be sold at a discount to someone who just found out they need to rush a package to Hebra."

Thought for 10s

Enchanted – discount rack • Early afternoon • Sun on the awning, fabric soft under your

fingers

Lasli lights up at the “complete outfits” idea like you just handed her a new game.

“Ooh, yes,” she says, clutching the tags. “People always come in going ‘I need something

for X’ and then stare at a wall of tunics like they expect them to jump onto their bodies. If I

can just point and say ‘this, this, and that,’ they might actually listen.”

You start the unglamorous part.

One by one, you lift pieces off the bar, untangle their neighbors, and re-hang them

properly. Tunics on the left half of the rack, trousers on the right, cloaks on the back rail

where their weight won’t pull everything forward. Within each section, you sort by size,

smallest near the middle aisle, larger pieces toward the outer edge—easy for someone to

skim their way across.

As you go, you flip tags outward, smoothing them so the numbers face front. A couple are

so smudged you set them aside for re-tagging later; a few items have no tags at all and

get hung in a “mystery corner” at the end for Lasli to price once Claree’s not watching.

She flits around you like a particularly helpful bird, reading sizes and colors aloud, already

matching them in her head.

“Okay, so this blue tunic with that darker pair of trousers would be good for someone

heading somewhere cooler,” she mutters, half to herself. “And this lighter one with the

short sleeves… that’s more for a Hateno merchant’s assistant, maybe.”

Whenever she spots a plausible trio—tunic, trousers, cloak—she pulls a fresh tag, scribbles

on it, and ties matching ones to each piece:

“Travel set – cooler weather”

“Field work – sturdy, not fancy”

“Light & easy – good for errands”

You keep working methodically, the rack physically transforming under your hands from

“heap” to “section.” Once tunics and trousers are in some kind of ranked order, you dip

down to the basket and unearth the loose things: scarves, belts, a couple of oddly cut

vests, one pair of the crooked-cuff gloves you clocked earlier.

The gloves are scuffed but solid. You hang them properly on the end of the rack near the

“field work” set instead of letting them languish folded at the bottom. Practical, not pretty,

and that’s the exact niche they fit.

By the time you’re done, the rack:

Has all garments hanging, not draped.

Shows its color range at a glance—browns and greens together, blues and blacks

together, oddball colors grouped so they look intentional instead of lost.

Lets someone with a “medium” or “large” in mind slide a hand along a line and find

that size without rummaging.

Lasli steps back with you and makes a delighted little noise.

“It looks like a real section now,” she says. “Not just… punishment for touching the good

stuff.”

She taps one of the new outfit tags, proud.

“And now, if someone bursts in saying ‘I need something for today, I don’t care what,’ I

can just say ‘do you want sturdy or warm?’ and point here or here. That’s so much easier

than pulling half the rack apart every time.”

You reclaim the broom and give the floor under the rack the justice it’s been denied—dust,

thread scraps, and a very old, very determined cucco feather all sweep up into a small,

satisfying pile. Your palms are protesting every grip and twist, but there’s a quiet

satisfaction in watching the corner finally match the rest of the shop’s standards.

When you’re done, you step back again. Lasli does the same, mirroring your posture, arms

crossed lightly.

“Okay,” she says. “Now I won’t feel like I’m sending all the weirdos to the naughty corner

when I say ‘try the discount rack.’”

From behind you, Claree’s voice:

“Hmm.”

It’s the kind of hmm that could go either way.

You turn to find her standing just behind the counter, ledger closed, eyes on the newly

organized chaos.

She walks over, not rushing, hands folded behind her back. She doesn’t touch anything at

first, just watches how things hang, how the tags sit, how much space sits between

garments. She slides one tunic aside with a finger, checks its neighbor, then looks at the

tags Lasli wrote.

“Type grouped. Sizes readable,” she says. “Tags legible. Nothing on the floor.”

She flicks a glance at the gloves at the end.

“And the truly odd pieces at the edge where someone will either notice them or ignore

them on purpose. Not bad.”

Her gaze shifts to you.

“For a half day, you’ve made yourself worth more than a single bowl of rice,” she says. “You

can sweep without breaking things, carry without complaining, and apparently bully Lasli

into writing useful notes.”

Lasli makes a small, scandalized noise. “He didn’t bully me, I liked it.”

“Yes,” Claree says dryly. “That is the frightening part.”

She heads back to the counter, slides open the small rupee box, and palms a modest but

respectable handful. When she returns, she offers you the coins in a closed hand, making

you hold yours out to receive them.

“This is for today,” she says. “It will not buy you half a wardrobe, but it will buy you food

and put a dent in a bed. If you want more, come back tomorrow or the day after and we

will see if there’s anything else that needs hauling.”

You feel the weight of the rupees in your palm—small, solid proof that you exist here as

someone who can do a thing and get paid for it.

As you curl your fingers around them, Claree tips her head toward the rack behind you.

“If you are stubborn about paying ‘full and fair’ for things,” she adds, “remember that the

discount rack is full and fair—for what it is. If you decide those gloves are worth a portion

of what you just earned, I will not stop you. If not, and they are still there when you’ve

worked again, we can discuss… further markdowns.”

That last phrase has the tiniest smile attached to it. She really is trying, in her own prickly

way.

Lasli leans closer and stage-whispers, “Translation: she likes that you organized things and

is being weird about it,” then straightens, cheeks pink when Claree shoots her a look.

The shop settles into a quieter rhythm again: Claree returns to her ledger, Lasli drifts to re-

fold a front display now that she has a better sense of “row” vs “landslide,” and you stand

there with a slightly lighter broom and a slightly heavier pocket.

Your hands sting, your back hums with used muscles, and there’s a faint tackiness of sweat

at your neck—but you’ve just:

Done honest work in Kakariko.

Been paid by one of its more exacting citizens.

Gotten yourself one small step closer to not sleeping in a cart.

Out on the lane, the light has slid a little toward afternoon. Harlin’s cart might be closer to

done; the fields are probably gearing up for another round of hauling and weeding; the

carpenters’ scaffolds still beckon in the distance.

For the first time since you arrived, you have coins in your hand and options—modest,

earthly, solid options—about what to do with the rest of your day.

I accept the payment appreciatively. Half a day's work perhaps, but if I'm gauging the shadows I glimpse through the window correctly (possibly not--that isn't a skill I'm particularly experienced with), then I made very good time. I liked these tasks too; I do find organising cathartic and enjoyable...and honestly I do like being around Lasli.

I jingle the minute little gems that are the realm's currency in my pocket--I've never been more grateful to have a pocket--and eye the gloves. Lasli and Claree both obviously know I want them. Need them even.

"Well there's no point in denying it. I agree Claree: it isn't wise to spend money the moment you get it, but..." I take a look at the discount price on the gloves, remove them from the rack and bring them over to Claree. "...I plan on asking the carpenters down the way if they could use some help too. I think this purchase might be necessary."

I count out the correct amount and immediately hand back some of what I was just paid. Only with slight reluctance. "Thank you miss," I put my remaining funds

back in my pocket and start making for the door, turning and doing a little flourish-y bow to Lasli, "and thank you miss. Maybe the next time I come back I might be able to do something about that troublesome beam. As it happens...I might know something about wood."

Thought for 8s

Enchanted – front room • Early afternoon • Light warm, fabric shadows longening

Claree watches you take the gloves from the rack with the air of someone whose

prediction just came true.

Up close, the tag tells you what you already guessed: marked down once from a

respectable price to something more mortal, then again—lighter ink over darker—as if

someone argued with themselves about how “imperfect” counted. The shorter cuff is

obvious in your hands, but the stitching is tight, the leather thick without being rigid.

When you lay them on the counter with your comment, Claree’s eyes flick from the tag to

your palms.

There’s a very small nod, like she’s acknowledging the logic in your choice.

She accepts the rupees without fuss, counts them with that quick, precise motion you’ve

already seen, then sets them aside in a separate corner of the box as if mentally

earmarking “coin that went straight back into circulation.”

“Necessary is fine,” she says. “It’s ‘impulse’ I object to. These are not impulse.”

As you pull the gloves on, the world shrinks pleasantly to the feel of them.

The leather is stiff at first, but softens quickly with your warmth. They’re snug across the

knuckles, leaving your fingertips free, the shorter cuff more of a cosmetic quirk than a flaw.

The inside seams rub against your blisters in a way that says “we’re going to argue for a

day” and “after that I’ll feel like skin.”

Lasli’s face does a visible little yes when you choose them. She tries to look casual about it

and fails completely.

“Those suit you,” she says, honest and a bit pleased. “Very… ‘I move crates and also fix

things so my sister doesn’t yell at me.’”

When you do your little bow and hint about the beam, her eyes widen a fraction, then

spark with conspiratorial delight.

“I knew you weren’t just good at stacking,” she says. “If you come back as ‘Zeth the Wood

Person’ I promise I’ll point at the beam a lot and sigh loudly until Claree gives in.”

Behind her, Claree pretends not to hear, but the tiniest twitch at the corner of her mouth

gives her away.

“Come back when you have more coin than bruises,” she says dryly. “We’ll see if Kakariko

hasn’t worn you out by then.”

Enchanted – outside, main lane • Early afternoon • Sun still high, hill shadow inching

longer

Stepping back into the lane, the sun hits your shoulders and the valley light feels just a

little different now that you’ve got leather between your skin and the world. The gloves

creak when you flex your hands, a small sound that feels like a promise: fewer torn blisters,

better grip on whatever comes next.

From here, you can see:

Down the slope, toward the lower terraces, the carpenters’ scaffolds and stacked

lumber, silhouettes of two or three people moving along beams with practiced

balance. Hammer blows carry faintly up the hill, rhythmic and solid.

Across the lane, Shuteye Inn’s door still propped open, the faint smell of something

simmering just starting to drift out as Ollie—or whoever’s in the back—preps for the

evening.

Further down, past the square, the edge of Harlin’s cart just visible between passing

villagers, the horse’s rump and a familiar flash of Mera’s scarf as she moves around

the wagon.

The village hums on in the early-afternoon lull: quieter voices, people conserving energy

for the later push. Your stomach reminds you it’s been a while since porridge; your legs are

aware of the extra walking you’ve done on top of yesterday’s labor. But your hands, gloved

now, feel… ready.

You’ve turned your first chunk of Kakariko work into both coin and kit. The next step—

whether that’s lumber, fields, or checking in with the two people who dragged you into

this life in the first place—waits where the hill dips and the lane forks.

*/ It remains true that, if appropriate, NPCs may be insightful, but it should be for a good reason. Either something that I as the player reveal through words or actions, or because a particular NPC is especially intelligent or wise, or has a special reason to know something I wasn't aware they did. It is not necessary in all instances to respond to everything that I include in my responses that is part of my internal monologue or reasoning, as if all characters know what I'm thinking all the time. Exceptions may occur if there is a legitimate narrative reason. Self- check yourself to make sure of what both player and NPCs should and should not know based on previous responses. /*

I note that it's an awkward time of day; too late in the day to really get much done with a fresh task with a new crew, but too early to simply call it a day. I decide to make introductions to the carpenters, if nothing else.

Making my way down the hill, I tug on the gloves a little here and there, feeling them out a bit more. I'm actually thrilled to find that they fit like...well, a glove. I'm a big person with large hands, and that's still true, Hylian or not. These gloves fit well in spite of that--most of the items on the discount rack hadn't actually looked as if they would fit me. On top of that, these gloves were of the "fingerless" variety. I never much liked gloves, even when they were beneficial for me, because of how they disabled me from really feeling my work, whatever that work may be. When I was forced to wear them out of necessity, I always made sure they were fingerless.

Thought for 9s

Lower terraces – carpenters’ worksite • Early afternoon • Sun warm, smell of wet wood and

rice

You head downhill, lane turning to packed earth, then to the broad, flatter space where

houses push closer to the paddies. The steady tok… tok… tok of mallet on wood guides

you the last stretch.

The carpenters’ corner is easy to spot:

A half-repaired house crouches at the edge of a terrace, its front veranda propped with

temporary posts and a section of roof stripped back to bare rafters. Planks are stacked

under a makeshift awning, sorted roughly by length and thickness. Off to one side: a low

workbench scarred by years of planing and chiseling, tools laid out in a row—saws with

broad, offset teeth, chisels with wrapped handles, wooden mallets, a couple of augers. No

nails in sight; joinery does the heavy lifting here.

Three Sheikah are at work.

An older man on the veranda roof, broad-shouldered despite his age, white hair tied

in a shorter knot than Dorian’s. He moves with the slow confidence of someone

whose joints complain but whose hands still know exactly where to go.

A woman about your apparent age on the ground, bracing a beam while he checks its

fit, muscles tight under a sweat-darkened tunic.

A lankier younger fellow at the bench, planing a board smooth, curls of pale shavings

piling at his feet.

Your new gloves flex comfortably as you approach. The cut across the back lets your

knuckles move easy; fingertips free means you still feel the grain of the broom you’re no

longer holding, the slight give of the leather as you tug it into place. They’re already

earning their keep.

As you near the edge of the work area, the woman on the ground glances up first. Her

eyes flick from your clothes to the gloves to your empty belt, then to your face.

“Careful there,” she calls, tone more practical than suspicious. “Watch the line—if that post

shifts while he’s up there, we’re all going to hear about it.”

You instinctively skirt wide of the temporary brace she means. The older man on the roof

pauses mid-check, looks down along the beam, then spots you as well.

“Afternoon,” he says, voice roughened by sawdust and years. “You lost, or looking for

someone?”

The younger one at the bench eases off his planing stroke, clearly listening without quite

stopping, but he doesn’t stare—just a quick, measuring glance.

You’ve reached the edge of their workspace now: close enough to speak without shouting,

far enough not to be in anyone’s way. Your stomach gives a small, hollow reminder that

breakfast was a while ago; your legs carry a faint, background ache from all the hill work,

but nothing that feels like a limit yet.

The older carpenter squints down at you, taking in your stance, the way you’re looking at

the beams rather than just the people.

“Most folks who wander over here are either clients or curious kids,” he adds. “You don’t

look much like either. What can we do for you?”

I instantly take a liking to this tiny crew of workers. They remind me of my own crew: my father-in-law, the older, very skilled boss; myself, the younger protégé; my wife, his daughter, a strong woman; and potentially a fourth "other" guy would sometimes work with us. None were one-to- one matches, but the *vibe* was there. Granted, from the looks of things, I would wager the woman here may be the protégé and the young man was relatively green. Guess I'd find out. "I don't mean to interrupt. I was told that you may have more work than you have hands. I don't want to get in the way though. I know my timing isn't ideal. I can wait until

you're done with this task if that's okay with you."

*/ If I am asked a question by an NPC, do describe my answer for me unless I suggest that I want you to do so. /*

Lower terraces – carpenters’ worksite • Early afternoon • Sun hot, wood cool in the shade

The older man snorts softly at your timing comment, shifting his grip on the rafter.

“If we waited to talk until a job was done,” he says, “we’d never talk to anyone.”

He thumps the beam once with his palm, satisfied, then eases himself back along the

rafters with the careful, practiced crawl of someone who’s fallen off things before and

doesn’t intend to again. When he reaches the ladder, he comes down in steady steps,

joints complaining just enough to make him grunt when his boots hit dirt.

Up close, you can see the fine sawdust stuck in the sweat at his temples, the way his hands

are thickened by old work—knuckles knotted, nails short and battered.

He wipes his palms on his trousers, then plants his fists on his hips, looking you over

without hostility.

“Name’s Tasho,” he says. “This is Rinna,” nod toward the woman, “and that string bean at

the bench is Sef.”

Rinna gives you a quick, acknowledging nod and shifts her foot slightly to keep pressure

on the post she’d been bracing. Sef lifts his head from the board, offers a brief, shy half-

smile, then goes back to his plane, though his strokes slow so he can still hear.

“You heard right,” Tasho continues. “We’ve got more work than hands most days. Roof

leaks, rotten posts, creek flooding the lower floors in the rains… Hyrule may be at peace,

but wood doesn’t know that.” There’s a dry amusement in his tone.

He eyes your gloves, then your shoulders, then the way you’re careful about where you

stand.

“You know what end of a saw to hold?” he asks. “Or are you just volunteering to haul and

wedge?”

He says it matter-of-factly, no bite in it—just trying to place you on his internal map of

“useful vs. about to hurt themselves.”

Before you can answer, Rinna chimes in without taking her hands off the post.

“If you’re from outside the valley,” she says, “you probably work different than we do.

That’s not a complaint. Just means we’d have to watch you a little at first.” There’s a hint of

a grin. “Make sure you don’t try and nail something that’s supposed to float.”

Tasho grunts his agreement.

“Anyway,” he says, “you’re right it’s not the best hour to start anything big. But if you’re

looking for work long-term, introductions are better now than when the light’s gone.”

He jerks his chin toward the half-stripped roof.

“Tell me what you can do—plainly, not bragging—and what you’re hoping for. Coin,

practice, a place to belong, all three… I don’t hire people blind, but I don’t turn away a

willing back without hearing it out.”

Rinna shifts her weight again, steady and solid at the post, watching between you and

Tasho with frank curiosity. Sef’s plane gives a soft shrrk along the board, not quite masking

the new stillness in his shoulders as he listens.

The worksite smells of shaved pine and old cedar, the steady ticking of cooling beams and

occasional creak of the temporary supports underlining the conversation. You’ve got

leather between your palms and the world now, a little coin in your pocket, and a chance

to see whether this familiar-feeling crew has room for one more pair of hands.

"Pleased to meet you Tasho, Rinna, Sef," I say, nodding to each in turn. "I'm Zeth. Rinna's fot the truth of it. I am familiar with carpentry and would be capable of working independently, if it weren't for thebfact that I know you're practicing a different style here I'm not so familiar with. I'm used to a lot more nails in my work; don't know my way around mortise and tenon joinery. As a professional I have

actually always wanted to learn though. I don't have any of my own tools, unfortunately, but I know how to treat a tool well. I won't break anything. I think.

"I don't know exactly how long I'll be in Kakariko, but at the least...I would say a week. Could turn into more. I'm just not sure yet. In the next day or two I may be needing to pop back over to Enchanted to help Claree and Lisli with some things, but otherwise I am free and ready to work."

Thought for 6s

Lower terraces – carpenters’ worksite • Early afternoon tipping toward later • Air hot, shade

under the eaves cool

Tasho listens without interrupting, eyes narrowing just a little at “professional” and “more

nails.” When you mention wanting to learn joinery, there’s a distinct shift in his face—

something like approval trying not to show itself.

“Mm,” he says. “So you know enough to know what you don’t know. That’s better than half

the lads who wander in here thinking a saw makes them a carpenter.”

Rinna huffs a quiet laugh at that, still braced against the post.

“No tools is a problem if you’re planning to wander off,” Tasho goes on, “but not if you’re

working with a crew. We’ve got more steel than hands most days.”

He looks up at the roof, gauges the sun, then back to you.

“Here’s what I can offer,” he says. “You show up at first light tomorrow. We start when we

can see the grain without squinting. You haul, you brace, you cut where I tell you, and you

keep your ears open.”

He taps the side of his head with a thick finger.

“If you’re as quick to learn as you say, I’ll let you start fitting simple joints once I’ve seen

you hold a chisel without gouging your own leg. Day’s work gets you a day’s coin. Not as

much as a full hand, but enough you won’t starve.”

He jerks his chin toward the half-stripped section of roof.

“Today, we’re already halfway through something I don’t want you walking into cold,” he

says. “Too many weights in the air. But—”

He glances at Rinna.

“Rinna, let him take that post for a spell. See if he knows how to stand without toppling.”

She grins and steps aside, gesturing you in with one hand while keeping the other on the

beam until you’re in place. When you take the post, you feel the subtle weight of the roof

section it’s helping support—a slow, insistent downward push. You brace your feet, adjust

your grip, let your shoulders settle.

The new gloves earn their keep immediately: leather biting into palm instead of raw skin,

fingerless tips letting you feel the roughness of the support and the small shifts as the

structure creaks and settles.

“Good,” Rinna says after a moment, watching how you adjust rather than freeze. “You’re

not fighting it, you’re following it. That’s a start.”

Sef glances over from the bench again, curious now, then goes back to his plane with a

little extra crispness in his strokes. The shavings curl off in thin, almost translucent ribbons.

Tasho watches you hold the post for a good slow count, checking the line of the beam

above, the angle of the support, the set of your shoulders.

“You’ll do,” he says finally. “For someone who ‘doesn’t know mortise and tenon.’”

He claps his hands once to dust them off, then nods toward the lane.

“Go rest those hands and feed your belly. No good to me if you show up tomorrow

already half-broken. Dawn at the bottom of the steps—there.” He points to a flat patch of

ground near the workbench. “If we’re not here yet, wait. We will be.”

Rinna steps back in to take over the post as you ease out, careful not to jolt it.

“Bring whatever you’ve got that passes for work clothes,” she adds. “You’ll be covered in

dust by mid-morning. If you don’t mind that, we won’t either.”

Tasho gives you a final, measuring look.

“And if Enchanted needs you now and then,” he says, “we’ll survive. Just don’t vanish

without a word. Wood likes routine. So do people.”

He turns back toward the ladder with the solid finality of someone who considers the

matter settled unless you give him a reason to reconsider. Sef’s plane resumes its steady

shrrk, Rinna’s stance tightens on the post, and the little worksite’s rhythm picks up again

around you.

As you step back out of their immediate orbit, the terrace opens up—fields shimmering

below, village rising above, the lane snaking between. Your pocket’s lighter than it was

when you left Enchanted, but your hands are better protected, and the morning holds the

promise of more than just wandering.

You’ve got:

A half day of honest work behind you.

Gloves that already feel like an extra layer of skin.

A tentative spot in a crew that builds the bones of this village.

It’s not a grand destiny. It’s not an ancient relic. It’s three people fixing a house and maybe

letting you help.

For where—and what—you are right now, that’s exactly the kind of footing you need.

*/ In subsequent responses, offer some more physical descriptors of people or creatures I meet for the first time, so I can get a better mental image of what they actually look like. Also start tracking the days since my arrival; so for example we are currently in the early afternoon tipping into the later of Day 2. /*

Thought for 5s

Kakariko – lower terraces to main lane • Day 2, early afternoon sliding later • Sun hot,

breeze from the falls

Tasho climbs back up the ladder, boots knocking solidly on each rung. From this angle you

get a clearer look at him: shorter than you by a fair bit, but built like a tree stump—thick

torso, strong forearms roped with muscle under sun-browned skin. His hair is steel-white,

pulled back into a short, practical knot, and deep creases run from nose to mouth in lines

carved by sun and frowns, not smiles. A faint, pale scar cuts across one eyebrow, then

vanishes into his hairline.

Rinna, closer to your height but more compact, has the kind of stance that says “used to

work” even when she’s standing still: feet square, shoulders open, every bit of her ready to

move lumber or a person with about the same effort. Her skin’s a warm tan, freckles

scattered across the bridge of her nose and cheeks; her Sheikah eye markings are a deep

brick red, and her dark hair is braided tight and looped around itself at the back of her

head to keep it clear of tools.

Sef is lankier, a head taller than Rinna but not as broad: long arms, narrow shoulders, still

growing into himself. His hair is pulled back in a shorter topknot, a few stray strands

escaping at his temples. His eye markings are thinner, like they were painted with a finer

brush. Up close, his hands show the faint, fresh nicks of someone still learning exactly how

close is “too close” to a blade’s edge.

When you step back off their work area, the rhythm of the site folds up around them

again: Rinna’s low murmur to Tasho about the next beam, Sef’s steady shrrk of the plane,

the occasional creak of old timber being persuaded into a new life.

The lane back upward curves between houses, then opens toward the main spine of the

village.

Your body is carrying the tally for Day 2:

Hands: sore but better shielded, the gloves taking the bite of movement instead of

your skin.

Back and shoulders: a steady, used ache from crates and bracing, not sharp enough to

limit you.

Feet: a bit tender from dirt roads and stone steps, but far from failing.

Stomach: not empty, but light—porridge and bread feel like they happened a long

while ago. The smell of cooking rice or broth from a nearby house makes the hollow a

little more noticeable.

By the time you climb back toward the main lane, the light has shifted: shadows from the

tall houses and the shrine’s gate stretch longer across the road, and the air has the faint

heaviness that hints at late afternoon a few hours ahead.

From this vantage:

Down slope toward the square, Harlin’s cart sits much lighter than this morning. The

horse swishes its tail lazily; Mera’s bright scarf marks her beside the wagon, talking

with a shopkeeper. Harlin himself is near the cart’s rear, hands on his lower back,

stretching between trips.

Up slope, Shuteye Inn’s doorway is still open; the scent of something simmering—

maybe a thin stew or miso-like broth—drifts occasionally on the breeze.

Across the way, Enchanted’s awning flutters; a traveler in road-stained clothes stands

at the counter, and Lasli’s silhouette moves behind them, animated as she talks.

Higher still, the steps toward the shrine and Impa’s house catch the light, stone faces

warmed to a gentle glow. Cado’s thin figure is visible at the distant gate if you glance

that way, spear upright, posture steady.

The village hums in its Day 2, early-afternoon state: not yet the lull of evening, not the

bustle of morning, just the middle stretch where people are mid-task and smoke from

cooking fires is only starting to rise.

Your pockets carry a small clink of rupees. Your hands are finally dressed for work.

Tomorrow’s dawn has a place and purpose attached to it.

The rest of Day 2, between here and sundown, is open in front of you like the main lane:

food, friends, or just a chance to walk through Kakariko as something more than a

passerby.

Seeing as I'd been given the opportunity to start fresh in the morning, I decide to really *see* the village, to some

extent. My first destination being the Goddess statue not far from Impa's house, with its tiny nearby pond. I was curious about something.

As I make my way there I come up near Harlin and Mera and the cart again and I wave. "Hey Harlin. Mera. Day gone well for you I hope?"

Thought for 11s

Kakariko village square, by Harlin’s cart • Day 2, mid-afternoon • Sun easing, shadows

longer

Harlin’s cart sits much lighter now, only a few sacks and a crate or two left in the bed. The

horse—short, stocky, dun-colored with a darker mane—stands hitched in the shade of a

nearby house, tail flicking lazily at flies.

Harlin is exactly where you’d expect him: one boot on the cart’s rear step, hands pressed

into the small of his back as he stretches it out, sweat darkening the collar of his shirt.

Close up you can see more of him than you did on the road: late-thirties maybe, sun-

tanned skin, brown hair tied back, a dusting of stubble along his jaw. There’s a faint white

scar at the base of his throat, old and forgotten.

Mera is perched on the cart’s sideboard, counting something in a small cloth purse with

ink-stained fingers. Her braids are pinned up off her neck in a crown, a few curls worked

loose by the heat. The green-and-cream scarf is tied back pirate-style today, shading her

eyes; a smudge of flour or dust sits on one cheek, unnoticed.

When you wave and call out, both of them look up almost in the same instant.

“Zeth!” Mera’s face brightens; she hops down as if she hasn’t spent the day lifting sacks.

“Day’s been busy, but good. Fewer sacks in the cart, more coin in the pocket. That’s how I

like it.”

Harlin gives you a tired but satisfied grin and returns the wave.

“Can’t complain,” he says. “The village still likes its grain and oil. We’ll be sleeping in real

beds tonight, which is more than the horse can say.”

He pats the cart’s side with something like affection.

He gives you a once-over, taking in the faint dust on your clothes, the new gloves, the

slight set of your shoulders.

“Looks like you found something to do besides stare at waterfalls,” he adds. “Did the day

treat you fair?”

Mera’s eyes drop to your hands and catch on the gloves.

“Ooh, those are new,” she says. “You did find your way into Enchanted then. Good. If you’re

going to work, you might as well keep your hands.”

She tilts her head toward the inn.

“We’ll be at the Shuteye tonight,” she says. “Harlin thinks we’ll roll out first thing Day 3—

either back toward the stable or up the road, depending on what Pella needs. If you’re still

dead set on staying here a while, we’ll not steal you away… but you’d better at least come

by later so we know you’re not lying in a ditch somewhere.”

Harlin snorts.

“Mera means: come break bread with us if you can,” he says, with that understated warmth

he still tries to hide under practicality. “Pella’ll want to hear whether you poked at her door

hinges, too.”

A villager comes over to haggle about one of the remaining sacks, and Harlin shifts his

attention to them with the natural ease of someone switching between roles.

Mera gives you an apologetic little shrug.

“Duty calls,” she says. “But you know where to find us. Don’t forget.”

Kakariko – by the Goddess statue • Day 2, mid-afternoon • Light softening, water still

The path up toward Impa’s house forks before the steps; to the right, a short stone walk

leads to the little plaza around the Goddess statue.

The statue itself is just as you remember from the game and somehow more: carved from

smooth, pale stone, the figure sits with hands folded, head slightly bowed, wings arched

behind her shoulders in a protective curve. Time and weather have worn soft edges into

her features, moss tracing faint lines along her base. A few offerings rest at her feet—

flowers, a small carved bird, a neat stack of rupees left by someone with more faith than

coin.

In front of her is the familiar round stone pedestal with the shallow basin in the middle,

the place where Spirit Orbs would once have resonated. Now it just holds clear water, no

more magical than the pond beside it… as far as you can tell.

The little pond to the side mirrors the sky: a bright oval framed by stones and a fringe of

damp grass. A couple of dragonflies skim the surface, wings glinting green and blue. Tiny

fish—no bigger than your thumb—dart in the shadows between rocks when your steps

crunch on the gravel.

The air here feels slightly cooler, the noise of the village damped down by the shrine gate

and the shape of the hill. You can still hear the distant rush of the waterfall beyond the

terraces, but it’s more of a murmur now than a roar.

Your body takes the chance to recalibrate:

Feet grateful for a pause on level ground.

Back easing now that you’re not under a load.

Hands flexing inside new leather, the gloves already picking up the faint scent of your

sweat and the day’s dust.
