Stomach sending up a quiet reminder that it will want something more substantial

before long.

The statue watches with her usual unreadable calm, stone eyes lowered, stone hands

folded. No glowing prompts, no chiming UI, just shaped rock and the weight of people’s

hopes over time.

Whatever you came here to test or ask—whether it’s something as simple as “does this

Goddess statue do anything if I talk to it” or as complicated as “does Hyrule’s divine

customer service recognize extradimensional walk-ins”—the spot is as quiet and receptive

as it’s ever going to be.

I intend to tell Harlin and Mera that I'll indeed be stayijg in Kakariko for a while, but as another customer approaches I decide it may be best left for when they are truly finished for the day. More of a relaxed and friendly chat. So I move on to my destination.

I enjoy the simple yet elegant design of the statue. Despite being obviously so ancient, its simple minimalism somehow give it a slightly modern vibe that appeals to me. But, artistic design appreciation aside, I didn't actually come for the statue itself. Or the ambience, as wonderful and peaceful as it was. I am actually curious about an individual I thought I might have found here.

Once upon a time, at least, there would have been a Korok here. Aside from the bokoblins that Harlin, Mera and myself had purposefully kept distance from, I hadn't yet seen anything truly "fantastic" in the world just yet. Not in the literal sense of the word, as in, having the quality of fantasy, anyways. I reach up with my right hand and feel my pointed ear, just to remind myself of the situation. I had immediately become blind to the fact that Hylians and Sheikah were not actually humans, in spite of the obvious visual reminder. As soon as I brought the thought back to mind with the tactile sensation of my fingers on my ear, I was hit with a wave of..."weirdness". Not necessarily unhappiness, but just...strangeness.

I'm not sure what seeing a Korok would have done to change this sentiment, but I had been eagerly anticipating meeting something or someone not so easily translated between my old world and this new one. I mentally shrug, however, and accept that this particular Korok was no longer here. Maybe I would still have a chance to see something new to me soon. Like a Rito postman or a Gerudo merchant or a Goron tradesman. The different regions of Hyrule had remained mildly insular during the Calamity, I knew, mostly owing to the danger of travel, but

if I understood where I was in the timeline correctly, that attitude should be rapidly crumbling. Kakariko was fairly isolated, and so may not catch up with that movement as quickly as other places, but it surely would at some point.

I sit near the statue and watch and listen to the falling water nearby for a while. I enjoyed being around Harlin, Mera, Lisli, Claree--even Dorian and Impa, though at the time fear had clouded my ability to appreciate them--but this moment was the first one since I arrived in Hyrule that I was actually alone. It was simultaneously refreshing and dreadful. Refreshing in that I had time to think, to ruminate, and centre. Dreadful in that it forced me to confront how very alone I actually was now. I had already made friends, sure. But they were all new. Not tried and true in a way that allowed for best-friend-intimate conversation or unburdening.

Thought for 9s

Goddess Statue plaza • Day 2, mid-afternoon • Shade cool, water soft and constant

The plaza around the statue is quieter than most of the village. The main lane’s voices and

cart-wheels reach you as a low blur, filtered through stone and distance. Up here it’s

mostly the sound of water: the steady trickle from the little basin, the hush of the nearby

falls, the occasional plink when a droplet breaks the pond’s surface just right.

The statue holds court above you: wings folded, hands pressed together, head bowed. Up

close, you can see the subtle asymmetries in the carving—the slightly different curve to

each wingtip, the tiny chip along one finger, the faint dark streak where rain has run in the

same path for what must be decades. Moss gathers in the shallow carving lines near her

feet, and lichen spots her base like pale freckles.

The pond beside her is a neat oval lined with rounded stones. Small, flat leaves float on

the surface, their green made vivid by reflected sky. Little fish—slender, silver-grey things

with a faint dark stripe—dart in and out of the shadows, scattering whenever your

reflection leans too close.

No Korok greets you.

No rustle of leaves from a non-existent tree, no little wooden mask peeking out from

behind the statue. Just the world doing what it does: water moving downhill, light moving

west, a dragonfly hovering over the pond like a tiny, jeweled helicopter.

You touch your ear and the illusion shivers.

Up here, in the quiet, it lands harder: the angle of that cartilage under your fingers, the

way it comes to a sharp point instead of soft curve. The feeling is not wrong, exactly, but it

is dissonant—like hearing your own voice recorded and recognizing it and not recognizing

it at the same time.

Your body files its status without asking you:

Feet: grateful to be off stone steps and away from crates, the ground here firm and

level.

Back and shoulders: a warm, used ache, not yet upgraded to pain, asking for rest later

and forgiving you for now.

Hands: snug inside leather, the gloves already picking up a faint salt-darkening along

the edges; the blisters under them throb less when you’re not gripping anything.

Stomach: that light, hollow feeling just starting to become insistent—more “nudge”

than “complaint,” but ticking toward “feed me” as the afternoon stretches.

Down in the village, life goes on without you for a little while.

A pair of kids tear past the far edge of the plaza, chasing a cucco that absolutely does not

want to be chased. They skid to a halt when they see you sitting by the statue, exchange a

whispered debate about whether they’re being disrespectful, then decide the answer is

“maybe” and drag the bird back down the steps instead.

Later, a middle-aged woman in work clothes comes up with a small bundle of flowers—

simple wild blooms tied with twine. She nods politely when she notices you, says nothing,

and lays the flowers at the statue’s feet with a soft, practiced motion before murmuring

something under her breath and leaving again. The scent of crushed petals lingers faintly.

At one point, as you sit watching the pond, a single leaf drops into the water right in front

of you.

It lands with barely a sound, sending out a perfect ring of ripples. There are no trees

immediately overhead, no obvious branch for it to have fallen from, just the wind and the

sky and a stray bit of green now drifting, slowly spinning, across the surface.

For a heartbeat, you almost hear the sort of chiming, wooden giggle you’ve heard a

hundred times through speakers. But it might just be the way the water and village noise

combine, or the way your brain is primed and hungry for something properly impossible.

The ripples fade. The fish come back. The leaf bumps gently against a stone and stays

there.

You’re still alone.

Alone in a way that’s both comforting and sharp-edged. No Harlin making practical,

pointed questions; no Mera with her easy warmth; no Lasli chattering while she tries to

make piles behave; no Claree’s dry, precise judgments; no Impa or Dorian looming like

embodied consequences.

Just you, a stone goddess, a small pond, and the knowledge that somewhere beyond

these hills there are Rito sorting letters, Gerudo arguing over prices, Gorons laughing as

they haul rocks twice their size.

Hyrule will get stranger and wider the further you walk. Right now, Kakariko is still mostly

people you can translate into shapes you know: parents, workers, sisters, guards,

innkeepers. The fantasy is in the edges—the ears under your fingers, the way the statue

seems to listen even though you know it’s carved, the leaf that fell from nowhere in

particular.

Your mind loops around the fact that this is the first time since Gatepost Town Ruins that

you haven’t had someone right there with you to anchor to. Harlin and Mera filled the

silence of Day 1; Day 2 has been one long braid of other people’s needs and expectations.

Now the braid loosens a little, and you feel how thin your line back to your old life has

become.

The village breathes around you. Smoke from a distant cookfire threads into the air,

carrying the scent of rice and something savory. A bell shaped like a little gourd clinks

softly as the breeze catches it on a nearby eave. The sun has tipped just enough that the

shrine gate throws a longer shadow across the steps.

You’ve got a roof you can probably claim tonight—either in the inn proper or near Harlin’s

cart—work waiting at dawn on Day 3, and a matriarch who has decided you are, for now,

Kakariko’s problem.

You also have this: fifteen, twenty minutes of being allowed to sit with your own thoughts,

in a space that has been absorbing people’s worries and wishes for longer than anyone

here remembers.

The statue doesn’t glow. The pond doesn’t reveal a secret. No divine UI pops up offering

you “heart or stamina.”

Just the quiet, the ache, the hunger, the new leather on your hands, and the knowledge

that when you stand up again, you’ll be doing it as someone who belongs to this village a

little more than you did this morning—and a little less to the place you left behind.

I return the polite nod to the middle-aged woman as she makes her offering and remain alone with my thoughts for a while longer. Even after sitting for a good 20 minutes or so, I take what I guess is another 10. At one point I stupidly, but instinctually reach for a non-existent side pocket on my pants to retrieve a cell phone and check the time. Even though I'm sure nobody saw it, and probably wouldn't make anything if they had, I still feel silly to myself. I'm not particularly bad at guessing the time, but I was going to have to learn to tell time however the locals did at some point. Hopefully it's something I just pick up along the way. I don't expect anybody to volunteer information on such a basic and fundamental skill.

Deciding I've wasted enough time though, I remove my gloves and scoop up some water from the water, rubbing my face and arms to clean up a little bit. I wasn't especially dirty, but it felt nice. I decide to head back over to Harlin and Mera for the time being.

*/ When composing response scenes, do not continue past where input from the player is required. Do not speak for the player with dialogue. Do not speak for the player by summarising something that they say. Always allow the player to speak for themself and maintain agency. /*

Goddess Statue plaza → village square • Day 2, late afternoon • Air cooling, light going

soft

The water is pleasantly cool on your skin. When you cup it up and splash your face, it takes

the heat right out of your cheeks and leaves you blinking at the world through droplets.

The little fish in the pond scatter at the disturbance, then drift back once they decide

you’re not falling in.

By the time you pull your gloves back on and stand, the shadows from the shrine gate

have crept further across the stone. The village sound has shifted, too—work voices a

touch rougher with tiredness, more clatter of pots from kitchens, fewer hammer blows and

more conversation.

On the way back down the steps, your hand does that old muscle-memory reach toward a

pocket that isn’t there, fingers brushing plain fabric instead of phone-shaped plastic. The

gesture dies halfway, leaving a faint embarrassed sting only you can feel.

Kakariko square – by Harlin’s cart • Day 2, late afternoon • Sun low, long shadows

Harlin and Mera are in the familiar “end of day” phase now.

Most of the cart is empty; only a few sacks remain, tied and ready to be taken in. The

horse is unhitched and tethered to a post by the square’s edge, head down in a nosebag,

tail flicking occasionally. Someone—probably Mera—has brushed a good deal of the dust

out of its mane.

Harlin is wiping his hands on a rag, leaning back against the side of the cart with his ankles

crossed. Up close in this light, he looks more worn than he did at noon: a smudge of dust

along one cheek, the lines at the corners of his eyes deeper, shirt collar gone from

“sweaty” to “definitely needs a wash.” His posture, though, is loose—job mostly done, tally

mentally made.

Mera is perched on the tailboard, feet dangling. She’s let her scarf slip back a bit; a few

curls have escaped and cling to her forehead. The small purse she was counting earlier is

now tied at her belt, and she’s nibbling on a piece of dried fruit, chewing slowly, eyes

tracking the square out of habit more than need.

As you approach, Mera spots you first. Her expression brightens; she lifts her scrap of fruit

in greeting.

Harlin glances over, pushes off the cart, and straightens, folding the rag over one shoulder.

“You look less like a man dropped in from nowhere and more like someone who belongs

to a day’s work,” he says, eyeing the gloves and the bit of damp on your hairline where

you washed up. There’s a dry note in it, but the approval’s real.

Mera hops down from the cart, dusts off her hands.

“We were just talking about you,” she says. “I made a bet with Harlin about whether you’d

vanish into the hills or wander back here sooner or later.”

She tilts her head, studying your face.

“You look… better,” she adds after a moment. “Not that you looked bad before. Just less

like you’ve had the ground pulled out from under you this very morning.”

Harlin snorts quietly.

“We’re about done for the day,” he says, jerking a thumb at the almost-empty wagon.

“One more sack to the general store and we’ll go claim our corner at the Shuteye before

some Zora trader beats us to it.”

He wipes his forehead with the back of his wrist.

“Figured we’d see if you’d turned up by then,” he goes on. “If you hadn’t, Mera was going

to insist on asking Cado whether he’d thrown you in a cell for looking at the wrong person

funny.”

Mera doesn’t even deny it; she just smiles.

“Have you got yourself sorted?” she asks. “Work, bed, all that? Or are you still just held

together by Harlin’s suspicions and my bread?”

She says it lightly, but there’s a real question there: are you staying, going, drifting?

They both wait, easy but attentive, clearly ready to fold whatever you say into their

evening plans.

I smile and nod to them before rubbing the tip of my ear momentarily. I stop myself abruptly, not wanting to start developing a nervous habit.

"Thanks. I think. Things worked out better than I could ask for, really. Spoke with Impa. I think I'll be staying in Kakariko for a little while. Not exactly sure how long." I leave out the details about how tense the meeting with Impa and Dorian was, and that really, I *couldn't* leave Kakariko for a minimum of a week. I didn't want to concern them. "Not sure how sorted I am exactly, to be honest, but, yeah, it does seem like I can feel the ground under my feet a little better."

I put my hand on the wooden side of cart and glimpse my sword and "shield" still inside. "I'd still love to maybe share the evening meal with you guys, if you don't mind. Maybe try some of that tea we talked about. After that...well, I already talked to Ollie at the inn and he said he'd already ear-marked the regular room for you two. First dibs and such. I know you'd probably offer me a space, and I appreciate that, but I was actually hoping...and I know it's an odd request.. But I'd like for the two of you to have the room to yourselves. You've been so extremely gracious and hospitable, not crowding you tonight is the least I can do. And I was hoping you'd let me bed down in the cart tonight." I bob my head side to side. "Just sort of feel like letting my head be clear, by myself, you know?"

Thought for 8s

Kakariko square – by Harlin’s cart • Day 2, late afternoon • Light golden, air cooling

Harlin watches you as you speak, his face open in that careful, listening way of his. When

you mention speaking with Impa and staying in Kakariko, his brows go up a notch.

“You went straight to the top, then,” he says. “Can’t say you don’t work quick.”

There’s respect in it, but also a hint of Impa, of all people? brave fool.

Mera’s eyes soften when you say the ground feels more solid under your feet.

“That’s good to hear,” she says. “Took me a full season after the Calamity to feel that way

again. If you’ve managed it in two days, you’re doing better than most.”

She follows your glance into the cart, spots your sword and battered “shield,” and gives a

small, approving nod like she’s glad you’ve still got them.

When you ask to share the evening meal, Harlin’s answer is immediate—a little snort, a

shrug that’s really just a nod.

“Of course,” he says. “Would’ve dragged you along even if you hadn’t asked.”

Mera grins.

“I promised you tea, didn’t I?” she says. “Can’t go breaking a tea promise.”

You lay out your request about the room and the cart, and both of them go quiet for a

moment.

Harlin rubs his jaw, thinking. Up close you can see a faint shadow of stubble there,

catching the light.

“Mmm,” he says finally. “Bed’s not much, but it does beat wagon boards.”

He looks you over again—how tired you actually look under the wash of the Goddess

statue’s water, the way your shoulders are carrying the day.

“But I get it,” he adds. “First few nights after the stable started taking us on regular, I still

preferred sleeping in the hayloft. Too many walls all at once.”

Mera folds her arms loosely, leaning a hip against the cart.

“I’m not going to lie and say I like the idea of you sleeping out here by yourself,” she says,

“but the square’s safe, and Cado’s boys do their rounds. If you need the space in your

head, the cart’s as good a place as any.”

She tilts her head.

“At least let us make sure you’ve got a blanket or two,” she says. “And you are coming

inside for stew and tea before you turn into a lone, tragic wagon ghost.”

There’s no pressure beyond that—just simple conditions: eat with us, don’t freeze, don’t

vanish.

Harlin pushes off the cart and hefts one of the last sacks.

“Come on, then,” he says. “We’ll drop this at the store and then claim our corner at the

Shuteye before Ollie talks himself into giving it to that Zora trader I saw sniffing around.”

Kakariko – on the way to Shuteye Inn • Day 2, edging into evening • Lanterns being lit,

cooking smells thickening

You fall in beside them as they walk: Harlin leading with the sack on his shoulder, Mera

matching her pace to yours. The square’s energy has shifted—less trade, more routine. A

few lanterns are already lit along the lane, small paper shades glowing warm. Smoke from

cooking fires drifts in thin blue threads; the smells of boiling rice, stewing vegetables, and

something meatier from one house cling to the air.

Your stomach tightens with anticipation. The ache in your legs has settled into a slow, dull

thrum. Your hands, encased in new leather, feel oddly equipped for the first time since

Gatepost Town.

Shuteye Inn sits ahead with its door propped open, light spilling onto the lane. Through it,

you can see the vague outline of tables, a couple of early diners hunched over bowls, and

Ollie’s lanky form moving between counter and back room in his familiar, slightly frantic

way.

Harlin drops the last sack off with a quick exchange at the general store, then rejoins you

and Mera at the inn’s threshold.

Inside, there will be:

Warm food.

Tea Mera has been talking about since the road.

A chance to sit and talk without the cart moving or tools in anyone’s hands.

Outside, later, there will be a wagon bed, blankets, and the night sounds of Kakariko

around you.

For now, Harlin ducks his head to step in, Mera follows with an encouraging glance over

her shoulder, and the smell of stew and steam-warmed tatami rolls out to meet you as you

cross the threshold after them.

I thank the two of them for not pushing the matter and nod happily at the mention of blankets. I certainly wasn't about to turn that offer down. I was feeling a little bit mentally fatigued, but I wasn't crazy. It was probably going to get a little chilly in the cart overnight if yesterday's night in the stable loft was anything to go by.

I try to mask my anticipation when Harlin casually mentions a Zora trader being around and follow Mera to the inn, asking about the food and tea instead as Harlin rejoins us and we enter.

"Do you know what they're serving tonight? What kind of tea are we having?"

Thought for 6s

Shuteye Inn – common room • Day 2, early evening • Lanterns lit, air warm with steam and

food

The heat and light of the inn wrap around you as you step inside. Tatami mats line the

floor; low tables sit in two rows, with cushions tucked neatly around them. Lanterns hang

from the beams, their paper shades throwing a soft amber glow that smooths the edges

off everything.

Ollie is behind the counter again, hair a little more chaotic than earlier, sleeves rolled up.

There’s a faint sheen of steam on his face from darting between the kitchen nook and the

front. When he sees Harlin and Mera, his shoulders visibly drop in relief.

“Y-you made it,” he says. “I mean, of course you made it, I just— your room’s ready, and—

oh, Zeth, good, you’re here too.”

He actually looks pleased, not just polite, to see you. His gaze flicks to your gloves, then

back up, taking in that you look tired but not wrecked.

To one side, you spot the Zora trader Harlin mentioned: tall and sleek, bluish skin catching

the lantern light, head-tail crest wrapped in a cloth band for travel, a short sleeveless tunic

worn over a water-resistant-looking sash. Their features are sharp and smooth at once, like

someone carved them from river stone and polished them with current. A few pieces of

jewelled coral glint at wrists and throat. They sit with a large pack at their side, spooning

stew with unhurried, precise motions, webbed fingers oddly delicate around the bowl.

It’s the most undeniably “fantasy” person you’ve seen yet, and your brain catalogs every

detail greedily.

Mera answers your question before Ollie can spin into another spiral.

“Tonight it’s vegetable and mushroom stew,” she says, smiling. “Bit of chicken if we’re

lucky. Pella said she had some left. And rice, of course.”

She looks toward the counter.

“And tea?”

Ollie perks up, nodding quickly.

“Y-yes! The usual barley tea,” he says. “And… uh… I managed to get some sakura-blossom

blend from a Hateno trader last week. It’s more expensive, but we can do a pot if you want

to share.” He glances between the three of you, clearly not wanting to assume.

Mera shoots you a look that says see, this is what I meant about tea being serious here.

“If you’re offering sakura, we’ll take a pot,” Harlin says. “We’ve had a good day. Might as

well drink like it.”

He glances at you, making sure you’re on board with the slight indulgence. Then he

gestures toward a table near the back wall.

“Same corner as always?”

Mera nods and leads the way, picking the table with its back to the wall and a view of the

room—habit, not paranoia. You sit with them: Harlin on one side, facing the door; Mera at

the corner; you on the other side, able to see both them and the rest of the inn.

Ollie brings mismatched ceramic bowls a few minutes later. The stew is thick and cloudy,

studded with carrot, daikon-like root, slices of mushroom, and shreds of pale meat—

chicken, by the smell. He follows with small wooden bowls of rice, then a clay teapot and

three cups, steam curling from the spout.

The sakura tea smells faintly floral and toasty at the same time—barley base with a softer,

sweet note laid over it. When you lift the cup, the warmth seeps straight into your fingers,

and the first sip is… tucked somewhere between familiar and new. No sugar, no milk, just

roasted grain and that ghost of blossom.

Your stomach practically sings when the first spoonful of stew goes down. It’s simple, salty

and savory, the vegetables softened just enough to give but not turn to mush. The rice is

slightly sticky, perfect for soaking up broth.

For a while, conversation is mostly the quiet, content noises of people who have been

hungry and now aren’t.

Eventually, Mera sets her spoon down, cups her tea between both hands, and looks over at

you.

“So,” she says, not prying but definitely inviting, “you’ve had a day.”

Harlin snorts softly into his cup.

“Enchanted on your hands, carpenters in your tomorrow, the elder’s eye on you, and you

still found time to sit by the statue,” he says. “Busy for someone who arrived with nothing

but a shirt and a headache.”

He tips his head slightly, watching you over the rim of his cup.

“If you feel like talking about how it went with Impa and the others, we’re listening,” he

adds. “If you’d rather just talk about tea and gloves, we can do that too.”

He doesn’t push beyond that—just lays the space out in front of you.

Around you, the inn hums quietly: the Zora trader murmur-speaks with Ollie in low tones,

another pair of villagers argue amiably about crop yields, someone laughs too loudly at a

joke near the door. Outside, through the window slats, the sky has gone streaky with

orange and violet; lantern light reflects faintly off the Zora’s damp skin, off the gloss of

your tea.

You’ve got hot food in your belly, warmth in your hands, and two people across the table

who chose to make room for you in their evening. What you tell them—or don’t—next is

yours to decide.

In spite of not caring for the taste of carrots, I appreciate the stew. *Two for two for the stew,* I think to myself. And I absolutely adore the tea, taking frequent, small sips, trying to simultaneously drink it slowly so I can savour it and quickly because I like it so much. I've never had a barley-based tea, but I have had hojicha and sakura before, and while not the same, this reminds me of it. I could never get tired of hojicha tea, and I think I could never tire of this either. But then, I had never doubted that Kakariko would impress in the tea department.

As I eat I look frequently at the Zora, trying to drink in every fascinating detail while also trying to avoid staring. I realise that Harlin and Mera probably already know me well enough to catch my subtle enthrallment, but I don't want to catch the attention of the other patrons--and definitely not the Zora.

I let Mera and Harlin's words tear me away from my target

of study, and put the almost empty cup of tea down on the table. "I did have a day, it's true. The work at Enchanted wasn't super hard, to be honest, and I actually enjoyed it. Can't say that if you'd told me I'd be in Hyrule today that 'getting a job', would be the first thing I'd be after, but...well...I can't afford *not* to be busy right now, right?"

Thought for 10s

Shuteye Inn – corner table • Day 2, early evening • Lantern glow, bowls mostly empty

Harlin nods slowly as you talk, spoon moving through what’s left of his stew more out of

habit than hunger now.

“Work helps,” he says. “Gives your hands something to do while your head catches up. If

you sit still too long after a big change, your thoughts start chewing on themselves.”

He taps his spoon once against the rim of the bowl, a little metallic tik.

“Besides,” he adds, “Hyrule doesn’t owe any of us a living. If she’s paying you for a day’s

effort, you’re already ahead of the bargain.”

Mera smiles over her cup.

“And Enchanted is hardly the worst place to land,” she says. “If Claree didn’t throw you out

after an hour, that’s as good as a recommendation letter.”

She leans in conspiratorially. “And if Lasli likes you, that’s two. She doesn’t say it, but she

gets lonely in there. Most of the village aunties just come to gossip and sigh at fabrics

they’re not going to buy.”

Your gaze drifts again to the Zora. You catch more this time:

Their skin isn’t just “blue” up close—it’s layered. Paler along the chest and inner arms,

deeper along the back and fin-edges. The head-fin starts in a smooth slope from brow to

nape, ending in twin points that drape like a hood; a strip of darker pigment runs along

the ridge. Small gill slits pulse faintly at the base of the neck as they breathe. Their eyes are

large, irises a soft gold, reflective in the lantern light. When they reach for their cup,

webbing stretches briefly between long fingers, then relaxes.

Gold-and-coral bangles clink softly at one wrist when they move. Their pack, propped by

the wall, shows edges of waterproofed cloth, metal clasps carved with wave patterns, and

what looks like a carefully wrapped spear-haft poking from one side.

Mera follows your line of sight for a moment, then back to you.

“First time seeing a Zora up close?” she asks quietly, more amused than teasing. “We get

one or two a month now. Used to be hardly any before the Calamity ended. They’ve got

some agreement with the guard captain about using our wells and keeping the square

from turning into a splash-fest.”

Harlin huffs.

“Lio’s all right,” he says, nodding toward the trader. “Buys oil, sells salt and dried fish.

Smells like a dock when he opens his pack, but he pays fair. He’ll be gone by mid-morning,

most likely. Doesn’t like to be far from flowing water for long.”

He shrugs one shoulder.

“Travel’s picked up everywhere since the Knight did his work,” he goes on. “Even tucked-

away valleys like this don’t get to stay sleepy forever.”

He drains the last of his tea, sets the cup down with a satisfied little sigh.

Ollie circulates with a small tray, collecting empty bowls and refilling cups with hot water

or more tea as requested. When he reaches your table, he hesitates.

“Do you… want a little more?” he asks you, eyeing your nearly empty bowl and cup. “We’ve

got enough stew for one more ladle each, I think. And there’s still hot water on the coals.”

Harlin gives you a sidelong glance that says take it if you need it; no one here is counting

spoons against you.

Your body’s verdict:

Stomach: pleasantly full but with just enough room that “another half-bowl” sounds

more tempting than threatening.

Muscles: loosening in the warmth, the day’s work sinking in as a heavy comfort rather

than sharp fatigue.

Head: slower, fuzzier around the edges in a way that says you’ll sleep hard wherever

you end up lying down.

Outside the inn, a cicada starts its evening buzz; someone slides a door shut with a

wooden clack. The sky beyond the window slats has gone properly twilight now, blue

deepening, first stars pricking through.

Mera cradles her cup again, watching you over the rim.

“Tomorrow you start with Tasho?” she asks. “You’ll want a proper night’s rest if he’s putting

you on a roof.”

Harlin snorts softly at that, but he doesn’t argue.

“We’ll make sure you get those blankets before we turn in,” he says. “And if the night gets

too loud, or too cold, the inn’s door isn’t exactly a fortress. Ollie will grumble, but he’ll

open it.”

He leaves it there, the invitation—and the tray with Ollie’s expectant look—waiting for

whatever you decide to do next.

My meals have been a little lighter than I'm accustomed to since I'd arrived, and the thought of just a little extra stew is definitely appealing. But I feel the light weight of my precious few rupees in my pocket. I look at my bowl and then look to Ollie, somewhat afraid to ask if I make a fool of myself, but not having a lot of choice. "Maybe...um...how much would that run me...?"

Shuteye Inn – corner table • Day 2, early evening • Stew steam, lanternlight soft

Ollie blinks, then shakes his head quickly, almost horrified.

“N-no, no, it’s not— I mean, you’ve already paid for the meal,” he says. “The pot’s on, the

bowls are out. A little more’s not going to ruin us.”

He glances at Harlin and Mera, like he’s checking he hasn’t overstepped. Harlin gives a

small, permissive tilt of his hand; Mera’s mouth quirks into a smile.

Ollie relaxes a fraction.

“If we were scraping the bottom, I’d say so,” he adds, tone softening. “But we’re not. You

look like you could use another half-bowl more than the pot needs to look pretty.”

He lifts your bowl carefully, holding it low so as not to drip on the tatami.

“I’ll just— I’ll bring you a bit. No extra charge. Tea refills are free so long as you don’t drink

the whole well dry.”

He flashes a quick, awkward smile and heads back toward the kitchen corner, collecting

Harlin’s empty bowl on the way. Mera covers her grin with her cup until he’s out of

earshot.

“Honestly,” she murmurs, “if you’d paid for extra stew he might have cried. Innkeeper’s

son, big heart, no sense of what things should cost.”

Harlin gives a quiet huff of agreement.

“He’d feed half the valley on credit if his mother let him,” he says. “Let him be generous

while the pot’s still got something in it.”

A few moments later Ollie returns with a refill: not brimming, but generous enough—a

ladle and a half of stew, freshened from the top of the pot so the vegetables still have

some bite. He sets it down with care.

“There you go,” he says. “Eat up. Tasho’s lot will work you like a mule if you show up

looking underfed.”

The sakura tea in your cup has cooled to a pleasant warmth; its scent still hangs in the air

above it. The extra stew lands in your stomach with the exact right weight: enough to push

you from “satisfied” toward “truly full,” but not so much you feel heavy.

Around you, the inn has shifted another notch toward night: more tables taken, low

conversations overlapping, someone in the corner quietly tuning a shamisen-like

instrument. Outside, through the slats, the last of the light has drained from the sky; the

lanterns now carry most of the illumination.

When the bowls are finally cleared and you’ve drunk the last of the tea, Harlin stretches

with a quiet groan, then gets to his feet.

“We’ll go up and claim our room before someone mistakes it for storage,” he says. “Ollie’ll

throw a fit if we sleep in the common room again when he’s gone to the trouble of

making beds.”

Mera stands as well, pressing her palms into the small of her back for a second.

“I’ll grab those blankets for you on the way,” she says. “Meet us by the cart in a bit? We’ll

get you set up before we fall over.”

They leave the table with the casual certainty of people who know exactly where they’re

going and exactly how tired they are.

The inn hums on as you sit a moment longer: the Zora trader finishing his meal, Ollie

ferrying dishes, the soft twang of strings being tested in the corner. Your body is warm,

fed, pleasantly heavy-limbed; your pockets still hold a few precious rupees, untouched by

tonight’s extra generosity.

When you rise, the floor creaks softly under your weight. The night outside waits: wagon

boards, blankets, the sounds of Kakariko after dark—your second sleep in this world, this

time under open sky rather than stable rafters.

I nod and give an undignified but friendly "mmhm!" through my mouthful of food as Harlin and Mera excuse themselves from the table. As they leave I scarf down the rest of the stew and then take my bowl and tea cup over to where Ollie--and the Zora, Lio--are near the counter. I'm sure I'll put my foot in my mouth, but at this point I

can't stop myself.

I offer Ollie the bowl and tea cup, using them as an excuse to come over here. "Thank you very much for the food. Sorry if I asked dumb questions. You, uh, you said there was some more tea available?"

Shuteye Inn – by the counter • Day 2, early evening shading toward night • Lanterns

bright, outside dark

Ollie takes your bowl and cup like you’ve handed him a delicate artifact, not dishes that

just held stew.

“N-no, no, it wasn’t dumb,” he says quickly. “Some folks try to get three extra ladles

without asking. You’re ahead of the curve.”

He sets the bowl with the others in a tub behind the counter, then reaches for the teapot.

“There’s still hot water,” he adds, lifting it slightly so you can see the steam. “I can top you

up. It won’t be as strong as the first brew, but it’s warm, at least.”

He moves to refill your cup.

You’re close enough now to get a proper look at the Zora.

Lio sits on a cushion at the end of the counter, posture very straight, long tail-fin draped

neatly behind. Up close, their skin looks almost lacquered where the lanternlight hits it:

sleek blue shading to a paler tone along the jaw and inner arms. Faint, pearly speckles run

along the cheekbones and shoulders like someone dusted them with ground shell.

Their eyes are large and golden, pupils a narrow vertical slit that widens and narrows with

the light. A thin silver ring pierces the thin membrane of one fin near the jawline. The coral

jewelry at their wrist is carved into tiny wave-crests, the metal fittings etched with the Zora

domain’s swirl motifs.

They’ve been pretending not to watch, but as you come over and mention tea, one

smooth brow ridge lifts.

“Barley and blossom,” Lio says, voice low and liquid, with a faint, almost musical accent. “A

good choice. Better than the bitter leaf-water they serve in some stables.”

Ollie flushes faintly.

“I like the leaf-water,” he mutters, then remembers himself. “Ah— Zeth, this is Lio. Lio, this

is… the, um, carpenter I mentioned. The one who came in with Harlin’s cart.”

He winces a little, realizing he’s just shoved you into an introduction without warning.

Lio turns slightly on the cushion to face you more directly, giving you the full effect of Zora

posture: poised, precise, like every movement is being done on purpose.

“You have the hands of someone who lifts more than bowls,” they observe, flicking a

glance at your gloves and the bit of wrist visible beyond them. “Ollie says you arrived with

empty pockets and full manners. That is… an interesting combination.”

Their tone isn’t mocking—more curious, amused in a gentle way.

Ollie tops off your cup and slides it toward you on the counter.

“There you go,” he says. “On the house. I— we’re closing the kitchen soon, but you’re

welcome to sit a little longer if you want to warm up before the cart.”

The fresh hot water brings the ghost of the sakura scent back up from the leaves: softer

now, but still present.

Lio wraps long fingers around their own cup, webbing stretching and relaxing.

“If you are working with Tasho’s crew tomorrow,” they add, “you will be glad of anything

warm in your belly tonight. His roofs are… demanding.”

Their golden eyes stay on you, calm and steady, giving you room to reply or retreat

without pressing. The lanterns crackle softly in their paper shades; from outside, a night

insect trills, and somewhere upstairs a floorboard creaks as someone crosses to their

room.

I thank Ollie for the extra hot water and cradle my own cup similarly to Lio. "I just hope I can keep up," I say to the Zora. "I know the trade, but not the local. Different sort of workmanship, but one I've always admired. I'll be glad to learn it better." I gesture to a cushion beside him. "Do you mind a few minutes of company?" I figure I might have just a little bit of time before Mera returned with the blankets, though I wasn't sure exactly how much. I doubt it takes that long to pull out a few blankets, but I simply had to experience the presence of the Zora.

Thought for 7s

Shuteye Inn – by the counter • Day 2, early night • Lanterns bright, outside deep blue

Lio inclines their head in a graceful little nod at your gesture.

“I do not mind,” they say. “The floor is kinder with a cushion between.”

They shift slightly to give you space. Up close on the neighboring cushion, you catch more

of the details the distance softened:

The skin along their neck and collarbones is a paler, almost opalescent blue, shading

deeper toward the shoulders. Faint lines along the gill slits flare and flatten as they

breathe. The fin-fringe along their forearms is thin and translucent at the edges, veined

like a leaf when the lantern light hits it. Their scent is subtle but distinct: clean water, salt,

and a hint of river stone baked warm.

They listen while you talk about carpentry, golden eyes steady over the rim of their cup.

“Joinery is a language,” Lio says after a sip. “Your hands know one dialect. Tasho will teach

you another. The wood only cares that you listen when it complains.”

The corner of their mouth—more a change in the line of the jaw than lips—quirks faintly.

For a Zora, that reads as a dry smile.

“I was first set to learning how to mend boat ribs when I was your age,” they add. “I also

thought I knew the trade. The river corrected me. It is a patient teacher, but… not always a

gentle one.”

They tilt their head slightly, studying you.

“You move like someone who has carried beams before,” they say. “But you look at me the

way some villagers look at the mountains. Have you not seen a Zora up close until today?”

There’s no offense in it; just curiosity, honest and open.

Upstairs, a door slides shut with a wooden hiss. A moment later there’s the muffled thump

of footsteps on the short hallway, then on the stairs. Mera appears, coming down with a

bundle of folded blankets in her arms—two thick woven ones and a thinner, softer layer

for on top.

She spots you by the counter, slows her steps a little when she notices Lio, then continues

over, shifting the blankets so she can tuck one under an elbow and adjust her scarf with

her free hand.

“Got you three layers,” she says to you. “Should keep the night off, unless the wind decides

to misbehave.”

Her gaze flicks politely to Lio.

“Lio,” she adds, with a small nod. “You trading long enough to freeze with us, or swimming

off at dawn?”

Lio inclines their head in return.

“Off with the morning light,” they say. “Zora Domain waits. The river does not like to be

kept wondering where I am.”

Mera huffs a quiet, amused breath through her nose, then looks back to you, blankets still

in her arms.

“Whenever you’re ready,” she says, “we’ll get you set up in the cart before Harlin falls

asleep sitting up. He’s already halfway to snoring in his tea.”

Through the open door, the night air lies cool and dark beyond the lantern’s warm

rectangle. The sounds from outside are thinner now: a few last voices, the creak of a cart

wheel somewhere, the chorus of insects starting up in earnest.

Mera waits, easy and unhurried, clearly happy to let you finish what you’re saying to Lio or

drain the last of your tea before she shepherds you out to your makeshift bed for Night 2.

I accept the blankets a bit awkwardly, piling them on my lap. "Oh, thanks Mera. Don't feel like you need to escort me though, I can take care of it. You and Harlin should get some rest."

Thought for 5s

Shuteye Inn → Kakariko square, cart • Day 2, early night • Lanterns bright, air turning crisp

Mera shifts the blankets as you take them, making sure the thinner one ends up on top of

the stack.

“Mm. Maybe I should rest,” she says, “but if I let you wander off with half the inn’s bedding

and then you fall asleep on the steps instead of the cart, Harlin will blame me.”

There’s a smile in it, not scolding—just that gentle, practical fussing she can’t seem to help.

She gives Lio another small nod.

“Sleep well when you get there,” she says. “Try not to drown Ollie in trade talk.”

Lio’s fin-fringe flicks, amusement in the movement.

“I will be gone before your sun is high,” they reply. “May your roofs hold and your roads

stay clear.”

Then Mera tilts her head toward the door.

“Come on,” she says to you. “At least as far as the cart. After that, you can decide which

blanket gets the honor of being between you and the boards.”

Outside, the night hits cooler than the inn: not biting, but enough that you feel the

difference on your damp skin. The sky overhead is a deep, rich blue-black, more stars

visible here than most modern cities on your old world ever allowed. A sliver of moon

hangs low over the hills, silvering the edges of the terraced fields.

The square has quieted.

Most shop shutters are closed; a few lanterns still burn under eaves, casting small islands

of warm light onto the lane. Insects sing from the grasses beyond the last houses.

Somewhere up on the slope, a cucco mutters in its sleep. The falls’ roar is lower now, more

of a constant, distant shush.

Harlin’s cart sits where you left it, drawn a little off to one side of the square. The horse is

gone—stabled for the night—but the wagon itself is the same mix of solid and worn: plank

bed, high sides, wheels chocked with stones. Your scavenged sword and makeshift buckler

still rest inside, shifted toward the front where they won’t roll.

Mera walks with you to the cart, then pauses, letting you take the lead. In the lanternspill

from the inn, her face looks softer, shadows rounding the lines at the corners of her mouth

and eyes.

“Here,” she says, reaching to pluck the top blanket off your stack and give it a brisk shake

to loosen the folds. “Thickest one on the bottom, then you, then this softer one on top. If

the wind picks up, tuck the corners under you so it doesn’t steal your covers.”

She lays the bottom blanket across the wagon bed in a rough rectangle, patting it once

with the flat of her hand.

“There,” she says. “It’s not a feather bed, but it beats bare wood. We’ll be just upstairs if

anything goes sideways.”

She steps back, dusting her palms together, satisfied.

“Sleep well, Zeth,” she adds. “You’ve earned it today. And you’re going to need it if Tasho

has you hauling rafters at first light.”

With that, she gives you a last, small, tired smile and heads back toward the inn, sandals

whispering over the packed earth. The door slides open, spilling light and voices for a

second, then closes again, leaving you with:

The cart.

The layered blankets.

Your sword and jury-rigged buckler.

The night sounds of Kakariko, Day 2 closing around you.

Lanterns gutter a little in the breeze, stars prick crisp overhead, and the wagon bed waits

for however you decide to make it into a temporary home.

I reluctantly allow Mera to drag me away from Lio, mentally protesting in a way she can't see or hear the entire way. Or maybe she already knew and wanted to spare Lio my idiot stares and embarrassing questions.

Out at the cart, I follow her directions and give her a hug before she returns to the inn. Climbing into the cart, I wrap the blankets around me like a cocoon and feel grateful that I have the space to myself. I may already count Harlin and Mera as friends, but I wouldn't have gotten much sleep sharing the space with them and laying awake thinking about inconveniencing them somehow. I also actually prefer a firm surface to sleep on over a soft one, so the thick, heavy blanket on the wagon boards doesn't seem nearly as bad to me as other people might think. And my Hylian neck doesn't seem to have any of the protestations and aches that my human one had.

Despite the fact that it was true that the work I did today at Enchanted hardly felt like any real kind of strain, I was dead tired. Likely just bottled anxiety and mental fatigue from the audience with Impa and the embarrassment of angering Dorian. I disliked myself for upsetting him so much, and while I knew that Impa's decision was actually

more blessing than malediction, having my freedom restricted still managed to feel like a scolding. Like I was child being grounded. I push the thought from my mind though, and try to focus on the positive. That Dorian wasn't treating me like I was his enemy, and that Impa had basically impressed on the village that they should treat me with 'kid gloves' in some wordless way that she had at her disposal.

I stare at the top of the cart feeling many other thoughts and questions buzzing around my brain like angered hornets, but not bothering to focus on any of them. If I did, I would probably only find some way of worrying. Better to allow the childlike fascination with the world and its people have its way and feel good.

As I start drifting, I wonder if I'll catch another glimpse of Lio before he departed tomorrow. It probably wouldn't matter if I did, since I'd be busy working. I felt a embarrassed--again--that my conversation with him was basically ended with him asking if I'd ever seen a Zora before. Lio didn't seem to mind, but it just felt sort of wrong to me. Another social faux pas.

*Just focus on the positive. Stay in the moment.* I think to myself. *Let each day be its own day.*

I force my eyes closed and try to sleep.

Thought for 7s

Kakariko square – in the cart • Night 2 • Clear sky, air cool and dry

The cart rocks once as you settle, then goes still.

The bottom blanket blunts the worst of the boards; they’re firm under your shoulders but

not cruel. The top layer traps your body heat fast, turning the wagon bed into a narrow,

rough-edged nest. The smell of old wood, canvas, and horse-sweat clings faintly to the

planks, softened now by the cleaner scent of washed wool from the blankets.

Outside the cart’s rails, Kakariko exhales into night.

Lanterns along the main lane gutter down to embers one by one. A few stay lit—soft

glows under eaves where someone prefers company against the dark—but the square

mostly cedes the scene to starlight. Crickets and other night insects take over the

soundscape, a steady, layered chirring. The waterfall becomes a low, constant rush, like

distant wind.

Boots scrape softly on stone at intervals: one of Cado’s patrols doing a lazy circuit, spear-

butt ticking every few steps. They pause near the square once, long enough to clock the

cart, you inside, the blankets. A brief silhouette against the inn’s dim light, then they move

on, satisfied.

Overhead, the stars are ridiculous.

The sky here doesn’t have the pale smear of light pollution your old nights did.

Constellations you half-recognize from the game’s skybox sit alongside ones you definitely

never saw on any OLED display. The moon rides higher now, a pale curve above the

terraced hills, silvering the cart’s rails and the edges of nearby roofs.

Beneath the blankets, muscles finally give up the day: shoulders loosening, hands

uncurling in their own time. The lingering tea warmth in your belly fades, replaced by a

calmer, heavier heat your body makes for itself. The aches from lifting, bracing, walking

hills all layer into one dull, even throb that morphs, slowly, into the background hum of

used but not broken.

Thoughts swarm, then blur. The top of the cart ceases to be boards and turns into just

“dark,” then “nothing” at all.

Sleep gets you.

—

Kakariko square – in the cart • Day 3, dawn • Sky pale, breath misting faintly

You surface to cold air on your face and warmth from the neck down.

The world is grey-blue when you blink your eyes open: that thin, pre-sunlight that makes

everything look softer and flatter. The inn’s lanterns are out; only a couple of small

household lamps still burn here and there on upper floors. The square is mostly empty—

no shoppers, no carts—just a couple of early risers ghosting along the lane with baskets.

Your breath fogs faintly when you exhale. The tip of your nose protests the chill; your ears

tingle a little in the open air. Under the blankets, though, your core is warm and damp with

sleep-heat. The lower blanket’s taken on the shape of your body; the upper one is twisted

just enough to tell you you moved around in the night.

Your back is… surprisingly fine.

There’s stiffness, sure—your spine reports that it spent the night on something closer to a

plank than a mattress—but it’s the clean stiffness of a camp sleep, not the grinding,

familiar complaint your old neck used to serve up every morning. Your feet feel the ghost

of yesterday’s miles when you flex them, but no real pain. Your hands, when you wriggle

them free to test them in the cold air, twinge where the blisters sit, but the gloves did their

job—no new damage.

Somewhere up on the terraces, a cucco cuts loose with the first proper crow of the

morning. Another answers, one terrace over. A moment later, another patrol boot-scrape

passes by: slower this time, more of a “sweep up the last of night” than a “ward off

trouble.”

The sky over the valley’s rim is going pale gold at the edges, the promise of the sun about

to clear the hills.

From the direction of the lower terraces, you catch the distant thunk of wood on wood,

then voices—low, carrying oddly well in the still air. Sounds like someone down there

believes “first light” means “actually first light.”

Your sword and rough shield are where you left them in the cart, cool under your fingers

when you reach out. The blankets are still yours to arrange or abandon as you climb out.

Day 3 is starting: breath steaming, village stretching awake, work waiting somewhere

between the cart and Tasho’s worksite.

I crawl out from the cart and stretch, yawning. Then I do the sensible thing and loosely fold my blankets and makeshift bedding. I know they'll just get unfolded anyways to be washed, but it still seems like a nice thing to do. I take them to the inn and open the door as quietly as I can. I don't know if Ollie--or somebody else, I also have no idea if he's a one-man show at the inn or trades shifts with someone else--will already be tending to things in the common area or not. I figure if he or someone else is there, I can return the blankets. If not, I'd leave them on the counter.

I also decide to see if the inn provides any sort of breakfast arrangements as it does dinner. All I know is modern American hotels, and have no idea what to expect from a Hyrulean inn loosely inspired by medieval Japan.

Thought for 10s

Shuteye Inn – common room • Day 3, dawn • Air cool, room dim and steamy at the edges

The blankets are a little chilly on your arms as you carry them, but your core’s still warm

from sleep. The square is mostly empty; only a couple of early risers pad past with baskets.

The inn’s door is shut, a faint rectangle of warmer darkness behind the paper.

You slide it open carefully.

The common room is dimmer than last night, lit only by a single lantern on a wall-hook

and the dull orange glow of coals in the kitchen nook. The air is already warmer than

outside, carrying the smells of soaked rice, hot water, and something savory just starting

to cook.

Ollie is up.

He’s at one of the low tables with a stack of bowls, hair tied back in a short, messy knot,

sleeves already rolled. Without the full evening rush to distract him, he looks younger—

late teens, maybe—dark circles faint under his eyes. There’s a little smear of soot along

one wrist where he’s clearly been tending the coals.

When the door opens, he looks up fast, then relaxes when he recognizes you.

“Morning,” he says, keeping his voice low. “You’re up early.”

As you step in, you can see past him into the kitchen corner for the first time:

An older Sheikah woman stands over a pot hung above the coals, stirring with a long

wooden spoon. She’s compact and sturdy, grey hair pulled into a tight bun, sleeves tied

back with cloth cords. Steam curls around her face, lending her an almost ghostly outline

until she shifts. A faint tattoo of the Sheikah eye sits at the corner of her neck, half-hidden

by her collar.

She gives you a brief, assessing look, then nods once—a silent “you’re fine, carry on”—and

goes back to her pot.

Ollie notices the blankets in your arms and straightens hurriedly, stepping around the

table.

“Oh— right, the bedding,” he says. “How was it? The cart not too drafty?”

He reaches to take the stack from you, careful not to drop any.

“Thanks for folding them,” he adds, a small, genuinely pleased note in his voice. “Most folk

leave them in a pile that looks like they fought a Hinox in their sleep.”

He tucks the blankets over one arm, clearly intending to take them through to the back in

a moment.

The pot over the coals burps a little puff of thickened steam. The smell is clearer now: rice

porridge, thinned to a breakfast consistency, with something else layered in—maybe miso,

maybe a mild broth. On the counter beside it sit a small dish of bright pickles and a jar of

what looks like shredded dried fish.

Ollie follows your glance toward the kitchen.

“We do a simple breakfast,” he says, anticipating the question. “Rice porridge, some

pickles, tea. Leftover stew if there’s any and you don’t mind it in the morning.”

He gives an apologetic little shrug.

“It’s not like the big inns in Hateno,” he adds. “No separate fancy menu. Just… what we’ve

got in the pot.”

He shifts the blankets to his other arm.

“If you want a bowl before you go down to the carpenters, we can manage that,” he says.

“You… ah… didn’t pay for breakfast with yesterday’s room, but I can do a cheaper morning

bowl for folks who slept under our roof. Or cart,” he amends, with a quick, lopsided smile.

Behind him, the older woman snorts softly—approving, by the sound of it—and drops

another pinch of something into the pot.

The coals crackle. The lantern’s small flame flickers. The room smells like warm grain and

the first cup of tea waiting to happen, and the light outside the door is just starting to shift

from grey to pale gold as Day 3 properly thinks about beginning.

"Good morning," I return, handing over the stack of blankets. "Cart wasn't drafty at all. Slept quite well. Thank you for asking." I look at the pot, curious to see how the porridge here compared to what I had from Pella back at the stables yesterday. "And a quick bite of porridge sounds just dandy. I'd love some tea too, but might have to skip that. Don't want to work on an empty stomach but don't want to be late either."

Shuteye Inn – common room • Day 3, just after dawn • Coals glowing, steam thickening

Ollie brightens a little when you agree to porridge.

“That’s easy,” he says. “Porridge doesn’t argue with the clock.”

He passes the blankets off to a peg by the kitchen doorway, then grabs a clean bowl and

moves to the pot. The older woman gives him a brief, approving nod as he ladles out a

generous portion: rice loosened with broth into a smooth, thick consistency. He tops it

with a small spoon of shredded dried fish and a fan of bright-pink pickled radish on the

rim.

“Here,” he says, setting the bowl at the nearest low table. “It’s hot, so maybe don’t inhale it

too fast.”

As he’s talking, the older woman takes a small teapot from near the coals and brings it

over herself. Up close, you can see more of her: short and solid, crow’s-feet at the corners

of her dark eyes, a faint burn scar along one hand that’s long-since healed to a lighter

patch of skin. Her hair’s more silver than black, pinned tight so it won’t fall in the food.

She sets a cup beside your bowl and fills it halfway with a steady hand. The scent is plain

roasted barley this time—no blossom, just warm, nutty grain.

“Tea is faster to drink than to fret over,” she says, voice dry but not unkind. “You have time

for both if you use your mouth for chewing, not talking.”

There’s the ghost of a smile at the edge of her mouth as she turns away, already moving

back toward the kitchen.

The porridge is simple and satisfying: soft rice with a mild, savory depth from the broth,

the dried fish adding salt and texture, the pickles cutting through with a sharp, vinegary

crunch. It eats quickly without feeling rushed—heat warming you from the inside out,

sitting heavy in a good way.

The barley tea washes it down with that toasty, almost breadlike flavor. It’s not as special

as last night’s sakura brew, but it fits the hour: plain, steady, easy.

By the time you scrape the last grains from the bowl, the grey outside the doorway has

turned to honest morning light. Sounds drift in: distant voices down in the lower terraces,

the more rhythmic thump of wood from Tasho’s direction, and a cucco that clearly thinks

everyone should already be up.

Ollie swings past to collect your empty bowl and cup.

“You’re clear with Impa and Cado now, right?” he asks, keeping his voice low. “Just…

wanted to be sure I won’t get yelled at for feeding a fugitive.”

He grins quickly to show he’s joking—mostly—and then nods toward the door.

“The carpenters start early,” he says. “If you go now, you’ll get there just in time to look like

you meant it.”

Outside, Day 3 is properly awake: breath fogging just a little in the cool air, sun starting to

clear the ridge, and the path down toward the worksite already calling your legs back into

service.

I thank Ollie and the woman as they serve and then try to eat quickly, but not so much as to be rude. I enjoy the porridge itself, but make myself eat the fish and pickled radish out of politeness, careful not to let anything but contentment show on my face. I like fish. I like pickles and radishes. But I've never cared to have them for the first meal of the day. Always felt like later-day types of food to me. I delight in the tea, of course, and then take Ollie's cue.

As I near the door to leave I turn to Ollie briefly, again. "When you see Harlin and Mera, would you mind letting them know where I am? Don't want to keep Tasho waiting, but I'd hate it if they left the village without getting to say a proper good-bye." I wait briefly for his response before I go, wanting to grab my sword and shield from the cart before heading to the jobsite so that they wouldn't get in Harlin and Mera's way.

Thought for 11s

Shuteye Inn – common room → square → carpenters’ worksite

Day 3, early morning • Air crisp, light soft gold

Ollie pauses mid-step when you call to him, then nods quickly.

“I’ll tell them,” he says. “Harlin’ll come down this way for feed before he leaves, he always

does. I’ll make sure he knows you’re with Tasho, not… I don’t know… eaten by cuccos.”

The older woman gives a quiet, approving grunt at that.

“Working with Tasho is better than loafing under my tables,” she adds without looking up.

“We’ll tell your friends you’re earning your butter.”

Outside, the cool hits your face again, but the sun’s just starting to clear the ridge now,

laying a pale line of light along the upper roofs. You cross the square to the cart, breath

puffing faintly in front of you.

The wagon sits much as you left it, just without blankets: empty bed, a bit of dew beaded

along the rails, your sword and “shield” where you’d nudged them toward the front. The

metal of the blade is cold enough to sting a little when you grip it bare-handed; the

canvas-wrapped sliver of shield is clammy with overnight moisture.

There’s no way to wear the sword properly yet—no belt, no scabbard—so you do what

you can: hand on hilt, blade angled inoffensively, shield hooked over one forearm. At this

hour, nobody bats an eye at someone moving through the village with tools of defense;

the only people awake are the ones who understand work and danger come early.

The lane down toward the lower terraces is busier than the square: a woman with a basket

of laundry heading for the stream, a boy trotting past with a bundle of firewood, a man

jogging lightly in what’s clearly his morning routine. They give you the brief, assessing

looks reserved for “new but not currently suspicious,” then go back to their own paths.

By the time you reach the carpenters’ corner, the sound of work is already steady.

Carpenters’ worksite – lower terraces

Day 3, early morning • Sun low, shadows long, wood scent sharp

The half-repaired house is framed in early light now. Dew still clings to the exposed rafters,

catching the sun in tiny sparks. The air smells strongly of fresh-cut cedar and damp earth.

Tasho is on the ground this time, not the roof, standing with arms folded as he inspects a

newly set beam. The morning light picks out more lines on his weathered face, the white in

his hair almost gleaming. His shirt is already dusted with sawdust, as if he’s been at it since

the sky was more purple than blue.

Rinna is up on the veranda roof where he’d been yesterday, one foot braced on a rafter,

the other on a temporary plank. From this angle you can see the strength in her legs,

corded with muscle from climbing and balancing on beams. She’s using a mallet to nudge

a joint into its final fit, each blow precise and controlled.

Sef is at the workbench again, but this morning he’s drilling rather than planing: an auger

turning in his hands, shoulders working, shavings spiraling out from a clean hole in a beam

laid across trestles. His hair is damp and slicked back, as if he dunked his head in cold

water not long ago to finish waking up.

Tasho spots you as you step into the edge of their space. His eyes flick to the sword and

canvas disk, then back to your face. He gives a short, approving nod—more to “you

showed when you said you would” than anything you’re carrying.

“Good,” he says. “You meant it.”

He jerks his chin toward a stack of timber near the workbench.

“Set your steel down where it won’t trip anyone,” he says, “then come here. We’ll start with

something that won’t drop you on your head if you get it wrong.”

Rinna glances over from the roof, gives you a quick, tight grin of greeting.

“Morning,” she calls. “Hope you like the smell of cedar. You’re going to be living in it for a

while.”

Sef pauses with the auger halfway through a turn and offers a small wave, shy but

genuine, before going back to his hole.

Tasho moves toward the stack of timbers, one hand already reaching for a marked beam,

ready to show you exactly what your first task of Day 3 is going to be.

I tuck my two items off to the side and pull my gloves from my pocket, pulling them over my hands. I smile up at Rinna. "I *love* the smell of cedar." Getting a better look at Rinna today, I can't help but feel a little childish. I thought

Lasli was pretty--and she was--but that came from a predisposition. From the character I had seen in the game. Rinna was something else. I had not known her before and she instantly made an impression with her worker's physique, tanned skin and freckles. She was taller than Lasli too--almost my height, which is...tall. I was mildly starstruck by Lasli. I was attracted to Rinna. I'd be lying to myself if I said otherwise.

I push the thought as far as I can to the back of my mind though. I didn't need to screw things up by acting like an infatuated little boy. I was here to work. So I set myself to it, and did my best to match the crew's workflow.

Thought for 8s

Lower terraces – carpenters’ worksite • Day 3, early morning • Sun low, cedar sharp in the

cool air

The gloves slide on with that familiar little creak, leather already molding closer to your

hands than yesterday. When you answer Rinna, her grin widens just a touch, the freckles

across her nose bunching.

“Good,” she says. “You’ll like us, then.”

From up on the roof, in full morning light, she’s even more striking than she’d been in

motion yesterday: tall for a Sheikah woman, only a little shorter than you, shoulders broad

from years of lifting, arms roped with lean muscle. Her tan isn’t the fashionable kind; it’s

the “works outside in all seasons” kind, with deeper color on her forearms and cheeks.

Dark hair is braided tight and bound up off her neck, a few shorter wisps escaping around

her temples. The brick-red eye markings stand out against sun-browned skin, softened by

the scattering of freckles.

Tasho plants a foot against a beam and drags it out of the stack with a grunt, bringing

your attention back where it needs to be.

“Right,” he says. “We’ll see what you can do without dropping anything on your toes.”

The beam he’s pulled is about as long as you are tall, squared and already dressed smooth

on all faces. One end is marked with charcoal lines: a rectangle drawn on one face and

wrapping around, clean and dark.

“You said you know nails,” he says. “Here, the frame mostly holds itself up. Nails are for

when we don’t trust the ground or the people.”

He drops down into a crouch with the ease of habit and raps the charcoal box with his

knuckles.

“This’ll be a tenon,” he says. “Tongue that fits into a mouth in the next piece. If you cut it

wrong, you get a loose, squeaky house or a joint that splits when it settles.”

He hauls the beam up onto trestles with your help—heavy, but manageable between the

two of you. The weight drags in your shoulders, your back, but the new gloves take the

bite of the corners, and you can feel your body falling into old patterns: lift with legs, not

spine; breathe with the effort, don’t brace and strain.

Tasho hands you a saw.

It’s a pull-saw rather than the push-saws you grew up with: long, thin blade, teeth that

lean back toward the handle, wooden grip wrapped in twine. The steel is thinner than you

expect; when you flex it experimentally, it sings a quiet, high note.

“You cut on the pull, not the push,” he says. “Let the teeth do the work. If you try to muscle

it like your own style, you’ll bend it and I’ll be annoyed.”

He draws the saw lightly along the line to start the kerf, then stops and offers it to you hilt-

first.

“Cut the shoulders,” he says. “Halfway down the beam, straight as your conscience. We’ll

see if you’re lying about knowing how to hold a line.”

The first few strokes are weird.

Your muscles want to push. The blade bucks a little when you forget and try to drive it

forward. When you remember to just draw it, the teeth bite in cleanly, making a soft,

almost silky shhk–shhk as they pull sawdust out of the cut. The line isn’t perfect, but it’s not

embarrassing either—your old experience shows through the new technique.

Rinna pauses her mallet work long enough to glance down and watch. When she sees you

adjust your stance and correct the angle on your own, she nods once and goes back to

nudging the roof joint into place.

Sef keeps drilling for a while longer, then Tasho calls him over.

“Trade out with him on the other shoulder,” Tasho tells him. “Let him see how you hold it.”

Sef’s closer in the morning light: lanky, early twenties maybe, with a narrow face and faint

stubble he definitely forgot to shave. His eye markings are thinner, more delicate lines;

there’s a small nick on one ear where something sharp got too close once. He takes the

saw from you in that careful two-handed way of his and sets up on the far line.

His cut is slower, but true—you can see he’s been drilled more on straightness than speed.

Watching him, you can overlay the different “dialects” of carpentry in your head: your old

world’s habits, Hylian tools, Sheikah priorities. The wood, Tasho said, doesn’t care which

language you use as long as you listen when it complains.

Once the shoulders are cut, Tasho pulls a chisel from his tool roll: broad-bladed, handle

wrapped in cloth, edge gleaming.

“Tenon cheeks next,” he says. “You ever chisel with the grain and not split the whole thing

in half?”

You have, but not with this exact tool, not on this exact wood. Still, the fundamentals carry.

He scribe-marks a line, shows you the first few taps—light at first, seating the chisel, then

heavier to pop out chunks of waste. The sound is a solid, satisfying tok–tok–tok as the

mallet hits the handle.

Then he steps back and lets you take over.

Your first few blows are too cautious; the chisel bites but doesn’t move much material.

When you commit a little more weight to it, the waste comes away in clean chips. You

nearly chase one split down too far, but catch yourself, easing up and coming in from the

other side. Your grip feels natural in a way it shouldn’t for tools you’ve never handled, that

mysterious muscle-knowledge threading the gap between worlds.

“You learn quick,” Tasho says, watching your hands. “Or someone in your family liked wood

and didn’t let you run away from it.”

He takes the chisel back, checks the tenon face-on, then side-on, thumbs the edge.

“Not bad,” he says. “We’ll fit it after we cut its mate. Sef—show him the mortise layout. If

either of you makes it sloppy, both of you get to fix it.”

The morning unfolds into a rhythm:

Marking beams with charcoal and a string dipped in ink, snapping straight lines that

leave black ghosts on pale wood.

Sawing shoulders and cheeks, swapping with Sef enough times that you start to feel

the pull-saw as less of an argument and more of a conversation.

Chiseling out mortises under Tasho’s watchful eye, your arms warming with the effort,

sweat starting at your back despite the cool air.

Hauling cut beams into place while Rinna guides them from above, her voice curt but

encouraging—“A little left. Stop. Down. Good.”

Your gloves earn every rupee: gripping damp wood, catching splinters that never reach

your skin, taking the abrasion instead of your palms. Under them, yesterday’s blisters

complain but don’t worsen.

Once, mid-task, Rinna drops lightly from the roof.

Up close on the ground, she’s even more substantial. There’s a faint white scar along one

forearm, a shallow groove like an old blade glanced there and healed. Sawdust clings to

the sweat at her throat; a streak of cedar smear has made a faint line along one cheek

where she wiped it with the back of her hand.

She takes the saw from you without preamble.

“Watch,” she says. “You’re still trying to push when you get tired. Let the blade do it.”

She plants her feet, shoulders stacked over hips, and runs the saw through a cut in a

smooth, economical rhythm—no wasted motion, the blade dead straight, teeth singing.

Then she hands it back.

“Like that,” she says. “When your arms burn, remember you’re not wrestling a boar, you’re

petting a cat with knives.”

The corner of her mouth kicks up at her own phrasing; then she’s back up the ladder,

mallet in hand, as if the gravity that glues everyone else to the ground has a slightly

weaker hold on her.

By mid-morning, sweat has dampened the back of your shirt despite the lingering chill.

Your shoulders have that pleasant, buzzing fatigue that says working but not yet

overworked. Sawdust dusts your gloves, your trousers, the tops of your boots. Cedar scent

has sunk into your clothes and hair.

Tasho finally calls a halt, wiping his forehead with the crook of one arm.

“Water,” he says. “Hands off the steel for a bit. If you start missing lines, I’ll blame thirst

and not stupidity.”

Sef drops his auger with obvious relief, rolling one shoulder. Rinna hops down from the

roof again, landing with a soft thump and a flex of knees that would make a younger

apprentice jealous.

They move toward a shaded corner where a water jar and cups sit on an upturned crate.

As you follow, you catch movement out of the corner of your eye up along the lane: a

cart’s silhouette, familiar horse, a flash of Mera’s scarf.

Harlin’s wagon is just visible between houses, angled as if it’s about to head up out of the

village… or making a last stop along the lower terraces before it goes.

The crew settles in the shade, hands reaching for water cups. Tasho glances toward the

road, then at you.

“Friends of yours?” he asks, not prying, just noticing. “If you’ve got a word to say before

they go, say it now. We’re not so cruel we won’t spare you five minutes.”

The water is cool in the jar, condensation beading along the ceramic. The sun has finally

cleared the ridge; shadows are still long, but the day is fully awake now.

Your tools are where you left them. Your sword and buckler are stacked near the trestles.

Harlin’s cart is a moving shape between the houses, not yet out of reach.

I accept the advice and direction on the pull-saw as its given, and eventually, after Rinna's mention of not fighting a boar, it finally clicks in my head that this isn't about making cuts of measured materials with a miter saw or push-saw, this is about shaping, like I used to with my coping saw, which...I always kept oriented as a pull-saw. After this small, personal revelation, the pull-saw becomes my friend, and I cut much better.

At the mid-morning water break and pointing out of Harlin's cart, I gulp down my water and jog over to the cart, spying the two familiar figures. Harlin walking on the far side and Mera riding. I hold up a hand in greeting as they pull closer and stop.

"Hey," I say. "I'm glad you could ride by on your way out."

Lower terraces lane • Day 3, mid-morning • Sun up, air cool in the shade

Harlin hears you before he sees you; the cart slows as your boots hit the packed earth a

little faster than a walk. By the time you raise your hand, he’s already reining in the horse.

Up close you can see they’re in “travel mode” again:

The cart’s loaded lighter than when you arrived in Kakariko: fewer sacks, more small

crates and bundles tied tight with rope.

Harlin’s cloak is rolled and strapped near the driver’s seat; his shirt’s fresh but already

gathering dust at the cuffs.

Mera sits sideways on the wagon rail, one leg inside, one out, scarf knotted tighter

against the morning chill, a small bundle in her lap.

Mera’s face lights when she spots you. She lifts her free hand in return, fingers wiggling in

a small wave.

“There you are,” she says. “Ollie said you’d been adopted by the carpenters. I was starting

to think Tasho had nailed your feet to a beam.”

Harlin eyes you with a faint, satisfied squint, taking in the sawdust in your hair, the cedar-

smell, the way you’re carrying yourself after a few hours’ honest work.

“You look like you belong there,” he says. “Better than when we picked you up in the ruins,

anyway.”

There’s a warmth under the gruffness. He shifts his weight on his feet, glances back the

way they came.

“We’re headed out,” he adds. “Down toward the stable first, then likely on toward the next

round of farms. Pella’s got a list longer than my arm.”

Mera hops down from the cart with the bundle in her hands. It’s a cloth-wrapped parcel

about the size of both her fists, tied with a simple knot.

“I didn’t want to leave without saying goodbye,” she says. “Or without leaving you

something that isn’t just advice.”

She presses the bundle gently into your hands.

“It’s nothing grand,” she says. “Couple of rolls, bit of dried fruit, and some of the tea leaves

from last night. For when your day runs longer than the inn’s kitchen. Brew it weak if you

have to stretch it.”

Up close, there’s a little shine in her eyes she’s pretending isn’t there.

“You’ve done well,” she adds, softer. “In two days you’ve gone from ‘lost soul on the road’

to ‘man people expect to see in the morning’. That counts for more than you think.”

Harlin clears his throat, like he’s not going to try to compete with that.

“If you end up in Hateno one of these seasons, ask after us at the grain house,” he says.

“They’ll know which route we’re on. And if you hear we’re coming through Kakariko again,

tell Ollie to start the stew early. I don’t like arriving to empty pots.”

He sticks out his hand this time—solid, calloused grip, quick and firm.

“Take care of yourself,” he says. “Impa may have her eye on you, but you’re still the one

that has to watch where you’re putting your feet.”

Mera steps back toward the cart, then pauses and gives you a quick, tight hug—more

squeeze than embrace, smelling of flour, dust, and that faint herbal note from her cooking.

“Don’t forget to rest,” she murmurs. “Work’s good. Exhaustion’s not.”

She clambers back up to her perch, skirts hitched just enough to keep them out of the

wheel.
