Harlin clicks his tongue, the horse leans into the traces, and the wagon starts to roll again.

Mera twists around on the rail to keep you in sight a few heartbeats longer, lifting her

hand one last time.

“You’ll do fine, Zeth!” she calls back over the creak of wheels. “And if you don’t, yell loud

enough and someone here will come yell at you until you do!”

The cart rattles on down the lane, turning a corner between houses; the sound of hooves

and wheels fades, replaced again by the thud of mallets and the saw’s pull-song from the

worksite behind you.

In your hands, the bundle is warm from Mera’s grip.

Up the slope: Kakariko proper, Impa’s house, the Goddess statue.

Down the path: cedar beams, Tasho’s measuring eye, Rinna’s pull-saw lessons, Sef’s careful

auger work.

Day 3 isn’t waiting. The crew will be back at it as soon as their water cups hit the crate.

I accept Mera's bundle happily and inhale deeply to smell it. Closing my eyes with an exaggerated expression to indicate how delicious I already knew it was going to be. When Harlin sticks out his hand I don't let him get away without pulling him into a more masculine embrace as well.

As they ride away and I walk back to rejoin Tasho's crew I

have a peek into the bundle, curious to see what fruit was inside.

Lower terraces lane → carpenters’ worksite • Day 3, mid-morning • Sun bright, air still cool

in the shade

The bundle in your hands smells like Mera: flour, baked crust, and that faint hint of herbs

she likes to sneak into everything.

When you loosen the knot and peel the cloth back a little, you get the full inventory:

Two small, dense rolls, their crusts brushed with something that’s dried to a soft

sheen. You can see flecks of herb in the dough—probably the same mix she used in

last night’s stew bread.

A twist of waxed paper with dried fruit: thin slices of apple, a few darker, sticky chunks

that are probably plum, and two bright orange pieces that look like dried persimmon.

A tiny paper packet, folded neatly and tied with thread, holding tea leaves. Even

through the paper you get that sakura-barley ghost—lighter than last night’s pot, but

unmistakable.

It’s not a feast, but it’s thoughtful: enough to bridge a missed meal, and just fancy enough

that you know she dipped into the “nice” stores, not the scraps.

You rewrap it and tuck it safely away, then head back toward the worksite.

Carpenters’ worksite • Day 3, mid-morning • Break almost over, cedar and sweat in the air

The crew is just finishing their water.

Tasho stands with one foot up on a low stone, cup in hand, watching the beam you and

Sef worked earlier as if it might misbehave while his back is turned. He drains the last of

his water, then sets the cup back on the crate with a soft tok.

Rinna leans against a post, arms folded loosely, breathing still a little quick from hopping

up and down the frame. A thin trickle of sweat has carved a clean line through the dust on

her neck. She eyes your returning back, clocking the wrapped bundle and the fact that you

came back at a jog, not a shuffle.

Sef is sitting on an overturned bucket, elbows on his knees, cup dangling in both hands.

He glances up as you rejoin them, gives a small, wordless nod of acknowledgment, then

sets his empty cup aside.

Tasho tracks you for a beat, just long enough to confirm you didn’t keep them waiting.

“Good,” he says simply. “Friends said what they needed to say, you said what you needed

to say, and you still came back before the water turned warm.”

He jerks his chin toward the beams you were working.

“Back to it,” he adds. “We’ve got tenons that want mouths and a roof that wants to be dry

before the next rain thinks about us.”

The saw waits where you left it on the trestles, teeth glinting. The chisel is laid carefully on

its side, edge turned inward. The beam you cut earlier sits next to its mate, charcoal lines

already telling you what needs to come off and what needs to stay.

Your hands flex inside the gloves. Your shoulders remember the rhythm from earlier. The

smell of cedar feels almost thicker now, wrapped around your clothes, your hair, the

morning.

Day 3 leans back into its groove: cut, chisel, haul, lift—one joint at a time, one beam at a

time, village sounds drifting around the edges while you make yourself part of the frame

of this place in the most literal way possible.

Over the next few hours until whenever Tasho decides to call the next stop I make sure to work diligently and carefully, judging by Sef's work that Tasho values accuracy and precision over time and quantity, in spite of how pressing the need for the roof to be done may be.

I also try to make some small talk as appropriate. Admittedly I find myself gravitating to Rinna, asking how she got her scar, if she has a favourite kind of wood, how she got into carpentry in the first place and so on. I also

make sure to chat with Sef and Tasho so as to not make anything too obvious.

Thought for 7s

Lower terraces – carpenters’ worksite • Day 3, late morning into midday • Sun climbing,

cedar scent deepening

The rhythm settles in fast once you’re back on the trestles.

Pull, breathe, pull.

Tap, tok, chip.

Lift, step, brace.

The saw behaves now that you’re treating it like a cousin to your coping saw instead of a

stubborn push-blade. Kerfs track truer along the charcoal lines; your shoulders hurt in that

good way, the one that says “you’re using these correctly.”

Tasho watches more than he says. That seems to be his natural state.

When your tenon shoulders come out straight, he grunts approval and leaves you alone.

When a line starts to wander, he’s suddenly there, big hand closing on the spine of the

blade, nudging it a couple of degrees.

“Listen to the teeth,” he says once. “If it squeals, you’re forcing. If it purrs, you’re right.”

Mostly, you hear purring.

Sef proves exactly as you guessed: slow, precise, almost fussy in the best way. When you’re

side by side—him drilling, you chiseling—you catch him sneaking looks at your hands as

you adjust your technique to match theirs. There’s a faint dawning respect there, the “oh,

this isn’t just some random extra pair of arms” realization.

When you draw him into small talk in the lulls—simple things, how long he’s been with

Tasho, whether he prefers roof work or framing—he answers without looking up, voice

quiet but clear.

“Four years,” he says about the apprenticeship. “Started because Tasho needed a pair of

hands and I was tired of weeding turnips.”

On roofs versus frames, he just huffs.

“Roof from the ground, frame from the roof,” he says. “Either way something’s over your

head.”

Rinna is easier to talk to once you catch her between tasks.

You ask about the scar along her forearm when the moment feels right—matter-of-fact,

no gawking.

“Dropped beam,” she says, flexing the arm as if testing it. “First year with Tasho. I

misjudged the weight and thought I could muscle it instead of asking for help. The timber

disagreed.”

She taps the pale groove with a finger.

“Could’ve been worse,” she adds. “Taught me to respect what weighs more than I do.”

On favorite woods, she doesn’t even hesitate.

“Cedar for roofs,” she says, “cypress for baths, oak if someone’s rich enough to waste it on

doors.”

Then, after another beat:

“And the scrub pines up on the ridge. They twist when they grow, so you have to think

sideways when you cut them. I like wood that fights back a little.”

As for how she ended up here, you catch the story in pieces between beams and joints.

Her father was a guard in his youth, her mother a weaver. She tried both for a while, she

says: sparring with wooden spears in the yard, weaving practice cloth that came out either

too loose or too tight. Neither took.

“What I liked,” she admits, “was helping patch the house when the winter storms came.

Holding ladders. Handing tools. Seeing something broken turn to something strong

again.”

She caught Tasho’s eye on a repair job when she was a teenager, she says. He complained

about her getting underfoot and then, next year, complained that there weren’t enough

young people who knew how to hold a beam properly and might as well teach someone.

She never left.

You make sure the small talk spreads around: a question about Tasho’s favorite project (he

names a bridge, not a house); a comment to Sef about how clean his mortises are; a nod

to Rinna when she hauls a beam most people couldn’t budge alone. You’re careful not to

orbit too tightly around her, even if your attention wants to.

The work stays the focus. The roof slowly stops being a set of individual bones and starts

looking like a real frame again. Each joint you’ve touched is literally part of the structure

now, hidden but crucial.

By the time Tasho calls the next halt, the sun is well up, heat starting to pool in the still air

where the valley walls hold it. Sweat has darkened the collar of your shirt and glued

sawdust to your arms. Your gloves are a shade darker than they were this morning, the

creases packed with fine dust.

Tasho glances up at the sky, then down at the frame.

“Enough,” he says. “If we don’t stop, we’ll start making mistakes, and I am too old to live in

a crooked village.”

He waves vaguely toward the shade.

“Food, water,” he adds. “Half an hour. If you can’t chew it in that time, it’s not lunch, it’s a

mistake.”

Rinna slides down from the roof again, landing lightly despite the height. Her hair has

started to escape the braid at the temples; she pushes it back with the back of her hand,

leaving another streak of dust.

She drops onto an overturned crate, rolling her shoulders.

“You’re holding up,” she observes, eyeing you. “Some apprentices are whining by now.”

Sef sinks onto his bucket with a soft exhale, untying a cloth bundle from his belt and

unwrapping what looks like a simple rice ball and some pickled vegetables.

You’ve got Mera’s bundle.

There’s shade near the water jar, a flat bit of ground where tools have been neatly stacked

and set aside. The smell of cedar is joined now by the faint, savory hints of other people’s

lunches, and the ever-present background of damp earth and distant waterfall.

Your stomach makes it pretty clear what it thinks about the timing.

The day has hit its first natural pause: tools down, sun overhead, half an hour where the

only things expected of you are to eat, drink, and be ready to go back at it when Tasho

stands up again.

I grab Mera's bundle and sit down on another crate nearby, unpacking one of the rolls and the apples.

"I hope so," I say to Rinna's comment. "Not really sure if I qualify as an apprentice back home anymore, though I'm certainly no master either. Guess that would've put me firmly in 'journeyman' territory." I take a bit of my roll. "I was somewhat specialised though. Did a lot of the interior work. Doors, the wooden parts of the windows, trim work that makes things look tidy and finished. Stuff like that. Don't know newely as much about framing and floors. And like I said before: very different style to here."

I chew thoughtfully for a moment, reflecting on how I managed to fall right back into my old occupation so easily. Hyrule made it new and exciting again. Something I could enjoy and not just do because I had to. "I like it though. It's good to learn new things." I look at Sef and Rinna. "'A man who loves what he does never works a day in his life,' am I right?"

Carpenters’ worksite – in the shade by the water jar • Day 3, midday • Sun high, heat

pooling, air still

The crate creaks a little under you as you sit. When you unwrap Mera’s bundle, the smell

comes up like a memory: warm herbs and yeast from the roll, the sweet-sour note of dried

apple. The bread is dense but soft, crust giving way with a quiet crackle when you bite in.

The herbs are subtle—something a little peppery, something almost floral.

Rinna lowers herself onto her crate with the loose, boneless ease of someone who’s been

on her feet all morning. When you talk about apprentices and masters, she squints at you,

amused.

“‘Journeyman,’” she repeats, testing the word. “Sounds like someone whose job is to walk

places and look thoughtful.”

She wipes a line of sweat off her temple with the back of her wrist, leaving another streak

of cedar dust.

“We’ve got something like that,” she goes on. “Apprentice, then… ‘takes their own

contracts’ if Tasho thinks they won’t embarrass him. He doesn’t like the word ‘master’.”

She jerks her chin at him, where he’s sitting a little apart with his back against a post,

chewing methodically on a rice ball.

“He says the wood doesn’t care what we call ourselves,” she adds. “Only whether the rain

stays out and the beams stay up.”

Sef, on his bucket, glances over at your proverb. He swallows his mouthful of rice,

considers, then shakes his head slightly.

“Whoever said that never planed seventy boards in a day,” he says quietly. “Even if you

love it, your arms still notice.”

There’s no bitterness in it, though—just dry honesty. He takes a sip from his cup, then

nods once toward your hands.

“But it helps,” he adds. “Liking it. Makes the splinters feel less personal.”

Your roll goes down easily. The dried apple is pleasantly chewy, a little tart around the

edges, cutting through the warmth of the bread. When you pop one of the darker plum

pieces into your mouth, it hits with a deeper, richer sweetness and a faint tang—

concentrated sun and sugar in a bite. The water from the jar is cool enough to make your

teeth ache mildly if you gulp it, so you sip instead, feeling it trail down into a stomach

that’s happily busy.

Rinna watches you eat with the companionable interest of someone mentally tallying

everyone’s energy.

“Interior work, hm?” she says. “Doors and trim. That explains your cuts. You look at lines

like they’re going to be seen, not buried.”

She plucks a grain of rice off her palm, flicks it to the ground.

“If you stay long enough, we’ll drag you inside a house instead of keeping you on the

skeleton,” she says. “Plenty of people wanting their old places to look less like ‘we survived

the end of the world’ and more like ‘we meant to build it this way’.”

Tasho snorts, not unkindly.

“Plenty of people wanting the trim straight before the posts are fixed,” he says. “One thing

at a time.”

He finishes his rice ball, brushes crumbs from his hands, and pushes himself up with a faint

grunt. Standing in the sun again, he squints up at the roof, assessing.

“For now,” he says, “we finish the bones. Then we worry about making it pretty enough for

gossiping aunties to praise.”

He looks down at you, then at the half-eaten roll in your hand and the remaining fruit.

“Five more breaths,” he says. “Then back to it. Eat the rest later if you have to. I’d rather

you worked with half a roll in your pocket than half your strength in your arms.”

The shade is starting to feel heavier, not cooler, as the day tilts past noon. The cedar scent

is stronger where the sun warms the fresh cuts; sweat makes the dust cling to your skin

wherever the gloves and shirt sleeves don’t cover.

Rinna drains her cup and stands, stretching her arms over her head until her shoulders

pop quietly.

“Back to the cat with knives,” she says, nodding toward the saw.

Sef wraps what’s left of his rice ball, tucks it back into his cloth, and pads over to the

workbench to pick up his auger again.

Your bundle still has one roll, some fruit, and that tiny packet of tea tucked safely inside—

future you’s problem, or comfort, depending how the afternoon goes.

Tasho claps his hands once, sharp.

“All right,” he says. “Let’s see if we can make this house forget it ever had a hole in its

head.”

Tools wait where you left them. The frame waits overhead, beams like ribs against the

bright sky. Your shoulders feel the morning, but they still answer when you square up to

the trestles again.

I unceremoniously stuff the remainder of the roll in my mouth and dash over to where my sword and shield are to stow the rest, before getting back to work. There was no way that was a 30 minute break, but I don't dare to say anything about it, and concede to falling back into the work rhythm for the afternoon hours.

Thought for 5s

Lower terraces – carpenters’ worksite • Day 3, afternoon • Sun bright, shadows short, heat

sitting on the roofs

The rest of Mera’s roll disappears in about three chews, and the remaining bundle tucks in

neatly beside your sword and makeshift shield—provisions stacked with protection in the

little “this is mine” corner by the trestles.

Then it’s back into the rhythm.

Afternoon work has a different weight than morning work. Muscles already know what’s

coming; they complain earlier, but they also find the groove faster.

You and Sef fall into a kind of relay:

He marks mortises with the inked string and square.

You cut the shoulders and cheeks of tenons.

He follows up with auger or chisel where needed.

Every so often, Tasho swaps you, just to keep either of you from getting too precious

about one step. When the saw sings too high, he corrects. When the chisel starts leaving

tear-out instead of clean faces, he taps the edge on his thumb, frowns, and takes a

moment to hone it on a small stone.

Rinna spends more of the afternoon on the frame itself.

From below, you see her moving along the skeleton of the roof like it’s solid ground: bare

feet gripping beams, toes curling around edges, balance never really in question. She calls

for beams to be lifted; you and Sef hoist them up together while she guides the far ends

into sockets. Each successful fit is marked by a satisfying thunk as tenon meets mortise

home.

The sun climbs and hangs.

Heat gathers under the eaves and in the still air around the house. The cedar smell

deepens—less sharp now, more resinous, a kind of dry sweetness that gets into the back

of your throat. Sweat runs down from your hairline, behind your ears, along your spine.

The gloves grow damp inside, sticking a little when you flex your fingers. When you peel

them off briefly during a water pause, your palms are wrinkled and pink, blisters puffed

but not torn.

At one point, you misjudge the weight on a beam. It drops a finger’s breadth too fast. Your

shoulder catches the jolt; something twinges deep under the muscle. Not a pull, just a

sharp reminder that gravity is very real and does not care how excited you are about

carpentry.

Rinna glances down at the noise, checks that the beam’s still where she wants it, then

gives you a quick, measuring look. When she sees you shake it off and reset your grip, she

nods once and goes back to her joint.

Tasho notices too. He doesn’t say anything right away, but later, when you’re planing

down a tenon that’s just a hair too fat, he shifts your stance with a knuckle to your knee

and a tap to your elbow.

“Use the floor as well as your arms,” he mutters. “You don’t have spare shoulders lying

around.”

The hours slide in a sawdust blur.

Cicadas start their afternoon whine in the trees above the terraces. Voices from

neighboring houses drift in and out: someone arguing about laundry, a child laughing, a

pot clanging on stone. Once, a pair of village aunties shuffle past at a distance, slowing

just enough to peer over and murmur approval-disguised-as-critique about the progress

on the roof.

By the time Tasho calls it, the light has shifted from above-you to angled, shadows

stretching longer from posts and trestles.

The roof frame is… a roof frame now. Not finished, but undeniably itself: rafters marching

in steady rhythm, cross-ties in place, joints snug enough that the whole structure has that

quiet, unified creak when the wind picks up, instead of a cacophony of individual pieces.

Your shirt sticks to your back. Your throat is dry enough that even sawdust feels like it

might be drinkable. Your arms have gone past simple ache into that hollow, heavy feeling

where even lifting the saw to put it away feels like an effort.

Tasho wipes his brow with the back of one hand and squints up at the sky.

“That’s enough,” he decides. “If we keep at it, we’ll start fixing problems we made by being

tired.”

He nods toward the tool bench.

“Put everything away where you found it,” he says. “Blades wiped. Edges covered. I don’t

like waking up to rust. Tomorrow we start on the overhang and the first layer of boards.”

Rinna is already climbing down, steps a touch slower than this morning but still sure. Stray

hairs have escaped her braid entirely now, sticking to her neck and forehead. She hops the

last bit and lands with a small grunt, then rolls her shoulders and starts collecting coils of

rope.

Sef returns chisels to their wrap, rolling the cloth carefully, fingers lingering a moment

longer on the ones he used most.

When you stack the saws, you feel the difference in your grip: where you were tentative

this morning, you’re now simply tired and efficient, setting each one teeth-up, handles

aligned, blades given a quick thumb-wipe to clear off dust and sweat.

Once the tools are squared away and the work area looks more like an organized site than

a battlefield, Tasho turns his attention back to you.

He looks you over from boots to hair: the dust, the sweat, the way you’re holding your

shoulders.

“You worked,” he says simply. “Didn’t spend all day telling us what you used to do

somewhere else.”

There’s approval in it, even if he delivers it like a complaint.

He reaches into his belt-pouch and pulls out a small cloth bag. The faint clink inside is

unmistakable. He weighs it in his palm for a second, then tosses it once and catches it

before holding it out.

“First day’s pay,” he says. “Not a full wage—we lost some time teaching you how not to

insult the saw—but you earned more than a pat on the back.”

The bag is heavier than Mera’s roll and fruit bundle had been; not much, but enough to

feel like something real. Rupees click softly against each other when you take it.

“We start again at first light tomorrow,” he adds. “If you mean to keep eating in this village,

be here. If not, put the coin to good use and don’t let the roof fall on you on your way out

of town.”

Rinna slings a coil of rope over one shoulder, then pauses as she passes you.

“You did well,” she says. “For someone who only just met a proper saw.”

Her mouth quirks in that almost-smile again.

“If your hands still work after you wash, you might want to stretch them before you sleep,”

she adds. “Otherwise tomorrow they’ll curl into claws and refuse to help.”

Sef gives you a small nod as he lifts the chisel roll.

“See you in the morning,” he says. “Or we’ll know the turnip fields won.”

They start to drift off in their respective directions: Tasho toward wherever his tools live at

night, Rinna and Sef uphill along a side path, the three of them already shedding the

workday in their own ways.

The sun is dropping toward the far rim of the valley; the heat eases a little as shadows

stretch longer. Your pocket now holds a bag with your first earned rupees in Hyrule. Your

body holds a full day of labor. Your little stash by the trestles still has half a roll, some fruit,

and a folded packet of tea waiting where you left it beside your sword and shield.

Kakariko is shifting into evening again—cooking smells starting up, voices changing

timbre. Day 3’s work chapter has very cleanly ended; whatever comes next is yours to walk

into.

I thank Tasho and add what little I had from my work at Enchanted to the bag I was just given. I retrieve my other belongings as the three carpenters make their own ways home, my eyes lingering in Rinna slightly too long as she and Sef make their way up the hill. I shake my head to clear it and instead focus on what needs doing.

Impa had stipulated I needed to check in at some point, and I didn't want to make her send Dorian or Cado to remind me. At the same time, I could imagine the disapproving glare I'd likely get from Dorian if I showed up to meet the elder in my current filthy state. I needed a proper cleaning, not just a splash of water. Problem was...I had no idea where to do that.

*Probably another question for Ollie,* I think, hoping I don't start giving the innkeeper the feeling I'm using him as a tutor to Hyrule life. I had to talk to him about

accommodations for later that night anyways, so I head over to the inn again for the moment.

Thought for 10s

Kakariko lanes → Shuteye Inn • Day 3, late afternoon • Sun lowering, village in “after work”

mode

The walk back uphill reminds you that, while your spine is happier than your old one, your

legs absolutely know they’ve been carrying beams all day.

Your shoulders have that hollow, used-up feeling: not sharp pain, just a deep, steady ache

that makes the idea of swinging the sword on your back seem… theoretical. Your hands

throb dully inside the gloves; when you peel them off as you walk, the air on your skin is

both relief and sting. Blisters have risen along a couple of old callus lines—angry pink

bubbles that didn’t quite burst. Sawdust clings to your forearms, neck, and hair, gritty

wherever sweat made it stick.

Kakariko is sliding into evening mode around you.

Smoke starts to rise in thin threads from cooking fires. Someone’s beating a rug out on a

veranda, sharp thwap sounds punctuating the cicadas. You catch a whiff of grilling fish

from one house, miso from another, the whole valley doing that slow exhale that comes

after a day’s work.

By the time you reach the square, the light is softer, shadows longer. Harlin’s cart is gone

—no wagon, no horse, just wheel ruts and a slightly flattened patch of dirt where it sat.

The empty space makes their absence feel more real than the goodbye did.

Shuteye Inn has its door halfway open, lantern just lit inside: a warm square of amber on

the packed ground.

You duck in.

Shuteye Inn – common room • Day 3, late afternoon • Lanterns just lit, coals restoked

Inside, the room’s in that brief lull between “afternoon” and “dinner rush.”

The older woman—Ollie’s mother, presumably—is at the hearth again, stirring a larger pot

this time. The smell is different from last night’s stew but related: root vegetables, stock,

maybe some kind of bean. Steam halos her head as she leans in; her bun hasn’t budged all

day.

Ollie is at one of the side tables with a stack of clean bowls and a cloth, polishing in small,

efficient circles. His sleeves are rolled back, and his hair’s escaped its tie again, falling in his

face until he pushes it back with an ink-smudged wrist. When he glances up and sees you,

his expression does that quick shift from neutral to “oh good, not a problem customer.”

He takes in the state of you—dust, sweat, cedar-smell, faint forward hunch of someone

whose back is filing complaints—and his eyebrows climb.

“Wow,” he says, keeping his voice down out of habit. “Tasho didn’t go easy on you.”

There’s no judgment in it; if anything, a touch of impressed.

“You look like a plank yourself,” he adds. “In a good way.”

He sets the bowl down, tucks the cloth over his shoulder, and steps closer.

“We started the stew early,” he says. “It’ll be ready in a bit. And there’s tea, of course.”

His eyes flick once over your clothes, the sawdust, the general grubby layer.

“If you’re… uh… wanting to wash up before you go visiting anyone important,” he goes on,

“we’ve got a tub out back. Nothing fancy, just a big barrel and a lot of hot water from the

stove. Some people go down to the stream instead, but that’s more for laundry and less

for getting cedar out of your hair.”

He hooks a thumb vaguely toward the rear of the inn.

“Use of the tub is a few rupees if you want soap and we heat the water for you,” he says.

“Less if you’re just after cold splash and no soap. I can ask my mother to put a kettle on

the fire anyway.”

He glances toward the stairs that lead up to the guest room, then back at you.

“And as for… uh… sleeping,” he adds, “Harlin and Mera are gone, so their room’s free. If

you still want it, the rate we talked about stands. You’ve got more dust than coin on you so

far, but less of one than yesterday.”

There’s a hint of a grin at that, like he’s proud of the little wordplay.

He wipes his palms on his apron, then folds his hands loosely.

“So,” he says, not pushing, “tub, tea, room, some combination of the three… or I can just

get out of your way while you decide.”

He waits there, easy, like he’s starting to get used to you showing up looking a little more

“Hyrule-shaped” each time.

I blink dumbly at Ollie for a moment as he perfectly summarises my needs before I can ask. His occasional nervous stammer aside, he clearly was good at his job. I put my few belongings down on the counter and hold out my dirty arms.

"What gave me away?" I ask with toothless sarcasm. "No, but really, that all sounds perfect. I think I have to go with cold and soapless tonight. As it happens I do need to meet someone and I can't keep them waiting," I say without elaborating. "Is it all right if I go ahead and leave my things in the room? I'll worry about food and drink after I get back too."

Thought for 6s

Shuteye Inn – common room → back yard → guest room → lane toward Impa’s house

Day 3, late afternoon • Lanterns brightening, sky turning amber

Ollie huffs a laugh at your outstretched arms, shoulders relaxing.

“The smell,” he says. “Definitely the smell.”

He gestures vaguely at the aura of cedar and sweat around you.

“But also the part where you look like your bones want to sit down before you do.”

He nods toward the rear of the inn.

“Cold and soapless is easy,” he says. “Tub’s out back. I’ll draw from the rain barrel; you can

dunk as much as you like. No charge for just water and a bucket.”

He glances at your belongings on the counter, then toward the stairs.

“You can leave your things in the room,” he adds. “Harlin and Mera’s old one. First door on

the right at the top. Just… try not to drip on the floorboards when you come back

through.”

A small snort comes from the hearth. His mother doesn’t look up from her pot.

“If he drips, he can wipe,” she says. “Better a wet floor than a dusty one.”

Ollie rolls his eyes affectionately and waves you along.

“Go on,” he says. “Back door’s by the kitchen. Tub’s just beyond.”

—

Inn back yard – washing tub

Day 3, late afternoon • Air cooler in the shade, stone damp underfoot

The back door opens onto a narrow yard hemmed in by stone walls and the inn’s rear. A

few herb pots sit along one side, leaves brushing the wall—shiso, maybe, and something

with needle-thin leaves. A line with a couple of towels hangs slack between two posts,

cloth stirring lazily.

The tub is exactly what Ollie promised: a cut-down barrel big enough for a person to

crouch in, set on level stone. Beside it, a rain barrel with a lid and a dipper. There’s already

some water in the tub, caught from earlier showers; cool, a little leaf litter settled at the

bottom.

The air back here smells of damp wood, wet stone, and whatever herbs are growing in the

pots.

The first pour from the rain barrel is a shock: cold that bites straight into skin heated by a

day in the sun. Dust and sweat run off in muddy rivulets, swirling in the tub’s shallow

water. Cedar scent lifts from your hair and clothes as you work it out with your fingers; the

water takes on a faint golden tinge from the sawdust.

Once the first shock ebbs, the cold has teeth in a different way—bracing rather than

punishing. Muscles twitch and then loosen a notch; the throbbing at your temples eases.

When water hits the blisters on your hands, there’s a sharp sting, then a dull, clean ache.

By the time the worst of the dust is gone, gooseflesh stands along your arms and

shoulders. The stone underfoot leeches heat from bare soles; breath shows faintly in the

shaded air each time you exhale.

A towel from the line is rough but effective, dragging off beads of water and the last

stubborn flecks of grit. Under the dried skin, muscles feel used but cleaner, less sticky and

constricted.

—

Guest room – Harlin & Mera’s old room

Day 3, late afternoon • Light soft through shoji, air faintly smelling of straw

Upstairs, the room is as Ollie described: simple, tidy, and unmistakably empty of its

previous occupants.

Tatami mats cover the floor in neat rectangles, faint straw scent rising when you step in.

Two folded futons rest against one wall, blankets rolled at their feet. A low chest sits in the

corner, closed; a peg on the wall waits for a cloak or bag.

No sign of Harlin and Mera remains except the sense of a space recently used, then

carefully reset: no loose hairs on the pillow, no forgotten scarf, just that subtle “someone

slept here last night” in the way the tatami fibers lie.

Your few possessions don’t take up much space.

Sword.

Canvas “shield.”

Mera’s bundle and tea packet.

The little bag of rupees, now noticeably heavier when it hits the chest’s top with a soft

clink.

They sit there together more neatly than they did on the cart, the beginnings of a personal

corner in a room that could be yours tonight if you choose it.

Outside the shoji, the sounds of the village shift toward evening: more voices returning

from fields and work, the rising note of insects in the terraces, a dog barking once and

then settling.

Impa’s house sits higher up the slope, beyond the shops and the Goddess statue: stone

steps, lanterns, the tall, layered roof and big front gate, guarded more by presence and

tradition than fortifications.

—

Lanes → Impa’s house

Day 3, early evening • Sky orange-pink over the valley, lanterns winking on

The walk up takes you past the familiar points of the village:

The Goddess statue’s little pool, now reflecting streaks of orange and purple.

Enchanted’s closed door and shuttered windows, a faint line of light under the

threshold.

A pair of gossiping aunties on a veranda, who break off their murmuring long enough

to watch you pass with open curiosity.

Higher up, the air cools faster; a breeze picks up, bringing the sound of the waterfall

clearer between the houses.

Impa’s house comes into view: the broad stairs leading up, the two big lanterns flanking

the gate already lit, casting warm light across the front path and the ever-present swept

yard. The Sheikah eye sigil hangs above, red paint dulled slightly with age.

Near the gate, Dorian stands at his usual post.

Spear grounded, back straight, armor neat, eye markings severe in the lanternlight. The

last of the sunset picks out the lines in his face, the set of his jaw. His gaze tracks you as

you approach, cool but not as flinty as it was the last time you saw him at close range.

Behind him, the sliding door to Impa’s interior sits mostly shut, a thin line of light visible at

one edge.

The steps are there.

The guard is there.

The elder is somewhere beyond.

The space between you and them is short, lantern-lit, and waiting for whatever you say or

do next.

After stripping down I find that cleaning myself up is a...pleasant but strange experience. As I do so I realise I...haven't even really much of my own self since arriving at Gatepost Town Ruins. Which just seems like a silly thing to think, but it's true. My body is still mine, but just...better. Hylian-me is no body-builder, there are no shredded abs or obviously bulging muscles, but I am obviously fit now, easily ready to tackle hard work and long treks without any problem. Things were a little more elegant too: a little less hair, no sign of imperfect from where I once broke my left big toe, scars erased, etc. Again: pleasant but strange. And regardless of the pleasantness, I find myself struck, briefly, by a sense of being overwhelmed by the strangeness. I screw my eyes shut and take a deep breath to push through it. *Focus on the positive.*

I hurry through the rest of the task, unhappy with the potentiality of anybody else coming back here while I clean. But thankfully, nobody does, and after making sure I won't drip I hurriedly make my way to my room.

—

In my room, I take stock as I dress. But only after frowning at my clothes. I shook them as free of dust as I could and then let them air out while I scrubbed, so they had managed to dry out and weren't horribly dusty, but...well they were definitely work clothes now. I'm thankful that the smell of cedar easily overpowers that of sweat. I meant

what I had said to Rinna that morning: I love the smell of cedar. I just hope other people do too.

The peg on the wall, begging for a cloak or pack catches my eye in particular. It reminds me I have neither, and probably need to try and acquire both somehow, sometime. A common theme in my life at the moment.

I make a quick mental checklist of things I need to try and get for myself beyond the basic necessities of food and shelter: - Certainly I needed a second pair of clothes at some point, or else I'd be trying to wash the ones I have in the nude while everybody else was trying to eat their dinner. Something nobody wanted, for sure. - An addendum to the clothes: I would like to acquire a hat. It bordered between want and need, since certainly I had been doing fine without one up to now, but the sun and rain could wear anybody down when they were doing hard labour. I had noticed most, though admittedly not all, the villagers seemed to have that distinctive curved, umbrella-like hat common to Kakariko. I hadn't seen as many of what, in my old home, I had known as a "rice farmer's hat", but they seemed to be around. I had always liked those hats, even if I didn't know what to properly call them, but had never gotten one since I knew I'd look ridiculous wearing one and even if I didn't, people would have opinions about it. Here, I didn't feel like that would be a problem. - It wasn't a pressing concern, but it would probably be a smart idea to eventually acquire a cloak of some sort. Something to help with the weather if I ever got to travel. Even if I was stuck in Kakariko, the weather wouldn't always be as nice as it had been. - More pressing, I probably needed to some sort of backpack, satchel, or just a bag. A place to put things when I eventually couldn't stay in the inn. - Most pressing, I definitely needed some kind of good belt. A place to put a money bag, maybe even a scabbard or sheath one day.

I already knew I would be needing some of these things, but wasn't sure how to go about acquiring any of them. I'd be able to buy some of them eventually, if I kept earning, but if I wasn't here and wasn't earning...I'm not sure how I expected to equip myself. I was hardly likely to run across some poor adventurer dead on the side of the road with everything I needed ready to loot. At any rate, worries for some other time. I just had to be patient. Working for coin was slow, but honest. I was here for at least a week anyways, so I didn't need to rush things.

I finish dressing and leave everything in the room; I'd definitely be staying here tonight.

—

As I approach the chieftan's house, I give a small bow to Dorian before even mounting the steps.

"Good evening. I'm 'checking' in. Is now a good time? I don't want to interrupt anybody's mealtime."

Thought for 9s

Impa’s house – front steps • Day 3, early evening • Lanterns lit, sky orange-pink and fading

Dorian’s eyes track you as you bow, the lanternlight catching on the edge of his

spearhead. For a half-second you catch a flicker of memory in his expression—what you

said on Day 2, what he did about it—but it’s buried quickly under the practiced guard-

captain composure.

“At least you remembered,” he says. His tone is dry, but not sharp. “Yes. Now is

acceptable.”

He glances past you at the village: smoke rising from chimneys, the distant clatter of pots,

the murmur of people settling in to eat. Then back to you.

“Lady Impa has eaten already,” he adds. “You’re not dragging her away from her bowl.”

He shifts his spear to one hand and steps aside, giving you a clear line up the stairs.

“Go on,” he says. “Announce yourself at the door. She knows to expect you at the end of

the day.”

As you climb, you can feel his gaze between your shoulder blades—not hostile, but very

much taking note.

The wooden steps are smooth under your feet, worn by decades of traffic but impeccably

kept. The big lanterns throw a warm wash across the courtyard stones; the Sheikah eye

sigil above the doorway glows a dulled red in the light.

You slide the front door aside just enough to step through and kneel briefly at the

threshold, as you’ve seen others do, then close it behind you.

Inside, the air is cooler and still, with the faint scents of old tatami, ink, and tea.

Impa is exactly where you’d expect: seated on a cushion in the main room, back straight

despite her age, hands folded loosely around a small, empty cup. The low table before her

holds a teapot, one other cup still half-full, and a small dish of untouched sweets.

To her right, a little back from the table, Paya kneels with her hands in her lap, shoulders

just a touch tense. Her eyes flick up at you, wide for a moment, then dart down again, a

pink flush rising at her cheeks. The tiny tremor in her shoulders suggests she remembers

very clearly the last time you were brought here.

Impa’s gaze finds you and stays there.

Her face reads much the same as before: lined, wise, hard to read, the red markings at the

corners of her eyes giving her a perpetually stern cast that you’re starting to suspect is

only partly intentional.

“You have returned at the end of the day,” she says, voice level. “Good.”

She studies you for a heartbeat longer: the damp at your hair from the cold wash, the

cleaned-but-still-worn clothes, the posture of someone who has spent all day hauling and

sawing.

“I see that the carpenters have claimed you,” she adds. “Kakariko is a village of many eyes

and only one road; word travels quickly.”

She gestures with a small tilt of her head to a cushion opposite her at the table.

“Sit,” she says. “You will tell me how you have used this day that Kakariko has given you.”

Her tone makes it clear this is neither accusation nor idle curiosity—more a formal

accounting, part of whatever unspoken bargain you stepped into when she decided you

would not be turned away.

Paya shifts just enough to pour fresh tea into the empty cup at Impa’s hand, then into the

spare cup in front of the place she’s indicated for you. Her hands are steady, but you can

see the way she holds her breath as she slides your cup into place, then retreats a fraction

of a hand’s-breadth back, eyes lowered.

Impa waits, cup untouched for the moment, gaze resting calmly on you as you settle—

ready to listen to whatever version of your Day 3 you choose to give her.

I take the indicated seat and smile timidly at Paya as she pours the tea. I give Impa a synopsis of everything that I'd done, everyone I'd spoken with since I'd last seen her yesterday, trusting that she would stop me with questions if she wanted clarification. I have a hunch she's more interested in knowing what I tell her and how, though, since it seems highly unlikely anything happens in Kakariko without her knowing. Somehow.

If she has questions, I wait patiently for them. If she doesn't...I still wait patiently.

Impa’s house – main room

Day 3, early evening • Lanternlight warm, outside sounds muted

You talk; Impa listens.

You give her the day in broad strokes—Enchanted, the discount rack, the gloves, Tasho’s

crew, the roof frame, Harlin and Mera’s goodbye, the room at the inn, the quick wash

before coming here. You leave plenty of space for interruption; she does not take it until

you are finished.

Paya’s head bobs in tiny, involuntary reactions as you mention people she knows well—

Claree, Lasli, Ollie, Tasho. Harlin and Mera. A little sympathetic wince at “carrying beams all

day.” A flicker of curiosity at “helping with Enchanted’s stock.”

Impa’s expression hardly shifts, but her eyes do. That’s where the movement is: a slight

narrowing here, a faint softening there, tracking where you put weight and where you

skim.

When you fall quiet, she lets a couple of heartbeats pass in silence.

Then she lifts her cup, sips once, and sets it down.

“You have spent the day doing three things,” she says. “Working, listening, and choosing

not to run.”

It is not framed as praise or rebuke, just observation.

“You chose honest labor,” she goes on. “You tied yourself to people who will notice if you

vanish. You used the help offered to you, rather than sulking in a corner and cursing your

fate.”

Her gaze sharpens slightly.

“You also chose to keep your word,” she says. “You came back here when you could have

pretended to forget.”

Her eyes flick toward the door—as if measuring the distance to the inn, to the stream, to

the path out of the valley—then back.

“This is good,” she says simply.

She shifts, a tiny realignment of spine and shoulders that somehow makes her feel even

more present.

“There are a few things, however, that we must make clear while you are still… new.”

One bony finger taps very lightly on the table.

“First,” she says, “your knowledge remains the most dangerous thing about you.”

A faint, almost imperceptible glance toward Paya, then back to you.

“You have already seen what happens when you swing it like a blade,” she says, and both

of you know she means Dorian. “I do not need to repeat myself there. You will not spread

stories of futures-that-may-be, or of secrets that are not yours, in my village.”

No heat in the tone, but the steel is unmistakable.

“Second,” she continues, “you are doing as I hoped: rooting yourself in work and routine.

You will continue this. Carpentry, errands, whatever honest tasks you can find.”

Her mouth tightens a fraction.

“You will be tempted, I think, to chase explanations,” she says. “To hunt for shrines, for

towers, for machines, for some… pattern that tells you why you are here and how to go

back.”

She lifts her cup, but does not drink.

“You may follow your curiosity, within the bounds I set,” she says. “But if your answers

begin to endanger the people here, I will cut off your questions.”

That is the clearest warning she’s given you yet: calm, but unambiguous.

“Third,” she says, “your movements.”

She ticks them off without needing to count on her fingers.

“For this first week, you remain based in Kakariko. You may walk the village, work where

you are welcomed, visit the statue, the shops, the inn. You may go as far as the nearby

fields by day, if someone expects you back and knows where you went.”

Her eyes hold yours.

“You will not leave the valley without my say-so. Not toward the hills, not toward the

plains, not toward the forest. If you believe there is some urgent need to do so, you will

bring it to me first. I decide whether the risk is acceptable.”

She sits back a little, letting that settle.

Paya, beside her, shifts her weight and finally dares a glance up. Her eyes are worried, but

less frightened than they were yesterday; she nods once, almost to herself, when Impa

says “you are doing as I hoped.”

Impa notices.

“Paya,” she says without looking away from you, “tell him what you saw when you walked

through the village today.”

Paya jumps a little at being addressed, but obeys.

“Ah— y-yes, Grandmother,” she says, then turns slightly toward you. “I… I saw you at the

carpenters’, earlier. Only from the road. You were… um… carrying a beam, I think. Rinna

was shouting something about ‘not fighting the wood’.”

Her mouth twitches, like she’s suppressing a small smile at the memory.

“People are… already talking,” she adds, voice soft. “About the ‘new man’ who’s helping

with roofs and sorting clothes and eating at the inn.”

Her fingers knot together in her lap.

“They are not whispering about omens or curses,” she says. “Just… about someone

working hard.”

Impa tips her head, satisfied.

“This is the point,” she says. “Kakariko has seen calamity and miracle both. It has no

patience left for mystery that does not put its hands to use.”

She reaches for her cup again, cradling it between both hands for a moment.

“As for Dorian and Cado,” she says, “you do not need to fear a spear at your back, so long

as you hold to what we have agreed. Dorian will watch you. That is his nature and his duty.

Cado will fret. That is his nature. Neither will move against you without my word.”

She finally drinks, then sets the cup down and breathes out slowly.

“From this evening onward,” she says, “you will not need to present yourself to me every

day at a fixed hour. That would be a poor use of both our time.”

Her eyes narrow a fraction.

“But you will come to me if any of the following happen:”

Now she does count, thin fingers ticking off each point.

“—If you remember something about our future that feels like more than idle story.

—If you encounter anything in this Hyrule that does not match what you half-remember

from your tales.

—If you are harmed—or killed—and find that the next morning you are somehow still

walking.”

That last one hangs in the air a heartbeat longer. She’s guessing, not reading your mind,

but she clearly hasn’t forgotten the impossible shape of your arrival.

“In return,” she says, tone easing just a hair, “I will do what I can to ensure you are not left

hungry, or homeless, or friendless while you find your feet.”

Her mouth flattens in something that might be her version of humor.

“You have already discovered that the inn will not let you starve,” she says. “Rinna’s crew

will not let you be idle. And if you find yourself with some minor need—needle and thread,

bandage, a word carried to someone—Paya can help with such things when she is not

attending to me.”

Paya straightens a little, startled but also… pleased to be entrusted with that.

Impa finally leans back, the formal frame of the conversation loosening.

“That is enough for tonight,” she says. “You have worked your body hard. Now let your

mind rest. Think on what I have said, but do not gnaw at it until you cannot sleep. There

will be more days.”

Her gaze softens just a fraction.

“You are not the first lost soul to come to this village, Zeth,” she says quietly. “Most of

them did not fall from… wherever you came from. But confusion, grief, and hope all look

the same on the face.”

She inclines her head, a small, precise gesture.

“You may go,” she says. “Eat, sleep, and present yourself at your work in the morning. That,

for now, is all I require.”

Paya reaches forward in a rustle of cloth to refill your tea cup one last time, then Impa’s,

hands steady despite the lingering tension in her shoulders.

The room is still: lanternlight, faint tea steam, the distant sound of the waterfall through

the paper walls.

You’ve given your accounting. Impa has set her terms more clearly. The rest of the evening

is once again yours to walk back into: the inn, the room, whatever small rituals you need to

wind down after your first full day as Kakariko’s newest almost-carpenter.

I drink my tea contentedly, and feel slightly more at ease. More at ease with Impa, anyways. Her mention of dying and still walking hits me like a stone from a sling. I don't know that I like the sound of that. My mind recalls *Groundhog Day*, the Bill Murray movie. Dying, waking up, dying, waking up, dying, waking up...an endless, unexplained cycle. Nobody noticing, nobody knowing, not able to really talk about it with anybody. It seems...utterly horrible. A worry I must force myself to ignore for now. I'll just have to do my best not to die, like anybody else.

I raise my eyes somewhat, hoping the clear conclusion of business isn't the same thing as dismissal. "Understood, ma'am." As my elbows rest on the table, hands around my cup of tea, a hand finds its way to rubbing the alien tip of my ear again, and again I make myself put it down. "May I speak candidly before I go, ma'am?"

Impa’s house – main room

Day 3, early evening • Lanternlight steady, waterfall a low murmur under the quiet

Impa watches your hand start toward your ear, watches you stop it. There’s the faintest

glimmer in her eyes—approval, maybe, that you’re catching yourself.

At your request, one of her white brows lifts a fraction.

“Candid speech is a Sheikah specialty,” she says. “Though it is usually we who give it.”

The corner of her mouth twitches—small enough that if you blinked, you might miss it.

“You may speak,” she continues. “Two conditions.”

She raises one thin finger.

“First: you will not use ‘candor’ as an excuse to throw more knives you cannot catch. Speak

for yourself—your thoughts, your fears, your hopes—not for what you think you know of

others’ secrets.”

A second finger joins the first.

“Second: you will accept that if I answer, I will do so just as plainly. You may not like what

you hear.”

Beside her, Paya goes very still. Her eyes flick between the two of you, worried but curious,

fingers tightening together in her lap.

Impa settles her cup down, empty now, and folds her hands loosely before her, giving you

the full weight of her attention.

“Go on, then,” she says. “Say what is in your chest, not just what is in your head.”

The room feels smaller for a moment: just you, the elder, her granddaughter, and the

space your next words are about to occupy.

I bob my head in thanks. "Thank you. I, uh...well we talk a lot about what I know and how dangerous it can be. And yeah, I understand that, perfectly. But I only know a few...very big things. It was mistake to say I was helpless because of that, I understand. But at the same time...I...just *don't* know a lot of things. I observed momentous events and terrible secrets, but I have not lived here. I know very few, very weighty things, but anybody around me knows infinitely more facts than I do, even if they may think they are inconsequential." I shift on my cushion. "They are not inconsequential to me. Given my...unique position, there is perhaps some small irony that in regards to some things, I can *only* talk to you about them. Otherwise people will think I'm just a wandering crazy person." I pause and shrug. "Maybe I am a wandering crazy person. But what I mean is: there are just...basic, fundamental things I don't know. And while a child could answer them..." I hang my head to one side, picturing the scene in my mind, "I think I'd start getting the wrong kind of attention."

I take another drink of the tea. "The thing in particular that makes me bring it up now is: I don't even know what season it is." I think about my own statement for a second. Does Hyrule even have seasons? I don't even know what kind of planet Hyrule is on. Is it even a planet? It's a fantasy world, so maybe it is, maybe it isn't. I decide to clarify. "I mean, I expect a place like Hebra, high in the mountains, to generally stay cold. I expect a place like Necluda, covered in tropical jungle, to generally stay hot. But what I've...'observed' was within a limited span of time. I saw trees blooming in Kakariko...but things don't stay the same all the time, surely. Surely there's a time when the grass is dry and old, and a different time when the trees blossom. What time is it now?"

Thought for 11s

Impa’s house – main room

Day 3, early evening • Lanternlight soft, tea cooling

Impa listens without interruption, fingers resting lightly on the rim of her cup. When you

finish, one corner of her mouth pulls very slightly—not quite a smile, not quite a frown.

“You are not wrong,” she says. “You have carried a few stones from a mountain you only

saw in the distance. You know where some of the cliffs are, but not where the wells and

paths lie.”

She breathes out through her nose, a quiet sound.

“Dangerous knowledge is still dangerous,” she continues. “But ignorance, when it is

wrapped in pride, is just as bad. You at least are not trying to pretend you understand

more than you do. That is in your favor.”

Her gaze flicks sideways to Paya.

“This is why I told you to use the help around you,” she says. “Ollie, Claree, Tasho, the

others. And Paya.”

Paya startles a little at hearing her name, then straightens.

Impa looks back to you.

“If you ask an auntie in the street whether the leaves fall in Kakariko, she will indeed decide

you are mad,” she says dryly. “But if you ask Paya, or Ollie, or one of your workmates some

small thing—how the days are counted, when the first frost usually comes, why the frogs

sing louder on some nights—they will think you curious, not cursed.”

She lifts her cup, finds it empty, and sets it down again.

“You do not need to learn this world all at once,” she says. “We have lived here long

enough that we forget which questions are basic. If something feels so simple that a child

would laugh at you for asking, bring it to those who have already seen you tired and dirty.

They will laugh less.”

At your specific question, she inclines her head, eyes narrowing thoughtfully.

“As for the season,” she says, “that I can answer without shame for either of us.”

Her voice shifts into the cadence of someone reciting something half by memory, half by

feel.

“Hyrule knows four turns of the year,” she says. “The budding, the growing, the fading, and

the sleeping. The Sheikah keep more precise measures, but the land does not care about

our names, only our habits.”

She gestures vaguely outward, toward the valley.

“Right now, we are near the end of the budding,” she says. “The plum trees in the village

have already flowered and dropped most of their petals. The fields in the lower terraces

are mostly planted; the last of the seedlings went into the earth not long before you

arrived.”

Her eyes soften a fraction.

“The nights are still cool enough that you see your breath at dawn, as you did this

morning,” she goes on, “but the days grow longer. Fireflies will start to gather in the

paddies soon. In Hebra, the snow loosens its grip on the lower slopes. In Gerudo, the sand

is no kinder, but the winds shift.”

She tilts her head.

“In the words you used,” she adds, “this would be… late spring, almost the first toes of

summer.”

Paya’s shoulders relax a little at that, as if glad there was at least one question she could

have answered herself.

Impa regards you for another moment.

“You may feel foolish for not knowing such things,” she says, “but remember: anyone

dropped naked in the middle of a strange land would be the same. The only difference is

that most of them would not admit it.”

Her tone sharpens, just a touch.

“What you must not do,” she continues, “is use your gaps as an excuse to forget your

weight. You are allowed to ask when the seasons turn. You are not allowed to ask, in the

middle of the square, what became of machines that the villagers would rather think of as

bad dreams.”

Her hands fold together, bones and tendons like knotted roots.

“You may speak to me of the heavy things,” she says. “You may speak to those you trust

about the light ones. Between those two, you will find a way to walk without tripping

everyone around you.”

There’s a brief, surprisingly gentle silence.

Then she nods once, decisive.

“That is enough candor for one evening,” she says. “You have work, you have a bed, you

have a season. For someone who arrived with nothing but questions, that is good

progress.”

Paya gathers herself and rises just enough to bow, then settles again.

“If you… ever wish to know about the calendar, or the festivals, or… um… tea,” she adds

haltingly, “I can… answer those. Or find out.”

Impa does not contradict her.

The lanternlight feels warmer now, the room less like a tribunal, more like a place where

people have simply been talking for a while. Outside, the sounds of the village evening

have thickened: bowls clinking, muted laughter, a distant cucco complaining about

something only it understands.

Impa gives you a final, measured look.

“Go on,” she says quietly. “Let your feet learn the way between here and your bed. You will

be walking it often.”

The door is where it was, the slope down to the inn the same path you took up—but the

knowledge that it is late spring in Hyrule settles somewhere specific inside you. The year

has a place now. So do you, at least for tonight.

*/ Begin tracking the season in addition to what is already being tracked. Assume a Hyrulean season (and subsequently, a Hyrulean year) are approximately the same duration as they are on Earth. /*

I have more questions--weightier ones too--but the subtle reminder of the door is not lost on me, and I take the hint that Impa is ready to retire from this conversation. I consider that maybe I can come back another time. I stand and give a respectful bow to Impa, then to Paya. "Thank you Lady. And thank you Paya. Especially for the tea. It was very good." I pause. "I really like tea. Please have a good night."

I excuse myself and leave the house the way I came. As I am about to descend the exterior steps, I stop by Dorian, giving the respectful head bow that I feel I will never be able to give to him and Impa enough. "I hope you have a good night, Dorian. And..." I fumble with words for a moment, "I hope you will let me know if there is anything I can do for you. To atone, I mean. I know you will probably say that keeping my promises and abiding by Lady Impa's word is enough, but I really mean it. If something does come to mind that you could use me for, please don't hesitate to call on me. I don't like living in debt with my money, and I don't like living in debt with..." I don't use the word friend, in case it is too presumptuous. "people." I stand there very awkwardly for few seconds as silence stands simply between us. Neither oppressive nor trivial, but present. But I excuse myself, so as to not pressure the man. "I hope you have a good night, sir." I correct myself. "Dorian."

Thought for 15s

Impa’s house – front steps

Day 3, early evening • Late spring (budding) • Lanterns warm, sky deepening blue

You step back out into the cooler air, Impa’s door sliding shut with a soft wooden sigh

behind you.

Dorian stands where he was, spear grounded, silhouette steady in the lanternlight. When

you bow and speak, he listens without looking away, jaw working once as if he’s chewing

on your words.

For a moment after you finish, there’s only the night sounds: waterfall, cicadas, a distant

dog bark from lower in the village.

Then he exhales through his nose—a short, controlled breath.

“You are right about one thing,” he says quietly. “I would have said that keeping your

promises is enough.”

He shifts his grip on the spear, eyes still forward, but there’s less iron in his posture than

there was that first day.

“I cannot ask you to undo what you know,” he goes on. “And I cannot forget how you

chose to prove it.”

A beat.

“But you are working,” he adds. “You show your face. You come when Lady Impa calls.

These are… not the habits of a coward.”

His gaze finally slides to you, measuring, the old hurt still there but no longer quite so raw.

“If there comes a day I have some use for you,” he says, “I will not be shy about saying so.

Until then, you owe me nothing but honesty and caution.”

He gives the faintest nod, almost a bow and almost not.

“Good night, Zeth,” he finishes. “Sleep. Tomorrow, do not make my job harder.”

The last is delivered in that dry, almost-humorous tone you’ve started to recognize. Then

his attention returns to the path, to the village below, to whatever passes for peace on

sentry duty in quiet years.

The steps down feel a little less steep with that behind you.

—

Kakariko lanes → Shuteye Inn

Day 3, early night • Late spring (budding) • Air cool, cooking smells thickening

The village has leaned fully into evening.

Lanterns glow at doors and along paths, casting warm puddles of light on stone and earth.

Voices drift from open windows—families talking over bowls, the clink of chopsticks, the

occasional burst of laughter. The waterfall’s murmur is a constant, softer now under the

closer, homelier noises.

You pass the Goddess statue again; someone’s left fresh flowers there since you last sat by

its pond, pale petals catching lantern glow. Fireflies have begun to rise in the wetter

patches between terraces, small green-gold sparks winking lazily.

By the time you reach Shuteye Inn, your legs are beginning to protest the day in earnest.

The doorway shows a familiar slice of light and shadow; the wooden sign creaks faintly as

the evening breeze shifts.

Inside, the common room is busier than before: three low tables occupied, villagers

hunched over bowls, steam curling up in the lamplight. The stew tonight is thicker, richer

—the scent of beans, root vegetables, and something smoky filling the room. Tea steam

adds a softer, roasted note on top.

Ollie is behind the counter, midway through stacking clean cups. When the door slides

open he looks up, spots you, and grins.

“You survived,” he says, keeping his voice pitched low enough not to disturb the other

diners. “And you smell more like cedar and less like… whatever happens when you mix

cedar with horse.”

His eyes flick over your cleaner hair, the still-worn clothes, the particular way you’re

carrying your shoulders.

“Room’s made up,” he adds with a little nod toward the stairs. “Your things are where you

left them. And there’s stew and tea if you want them. You look like you could use both.”

He reaches for a bowl almost automatically, as if assuming the answer but polite enough

to wait for it, ladle hovering over the pot. A teapot sits ready nearby, faint tendrils of steam

escaping from under its lid.

Your bed is a short staircase away. Your first full earned coin in Hyrule weighs in your

pocket. The day’s work has settled into your muscles like sand after water drains away.

Evening at the inn stretches in front of you, bounded by food, tea, and the welcome

prospect of lying down and not having to move for a while.

I nod and exhale with a deep sigh. "I am glad I do not smell like a horse. And I am famished, it's true," I say, positively acknowledging the bowl and tea. "What's on tonight?"

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 3, early night • Late spring (budding) • Lanterns warm, stew steam thick in the air

Ollie tips the lid of the pot back with the ladle, letting a fresh cloud of steam roll up

between you.

“Tonight’s the ‘we had beans and roots to spare’ special,” he says. “Lot of white beans,

carrots, onion, bit of turnip. My mother threw in some smoked river fish for flavor—don’t

worry, it’s more ‘rich’ than ‘fishy’.”

You catch a good whiff: earthy beans, sweetness from carrot and onion, that deep, almost

bacon-like smokiness from the fish, and a hint of something herbal you can’t quite place.

The broth looks thick and glossy, clinging to the ladle.

He nudges the teapot with his knuckles.

“Tea’s barley again,” he adds. “She toasted it darker this time. Good for after a long day;

sits in the stomach like a friend, not a stone.”

There’s a faint smile at that—he’s clearly quoting someone, probably his mother.

He lifts a clean bowl, ladle hovering over the pot.

“Same deal as last night,” he says. “Few rupees for a bowl and as much tea as you can

politely drink.”

He glances up from the pot to your face, reading the exhaustion there, then cocks his head

toward one of the open tables.

“Just say the word and I’ll fill this,” he adds, steam curling around his wrist as he waits.

"The word is given," I say with a smile. "That sounds great on both counts." As he acquiesces and fills the bowl and cup I roll around in my mind things I know about food, both from the games and from my old world.

"Say Ollie, what other sorts of places are there in the village for meals? I'm not slighting Shuteye in the least, it's pure curiosity. I love rice, could eat a lot of it, but I'm not exactly a chef myself. I have one dish I could probably make in a good way that some people might consider to be 'Kakariko' in style," I think about being in my old home making hibachi-style fried rice in a wok. It was the only rice dish I knew how to make, but I think I did it pretty well. Assuming somebody else made the yum-yum sauce, that is. I had no idea how to make that stuff, or really what even went into it. I also wondered if Kakariko had an equivalent to hibachi. "But regardless, I've always wanted to try some good rice balls. Especially a good and hearty mushroom rice ball. They don't have them where I come from."

I think twice on that as he serves me the stew and start to eat. "Well, I guess they do, but they're very uncommon, and I didn't know anybody who made them."

Thought for 6s

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 3, early night • Late spring • Lanterns warm, stew & barley tea

“The word is given,” you say, and Ollie grins like that’s exactly the answer he was

expecting.

He dips the ladle deep, gives the stew a stir from the bottom, then pours a generous

helping into your bowl. Beans, carrot coins, soft onion, a few small flakes of pale fish that

look like they’ve mostly melted into the broth. It lands with a satisfying plop and a wave of

rich, savory smell.

He follows it with tea, tilting the pot in a slow arc. The barley brew comes out a deep,

toasty brown, little wisps of steam curling up.

He slides both across the counter to you and listens as you talk, the corner of his mouth

quirking higher when you mention having one “Kakariko-ish” dish you can cook.

“Careful,” he says. “You tell my mother you can cook anything and she’ll put you behind

the stove the next time we’re short.”

He leans his hip against the counter, polishing a stray spot on a cup while he thinks about

your question.

“As for food in the village,” he says, “we’re not exactly Hateno. No row of restaurants

waiting to fatten travelers.”

He gestures loosely with the rag.

“There’s us,” he says. “We feed whoever’s staying under our roof and anyone who can’t be

bothered to cook their own dinner.”

A nod toward the door.

“High Spirits Produce does roasted corn, grilled pumpkins, that sort of thing when they’ve

got extra and the weather’s nice,” he adds. “Olkin can’t resist showing off if he’s had a

good harvest.”

He taps his chin with the back of his knuckle.

“Most other cooking stays in people’s houses,” he goes on. “Every family’s got its own way

of doing rice and stew and pickles. If you start making friends, you’ll start getting

invitations—and then you’ll find out what you’ve really been missing.”

The mention of rice balls gets a more focused look.

“Onigiri, you mean,” he says. “Rice pressed around a filling, wrapped in seaweed if you’re

lucky enough to get it.”

He jerks his head toward the uphill lanes.

“Rinna’s mother makes good ones,” he says. “Simple, but they hold together even if you’re

hanging upside down from a roof.” A fleeting grin. “Sef’s aunt too. She sells them from a

basket some mornings—plain salt, pickled plum, sometimes mushroom if she’s been

trading with the foragers.”

He considers you for a beat.

“If you’re after mushroom rice balls, that’s not hard,” he says. “We get good ones from the

hills. Mix them into hot rice with a bit of soy and salt, let it cool just enough to handle,

then press them. The trick is not burning your fingers and not letting the rice get cold.”

He shrugs.

“Tell you what,” he adds. “If you bring mushrooms that aren’t poisonous”—a tiny, teasing

emphasis—“and you’re willing to help in the kitchen, we could probably turn out a batch

one evening. Call it… ‘cultural exchange.’”

From the hearth, his mother snorts softly, but doesn’t object.

You take your first spoonful of stew and it lands like exactly what your body wanted: beans

soft but not mushy, carrots sweet, broth thick and smoky with the fish. It’s rustic, filling, the

kind of thing that feels like it’s patching holes inside you.

The barley tea chases it down with a warm, toasty note. It does, in fact, sit in your stomach

like a friend.

Ollie gives you space to eat, moving off to refill another customer’s cup, but as he passes

back by, he tilts his head toward the stairs.

“When you’re done,” he says quietly, “your room’s ready whenever you are. Doors stay

open till the last bowl’s washed, but you look like you might fall asleep in your stew if you

sit too long.”

The evening hum of the inn wraps around you: clink of bowls, low conversations, the soft

rush of the waterfall just beyond the walls.

You’ve got hot food, hot tea, a bed with your name on it, and the pleasantly bone-deep

ache of a day that actually meant something.

For Night 3 in Hyrule, that’s not a bad place to be.

I make a mental note of the offer to make some mushroom onigiri if I can provide the ingredients, and wonder for a minute when I could possibly make time to do so. Then again, if Impa wasn't requiring me to check-in every evening, that did leave me at least some time in the afternoons, and she had said that if I made sure Dorian or Cado knew where I was going, I had a little mobility. There were some woods up the hill toward Lakna Rokee Shrine and the Great Faerie Fountain that surely did have some mushrooms. I've never been mushroom foraging before, but I do recall distinctly what most of the edible, collectible fungi around Hyrule look like, and it seems to me like it might be easier to sus them out here than in my old world. If I was allowed to go there. I'd check tomorrow after work.

As I near finishing my meal, I like the sound of Ollie's reminder of my bed and my room. "Thanks. Hey, before I head up there, I don't suppose you have something I could write on and write with, do you? I just need to make some notes for myself."

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 3, early night • Late spring • Lanterns low, bellies full

Ollie is already reaching for your bowl for a refill that never comes when you ask about

writing materials. He pauses, tilts his head, and then brightens a little.

“Notes, huh?” he says. “That’s… surprisingly responsible of you.”

He glances toward the hearth.

“Ma? Spare paper?”

His mother sniffs, but there’s no real resistance in it.

“In the chest,” she says, not looking up from the pot. “Not the good stuff. The one with the

smudge on the lid.”

Ollie ducks behind the counter, rummages for a moment, then comes up with:

A thin, slightly bent wooden writing board, about the size of a slate.

A few half-sheets of rough paper—fibers visible, not the fine calligraphy stock.

A small covered inkstone and a slim brush with worn bristles.

He sets them on the counter in a neat stack.

“We don’t keep pencils just lying around,” he says. “But this will work if you don’t mind

getting along with a brush. Try not to lean on the paper while the ink’s wet, or you’ll

smudge it and look very mysterious by accident.”

There’s a faint, teasing smile at that.

“You’re welcome to take it up to your room,” he adds. “Just bring the stone and brush back

down in the morning so I don’t get yelled at for ‘losing the tools of literacy’.”

From the hearth: a quiet, “I heard that,” with no real bite behind it.

The paper is rough under your fingers, pleasantly toothy. The brush has seen better days

but still holds a point if you treat it gently. The ink smells faintly metallic and earthy, a little

like wet stone and old tea.

The stairs up to your room wait, along with a bare tatami floor, a low chest, your little stack

of belongings—and now, the means to start turning the whirling list in your head into

actual written plans before sleep.

I accept the utensils gratefully, and decide to take him up on his offer to bring them to my room. I wasn't sure what I was going to be given, and when I see it is literally a calligraphy brush and ink, I mentally begin to fret a bit. I have no idea how to use these, and I preferred to struggle in privacy this time. Back when Harlin had first met me he'd commented on my preference for books and maps. Said I sounded like I was from a city. Code for "nerdy" or "geeky", is how I'd taken it at the time. I mentally squirmed at the thought of him and Mera seeing me not really knowing how to *write*.

I take the items upstairs and realise, with relief, that Ollie seems to have left some sort of lamp or lantern lit for me. Another thing I wouldn't have known what to do with. With it already being lit, at least I could postpone that concern for another day. I sit down on a tatami mat and spread the materials out. I thought I'd be scribbling down a quick note, but now I felt like I was about to take an exam about some kind of elaborate tea ceremony nobody told me about.

"Shouldn't be that hard," I say quietly to myself. "Just think of it like an ink pen with a squishy, leaky point." I open the ink, pick up the brush and dip it in, thinking to myself that I'd go very lightly at first. But before I even put brush to paper I stop again. It suddenly occurs to me that I have a choice. I could write this in English...or Hylian. It had not even occurred to me before now that I'd been seeing and reading Hylian script on signposts and labels ever since I'd arrived and never had a single problem with it. It wasn't as if Hylian had simply supplanted English in my brain--

English was still very much there and accessible--but I just *did* understand Hylian. And that was weird. Cool though.

I ponder for a moment. Writing in Hylian would certainly be "normal" and not raise any eyebrows, but then, this was a note for myself. It wasn't especially for anybody else. And writing in English felt...nostalgic, somehow. And now, if I was the only one reading and writing it, it was like my own secret little code that only I knew. So I settle on English The brush and ink was clearly intended for Hylian, and the strokes for the English letters are slightly more clumsy to write with it than their Hylian counterparts would have been, but I manage just fine. It didn't matter anyways. So long as I could read it, nobody else would see it, and even if for some reason they did, they wouldn't know what the letters were supposed to look like anyways.

First I make out my would-be shopping list from earlier that day: - Backpack/stachel/bag - Cloak - Hat (?) - Belt (!) - Sword sheath/scabbard (?) - Extra set of clothes (!)

I look at my handiwork. It's clunky, but at least it didn't look like a 5-year-old wrote it. Maybe more like an old man with a slight tremor in his hand. The Bs, Cs and Ss are especially clunky though, the calligraphy brush not intended to form its particular type of curves. But I'm content with it. It only needed to be okay by me. A nice place not to be judged or scrutinised. I add a bullet at the end: - Notebook and pencil (?)

Pleased with that list, I set it aside atop the chest in the room to make double-sure the ink dries (I don't know how long it needs), and start another list. This one less practical or necessary.

- Western Dueling Peaks Stable: Herb + Mint (Pella heavy on mint) - Kakariko: Toasted Barley -- Sakura Barley It's a list of teas I've tried and liked since I arrived. Which is to say, all of them, so far. I wasn't going to have many luxuries here for a while, but a good tea still felt like one I could still enjoy. And, much like writing the English script, it felt a little pleasantly nostalgic.

I place the tea list beside the list of desired items to dry, then replace the lid on the ink and stack the materials neatly just beneath the edge of the bed, intending to return them in the morning. Then I look for the correct way to stifle the light in the room so I could get some sleep.

Thought for 12s

Shuteye Inn – guest room
