Night 3 • Late spring (budding) • Cool air, faint village sounds

The lantern is a simple thing: a wooden frame, thin paper panels, and a shallow dish of oil

with a short, fat wick. Someone—almost certainly Ollie—has set it on a low stand near the

futon, wick turned up just enough to give a steady, modest flame.

Up close you can see the tiny gear on the side of the bracket: a little metal wheel, speckled

with old soot. Turning it slowly lowers the wick. The flame shrinks from bright almond to a

small, stubborn bead of orange, then to a dull coal before it gutters out with a faint tch

and a wisp of smoke that smells of warm oil and singed dust.

The room exhales into darkness.

Not absolute—soft seams of moonlight and village lantern-glow spill in around the edges

of the shoji and across the tatami, silvering the lines of the mats and the curve of the futon

where you pull it out and spread it.

The day catches up to you the moment you lower yourself onto it.

Your shoulders sink into the thin padding like they finally got permission. Every muscle

along your back has an opinion: not sharp pain, just a chorus of used, used, used. Your

hands throb more now that you’re not moving, blisters pulsing in time with your

heartbeat. The smell of cedar still ghosts off your hair and clothes, mingling with the

straw-sweet scent of the tatami.

From outside, Kakariko at night is a quieter creature:

Waterfall, steady and low.

A cucco protesting once and then shutting up.

Laughter from somewhere down the slope, already fading.

The high, thin chorus of insects in the paddies.

The two sheets of paper on the chest are just visible in the dim: your lists in unfamiliar

tools but very familiar letters. A little island of “you” in a room that is firmly “here.”

The brush and ink sit neatly stacked at the futon’s edge, ready to be returned in the

morning. Your sword and sad little shield lean against the chest. The rupee bag rests

beside them, its small weight newly significant.

Lantern out.

Door closed.

Bed under you.

Work waiting at dawn.

Night 3 in Hyrule settles around you like one more thin blanket: not heavy enough to

smother, just enough to say stay, rest, there will be more tomorrow.

I only lay awake in the bed briefly before starting to drift off to sleep this night. No evening chill in the cart, a harder day's work behind me. I don't have time for any overly troubling thoughts.

At least, until one little one resurfaces. Impa's foreboding statement about death. What had she said? If I find myself

dead but still walking? If that means not actually dying, surely that was a good thing, right? Maybe not. Undeath, or at least a form of it, existed in Hyrule. The thought of becoming a Stal-creature was not an appealing one. Was she hinting that whatever brought me to Hyrule...would insure that I would stay in Hyrule, even beyond death? Wouldn't be any good trying to leave in that case.

Another night, another hornet's nest of worrying thoughts I would have to drown out and sleep through. I hope this doesn't become a habitual thing as I try to force myself to empty my mind a bit and get some rest.

Shuteye Inn – guest room

Night 3 → Dawn 4 • Late spring (budding) • Night cool, dawn mist clinging low

The thought about death and still walking hangs around like a mosquito in the dark—

small, but impossibly good at finding the soft parts of your brain.

Stal-creatures. Waking up again when you shouldn’t. Groundhog Day with bokoblins.

Your body, at least, has its own opinion about how long to entertain this.

Your shoulders pulse in slow, steady waves of ache; your hands throb at the blisters; your

legs hum with that heavy fatigue that feels almost pleasant if you don’t poke at it. The

futon warms under you, tatami scent soft and dry, cedar clinging to your hair. Each time

your thoughts try to circle back to Impa’s warning, a yawn interrupts them, stretching your

jaw till your eyes water.

Outside, the sounds of Kakariko thin as the night settles fully:

The last voices fade.

A door slides shut.

The waterfall keeps its own time, unconcerned with yours.

Your mind makes one more clumsy lap around the worry—undeath, waking after death,

being stuck here forever—and then the edges blur. The hornets in the nest lose their

stingers and become just… buzzing. Background.

Sleep takes you the way a wave takes a stone: no ceremony, no clear boundary, just gone.

—

Shuteye Inn – guest room

Day 4, early morning • Late spring (budding) • Dawn chill, faint mist in the valley

You surface to pale light pushing around the edges of the shoji and a slice of cool air on

your face.

Your body reports in all at once:

Back: stiff, but not broken.

Shoulders: sore, a deep, used ache rather than sharp pain.

Hands: tight, blisters tender when you flex your fingers, but nothing split or weeping.

Legs: that pleasantly heavy feeling from a day well spent, not the rubbery weakness of

overdoing it.

The futon is still warm under you; the air above the blankets has bite, enough that seeing

your breath wouldn’t be surprising if you sat up too fast. The faint smell of straw and cedar

lingers in the room, mixed with a ghost of last night’s barley tea in your memory more

than the air.

From outside come the small sounds of Kakariko waking:

A broom brushing stone somewhere below.

Soft cluck-clicks from cuccos being let out to scratch.

Waterfall, constant.

A pair of women’s voices trading early-morning gossip at a distance, too muffled to make

out the words.

Your lists rest on the chest where you left them, ink dry and matte in the dim light:

practical needs, and tea. The brush and inkstone sit neatly where you stacked them by the

futon’s edge, waiting to be returned downstairs.

Your rupee bag is still where you left it—first wages in Hyrule, real weight in the world.

Your sword and canvas “shield” lean in their corner, very slightly ridiculous but very clearly

yours.

Stomach: not empty enough to hurt, but definitely interested in the concept of breakfast.

The inn below will be stirring soon—porridge, maybe, and tea if you’re lucky—Tasho’s

crew will expect you once the sun clears the ridgeline, and Impa’s terms sit quietly in the

back of your mind like a new beam in an old house.

Morning of Day 4 has arrived. The room is cool, your muscles are honest-sore, and the

path between your futon, the stairs, and the worksite is starting to feel like part of your

own map of Hyrule.

I roll to one side lazily, enjoying the warmth on the futon for a minute more before getting up. I somehow feel both better and worse rested than the night before. My body still seems to have rested but my mind still groggy, as if maybe I had a nightmare I can't remember.

As I lay there on my side I feel a little bit more of a faint scratchiness on my chin and cheek. A reminder that I hadn’t shaved for a few days now. Pushing myself up and swinging my legs over the edge of the futon, I hover for a second before standing, feeling the bristles with a hand. A little prick makes me check my hand as well, seeing that blisters were starting to show signs of healing already. That was something.

Standing up, I take the opportunity to place most of my things actually inside the chest for safe keeping, except for some rupees needed to renew my stay at thr inn for another night, and what was ledt of Mera's gifted foodstuffs to have as another lunch today. I also leave my notes on the stand near the lantern, though I take the time to fold them in half so they arent immediately visible to anybody who might go by.

Giving my head a little shake, I head down to renew my stay another night ans hopedully have some breakfast before heading out.

Shuteye Inn – guest room → common room

Day 4, early morning • Late spring (budding) • Dawn cool, thin mist in the valley

Getting up is a whole-body negotiation.

Your back complains for exactly three seconds, then loosens as you stand. The blisters on

your hands twinge when you flex your fingers, but the skin looks better: less angry, edges

already beginning to toughen. The faint scruff on your chin and jaw is new enough to feel

unfamiliar on this face—coarse stubble under Hylian skin.

Most of your worldly goods fit neatly into the chest:

Sword and canvas “shield,” laid in the bottom.

Rupee bag, minus a modest handful for the inn.

Mera’s bundle, lighter but still enough for a lunch.

Your folded notes go on the low stand by the lantern, half-hidden when you crease them.

English strokes in Hyrulean ink—your own little secret punctuation mark on the room.

The lantern wick is still dark and cold from the night; pale dawn light sliding around the

shoji is enough to see by. The air has that early chill again, not quite biting, but insistent

enough that bare feet on tatami feel it.

Downstairs, the inn is already awake.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 4, early morning • Porridge steam, low voices, barley tea

The common room is quieter than last night, but not empty.

Two older men sit at one table, already halfway through their bowls, talking in low voices

about weather and planting as if those were the only gods that mattered. By the hearth,

Ollie’s mother stands over the big pot, stirring with the same steady rhythm as yesterday.

The smell is familiar: grain, a hint of fish, something pickled and sharp on the side.

Ollie is by the counter, sleeves rolled, hair only half-tamed, drying bowls with quick,

efficient motions. A small stack of clean ones is already waiting beside the pot.

When he spots you on the stairs, he gives a brief, satisfied nod—like a craftsman checking

a joint he glued the day before.

“Morning,” he says, keeping his voice pitched low so it blends with the room instead of

chopping through it.

His eyes tick over you: a little stiff, but upright; cleaner than last night; pockets a bit

heavier; the look of someone who slept enough even if not perfectly.

He sets a bowl down, already ladling porridge.

“Same as yesterday,” he adds. “Rice porridge with a bit of fish and pickle. Tea’s on.”

As the ladle moves, his expression shifts to that slightly more businesslike set.

“And about the room,” he says, glancing toward the stairs and then back. “Harlin and Mera

don’t need it anymore, so it’s yours as long as you can pay.”

He wipes his hand on his apron, then rests it lightly on the counter.

“Today’s stay is the same we talked about before,” he says. “You cover what you can with

coin, and the rest we count against you not causing trouble or scaring off my other

guests.”

The last is said with a hint of humor, not accusation.

He nods once at your hand, where the blisters are visible.

“Looks like you’ve earned more coin than gossip yesterday,” he adds. “So renewing

shouldn’t be too hard.”

The bowl of steaming porridge and an empty cup for tea slide into easy reach on the

counter. The air above them smells like warmth: rice, a little salt, a thread of roasted barley

from the pot nearby.

Ollie waits there, relaxed but attentive, ready to take whatever rupees you lay out and pour

tea once the exchange is settled. The morning is still young; Tasho’s roof will want you

before the sun’s too high, but there’s time yet for food, payment, and a few words.

"Morning Ollie," I say as I return the writing implements and layout payment for another night. "I'm afraid you haven't seen the last of me for a little bit yet. Thanks again for letting me borrow these," I indicate the paper, brush and such. I nod approvingly at the breakfast and tea, satisfied that I feel a little less rushed this morning than yesterday.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 4, early morning • Late spring (budding) • Steam, quiet voices, cool air at the door

Ollie takes the brush and inkstone with visible relief, like a man happy his tools survived

their first loan.

“Didn’t spill ink on the tatami,” he says. “Already ahead of half the people who borrow

those.”

He tucks the inkstone and brush back under the counter in their place, then accepts your

rupees, counting them with a quick, practiced touch—no fuss, no suspicion, just making

sure the math works. He nods once, content.

“Right,” he says. “Then the room’s yours another night. If you vanish in the middle of the

week now, I’ll have to actually be disappointed.”

There’s a dry little glint in his eye that reads very clearly as joke, not curse.

His mother sets a small dish on the counter beside your porridge: a couple of thin slices of

pickled radish and a scrap of fish, grilled until the skin puffed and crisped. She gives you a

brief, assessing look—up, down, hands, shoulders.

“You’re standing straighter than yesterday,” she says. “Good. Keep it that way. Men who

slouch end up asking for cheap beds and expensive medicine.”

Then, more gently: “Eat. It will help your hands forget they’re injured.”

She moves away to tend the pot, conversation over on her end, but the little nod she gives

your bowl counts as something like approval.

The porridge is simple but hits every empty place: soft rice carrying the salt and richness of

the flakes of fish, the pickles adding sharp snaps of sour-salty crunch between bites. The

barley tea is less smoky than last night’s stew, more roasted and clean—warmer than the

air, just shy of hot.

You’ve got time to eat without inhaling it. The room runs on quiet morning energy: muted

talk at the other table, the clink of bowls as Ollie stacks the washed ones to dry, the

occasional creak of the building as it adjusts to the rising sun.

By the time you set your chopsticks down, your stomach has settled into that comfortably

weighted state that makes the idea of carrying beams again seem possible rather than

cruel. The tea leaves a lingering warmth in your chest and a faint toasted taste on your

tongue.

Outside, the inn’s doorway shows the village in early activity: thin mist still hanging in the

lower terraces, cuccos scratching, someone already sweeping the lane in front of their

house. The sky over the valley is slipping from pale lavender toward clear blue.

Tasho’s worksite waits downhill, half-framed roof and stacks of cedar. Rinna and Sef will be

there soon if they’re not already, and the day will want your back and hands again.

You’ve got a full belly, a roof for tonight paid up, and enough time to walk to the

carpenters without having to rush or run. The path down the slope is becoming familiar

under your feet, another groove in the new life this Hylian body is settling into.

I finish my breakfast and grab what will pass for my lunch, realising that after today I'll have to figure out exactly how to provide something for lunch. I enjoy taking in more of the sights, sounds and smells of Kakariko as I walk to the jobsite this morning, watching for any faces that are becoming familiar, any that distinctly aren't.

Kakariko lanes → lower terraces, carpenters’ jobsite

Day 4, early morning • Late spring (budding) • Mist thinning, sun just catching the

rooftops

The air outside bites just enough to wake you up properly.

Kakariko at this hour feels like a shy animal slowly coming out of its burrow. Lanes are

damp from night mist; swept stone and packed dirt are darkened a shade, footprints

already smudging the smoothness where early risers have passed.

You walk the now-familiar curve past:

A pair of aunties on a veranda, one sweeping, one “helping” by leaning on the railing

and talking. They both pause to glance your way—a flicker of recognition now instead

of pure curiosity—then return to their conversation.

High Spirits Produce, door propped open, Olkin already moving crates just inside,

humming something tuneless. He doesn’t stop you, but you catch the brief nod of

“seen you around, not a stranger anymore.”

Enchanted, its shoji still closed, but a hint of movement shadows the paper from

within—Claree’s silhouette stretching as she starts her day, Lasli’s shorter one

flickering past.

A child barrels past you barefoot, clutching a wooden toy horse, hair half-combed,

someone calling after them from up the lane. They dodge around you easily, barely

glancing up.

The further downhill you go, the more the village opens up: houses giving way to paddies

and small fields. The mist in the terraces is thin now, clinging low over the water like

breath on glass. Frogs are bold this morning—occasional splashes, the soft creak-croak

chorus from ditches and banks. A few early fireflies still blink lazily in the shadowed spots

before winking out in the growing light.

By the time you reach the jobsite, the sun’s just starting to peek above the eastern ridge,

light catching on the skeleton of the roof you’ve been helping build. The cedar beams

glow a soft gold where they’re bare, the freshly cut faces lighter than the seasoned posts

they join.

Tasho’s crew is already there.

Rinna is up on the frame, one foot braced on a beam, the other hooked casually behind a

post, as steady as if she were standing on flat ground. She’s rolling her shoulders,

stretching out muscles, hair tied back in a quick knot. From below you can see the line of

the old scar across her forearm when she lifts it, the freckles on her nose dark against

morning-pale skin.

Sef is on the ground by the tool tarp, sorting through saws and chisels. He looks up when

he hears your steps, gives a quick, shy half-wave, then goes back to making sure

everything is where it should be.

Tasho stands near the front corner of the house, hands resting on the top of a post, legs

planted wide. His stocky frame looks even more solid in the early light, gray threaded

through his short-cropped hair and beard catching silver. He watches the roofline like he’s

checking an old friend’s posture.

He notices you a moment later and turns, giving you a once-over: face, hands, the way

you’re carrying yourself after yesterday.

There’s a little grunt that, for him, passes for approval.

“Good,” he says. “You came back.”

He jerks his chin toward the stacked timbers and the half-finished rafters laid out on

trestles.

“Today, we fit and set more of the roof ribs,” he says. “Less lifting, more shaping. Your

hands will curse me, but your back will thank me.”

Rinna calls down a greeting, voice bright in the cool air. Sef shifts to make room for you at

the trestles, nudging a saw closer with his foot.

The cedar smell is strong here—sharp and clean, mixing with the damp-earth scent of the

lower fields. Your shoulders remember the weight from yesterday, but not with dread:

more like your body already understands the pattern of the work.

Tasho looks from the tools to you, then up at the roof.

“Eat enough?” he asks. “Good. Then we work until the sun is there—” he nods to a point

higher on the slope “—and then we complain.”

The rhythm of Day 4 is laid out in front of you: marked in beams to cut, joints to fit, and

the slow, steady rise of the sun over Kakariko as the village moves from cool mist to full

wakefulness.

I say my greetings cheerfully and tuck my lunch off in a corner, then pull on my gloves. Ready to work. I let the time pass as it will as I do, prepared to react to whatever noteworthy thing may happen next.

Thought for 11s

Kakariko – lower terraces, carpenters’ jobsite

Day 4, morning • Late spring (budding) • Sun burning off mist, cedar sharp in the air

You tuck your lunch safely out of the way, tug on the gloves, and the day clicks into the

groove Tasho laid out.

The morning is all about rafters.

Sef helps you get the first few lengths of cedar up on the trestles. The boards are lighter

than yesterday’s big beams, but still have a satisfying heft—enough that your back knows

you’re working, not enough to feel cruel. The grain runs straight and tight, pale where

Tasho’s plane has already skimmed them.

You find your rhythm with the pull-saw faster today. The first cut bites a little, the teeth

catching where you try to push instead of draw—but Rinna’s warning from yesterday rings

in your memory, and the second stroke glides. The blade sings a quiet shhk with each pull,

curls of cedar dust falling onto your gloves and sleeves and drifting to the ground.

Tasho moves among you with the easy authority of someone who’s built more roofs than

most people have had birthdays. He checks your first joints closely, thumb pressing into

the shoulders where the rafter will sit on the beam. He grunts once when a line is true,

twice if he wants you to take another shaving.

“Again,” is all he says when something needs correcting, but there’s no sting in it—just

insistence on getting the wood and the joint to agree with each other.

Rinna spends the early part of the morning up top, calling down measurements and

marking where each rib will land. From below, you can see the sure way she moves along

the skeleton: knees bent, weight low, toes gripping the beam. The scar on her forearm

catches the light whenever she wipes her brow with the back of her hand. A pencil sits

tucked behind one ear; a few curls of hair have escaped her knot and stick to her cheek

with sweat.

“Send the next one up,” she calls at one point, voice bright. Sef and you heft a finished

rafter between you and pass it to her waiting hands. She slots it into its notch, tests the fit

with a few solid thunk-thunk taps of a mallet, and gives Tasho a sharp nod.

“Good,” Tasho says. “Your hand is learning.”

Your hands don’t completely agree. The blisters complain when you tighten your grip; the

pull-saw’s handle presses against healing skin in a way that makes your teeth clench. But

the pain is cleaner now—less raw, more “you used me” than “what did you do to me.”

Midmorning, Tasho calls a water break.

A jug sits under the lean shade of a half-built overhang. The water inside is cool from the

morning air, tasting faintly of clay. Your tongue feels a little rough by the time you get

there; the first swallow is almost shockingly good, the second settles into something

calmer. Sweat has pasted cedar dust to your forearms and the back of your neck; in the

breeze, the damp patches chill quickly, raising gooseflesh.

Sef sinks onto an overturned crate beside you, stretching his legs out with a groan that

sounds older than he is. Up close, you can see more of him than you took in yesterday:

thinner than Rinna, wiry rather than broad, hair pulled back in a messy knot, a faint ink

smudge along one wrist where some old mark hasn’t entirely washed out.

“Rinna says you worked at Enchanted before Tasho roped you in,” he says between sips.

“Sorting clothes and such. That’s two honest days in a row. If you keep going you’ll ruin

your reputation as a mysterious stranger.”

There’s a shy grin there, quick and crooked.

Rinna hops down from the frame with a thump, landing light despite the height. She snags

the jug from Sef and drinks, then wipes her mouth with the back of her hand.

“You’re holding the saw better today,” she says to you. “Less fighting, more… listening.”

She gestures with the jug vaguely toward the hills.

“Wood’s not so different from people,” she adds. “It tells you if you’re pushing it the wrong

way. You just have to stop being stubborn long enough to hear it.”

She tips her head, considering you for a moment.

“If you mean to keep working with us a while,” she says, “you should think about getting

something for that belt you keep not having.”

The corner of her mouth quirks.

“Not just for your rupees,” she adds. “You keep asking to borrow my chisel, I’ll start

charging you a rental fee. There’s a leatherworker who comes through some market days.

Or you might get lucky with something secondhand.”

She glances up the slope, toward the direction of the shrine path and the fairy fountain,

squinting at the tree line.

“And if you really do know your mushrooms like you told the innkeep,” she says, “the

woods up that way are good picking—if you ask Cado first and don’t dawdle. My mother’s

always grateful for extra. She’ll turn them into dinner, and smoked rice balls, and ‘what do

you mean you’re full, there’s still one left.’”

Tasho clears his throat, the sound like a small thunderclap.

“Less talking, more rafters,” he says, but there’s no real heat in it. “The roof does not build

itself while you gossip.”

Break ends. Back to work.

The rest of the late morning and early afternoon slip into a pattern: measure, mark, saw,

test-fit, shave, set. Each rafter you send up makes the skeleton of the roof look more like a

house and less like a question mark. The sun climbs, burning the last of the mist from the

lower fields; the frogs go quiet as the day warms. Sweat trickles down your spine; cedar

dust works its way into your hair and the creases of your gloves.

Your back, as promised, complains less than yesterday. Your hands complain more, but in

that way that feels like they’re getting tougher with every stroke.

By the time Tasho finally calls a halt, the sun has moved a good distance across the sky;

shadows are shorter, the heat more direct.

He steps back, hands on his hips, and studies the roofline with a craftsman’s squint.

“Enough for today,” he says at last. “If we keep going, someone will start making mistakes.

Mistakes leak.”

He turns his attention to you, then.

“You did not fall off anything, cut anything important off, or run away,” he says. “For Day

Two, that is decent.”

It’s delivered in his usual gruff tone, but there’s a trace of something like approval under it.

He gestures toward the lane, the village beyond.

“Go,” he says. “Eat the rest of what that stable hand sent. Soak your hands in cool water if

you can, or they’ll swell. Be back at the same time tomorrow, if you want the work.”

He gives you another little once-over, then nods once, satisfied.

Rinna and Sef start packing tools: blades wiped, chisels sheathed, saws stacked under the

tarp. Rinna tosses you a glance as she loops a strap around a bundle.

“If you stop by Enchanted later, tell Claree those crates didn’t break your back,” she says.

“She was worried she’d sent us a wilted reed.”

Sef shoulders a smaller bundle and shrugs.

“And if you go mushroom-hunting,” he adds, “bring some to the inn, too. Ollie makes

good rice balls when he’s trying to impress people.”

The crew peels off in their own directions—Rinna and Sef heading uphill together toward

the village, Tasho lingering to have a last, private word with the beams before he follows.

You’re left with the afternoon sun, the cedar smell still in your clothes, and the weight of

Mera’s dwindling bundle to serve as lunch.

Your body is tired but not wrecked. Your hands are sore but usable. Your stomach is ready

to be reminded it exists. The rules Impa set sit quiet at the back of your mind: village and

nearby fields by day are fair game, so long as someone knows where you went.

Kakariko stretches up the slope ahead: the inn, Enchanted, the Goddess statue, the guard

posts… and, further yet, the path that winds past Cado toward the woods and whatever

mushrooms might be waiting under the shade.

I was just starting to get worried about missing lunch when Tasho calls a stop to work. Earlier than yesterday. I realise then he simply had us work through lunchtime to finish even earlier, letting us eat a late lunch afterward. A familiarly normal thing I've asked people working with me to do many times while trying to figure out how to make the time work on a given day.

I open Mera's bundle and look at what's left. Two rolls, the tea bags (which I'm saving for a special time) and what I suspect are persimmon slices. I take a roll for now and begin eating as I walk over to Tasho before he gets away. I don't have anything special to talk to him about, and I don't interrupt his whatever mental calculus he has going. I simply accept the company. I have places to be, but I don't mind hanging around while I have my little bite to eat.

Kakariko – carpenters’ jobsite

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun warm, breeze cutting the edge

You unwrap what’s left of Mera’s bundle: two herb rolls, carefully wrapped, and the neat

stack of tea bags you’ve been hoarding like treasure. The fruit slices are soft and a little

sticky, smelling sweet and faintly floral—persimmon seems like a good guess.

You take a bite of a roll as you wander back toward Tasho.

The bread has gone a bit denser since yesterday but still tastes good: herbs, a hint of oil,

the comfort of something made by a hand that cares. It sits well on a stomach that’s been

working all morning.

Tasho stands a little off from the house, looking up at the roof. From this angle you can

see how carefully his eye tracks along the new rafters: checking spacing, checking line,

checking the way the shadows fall between them. His arms are folded, hands tucked into

his sleeves, body at rest but mind clearly still measuring.

He notices you in his peripheral vision, gives the smallest of nods, and doesn’t shoo you

away.

For a moment the two of you just stand there—him watching the structure, you chewing,

cedar and bread smells mixing on the air.

After a while he speaks, still looking at the house.

“First roof I worked on in this village,” he says, “I was about your age. Maybe a little

younger. Hands soft, back stubborn, head full of ideas about how fast things should go.”

The corner of his mouth twitches, very slightly.

“Old master back then made us work through the midday bells to finish a frame before the

weather turned,” he goes on. “Fed us late, same as today. Said roofs do not care what time

you usually eat.”

He finally shifts his gaze to you, eyes narrowed in the sun.

“You didn’t complain,” he notes. “That’s worth more than most of the lads I’ve had.”

He lets that sit, then snorts softly.

“You cut better today,” he adds. “Less fighting. More listening.”

There’s an echo of Rinna’s earlier comment in that, though he doesn’t say so outright.

He tips his chin toward your gloved hands.

“Those will harden,” he says. “Blisters now, calluses later. Just keep them clean and don’t

tear them open for pride.”

His attention returns to the house, gaze tracing the line of the ridge again.

“Stay with the work a few more days, I’ll trust you with more than rafters,” he says.

“Windows, perhaps. You said you like finishing work, yes? That’s where houses really show

whether the carpenters cared.”

He falls quiet after that, not out of dismissal but out of having said as much as he feels

needs saying for now.

The two of you share a companionable silence: you finishing off the roll; him taking stock

of the day’s progress. The sun is warm on your shoulders, but the breeze from the valley

keeps it from becoming heavy. Your stomach untwists a little with the food; the ache in

your hands settles into a dull throb rather than a sharp complaint.

After a minute or two, Tasho uncrosses his arms.

“Go on,” he says, voice back to its usual gruffness. “You’ve eaten enough to walk without

falling over. There’s still day left. No sense standing here watching wood that won’t move

until tomorrow.”

He gives you a final nod—approval, dismissal, and “see you in the morning” all wrapped

into one—and turns toward his own path back up toward the village.

You’re left with the rest of Mera’s bundle in hand, the afternoon still stretching ahead:

Kakariko up the slope, the inn, Enchanted, the Goddess statue… and, beyond the guard

posts, the tree-draped rise of the path that eventually bends toward the shrine and the

woods you’ve been thinking about.

Rather than push the conversation, I accept the gentle dismissal and wander off on my own, a mental checklist in

my mind. The day finishing slightly early had its benefits for me, since there were a few things I wanted to get done: - Check in at Enchanted as Rinna had mentioned. Wanted to give their beam a once over to see if there was anything I could do for it anyways, since I'd told them as much. - Check in with either Dorian or Cado (whomever is on duty outside Impa's at the time) about heading up near the fountain and the shrine to forage for mushrooms. Probably also a good idea to ask about the marketdays that Rinna mentioned, either from them or Paya if she was around. If I could get a deal on a belt I didn't want to miss it. It occurs to me that if they let me go, I had a chance of catching sight of a blupee. Maybe faeries as well. I didn't think the Great Faerie came out unless specifically summoned, but who knows. That would be a neat thing. - If I did get permission, I'd need to ask Ollie about borrowing a basket or a bag to put the mushrooms in. Assuming I managed to gather some.

For now, I head to Enchanted first.

Kakariko village – mid-slope • Enchanted

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun warm, breeze cool, laundry flapping

on lines

The walk back up the terraces is starting to feel like a familiar climb.

The mist is long gone now; the village has that bright, rinsed look it gets on clear days.

Someone’s hung washing between two houses—shirts and cloths and a couple of

patterned towels swaying lazily in the breeze. Frogs have mostly gone quiet, replaced by

cucco complaints and the clack of someone splitting kindling a few lanes over.

Enchanted’s shoji door is propped open today, a strip of shade on the threshold. Inside,

the shop feels as you remember it: colors and fabrics, everything smelling faintly of clean

cloth, cedar from the storage, and a floral note from some sachet you haven’t quite

located.

Claree is near the front, up on a small stool, re-tying a display of scarves so they hang in a

neater cascade. Lasli is halfway between the front and the back, arms full of folded

garments, clearly in the middle of ferrying them to the shelves.

She spots you first.

Her face brightens in that unforced way she has; the stack in her arms wobbles just a little

as she adjusts.

“Oh, good, you didn’t vanish back to the stables,” she says. “Or to… wherever wanderers

wander.”

She nods toward your gloves and the faint dust on your clothes.

“Looks like Tasho didn’t scare you off either.”

Claree turns at her sister’s words, one hand still holding a scarf in mid-loop. Her gaze flicks

over you—face, hands, posture—with a measuring look that’s more merchant than auntie,

but softer than the first time you met.

“Back in one piece,” she says. “That’s a good sign.”

She climbs down from the stool with practiced ease, tucks the loose end of the scarf into

place, and comes closer, dusting her hands briskly.

“If you came to complain about the crates, you’re too late,” she adds. “I already decided

you did well and told at least three people so. Gossip moves faster than you can sulk.”

Lasli huffs a tiny laugh at that as she sets her armful of clothes on a nearby table to sort.

The conversation about the beam clearly wasn’t forgotten on their end. Claree tips her

head toward the back without making a fuss.

“The beam’s still there, bothering me,” she says. “If you wanted to look at it while you’re

here, I won’t stop you. No promises needed; if it’s too much trouble, just say so.”

She glances at your hands, notices the blisters, and lifts a brow.

“And if Tasho already owns your fingers, don’t go breaking them for my ceiling,” she adds.

“I’d take a crooked beam over a broken guest.”

ChatGPT 5.2 Thinking

The back of the shop is as you left it: crates stacked with more sense than before, thanks

to your work, a cleared strip of floor, and above it all that slightly offending beam—

running across the ceiling, bowed just a little, like it’s slouching out of alignment with the

rest.

Up close, you can see more detail:

The beam is older than some of the other structural timbers, darker and more worn.

It looks like it’s sagged a finger’s width in the middle, enough to be visible if you have

an eye for straight lines.

There are two old mortises near one end, filled with wedges and patches—someone

has already done at least one repair in the past.

No obvious fresh cracking, but a hairline split runs along one edge for part of its

length, not deep enough to gape, but worth respecting.

Lasli trails after you with a handful of folded garments she uses as an excuse to hover

nearby, pretending to adjust a shelf while she peeks up at the beam in question.

She glances sideways at you.

“So?” she says. “Still think you might have ‘a little idea’ about what to do with it, or is it

more in the ‘pray it doesn’t fall on a customer’ category?”

She says it lightly, but there’s genuine curiosity under the teasing.

The room is quiet here, away from the street, just the soft rustle of cloth and the distant

hum of village noise. The beam waits overhead like a problem statement: not an

emergency, but not something you can un-see now that you’re looking for it.

"Oh I don't think you have to worry about it falling on anybody," I say. "Right now this is an annoyance, not a pending tragedy." I look at Claree, "Though I assume you already know that."

To illustrate my point I slap the beam on the side,

demonstrating it was still solid. "I'm not totally sure how to deal with it, but consider this a reconnaissance mission. Now that I've been able to give it a better look-over, I can start trying to figure out what can be done with it." I turn my attention to Lasli. "Can't expect a sprained ankle to heal overnight, you know?"

Enchanted – back room

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun slanting in, dust motes in the beam’s

shadow

Claree watches you slap the beam, eyes tracking the way it shivers and settles.

“Mm,” she says. “Yes. If it were planning to kill anyone, it’s had plenty of years to try.”

Her gaze lingers on the old patched mortises, mouth thinning a little.

“Annoyance is the right word,” she adds. “Every time I look up at it, it reminds me that

whoever fixed it last cared more about ‘good enough’ than ‘done properly.’ I do not like

being reminded of that in my own shop.”

Lasli leans back, hands braced on her hips, following your look with her own.

“Sprained ankle sounds about right,” she says. “Enough to make you walk funny, not

enough to justify screaming.”

She tips her head, studying the slight sag.

“So what does reconnaissance tell you?” she asks. “More like ‘wrap it tight and rest it,’ or

more like ‘we’re going to have to re-break it and set it straight’?”

There’s a flicker of mischief in her eyes, but she’s paying attention for a real answer.

Claree folds her arms, expression settling into practical mode.

“You don’t owe me an answer today,” she says. “You’ve got your own work and your own

bed to keep. But if you decide there’s something that can be done without tearing half my

ceiling down, and it’s something you and Tasho can agree on…”

She glances from the beam back to you.

“…then we can talk about payment that is more than just letting you rummage the

discount rack,” she finishes. “I don’t expect miracles. I expect honest effort and not making

it worse.”

Lasli gives you a sideways smile.

“And if it does all come crashing down someday,” she says, “at least I’ll know who to

haunt.”

She steps away from the shelf, brushing her hands on her skirt.

“You should go wash the cedar off before you go near the shrine path,” she adds, tone

light but with a friendly undertone. “Cado looks like the kind of man whose eye twitches if

sawdust gets on the wrong paving stone.”

From the front of the shop, a muted jingle of the door beads and the faint murmur of a

customer’s voice drift back.

Claree straightens.

“That’s our cue,” she says. “Thank you for looking, at least. If you think of something, we’ll

still be here—inconvenient beam and all.”

She heads toward the front with the easy, flowing stride of someone who’s been walking

this floor her whole life.

Lasli gives you one more quick look, half grateful, half conspiratorial.

“Good luck with the guards,” she says. “And with the mushrooms, if they let you up there.

If you come back smelling like the hills and not like a monster, I’ll call it a success.”

The back room settles again as they drift toward the front: the crooked beam above, your

own dust-streaked clothes below, and the late spring light sneaking in across the floor,

reminding you there’s still a fair bit of afternoon left for shrine paths, guard posts, and

maybe—if the day goes your way—your first bit of foraging in Hyrule.

**/ Please revise your last response to omit Claree and Lasli having knowledge about the player needing to talk to the guards or going foraging. That is information they have no way of knowing. /**

Enchanted – back room

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun slanting in, dust motes in the beam’s

shadow

Claree watches you slap the beam, eyes tracking the way it shivers and settles.

“Mm,” she says. “Yes. If it were planning to kill anyone, it’s had plenty of years to try.”

Her gaze lingers on the old patched mortises, mouth thinning a little.

“Annoyance is the right word,” she adds. “Every time I look up at it, it reminds me that

whoever fixed it last cared more about ‘good enough’ than ‘done properly.’ I do not like

being reminded of that in my own shop.”

Lasli leans back, hands braced on her hips, following your look with her own.

“Sprained ankle sounds about right,” she says. “Enough to make you walk funny, not

enough to justify screaming.”

She tips her head, studying the slight sag.

“So what does reconnaissance tell you?” she asks. “More like ‘wrap it tight and rest it,’ or

more like ‘we’re going to have to re-break it and set it straight’?”

There’s a flicker of mischief in her eyes, but she’s paying attention for a real answer.

Claree folds her arms, expression settling into practical mode.

“You don’t owe me an answer today,” she says. “You’ve got your own work and your own

bed to keep. But if you decide there’s something that can be done without tearing half my

ceiling down, and it’s something you and Tasho can agree on…”

She glances from the beam back to you.

“…then we can talk about payment that is more than just letting you rummage the

discount rack,” she finishes. “I don’t expect miracles. I expect honest effort and not making

it worse.”

Lasli gives you a sideways smile.

“And if it does all come crashing down someday,” she says, “at least I’ll know who to

haunt.”

From the front of the shop, a muted jingle of the door beads and the faint murmur of a

customer’s voice drift back.

Claree straightens.

“That’s our cue,” she says. “Thank you for looking, at least. If you think of something, we’ll

still be here—inconvenient beam and all.”

She heads toward the front with the easy, familiar stride of someone who’s walked this

floor her whole life.

Lasli lingers a heartbeat longer, then scoops up the folded clothes she’d left on the table.

“I’ll tell Rinna you gave it a proper look,” she says. “She likes it when beams get taken

seriously.”

She flashes you one last, quick grin and follows her sister toward the shop front.

The back room settles again as they drift away: the crooked beam above, your dust-

streaked clothes below, and late spring light sneaking across the floor, reminding you

there’s still a fair bit of afternoon left for whatever comes next.

I bid farewell to the Enchanted sisters and start making my way leisurely toward Impa's house to see who was on guard duty, observing the village for anything noteworthy

as I went, waving and nodding to anybody who might accept it.

Kakariko – mid-slope lanes → Impa’s house

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun bright, breeze cool in the shade

You leave Enchanted and step back into the lane.

The village is in that easy middle-of-day rhythm: no rush, but plenty happening.

A few familiar sights as you climb:

One of the aunties from yesterday sits on a low stool, trimming greens into a basket,

nodding back when you wave.

A pair of kids chase each other around a rain barrel, wooden swords clacking; they

skitter out of your way and immediately resume their argument about who “gets to

be the knight this time.”

High Spirits has a basket of bright pumpkins out; Olkin is halfway through rearranging

them into a more impressive pile, pausing just long enough to grunt a friendly

acknowledgement when you pass.

The air grows a bit cooler as you climb toward the higher terraces, the waterfall’s sound

sharpening as you near it. The Goddess statue’s little pond flashes between houses, water

lit bright in the sun.

Impa’s house sits at the top of its familiar stairway, roofline a steady silhouette against the

sky. The courtyard is quiet—no visitors waiting, no one on the steps.

Dorian is at his post.

He stands where he did yesterday evening: beside the path near the base of the stairs,

spear grounded, armor neat, eyes watching the village below with that measured,

practiced awareness. In the full light of day his features are clearer: the lines at the corners

of his eyes, the set of his jaw, the faint shadows of old tiredness that never fully leave even

in calmer times.

When he notices you approaching, his gaze sharpens for a heartbeat, then relaxes by half

a shade.

He inclines his head in a short, formal nod—acknowledgment, not challenge.

“Zeth,” he says. “You look like you’ve been at war with lumber again.”

His eyes flick briefly to your hands, then back to your face.

“Is this a check-in for Lady Impa,” he asks, “or something else I should be concerned with?”

I bow my head in greeting to Dorian as he addresses me. "No check-in today unless she desires it. I am at her disposal, but I wouldn't want to wear out my welcome. I came to ask permission to head up to the woods near the shrine and fountain. I actually received, ah," I hold up two fingers, "*two* invitations to make some riceballs." I rub the point of my ear, "but I need to find a way to provide some mushrooms. Can't afford to drop rupees on buying any, so...I figured I might be able to forage for some up in the woods. They can be found there, right?"

Thought for 16s

Kakariko – path below Impa’s house

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun high, waterfall loud and cool-scented

Dorian listens without interrupting, eyes on your face, then on the two fingers you lift.

At the mention of rice balls and mushrooms, the hard line of his mouth softens a fraction.

The corner twitches like he is very carefully refusing to smile.

“There are worse reasons to ask for leave than feeding people,” he says.

He shifts his spear, resting it more comfortably, and glances up past you—toward the

narrow path that winds by the Goddess statue and then on into the trees toward the

shrine and the hidden hollow beyond.

“There are mushrooms in those woods,” he confirms. “Plenty, if you know what you’re

looking for and do not get greedy.”

His gaze comes back to you, weighing.

“Here are my conditions,” he says, voice going into that clipped, professional cadence:

“First: you stay to the paths we use. The one past the Goddess statue, then into the lower

woods. Do not wander so far you lose sight of the main trail. The hills look friendly until

fog rolls in or shadows play tricks.”

A brief pause.

“Second: you mind the time. Go now, you have some hours before dusk. Be back in the

village before the sun slips behind the ridge. I do not want to send anyone searching for

you by lantern-light.”

His eyes flick once to your beltline, where there is still no real belt, then to your hands.

“Third: you do not go unarmed,” he adds. “Even near the shrine, there can be chuchus,

keese, a stray bokoblin that has not yet learned better. Your sword may be old and your

shield may be… inventive, but they are better than bare skin.”

He lets the words hang for a heartbeat, making sure they land.

“As for mushrooms,” he goes on, tone easing a shade, “most folk up there look for the

brown-capped ones with pale stems that grow near deadfall, or the orange ones that like

the roots of cedars. Anything with bright spots, strange colors, or a smell that makes you

think of rot—leave it. If you are unsure, bring one to someone who cooks before you eat

it.”

He studies you a moment more, then exhales through his nose.

“I will mark you as ‘in the woods above the village’ for this afternoon,” he says. “When you

return, if I am not here, tell Cado you are back inside the valley so I can sleep tonight

without wondering whether you tripped into a ravine.”

The hard edge of his expression eases just a little further.

“You are under Lady Impa’s eye while you stay here,” he adds. “That includes when you are

hunting mushrooms. Act like you remember that, and we will have no trouble.”

He shifts his spear back to its grounded stance and inclines his head again—formal, but

not cold.

“You have leave to go,” Dorian says. “Foraging in the shrine woods only, back before dusk.

Do not make me regret it.”

"Thank you sir," I say with another head bow. Looking around and not seeing Paya anywhere, I decide not to push any further, and decide to ask Ollie about the marketdays. I begin to turn and head out, but I stop, just in case. Don't want to go in unprepared.

"I think I can manage myself, but just to be sure: how prepared for a fight should I really be?"

Kakariko – path below Impa’s house

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun bright, shadows short

Dorian’s eyes narrow a touch at your follow-up, but it’s not displeasure—more like

recalculation.

“A fair question,” he says.

He shifts his weight, free hand resting lightly on his hip as he answers.

“For the shrine woods?” He tilts his head, considering. “Prepared enough to finish a fight,

not go looking for one.”

He nods uphill, in the direction of the path.

“Most days, you are likely to see nothing worse than choo-choos and keese,” he says.

“Maybe a skittish boar, maybe a fox that thinks it owns the underbrush.”

He taps his spear lightly on the packed earth, a small, sharp sound.

“Still,” he goes on, “a lone bokoblin wandering too far from its camp is not unheard of. Or

a wolf that got too clever for its own good. If that happens, your goal is simple: end it

quickly, or make it clear you are not worth the trouble and withdraw toward the village.”

The way he says “withdraw” carries do not be stupid in its undertone.

He looks you up and down again: your height, the way you stand, the memory of how you

handled yourself when he marched you into Impa’s house.

“You have reach,” he notes. “Use it. Do not let anything with teeth or a club inside your

arms if you can help it. Your sword will serve well enough if you remember that you are

cutting meat, not waving at clouds.”

A brief flicker of something wry crosses his face.

“And remember: this is not the open road,” he adds. “If you shout and truly need help,

someone at the shrine or in the terraces below is likely to hear. Pride is cheap; your spine

is not.”

He settles back into his ready stance, spear grounded.

“For today,” Dorian concludes, “expect nuisance creatures and be ready for one real threat.

If the woods feel wrong—too quiet, or suddenly too loud—you turn around and come

back. There will be other mushrooms on other days.”

Another small, formal nod.

“You have your answer,” he says. “Go while the light is good.”

"Noted. Thank you again." I quickly clamber down the steps and make a quick pace back to the Shuteye Inn to speak with Ollie and grab my sword and shield.

Thought for 5s

Kakariko – lanes → Shuteye Inn

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Warm sun, cool breeze, waterfall steady

You clatter down the stone steps from Impa’s house, the waterfall sound fading behind

you as you descend into the busier part of the village.

The terraces are in full daytime mode now:

A farmer in a wide straw hat is knee-deep in a paddy, checking seedlings, trousers

rolled to the knee.

Someone has set strips of daikon out to dry on a woven mat, the sharp-sweet smell of

them catching the breeze.

The cuccos near the lower pens are making their opinions known about absolutely

everything.

Shuteye’s signboard creaks softly as the breeze pushes at it, the painted lettering familiar

now. The inn’s door is propped open; inside, the light is softer and cooler.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 4, early afternoon • Stew ghosts in the air, floor swept, teapot warm but idle

The common room is quieter than it was at breakfast. The morning’s rush has passed;

benches sit empty, bowls stacked neatly to one side. The big pot over the hearth has been

scraped nearly clean, only a faint stew smell lingering.

Ollie is there, of course.

He’s by the counter, sleeves rolled up, wiping down the surface with a damp cloth. His hair

is a bit more tamed than it was in the early morning, though one stubborn piece still sticks

up at the back. There’s a teapot just off the heat, keeping warm, and a pair of clean cups

turned upside down nearby.

He looks up as you step in, eyes doing that quick inventory he seems incapable of not

doing: dust, posture, expression.

“You survived another day with Tasho,” he says, setting the cloth aside. “That’s two in a

row. At this rate I’ll have to stop thinking of you as ‘temporary.’”

There’s the faintest hint of a smirk at the corner of his mouth.

He nods toward the stairwell.

“Your room’s as you left it,” he adds. “No one’s run off with your treasures.”

He doesn’t press further yet, just leans one elbow on the counter in a casual way that says

he has time to listen if you have something to say.

Upstairs, your room is much as you left it:

Futon folded, tatami sun-warmed.

Chest at the wall, lid closed over your small hoard.

Your folded lists still on the low stand, ink fully cured.

Inside the chest, your sword and canvas “shield” wait. The sword’s grip feels familiar now

when you pick it up, the wrapping you improvised slightly rough but solid in your hand.

The canvas shield is as ridiculous and endearing as ever, but it hangs off your arm without

complaint.

With your gear retrieved and your few other things left safely inside, you head back down

the stairs.

Ollie is still at the counter when you return, now half-turned toward the hearth as if

debating whether to make himself tea.

He glances back as you step into the room, eyes flicking to the sword at your side and the

shield on your arm. One brow lifts a fraction—acknowledging, not judging.

“Looks like you’re off somewhere that isn’t just the jobsite,” he says. “Or you’re very

worried about my mother’s cooking.”

He straightens a bit, giving you his full attention, open and expectant, ready for whatever

question or request brought you back here before your walk into the woods.

I smile almost playfully. "Indeed. Gotta keep my momentum, you know? If I sit down I won't want to get up again." I lean on the counter, slightly awkwardly so I damage anything with my sword or almost-buckler. "Two questions, unrelated: One, I'm out to gather those mushrooms you recommended, so, I was wondering if you had a bag or a basket or satchel or something I might be able to collect them in. Most of them're coming right back to you of course so I don't need it long. Two...uh...what's the status of marketdays? Rinna tipped me off there's a leatherworker who comes through on some marketdays that I might want to talk to."

Thought for 11s

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 4, early afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun slanting in, inn cool and quiet

Ollie huffs a small laugh at your “momentum” comment.

“Dangerous thing, chairs,” he says. “You sit in one after work and suddenly the whole day

disappears.”

He listens to your two questions, eyes flicking briefly to your sword and the almost-shield,

then back to your face.

“For mushrooms, that’s easy,” he says, pushing off the counter. “Stay there a moment.”

He disappears through the little door behind the counter into the back room. You hear a

bit of rummaging, the soft clack of wood on wood, something wicker shifting. After a

moment he returns with a small woven basket and a folded square of cloth.

The basket is shallow but wide, with a simple handle you can grip or hook over your

forearm. The weave is tight enough that smaller caps will not fall straight through; the

cloth feels like old but clean linen.

“Here,” he says, setting them on the counter. “This used to be for herbs. Light, and it won’t

bruise the good ones as quickly as a sack would.”

He taps the folded cloth.

“Put this on top once you’ve got a few in there,” he adds. “Keeps the sun off them and

stops them bouncing out if you slip.”

There’s the barest hint of a warning in his eyes, but it’s gentle.

“Bring the basket back in one piece,” he says. “Fill it in whatever order you like: yours, the

carpenters’, mine. I’m not counting caps. If you show up with at least a handful that you’re

sure about, I can work with it.”

The subject of marketdays shifts his expression into a more thoughtful frown.

“Market’s not every day,” he says, leaning a hip on the counter again. “Too far for most

traders to bother unless they can hit a few stops in a row.”

He glances toward the door, as if picturing the main road beyond the village.

“Most of them come in on a three-day rhythm,” he goes on. “Yesterday was quiet, today’s

just locals. Tomorrow will be a little busier—produce, dried fish, odds and ends. The

leatherworker Rinna’s thinking of usually shows up the day after that when he comes

through this part of Necluda.”

He counts off days on his fingers, more for shape than need.

“So, if his luck and the weather hold,” he says, “you should see him here in two days’ time.

Late morning, usually. Sets up near the pond, under the tree with the wind chimes.”

His mouth quirks slightly.

“He’s not the cheapest man in Hyrule,” Ollie adds, “but he does work that doesn’t fall apart

the first time you run. Belts, pouches, sometimes dagger frogs, that sort of thing. If you

want him to cut something custom, try to talk to him before everyone else remembers

their old straps are fraying.”

He nods toward the basket again.

“Bringing mushrooms today won’t hurt your case either,” he says dryly. “Traders pay better

attention to people who look like they eat something besides air.”

There’s a beat where he seems to consider saying more, then he settles for a simple,

practical line.

“Stay under the trees if the sun gets too sharp,” he says. “And if you come back with

nothing but stories about tripping over roots, that’s still better than not coming back at

all.”

He nudges the basket and cloth a little closer across the counter—clear invitation.

Outside the doorway, the lane waits in bright afternoon light; above the village, you know

the path curls past the Goddess statue and on into the shade of the shrine woods, green

and dappled and hiding whatever fungi, animals, and small surprises late spring has

decided to tuck under its trees today.

"Thank you sir," I say chipperly, taking the basket. and hanging it in the crook of my arm with the "shield" on it. I realise I probably look a little ridiculous, like some kind of Little-Red-Bandit-Riding-Hood. I look at Ollie and shrug. It would just have to do.

Heading out into the sunlight, I head out on the trail towards the woods near the shrine with purpose.

Thought for 10s

Kakariko – lanes → shrine path → lower woods

Day 4, mid-afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun warm, under-tree air cool and damp

The basket swings lightly from your arm as you step back out into the lane, shield and

handle sharing space in a way that feels faintly ridiculous and completely functional.

Up past the Goddess statue, the air cools a touch. The little pond catches sunlight in

ripples; dragonflies skitter over its surface, wings flashing. Someone has left a fresh sprig

of flowers at the statue’s base—tiny white bells, still beaded with water from their last

rinse.

The path beyond narrows and rises.

Stone gives way to packed earth and then to leaf litter under your boots. Birdsong grows

louder, the chorus shifting from village sparrows to forest voices. The roar of the waterfall

softens into a broad hush behind you; ahead, the woods gather themselves into layered

greens and shadow.

The shrine woods aren’t thick enough to be oppressive, but they’re dense enough to feel

like a threshold. Ferns fan out along the path edges, and moss puddles on stones and

roots. Shafts of sunlight angle through cedar boughs and maple leaves, turning every

drifting bit of dust and pollen into slow, lazy stars.

The air smells wetter here: earth, wood, a hint of leaf-mold and distant water.

You pass the little stone bridge over the narrow stream that runs down from higher up.

The water is clear and quick, just deep enough in places that a cupped hand would come

away cold and clean. Dragonflies and a lone frog share ownership.

Further on, the faint, familiar hum of Sheikah tech starts to thread the air—Lakna Rokee

Shrine, still sealed but very much present, sits tucked off one of the spur paths, its stone

ring overgrown with greenery. From the main trail you catch only flashes of its geometry

between trunks: straight lines and patient silence.

Mushrooms take a little more attention to spot.

At first, it’s just the usual forest clutter: pale bracket fungi on fallen logs, too hard and

woody for a cookpot; tiny, almost transparent caps clustering on a rotting stump like

something out of a fairy story.

Then, as your eyes adjust:

Near the base of a broad cedar just off the path, you spot a trio of stout, brown-

capped mushrooms with pale stems—classic cooking shapes. They grow from rich,

dark soil near the tangle of roots, not on the wood itself. The caps are matte, not

slimy, and the gills underneath are a creamy beige.

A little further along, where a big limb came down seasons ago and has half-rotted

into the ground, another cluster of similar mushrooms pushes up through the leaf

litter—some smaller, some hand-sized.

Off to the other side of the trail, around a maple whose roots knot the slope, you

catch the bright orange of what might be razor-shrooms in game terms: rounded

caps with a faint, almost scale-like texture, growing in a loose ring. They look healthy,

but their color is much louder, a little more “look at me” than the browns.

As you pause to take it in, the woods remind you they’re not just a pantry.

There’s a soft plup sound from ahead and to the right, like someone dropping a sack of

wet cloth. Then a faint jiggle-slosh.

Peering between the ferns, you spot a small blue chuchu oozing near a fallen log, maybe

ten paces off the path. It bumps against the wood in an almost aimless way, quivering,

then settles. Every so often it gives a little bounce, as if considering whether anything

nearby might be worth lunging at.

Between you and it, close to the log, there are more of the brown-capped mushrooms, a

larger patch than the two near the cedar: maybe a dozen caps at various stages, some

perfect for picking.

The chuchu hasn’t noticed you yet. The breeze is in your favor, carrying your scent back

toward the village rather than toward the jelly.

Closer to the main trail, the cedar-root cluster sits in easy reach, no monsters in sight. The

orange caps by the maple are also clear—for now. A couple of fat beetles trundle over the

bark nearby, minding their own business.

Your hand remembers the weight of the sword hilt. The basket tugs lightly at your arm.

The woods are bright enough that shadows are soft-edged, but under the trees the sense

of distance gets fiddly: things are closer or farther than they first seem, depending on how

you look.

You’ve got:

A safe patch of brown caps by the cedar, easy reach, low risk.

The louder orange ones by the maple, close to the path, brightly inviting.

A richer haul of brown caps nearer the log—if you’re willing to get close to the blue

chuchu, or deal with it.

The air is cool on your face, warm on your shoulders where the sun finds gaps in the

branches. Your stomach is still reasonably satisfied from Mera’s roll and earlier meals; thirst

is a manageable background suggestion, easily answered at the stream if you choose.

The woods wait—not impatiently, but attentively—as you decide where to step first.

The larger cluster of brown-capped is tempting for a moment, but I recall Dorian's admonition about not straying too far or taking unnecessary risks and so decide against it. There would undoubtedly be times I'd be forced to fight. No need to create them. Not over 'shrooms.

I let the chuchu keep its prize and give it a wide berth, instead gathering the orange-capped razorshrooms and the lesser gathering of the browncapped mushrooms, Dorian-approved. As suspected, it takes virtually no time at all compared to what it likely would have in my old world, and I decide to keep looking a little longer in case there are any other stashes of mushrooms. The more the merrier.

Thought for 14s

Shrine woods – below Lakna Rokee

Day 4, mid-afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Light dappled, air cool and damp

You leave the richer patch and its gelatinous custodian alone, circling wide enough that

even a curious chuchu would have to work to notice you.

The orange-capped mushrooms near the maple come up easily. Their stems give with a

faint, fibrous snap when you twist them just above the soil. Up close, they smell pleasantly

earthy, not sharp or sour. A little dust clings to your fingers; when you brush it off on your

trousers it leaves the faintest orange smudge.

The brown caps by the cedar are more modest but feel like the real prize: classic “cooking

mushroom” shapes. You dig your fingertips into the soft soil around them and lift carefully,

bringing up a bit of the mycelium mat rather than just snapping stems. Cooler, wetter dirt

gets under your nails; it smells clean, like good compost and rain.

The basket starts to sound different when you move: a faint rustle-soft thump of caps

shifting against one another. You lay the cloth over them as Ollie suggested. The linen

mutes the movement, keeping them dim and cool.

You push on a little further.

The path rises and falls gently, weaving between cedars and maples. Roots twist across

your way like old ropes; here and there, stones show the faint chisel-marks of someone

long ago making the route a little less treacherous.

You find more as you go, not in grand caches but in useful little pockets:

A small cluster of brown caps at the foot of a mossy stump, tight against the wood

where rain must drip.

A slim ring of paler mushrooms under a bush, which you leave alone—they look a bit

too ghostly, gills too tight, the vibe just wrong.

Two more orange caps half-buried in leaf litter near a fallen branch, slug-nibbled at

the edges but still serviceable if trimmed.

Once, when you bend to check a promising shape in the shadows, something darts away

with a rapid skitter—just a lizard, tail whipping as it vanishes between stones. Your pulse

jumps for a second and then settles, leaving you a little amused at yourself.

The forest noise shifts as the afternoon stretches.

Birdsong thins slightly, turning to more occasional calls. Higher up the slope you hear the

faint clack of something—maybe a squirrel or bird dropping shells or seeds from a branch.

A breeze pushes through the canopy, setting needles and leaves whispering together

overhead.

At one point, as you’re straightening from another careful harvest, you catch a different

kind of glimmer through the trees.

Not sunlight on leaves or shrine-stone—more like a soft, bluish flicker, low to the ground,

here and gone again in the space of a blink.

When you ease a few paces in that direction, keeping the main trail in peripheral sight, you

glimpse it more clearly for half a heartbeat: a small, rabbit-sized shape at the base of a

rock, body made of lucent, bluish light rather than fur. Big ears, little round hindquarters, a

tail that seems more like a spark than a puff of hair.

The creature freezes, eyes bright pinpoints.

The instant your gaze truly locks on, it springs away—silent, impossibly quick, leaving a

faint trail of afterimages in the air as it bounds deeper between the trees. By the time your

brain finishes the sentence That has to be a blupee, it’s already gone, absorbed into the

dapple and shade.

Where it had been, a single small rupee—green—rests between roots, as if dropped or

shed.

The woods close back around the moment as if it were a held breath released.

By now, your basket has a respectable weight to it. Not full, but more than a token

offering: a decent mix of brown and orange caps, all ones you felt confident about. The

cloth keeps them shaded; when you lift a corner to check, cool, earthy air puffs up, sharp

with mushroom scent.

The light has shifted some while you’ve been walking and searching. Sunbeams angle

lower, slanting through the branches in longer spears. The air is still bright, but the

shadows between tree trunks have deepened a shade. The waterfall’s rumble sounds more

distant, the village noise almost entirely muted by the trees.

Your throat reminds you that you’ve been breathing forest air and working earlier; the idea

of cupping water from the stream on your way back has its appeal. Your hands are

pleasantly sore rather than screaming, the gloves doing their job, but you can feel the long

day in your shoulders and calves.

The main path is still close at hand—you’ve been careful to keep it in sight or easy reach.

Up-slope, the trail continues toward the more hidden bowl where the fairy’s pool lies.

Down-slope, it curls back toward the bridge, the Goddess statue, and the layered roofs of

Kakariko.

Late-spring birds trade calls overhead. A beetle lands on a fern near your knee, considers

you, and trundles away.

The shrine woods feel watchful but not hostile, like a host quietly noting that afternoon is

beginning to lean toward evening.

I edge forward and take the rupee--no sense in letting *that* go to waste. Doing so lets me catch another glimpse of the blupee, and I stay rooted to the spot as quietly as possible. The awkward crouch is uncomfortable, and it's difficult to keep my balance while trying to maintain my sword, shield and the heavy basket, but it's worth it to observe the fantastical creature. Eventually, my poor balance wins and I'm forced to shit my footing to avoid falling, and the creature notices and darts off again, leaving me alone with the sounds of the woods. It is enough.

Standing up straight, I begin making my way back out of the woods and back toward the village, thinking I probably will get a drink from the stream along the way. I wouldn't dare do such a thing in my old world. Too likely to get a parasite or polluted water or just plain disease. Somehow, I don't find myself worried about such a thing here and now. I hope I'm right.

Thought for 5s

Shrine woods → stream → Kakariko lanes

Day 4, late afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Light slanting gold, air cooling under the

trees

The green rupee is cool and solid under your fingers when you pick it up, its facets

catching stray shafts of light as if they were made for one another. It drops into your

pocket with a quiet clink that’s louder in your mind than in the woods.

As you crouch, balance wobbling under the combined awkwardness of sword, shield, and

mushroom-laden basket, you catch that second glimpse.

The blupee is half-hidden behind a stone, ears perked, body a soft lantern of blue-white.

For a breath or two it holds still, watching you. The light that makes up its fur seems to

drift a little, like wind-blown dust trapped inside glass.

Your calves protest, your weight shifts, and a twig betrays you with a sharp little crack.

The blupee explodes into motion—no sound, just light, bounding away through

undergrowth that barely rustles at its passage. It leaves the sense of a path traced in your

vision, afterimages fading into the ordinary green and brown of the forest.

Silence refills the space it occupied. A bird resumes a song it had paused. A leaf drops,

landing on your shoulder.

You straighten up, knees grateful, and turn back toward the main path.

The walk downslope feels easier with the basket’s weight settled into a familiar rhythm

against your arm. Your boots scuff leaf litter; roots demand just enough attention to keep

your mind from spiraling too tightly around Impa’s warnings or Dorian’s conditions.

At the little stone bridge, you pause.

The stream is clear as glass, running over rounded stones mottled with algae. Small fish

flick in and out of shadows under the bank. You kneel, brace one hand on the cool stone,

and dip the other into the water.

It bites in the best way—cold enough to make your skin ache for a moment, then numb,

then refreshed. You bring a double handful up and drink.

The taste is shockingly simple: cold, clean, with the faint mineral tang of rock and soil. No

chemical ghosts, no hint of pipe-metal, no warning funk. Just water that has not yet

learned how to be anything else.

Your throat thanks you. You splash the remainder over your face, pushing hair back, feeling

grit loosen and run away downstream.

By the time you’re crossing back into the edges of the village, the angle of the sunlight has

changed.

Kakariko – lower terraces

Day 4, late afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun low, long shadows, cooking fires just

starting

The waterfall’s white noise swells again as you leave the thicker trees. The sight of rooftops

and terraced gardens comes one step at a time through gaps in the foliage, until you’re

fully back among tilled earth and woven fences instead of moss and cedar roots.

The village is shifting gears:

Thin threads of smoke rise from a few cookfires; someone is roasting something that

smells very much like fish near one of the lower houses.

A couple of children are being rounded up by an exasperated aunt, wooden swords

confiscated until after supper.

The farmer in the wide straw hat you saw earlier is stacking bundles of cut greens by a

shed, giving you a brief, curious glance when he notices the basket on your arm.

The Goddess statue’s pond is calm in the lower light, reflecting the sky and the first faint

hints of evening color. A frog plops off a rock as you pass.

From up the slope, you can just make out the watchful shape of a guard at Impa’s—too far

to see which one, but present, as promised.

Your hands smell faintly of streamwater and mushroom earth. The basket under your arm

has the satisfying heft of enough: not a heroic haul, but a solid offering. Your legs are tired

in that good, used way, and somewhere under the fatigue there’s a small, stubborn ember

of satisfaction that today you met the woods on their terms and came back with

something tangible.

The inn is only a short walk from here, a warm rectangle of shadow and wood where Ollie

is likely taking stock of the hour and thinking about the evening stew. Enchanted, High

Spirits, Impa’s house, the quiet pond—each sits in its own pocket of the village, waiting to

see where you carry the smell of cedar and moss and mushrooms next.

Before heading straight to the inn I make good on Dorian's instruction and go to report back to whomever is on guard at Impa's.

Kakariko – path below Impa’s house

Day 4, late afternoon • Late spring (budding) • Sun low, ridge line glowing, air cooling fast

You climb the familiar stairs again, basket tucked under your arm, sword and makeshift

shield bumping lightly against your hip.

The light’s gone softer up here; the waterfall is copper-tinged where the sun hits it,

shadow-blue where it doesn’t. Crickets are just beginning to test their evening voices in

the brush.

Cado is on duty now.

He stands where Dorian had been earlier, near the base of the stairs, spear grounded,

posture straight but lacking that coil of tension Dorian carries even at rest. In the slanting

light he looks every bit the neat, meticulous guard: armor well-kept, headband perfectly

tied, expression alert but not severe.

His eyes track you as you approach. The first thing they land on is the basket; the second is

your face.

“Back in one piece,” he says, a small smile tugging at his mouth. “That’s good news.”

He glances past you toward the woods, as if confirming you haven’t dragged any trouble

down the slope with you, then looks back.

“Dorian will want to sleep tonight without pacing holes in the floor,” he adds. “Shall I tell

him you returned from the shrine woods safely, or would you like to put it in your own

words?”

He’s clearly expecting a simple report: you went, you foraged, no ravines swallowed you.

The set of his shoulders says he doesn’t sense an emergency—just a duty to mark the

ledger in his head as “back inside the valley.”

I hadn't made it a habit to shake hands with people in Kakariko since testing it out on Cado a couple days ago, since it apparently wasn't as customary here as elsewhere, but the thought of doing so specifically with Cado again crosses my mind. Then I realise I have no spare hands to shake anyways so it didn't matter. So I give the respectful head bow instead. "That about sums it up. Don't think I can add anything much else." I pause, then add, "I saw a chu and a Blupee. I left them both alone." I lift the basket slightly, "Got a good haul for not much time invested. Them's good woods for 'shrooms."

Kakariko – path below Impa’s house

Day 4, late afternoon • Late spring • Sun kissing the ridge, air cooling

Cado’s eyes brighten a notch at the mention of the blupee.

“A blupee?” he echoes, glancing past you toward the woods again, as if he might spot the

little spirit hopping along the tree line. “You are settling in quickly.”

His gaze drops to the basket when you lift it slightly. He gives a low, approving hum.

“Those are good woods,” he agrees. “My sister used to sneak up there and come back with

enough mushrooms to feed half the house—until my mother made me walk with her.”

There’s a touch of conspiratorial amusement in his voice, then he remembers his role and

straightens a bit.

“I’ll let Dorian know you went up, saw trouble, and had the good sense not to go

introducing yourself to it,” he says. “He’ll pretend not to be relieved, but that’s his own

problem.”

He plants the butt of his spear a little more firmly, the formal edge of his stance returning.

“You’re marked as back inside the valley,” Cado says. “As far as we’re concerned, that’s a

day well-spent. Go on—before the cooks decide they’re tired of feeding the late

stragglers.”

There’s a small, genuine smile with that last line, then his attention returns to the village at

large—still aware of you, but settling back into guard-watch.

—

The walk down from Impa’s house feels shorter this time.

Light slides warm across tiled roofs and the tops of bamboo fences, shadows stretching

long across the stone steps. Someone is beating dust from a futon over a railing. The smell

of cooking is stronger now: rice, something stewed, a hint of miso or soy drifting on the

breeze.

By the time you reach the lane where Shuteye sits, the inn’s lantern has been lit, casting a

soft, orange glow on the signboard. The door is propped open again, inviting, a strip of

interior light spilling across the threshold.

Inside, the common room is beginning to wake up for evening:

A couple of villagers sit at one of the low tables, talking quietly over cups of tea.

The hearth is going, a fresh pot hanging over it; the smell is recognisably stew again,

though tonight’s blend carries more herbs and something smokier than last time.
