Ollie is behind the counter, halfway through arranging bowls. When he notices the basket

on your arm and the way you carry it—careful, a little proud—his eyebrows rise just a little,

curiosity sparking.

He sets the bowl in his hands down and gives you his full attention, clearly ready to see

what the woods have traded you for your afternoon.

I set the basket down on the counter, clearly content with the results it held. "Wondering how I made out, I see." I whip the linen cover off the basket for Ollie to inspect. "I don't think I did bad for not spending an excessive amount of time on it. I'm fine to just let your mother take her pick of what she wants.I was sort of hoping there might be a few leftover when she's done though; I actually received a second offer on onigiri education earlier today."

Thought for 33s

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 4, late afternoon sliding toward evening • Late spring • Hearthwarm, stew-thick air

Ollie leans in as you lay the basket down, hands braced on the counter. When you whip

the linen back, the smells come up first: damp earth, cedar, that deep, savory note good

mushrooms all share.

His eyebrows climb.

“Huh,” he says, with the quiet satisfaction of someone whose guess just paid off. “For ‘not

an excessive amount of time,’ that’s… respectable.”

He wipes his hands on his apron and starts sorting without quite touching anything at first,

just visually picking through.

“You’ve got good instincts,” he adds. “These browns are exactly what my mother bullies

me into finding when I go up there. And the orange caps—razor types—she’ll like those

grilled.”

He picks up one of the orange caps, turns it, checks the underside, then sets it back gently.

“No slime, no rot, no ‘are you sure this isn’t a curse’ colors,” he says. “You did fine.”

He starts a quick, practiced divide:

A generous portion of the brown caps into one invisible pile in his mind.

Several of the orange caps alongside.

A solid handful of each left comfortably in the basket.

He glances up at you as you mention the second offer of onigiri education, eyes glinting.

“Two offers?” he says. “I see how it is. I thought we had something special.”

The mock injury lasts about half a heartbeat before he snorts softly and shakes his head.

“Tell you what,” he goes on, more serious now. “I’ll let my mother pick what she wants for

supper and for drying. These—” he nudges the ones he’s notionally left to your side of the

basket “—I’ll leave aside. Tomorrow, or the next time dusk isn’t chasing you by the heels,

bring them back to the kitchen and I’ll show you how I do rice balls.”

He eyes you meaningfully.

“Then you can compare techniques and decide which teacher you want to flatter more,” he

adds dryly. “Just don’t tell either of us if it’s someone else.”

He gathers “his” share of the mushrooms into a shallow wooden tray, moving with an ease

that says he’s done this dance more than once, and sets them aside near the gap in the

counter that leads back to the kitchen.

When he turns back, his gaze flicks over you again—the forest dust on your clothes, the

way you’re holding yourself.

“You look like the woods and the roof both had a go at you today,” he says. “Sit before

your legs decide to fold on their own. Stew’ll be ready in a bit. I can stretch to a bowl and

tea on the usual terms.”

There’s a chair-free stretch of floor near one of the low tables, the kind of spot where the

warmth from the hearth reaches just enough to take the edge off the evening chill without

making you drowsy on contact. The murmur of another pair of patrons talking quietly

drifts over—a familiar, village-soft sound.

The basket under your hand feels lighter now, but still usefully not empty. The green rupee

in your pocket is a cool little reminder of the blupee’s brief visit, and the day has the solid,

tired shape of one that has been full rather than merely long.

I settle down in the obvious seat, setting my things beside me for the moment and feeling a little dirty to just be plopping down in the middle of the inn's floor. As I wait for Ollie to return I feel the other patrons look me over, but they have the courtesy not to say anything. At least not at this moment, anyways.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 4, early evening • Late spring • Hearth warm, lamps lit, stew in the air

The tatami creaks just slightly as you sit. Your clothes are dusted in the colors of your day

—cedar, earth, a bit of leaf—and you can feel the village eyes make a quiet circuit over

you:

An older man with a thinning topknot glances up from his tea, notes the shield,

basket-less arm, and callused hands, then returns to his cup with a small sound that

might be approval.

Across the way, a middle-aged woman in a patterned wrap leans just enough to see,

decides you’re “someone else’s business,” and resumes her murmured conversation.

If there are comments, they’re saved for later, when you’re out of earshot and safely

converted into a story.

The clink of crockery from behind the counter precedes the smell. Ollie appears a moment

later with a tray balanced against one hip: a deep bowl, a cup, a small saucer with a few

pickled vegetables.

He kneels to set them within easy reach.

Tonight’s stew is thicker, darker: you can see chunks of root vegetable, slivers of onion, and

a few of your own mushrooms bobbing near the surface, their edges just starting to take

on the color of the broth. Something smoky lurks under the usual savor—maybe dried fish

or a different cut of meat.

The tea is barley again, but toasted deeper: the steam carries a nutty, almost caramel hint

without sweetness.

“Mother approves of the mushrooms,” Ollie says quietly, tone pitched not to disturb the

others. “Which means I approve, or I’ll hear about it all week.”

His mouth quirks.

“Eat,” he adds, in the simple, practical way of someone who has decided you count as

“ours” enough to nag. “Roof work and forest paths don’t care how tired you were the day

before.”

He straightens and pads back toward the counter, already turning to ladle stew into

another bowl for a newly-arrived patron.

The first spoonful is hot enough to make you pause and breathe through it, but not

enough to burn. The mushroom pieces give the broth a deeper, rounded savor; when you

bite into one, it’s tender but still has a little resistance. Earthy, rich, exactly the kind of thing

that feels like it puts weight back into your limbs.

The pickles are sharp and bright, cutting through the fat. You end up alternating without

really planning to: stew, rice from the bottom of the bowl, pickle, tea. The barley tea does

its usual magic of “warmth without heaviness,” sliding down your throat and loosening the

last of the forest chill in your chest.

Around you, the room fills slowly:

A pair of younger men in work clothes come in laughing about something that

happened in the paddies; they nod as they pass, that brief shared recognition of “also

tired.”

Someone by the door complains amiably about a cucco that escaped and had to be

chased halfway up the slope.

The older man with the thinning topknot asks for seconds on stew and gets a mock-

scolding about his waistline from Ollie’s mother’s voice drifting in from the back.

By the time the bottom of your bowl shows through and your cup is mostly dregs, the

light outside the doors has gone from gold to blue. Lamps along the walls carry most of

the work now, their soft, wavering glow turning the room into a series of warm islands in a

cooler world.

Your muscles have done that nice trick where, fed and heated, they stop complaining and

start promising that later they’ll let you know exactly what you put them through. For now,

there’s just a heavy, pleasant fatigue and the awareness of a bed upstairs that is yours for

the night.

The basket of “your” remaining mushrooms rests behind the counter where Ollie tucked it,

easy enough to retrieve whenever you’re ready to claim it. The green rupee is still a cool

weight in your pocket. Your sword and slapped-together shield lean within arm’s reach,

the two most obvious symbols of a life you didn’t even know was possible three days ago.

Evening in Kakariko hums around you—low, domestic, content—with just enough edge of

“things still need doing” to keep it from turning into a lullaby.

I look around at the groups of people, and am hit with a pang of both loneliness and envy. I was typically fine to be alone, in fact, sometimes I actively preferred it. But in this moment my ruminations by the giddess statue the other day compound my desire to have the comradery that I see other people enjoying at the inn over their evening meal. There was only so much idle chit-chat you could make during work, and it was easily playing fourth fiddle to good work, quick work and safety. The people here were enjoying conversation with their friends for conversation's own sake. I felt like I almost had that with Harlin and Mera on the one night all three of us stayed here, but aside from that...well, I simply didnt own that luxury yet.

But I push myself up from the mat and swallow my negativity, walking over to the counter again to politely wait until Ollie was done with whatever needed doing so I could pester him again.

Shuteye Inn – common room, by the counter

Day 4, early night • Late spring • Lamps glowing, outside sky deep blue

The floor creaks softly under your feet as you rise. The warmth of the hearth falls away a

little when you step out of its circle, replaced by the more neutral, lamplit air near the

counter.

Behind you, the low murmur of conversations blends into a single friendly blur: laughter

from the paddy-workers, the clink of a cup set down a bit too hard, someone telling a

story about a wayward goat.

Up here, it’s quieter.

Ollie is mid-task when you arrive—stacking bowls that have come back empty, wiping a

faint stew spill from the counter’s edge. He finishes that pass before looking up, the

instinctive efficiency of someone who’s done this a thousand evenings in a row.

He clocks a few things in one sweep of his gaze:

Your empty bowl and cup left behind.

The way you’re standing—tired, but not yet dragged under by it.

Something in your face that isn’t just “long day.”

No pity, no overreach; just a small adjustment in his expression from “busy innkeep” to

“has a moment.”

He sets the last bowl aside and leans his forearms lightly on the counter, closer to your

height.

“Back already,” he says, tone mild. “Stew didn’t put you straight to sleep after all.”

There’s a faint hint of wryness at the edge of his mouth, but it’s gentler than the earlier

teasing.

He tilts his head a little, studying you.

“Still have a bit of the evening left,” Ollie adds. “What can I do for you?”

He leaves the question open—not pushing, not prying, just giving you something solid to

push against if you choose. The lantern above the counter hums softly, throwing warm

light over the polished wood between you.

I shrug. "Yesterday you mentioned a few extra rupees for a hot bath and not a cold one. Might like to take you up on that tonight. How long would that take to arrange? I can run upstairs and put my things away, grab the money while it's preparing."

Thought for 11s

Shuteye Inn – by the counter

Day 4, early night • Late spring • Lamps warm, sky darkening

Ollie huffs a soft, approving sound.

“Now there’s a man who’s learned from experience,” he says. “Cold water is for people

who lost a bet.”

He straightens a bit, thinking.

“Hot bath’s not complicated,” he goes on. “Fire’s already going for the stew. I just have to

set the kettle to doing more work for you instead of the pot.”

He holds up his hand, thumb and two fingers slightly spread.

“Same as yesterday,” he says. “A few extra rupees for the trouble and the fuel. You can

afford it, or I’d tell you not to bother asking.”

He nods toward the stairs.

“Go on up, drop your gear, count your coins,” he adds. “By the time you’ve done that and

come back down, I can have water ready to mix.”

There’s a ghost of a grin.

“Mother appreciates it when the beds don’t smell like the day’s work,” he says. “I

appreciate it when people can sit at breakfast without fog drifting off them.”

—

Upstairs – your room

Your chest swallows sword, shield, and the weight of the day’s little treasures. The

shopping list and tea notes sit where you left them, feeling more like plans and less like

fantasies now that you’ve seen a trader’s schedule and held a blupee’s rupee.

When you fish out your money, there’s enough there that “a few extra” doesn’t feel like a

reckless luxury. Just a small tax you’re willing to pay to not go to bed with forest still stuck

to your skin.

—

Shuteye Inn – back hall, washing area

Day 4, early night • Late spring • Steam starting to fog the corners

When you come back down with the coins, Ollie takes them with a nod and a clink into a

small bowl behind the counter.

“Right,” he says. “This way.”

He leads you through the side door behind the counter, down a short, dim hall that smells

of wood, soapleaf, and old steam.

The washing room is simple but a step up from cold water behind a stable:

A wide wooden tub, banded in metal, already quarter-filled with hot water that

steams gently in the lamplight.

A couple of buckets stacked by a low bench, their insides still damp from recent use.

A shallow basin with a ladle and a small bundle of soapleaf hanging from a peg—

broad leaves tied together, faintly sharp and green-smelling.

The air here is warmer than the common room, the kind that makes your shoulders want

to drop an inch on instinct.

Ollie sets one of the buckets beside the tub and nods toward a low shelf where a clean

cloth and another towel are neatly folded.

“Hot water’s there,” he says, indicating the tub. “Cold’s in the big barrel”—a stout cask

against the wall with a dipper on top—“so you can mix it how you like. Soapleaf’s fresh.

Don’t drown yourself trying to be heroic about the temperature.”

He steps back toward the doorway, giving you space.

“Leave the cloths on the peg when you’re done,” he adds. “I’ll deal with the rest.”

He pauses just long enough to tack on one last, dry remark.

“And try not to fall asleep in there,” he says. “Explaining that to Lady Impa would be very

awkward for both of us.”

With that, he slips out, pulling the door to until it’s mostly closed, leaving you alone with

the tub, the rising steam, and the small, well-earned luxury of hot water at the end of a

long, strange, very real day.

I thank Ollie and wait for him to leave before stripping down very quickly, all too excited at the prospect of the hot bath. More excited than I would have imagined over such a simple thing. I had actually expected the same outdoor experience as yesterday just with hot water instead of cold, so instead being treated to a private room with--I look at the leaves blankly--something like soap, was enough to make me ecstatic.

I start pouring the hot water in the tub and dipping my hand in to gauge the temperature. I add enough of the cold so I don't scald myself, but in spite of Ollie's instance to "not be heroic" I let the water remain fairly hot. I enjoy

very hot water and while in my old world I had been forced to endure shorter and cooler showers because of a somewhat severe eczema condition leaving me dried out afterwards...Hylian-me obviously did not suffer this problem at all. And I was ready to revel in it.

I just had to figure out what to do with the soapleaves. I'd never even heard of such a thing.

Thought for 8s

Shuteye Inn – washing room

Day 4, early night • Late spring • Steam-thick air, wood creaking softly

The tub takes the heat greedily, steam rolling up the more hot water you pour in. When

you dip your hand, the surface bites pleasantly—too hot for a long soak, but perfect once

tempered. A few scoops from the cold barrel shifts it into that narrow, wonderful place

between “bracing” and “boil alive.”

The soapleaf bundle smells faintly green and bitter when you bring it to your nose—

somewhere between crushed herbs and raw bean pods. Up close you can see that the

leaves are thick and a little waxy, tied together at the stems.

Instinct and design line up when you:

Dip the whole bundle briefly in the hot water,

Then squeeze and rub a few of the leaves between your fingers.

A slickness blooms along the surface as you work them. When you run your wet hand

along your forearm, it leaves a faint, milky sheen that tightens into a light foam with a bit

more rubbing. Not bubbles like your old world soaps, but a soft, slippery lather that clings

and then rinses away clean.

Once you know what you’re dealing with, the rest comes easily:

You step into the tub and sink down.

The heat hits in layers—feet first, then calves, knees, thighs, finally your back as you ease

in. Muscles that have been quietly complaining for two days decide this is a truce they can

accept. The wood staves creak a little as the water shifts; the metal bands hold firm.

You work the soapleaf along your arms, chest, shoulders, legs. The lather lifts cedar dust,

sweat, and forest grit in slow gray veils that swirl away when you splash clean water over

yourself. The leaves leave behind the faintest tacky feeling for a moment, then nothing—

just skin, warm and bare of the day.

Your sword-hand blisters, scabbed and healing, soften slightly in the heat, the ache easing

from sharp to dull. When you flex your fingers, they feel looser, more willing to pick up

tools or a hilt again tomorrow.

Heat settles into your bones. The room is quiet, just:

The soft drip of condensation off the ceiling,

The occasional tiny pop from the wood as it adjusts,

The faint muted thrum of life from the inn beyond the door.

You don’t linger quite long enough to go boneless, but you get close. When you finally

rise, the air on your skin feels cool and new. The towel is rough-woven but clean, pulling

away the last of the damp without scratching.

Dressed again in clothes that somehow feel less oppressive now that the sweat is gone

from your skin, you leave the used cloths where Ollie told you to and step back into the

hallway.

Shuteye Inn – your room

Day 4, night • Late spring • Lamp low, outside crickets strong

Upstairs, the futon waits where you left it. The room smells faintly of tatami, wood, and a

ghost of your last tea. Your notes—shopping list and tea list—sit folded on the stand; the

ruined, improvised buckler and sword rest in the chest below, safely shut away from

curious hands.

Outside, through the small window slit, the sky is fully dark now, scattered with stars

unfamiliar and yet weirdly comfortable. Crickets and frogs carry most of the night’s

conversation; the village itself has quieted to the occasional door-slide or distant laugh.

Tired in the limbs, clean in the skin, and with tomorrow’s loose plans already sketching

themselves in the back of your mind whether you want them to or not, you have nothing

left the day can reasonably demand from you.

The lamp wick can be pinched low with a twist. The futon will take your weight without

protest.

Night in Kakariko hums softly outside as you choose how quickly to let it pull you under.

I don't think much tonight as I ease myself onto the futon. The hot bath was enough to do what the hard work and heavy evening meals of stew couldn't, and the comforting, warm feeling of contentment manages to keep out any worrying thoughts tonight. I drift off to sleep quickly this time.

Shuteye Inn – your room

Day 5, early morning • Late spring • Cool air, soft light through the shutters

Sleep takes you in a clean drop this time—no hornets’ nest of thoughts, no circling

questions. Just warmth, weight, and the gentle, anonymous murmur of a village night.

If you dream, it’s nothing that sticks. A swirl of water and forest shade, the ghost of a

bluish glow behind your eyes, the shape of a roofline that keeps turning into something

else before you can name it.

When you surface, it’s not to any sharp sound.

Just:

The faint clack of someone downstairs setting bowls together.

A kettle beginning to murmur rather than boil.

Crickets faded to almost nothing, replaced by a few early-rising birds testing out their

morning calls.

Light sneaks past the shutters in narrow stripes—soft, grey-gold, the color of a day that

hasn’t quite chosen what it’s going to be yet. The air in the room is cool enough that the

first movement you make raises a little line of gooseflesh along your arms.

Your body has its own opinions about yesterday:

Shoulders and back: pleasantly sore, the kind that promises strength if you keep at it.

Hands: blisters mostly settled into tougher skin, only a faint tug when you flex.

Legs: a low, steady ache that registers more as “you did something” than “you did too

much.”

Your skin still holds a ghost of the bath’s heat, and when you shift on the futon, the

bedding smells of clean cotton and a little of soapleaf instead of sweat and cedar sawdust.

The chest at the foot of the bed is where you left it; your sword and sad, loyal little buckler

wait inside, along with whatever rupees you didn’t press into Ollie’s hands last night. On

the stand by the lamp, your folded notes sit exactly as you left them:

One list of practical wants: belt, bag, extra clothes, cloak, maybe a hat.

One list of teas you’ve tasted so far, ambitions in ink.

The inn is waking below you. Not rushed—this isn’t a city—but shifting out of its night

slowness:

A faint rise in voices, a chair moved, the soft thunk of a pot being set somewhere firmly

but not harshly.

Outside, the air that sneaks through the cracks smells like it did two mornings ago: damp

earth, stone, and the promise of a day that will warm up once the sun climbs over the

ridge.

You have:

A room that is yours for at least one more night.

Work waiting with Tasho’s crew if you choose to show up.

Mushrooms waiting in Ollie’s keeping for future experiments.

Two different people expecting to see you again about rice balls, eventually.

An old woman on the hill who knows you’re out here and, for now, has decided that’s

not a catastrophe.

No one is pounding on your door. No emergency has smashed through the roof.

Just a village morning in Kakariko, starting without you—but not minding if you join in

whenever you’re ready.

I sit up and turn around, swinging my legs over the side of the futon and stretch with a deep yawn. I sit on the edge of the bed for a minute, just appreciating the wholesome peacefulness.

The time is broken as my tongue glides over my teeth. I hadn't had a single way of cleaning since I arrived, and it was bothering me. The thought of how, or if, a Hylian or Sheikah might clean their teeth had never entered my mind before now, but I was going to have to find a discreet way of finding out. I could ask Ollie...but this actually seemed to be something worth asking Paya about. Thanks to her grandmother she already expected me to ask stupid and embarrassing questions.

There was also the matter of food. I hadn't actually finished Mera's gift bundle as I'd intended yesterday, but a single bread roll and two slices of fruit were all I had left. After that...well I'd have to figure out what something different to satisfy a mid-day meal.

But for now, I pull on my boots and hurry downstairs to start what was becoming a morning routine.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, early morning • Late spring • Cool, pale light, hearth just waking

The steps give their familiar soft tok-tok under your boots as you head down. The air shifts

from your room’s cool quiet to the inn’s warmer, lived-in morning.

The common room’s a little different every dawn, but the bones are the same:

Hearth: banked low, now coaxed back to life. A small flame licks at kindling under the

iron pot.

Smell: rice porridge just starting to thicken, a faint edge of fish, and the comforting

roast of barley tea in the works.

Sound: the soft clatter of bowls, the murmur of two early patrons speaking in low

voices at a corner table.

Ollie’s behind the counter, hair still a little mussed, sleeves rolled up. He’s halfway through

ladling porridge into a bowl when he spots you on the stairs.

His eyes flick over you: rested, cleaner than you’ve been most mornings, and moving

without the same stiff caution as after your first day’s work. That earns you a small,

satisfied nod.

He sets the bowl down, pours hot water over a scoop of toasted barley in a cup, then

looks your way—an unspoken check-in that says: Same as yesterday? Porridge and tea? No

need for words; his hand hovers over a second bowl, ready to commit.

From here you can see a few other little details:

A shallow tray pushed back on a shelf behind the counter, lined with a cloth: your

remaining mushrooms, still where he tucked them aside.

A bundle of clean cloths folded near the end of the bar, as if he’s expecting at least

one person to need a quick wash before heading out.

The board by the door, now with a fresh scrap of paper pinned to it, ink still dark.

From this angle you can just make out a few Hylian characters that look like names

and numbers—maybe a note about stall assignments for the coming marketday.

Your stomach gives its opinion about the situation: ready. Not empty enough to be an

emergency, but clearly eager for porridge and something warm to drink before roof work

or errands claim the rest of your energy.

One of the early patrons—a woman you vaguely recognize from the terraces, hands

stained a little green from handling leaves—glances over as you reach the bottom of the

stairs. She gives a brief nod of acknowledgement, then returns to her bowl, more curious

than judgmental.

Ollie lifts the kettle a little, waiting to see if he’s pouring for one more this morning, the

steam curling up between you like a question mark you don’t need translated.

I eat my food quickly this morning and pass on the second cup of tea. I wanted to see if I could manage to not be the last one to the job today.

I say a "good morning" and a "hope you have a good day" to the woman with the green stained hands and then make a brisk pace out the door with my meager lunchtime supplies and my gloves, almoat jogging to the jobsite.

Thought for 9s

Kakariko – carpentry site

Day 5, early morning • Late spring • Cool shade, bright sky, faint sawdust in the air

You make good time.

By the time the terraces give way to packed earth and stacked lumber, the sun is only just

clearing the eastern ridge. Light slants in at a low angle, catching on motes of dust and the

pale grain of freshly planed beams.

You’re not last.

Sef is only just arriving when you do, hair still damp from a hurried splash-wash, a yawn

half-stifled behind the back of his hand. He blinks when he sees you already closing in on

the site and lifts his chin in a small, impressed greeting.

Closer in, the work tells its own story:

The roof frame is noticeably further along than when you left yesterday: more rafters

in place, lines straighter, the skeleton of what will actually feel like a shelter instead of

just a promise.

A neat pile of offcuts and shavings sits in one corner, Rinna’s yesterday-afternoon

handiwork, now slightly crusted where dew caught them overnight.

Chalk lines and ink marks trace the boards Tasho has already measured this morning

—signs he’s beaten everyone here, as usual.

Rinna is hauling a bundle of thin battens off a cart when you arrive, muscles taut under her

sweat-darkened tunic, hair tied up in a quick knot that’s already thinking about escaping.

Her skin’s taken on more color in the last few days—sun building on an already-deep

working tan—and a faint smear of cedar dust runs along one freckled cheek where she

must’ve swiped at sweat without thinking.

She clocks you, then Sef, then the sky, and grins.

“Look at that,” she calls, voice easy, a little rough from early-morning air. “Our guest beats

you here, Sef.”

Sef mutters something about unfair head starts and longer legs, but it’s more good-

natured than wounded.

Tasho stands near the sawhorses, checking a mortise with his thumb. Up close you see the

lines in his face more clearly this morning—sun-etched, but not harsh. He’s a compact

man, wide across the shoulders, his hair threaded with grey but still thick and tied back in

a low knot.

He gives you a brief, appraising look as you come within speaking distance, eyes flicking

to your hands, your posture, the way you’re moving after two days of work. Whatever he

sees there passes muster: his nod is small but approving.

“Early start,” he says. “Good.”

He gestures with the chisel toward the stacked boards.

“Same as yesterday,” he adds. “You and Rinna on rafters. Sef with me on the joinery. We

push, we might have it ready for tiling before the weather remembers it lives in the hills.”

The air is still cool enough that the sun feels welcome when it catches your shoulders. Your

breakfast sits comfortably in your stomach—not heavy, not empty—and your hands feel

almost eager when you pull your gloves on, fingers flexing into familiar work.

As the morning settles in, the rhythm returns:

Rinna measuring and marking, her quick, precise lines guiding your cuts.

Your saw finding its groove again on the pull stroke, cedar scent blooming with each

pass.

The tok-tok of mallet on chisel from where Tasho and Sef work the more precise joints.

Sweat comes slower today, your body less shocked by the demand. When it beads at your

temples, it’s more from the growing warmth than sheer strain.

A little before mid-morning break, as you and Rinna maneuver a newly cut rafter into

position, she glances sideways at you, breath steady but shallow from the lift.

“You’re getting the hang of this,” she says, nudging the wood into place with her hip. “If

you keep showing up this early, Tasho’ll start pretending you’ve always been on the crew.”

She sets the rafter, then steps back to eye the line, squinting along it with the practiced

look of someone who doesn’t trust anything until she’s seen it herself.

“Marketday tomorrow, by the way,” she adds, still looking at the beam but clearly talking

to you. “Leatherworker should be in, if the weather holds. Saw your eyes go to the empty

belt-loop once or twice.”

She wipes her forehead with the back of her wrist, leaving a fresh smear of dust.

“You still breathing after today’s done, you should go look,” she says. “No sense carrying

coin around if it’s not allowed to turn into things.”

The rafter sits right. Tasho gives a curt nod from below without pausing his work, the

closest thing he gives anyone to verbal praise mid-task.

Your shoulders burn a little when you roll them, but it’s the kind of burn that says working,

not warning. Your meagre lunch waits back where you tucked it, and the angle of the sun

tells you there’s a good block of labor between now and when you get to tear into that

last roll and fruit slices.

The day is properly awake now:

Birds louder in the trees beyond the site.

Village sounds drifting up—voices, a cluck of cuccos, the ring of a hammer on

something that isn’t wood.

The faint, constant hiss of the waterfall below, tying everything together.

Work calls your focus back to the next cut, the next lift, the next alignment—one rafter at a

time, one morning at a time, making yourself a little more of the village and a little less of

the stranger who arrived with nothing but a name and a body that didn’t quite match.

"Thanks," I say to Rinna's compliment. "I try to be a quick learner. A lot of it seemed pretty foreign at first, but it's like..." I sort of akwardly motion my hands. "Like occasionally I have a tiny revelation that 'oh this is just that with a different face', and it all sort of clicks into place in my head." I run a hand over some of the work, "Still, hearing you say the inprovement is noticed is a comfort.

"I do definitely intend to hit up that leatherworker for sure tomorrow. I was going to ask Tasho if he minded me being a little late so I can get there before anybody else. Figure he'll be okay with it, since it'll only help me do my job better anyways."

Seeing that we have a spare moment as Tasho and Sef are still prepping a rafter on the ground, I lean on one of the secured rafters and take my pinkies to the edges of my eyes to get some dusty sweat out of the way. "I did get some mushrooms by the way. After you mentioned them yesterday. I mean, I was already going to get some for Ollie and his mother, but I made sure to get enough for your mother too. If you think she'd still want some."

Thought for 7s

Day 5 • Mid-morning • Roofline above Kakariko • Sun warming, breeze cool

Rinna leans her hip against the same rafter you’re resting on, listening as you talk your way

through the “click.”

At the gesture you make, she huffs a short laugh.

“Yeah,” she says. “Wood’s still wood. Weight’s still weight. Just different words and

different ways of getting yelled at when you get it wrong.”

She runs a calloused thumb along the edge of one of your cuts, testing it like she’s testing

a blade, then nods to herself in quiet agreement with her own earlier compliment.

When you mention the leatherworker and being late tomorrow, she glances over the edge

of the roof toward where Tasho and Sef are working below.

“He won’t like it,” she says frankly. Then her mouth quirks. “But he’ll accept it. Especially if

you come back with a decent belt so you can stop doing that thing where you pat your

waist like you’ve lost something.”

Her eyes go briefly amused; clearly she has noticed.

You bring up the mushrooms, and that catches her full attention. She straightens a little,

pushing hair back from her forehead, leaving another faint streak of dust.

“You did?” she says. “For Mellie?”

There’s a flicker of something softer there—pride, maybe, or a quiet gratitude that doesn’t

quite know where to land yet.

“She’ll absolutely want them,” Rinna goes on. “If you let her, she’ll try to pay you in about

six different ways—coin, extra greens, scolding. That last one’s free.”

She takes a breath, glancing down toward the terraces as if she can see her mother’s fields

from here.

“Best time to catch her’s late afternoon,” she adds. “When the sun’s not hammering her

shoulders and she remembers she’s supposed to eat what she grows. Bring those

mushrooms, mention you’re the one helping on the roof, and she’ll probably sit you down

and fill your ears with stories about how Tasho used to be the clumsy one.”

She eyes you sidelong.

“And if you say the word ‘onigiri’ anywhere in that conversation, you may not be allowed

to leave until you’ve eaten three. Consider yourself warned.”

Below, Tasho gives the rafter he and Sef have been fitting a final, decisive tok with the

mallet, then steps back to measure the line. Apparently satisfied, he shades his eyes with

one hand and calls up.

“That’s one more before water,” he says. “Then hands off tools a moment.”

Rinna pats the rafter you’re on twice—an unspoken “back to it”—and moves to take her

side of the lift as Sef and Tasho angle the next piece up toward you.

As you bend to take the weight, feet finding their grip on the beams, the small, domestic

future-thoughts—leather belts and mushroom rice balls and being scolded by someone’s

mother—slot themselves into place beside the bigger, stranger questions you’ve been

trying not to drown in.

For the next few minutes, though, there’s only the shape of the timber in your hands, the

pull of the saw, Rinna’s quick counting under her breath as she guides the fit, and the

steady, familiar background music of Kakariko working through another morning.

I frown a bit at Rinna saying that Tasho wouldn't like the request, and it makes me double guess my plan. He did keep saying he'd use me if I'd show up though. I'll have to talk to him about it regardless, I guess.

I'm also surprised to hear Rinna refer to her mother as 'Mellie'. The Mellie I knew in the game was married to Olkin and was an older woman without children. Rinna had also said that her father had been a guard in his youth and her mother a weaver, and I only knew Olkin and Mellie as a pumpkin farmer and his wife who tended to a plum orchard. Granted, that did not preclude them being a guard or a weaver when they were younger and now they simply do other things as they've aged. I could easily imagine Olkin and Steen being precursors to Dorian and Cado brfore retiring to farm. It also could be that there was a different, second Mellie. Or it could be the same

Mellie and Olkin and the game simply never represented Rinna because she wasn't relevant to what stories the game wanted to tell. It would explain some things if Olkin and Mellie had a child later in life; I had wondered why Rinna, despite being near my age, still lived with her mother. Mellie and Olkin could clearly still take care of themselves, but they weren't getting any younger. It could be, if they really were Rinna's parents, that she simply thought it was easier to remain living with them in preparation for when they actually needed help.

Or it could be that I simply misread the entire situation and all that was wrong. I dutifully help her get the rafter fitted, and then Tasho calls for a water break, I follow her down.

"So when you say your mother's Mellie," I ask, as Rinna ladels her self out some water, "do you mean, like, 'takes care of the plum trees, married to Olkin' Mellie, or...?"

Thought for 11s

Day 5 • Mid-morning water break • Roof site above Kakariko • Sun bright, shade cool

At the barrel, Rinna braces one forearm on the rim while she works the ladle with the

other, sweat-darkened hair stuck to the back of her neck. She pours a little into the dipper,

downs it in two gulps, then refills for a slower drink.

Your question makes her pause with the ladle halfway back to the barrel.

She squints at you, one freckled brow creeping up.

“Is there some other Mellie I should know about?” she says, deadpan. Then her mouth

softens. “Yeah. Plum trees. Married to Olkin. Shouts at him when he overdoes it on the hill.

That Mellie.”

She tips the ladle, offering it over so you can take your turn.

“Olkin’s my father,” she adds, like it’s the simplest thing in the world. “Used to wear armor

and complain about his knees at the gate. Now he wears straw and complains about his

knees in the pumpkin patch.”

There’s affection under the dry delivery.

“As for the weaving—” she rolls one shoulder, remembering “—Mam grew up at the loom.

Her mother did, and hers before that. When she married my father, she traded patterns for

pits and seeds. Still keeps the old frame, though. Can’t sit still if there’s cloth that needs

mending.”

She glances up the slope, toward where the plum trees would be, hidden behind roofs and

fences.

“I grew up between fields and workshop,” Rinna says. “Turned out I liked wood better than

thread. Mam says that’s because wood listens when you hit it.”

She snorts softly at her own joke, then angles her head at you.

“How’d you pick up all that, anyway?” she asks, not suspicious, just curious. “You’ve only

been here a few days, and you already sound like one of the aunties keeping track of

who’s married to who.”

Before the question can turn into anything weightier, Tasho claps his hands once, sharp,

from where he’s checking a joint.

“Water’s not forever,” he calls. “Five more breaths, then back up.”

Rinna gives you a look that says you don’t have to answer right now and pushes off from

the barrel, rolling her shoulders. She tugs her gloves back into place, fingers flexing, and

starts back toward the stacked rafters, the line of her back already shifting from “daughter

talking about her parents” to “craftswoman back on the clock.”

The barrel’s cool shadow hugs your side as you drink. Above, the unfinished roof waits—

one more rafter’s worth of effort between you and whatever this day shapes into next.

I drink my own helping of water slowly, letting Rinna go on ahead of me before I go to rejoin her. It hadn't occurred to

me that my simple question may have led to me laying a trap for myself. Maybe she would just forget about that. She probably wouldn't. Fortunately she'd already given me an out I could roll with, and I'd have to just make sure I played it smooth enough to be believable.

Thought for 19s

Day 5 • Late morning into early afternoon • Roof site above Kakariko • Sun high, breeze

drying sweat

You let Rinna get ahead of you on the ladder, finish your water in a few slow swallows,

then follow her back up.

Once you’re on the rafters again, the conversation folds back into the grain:

Chalk marks.

Measurements called across the frame.

Wood answering in long, clean curls as the saw rides the pull stroke.

Whatever tangle your question might’ve started, the work unknots it for now. Rinna falls

into the same rhythm as yesterday—steady, practical, occasionally humming under her

breath as she checks your cuts, adjusts a line with a tap of her knuckles, or braces a beam

while you set your end.

Tasho and Sef form their own counterpoint below: the tok of mallet on chisel, the quiet

murmur of numbers, the crack-snap of a joint seating just right.

By the time the sun has climbed high enough that the roof starts to feel like it’s actually

attracting heat instead of just sitting under it, the skeleton of the structure is all but

complete. The rafters form clean, repeating ribs; the shadow they cast actually looks like

the outline of a building instead of a pile of good intentions.

Tasho calls a halt with a sharp clap of his hands.

“That’s the line for today,” he says, voice carrying just enough. “If we push past this in the

heat, we start making mistakes instead of a roof.”

Down on solid ground again, the air feels cooler in the shade than it did atop the beams.

Your shirt sticks to your back in a way that tells the truth about the morning; your hands,

inside the gloves, are damp but no longer raw. The aches are there, but they feel…earned.

You retrieve your little bundle from where you tucked it—Mera’s last roll and the

remaining slices of fruit—and find a spot on a low wall near the site. Rinna drops onto a

nearby crate, stretching one leg out in front of her, boot toe rolling absent patterns in the

dust. Sef flops farther off in the shade, drinking his water like it personally offended him.

Tasho joins you only long enough to lean against a post, arms crossed, eyes running over

the day’s work with the calm, critical satisfaction of a man who’s spent his life translating

lines on wood into places people can stand under.

He gives one small nod, more to himself than anyone else.

“You’ve got the measure of it,” he says, eyes flicking your way for a heartbeat. “Come back

tomorrow. Market or no.”

There’s the faintest dry note under market, like he’s already resigned to you being a little

late and has decided that’s better than losing you to someone else’s project.

He pushes off the post and starts gathering his own tools, clearly headed homeward.

Rinna finishes her water, then jerks her chin toward the terraces below.

“If you’re serious about giving Mam those mushrooms,” she says, “you’ll find her where

the pumpkins start and the plum shadows end. She keeps a little table near the trees so

she can pretend she’s resting while she’s still working.”

A corner of her mouth lifts.

“Tell her I didn’t send you to help,” she adds. “She’ll make you work twice as hard out of

stubbornness.”

The sun’s shifted enough that the village has that early-afternoon brightness: shadows

short, colors a touch washed-out, the heat just starting to gather its strength for the later

hours. From up here, you can see:

The faint line of the path down toward the terraces.

A glimpse of the orchard’s greener patchwork beyond the houses.

Smoke from a few cooking fires, curling thin and white into the sky.

Your stomach, modestly topped up by the roll and fruit, is content but not indulgent. Your

coin pouch is marginally heavier than yesterday. Your basket of foraged mushrooms waits

at the inn, still in Ollie’s keeping, ready to be split between obligations and opportunities.

Tasho and Sef drift off in one direction, talk already turning to something about nails and a

stubborn beam somewhere else in the village. Rinna lingers just long enough to roll her

shoulders and test the stretch in her back before heading uphill, toward where you now

know her parents live.

The jobsite settles into afternoon quiet behind you.

From here, the next steps are yours: back to the inn to reclaim mushrooms, down to

Mellie’s terraces, up the hill to trouble Paya with impossible questions about teeth… or

some new path that’s only obvious once you start walking it.

I get very into the rhythm of the work in the afternoon, and the workday ends abruptly and unexpectedly. I acknowledge Rinna's comments with only a touch of timidity, not wanting to mess anything up, and let her go. I instead run after Tasho and Sef before they can get too far away.

"Sorry," I say as I jog up abruptly. "Don't want to interrupt anything, just wanted to hit you up with a pair of questions before we all headed out, Tasho. Sir."

Kakariko – lane below the jobsite

Day 5, early afternoon • Late spring • Heat building on stone, breeze off the falls

Tasho and Sef are only a dozen paces down the path when you catch up. Sef has a bundle

of tools over one shoulder; Tasho’s carrying his chisel roll and mallet, steps short and

deliberate.

At your jogged apology, both men half-turn.

Sef looks mildly startled; Tasho just stops, plants his feet, and waits. Up close, his face in

this light shows more of the fine lines at the corners of his eyes, but they don’t look

unfriendly—just used.

“Mm,” he grunts, listening.

When you tack on the “sir,” he snorts once, very quietly.

“I answer faster to ‘Tasho’ than ‘sir,’” he says. “But I’m listening. Two questions, you said.

Ask ’em before the sun steals my patience.”

Sef shifts his weight, adjusting the tools on his shoulder, but he doesn’t peel away—clearly

curious enough to stay put while you get your say in. A small bead of sweat tracks down

along his temple; he wipes it away with the back of his wrist, glances between the two of

you, and then focuses on a knot in the path as if that’s suddenly very interesting.

Tasho hooks his thumb into his belt, giving you his full attention without any extra warmth

or chill—just that steady, measuring look you’ve seen him give lumber.

“Go on,” he adds. “You’ve earned a few words.”

"Right," I say with a quick, sharp nod, "I'll be quick. First, I was hoping maybe at some point when you have a little more time I could pick your brain about a saggy beam in Enchanted that I promised I'd try and find out something about. I don't mean like, now, or anything. Just, you know, when it's convenient for you. And second, I, uh, I know it's not very professional, but, uh, tomorrow being a market day like you mentioned..." I hold out my arms to demonstrate how empty they are compared to his own and Sef's, "Rinna mentioned I might be able to find a belt I desperately need from a leatherworker who might be here, but apparently his work goes fast. Would I be holding you up if I was a little later coming in so I could see them?"

Kakariko – lane below the jobsite

Day 5, early afternoon • Late spring • Sun hot on your shoulders, air bright

Tasho listens without interrupting, eyes narrowing a little—not in annoyance, more like

he’s lining up joints in his head.

At the mention of Enchanted’s sagging beam, one corner of his mouth twitches.

“Of course there’s a sagging beam,” he mutters, mostly to himself. “Shop like that, full of

cloth and pride.”

He shifts his chisel roll to the other hand.

“I’ll walk past it tomorrow,” he says. “On my way down, before I meet you. I look, I’ll know

what’s wrong. Telling you how to fix it is more, mm, generous.” The ghost of a dry humor

there. “If the sisters are clever, they’ll have you nearby when I do. Then I only have to

explain it once.”

Sef snorts softly at that, amused, then does his best to look like he didn’t.

When you bring up the belt and the market, Tasho’s gaze drops briefly to your waist, then

to your bare hands and the way your things tend to end up piled rather than worn. He

exhales through his nose, long-suffering but not unkind.

“Tools,” he says, tapping the side of his own belt with a knuckle, “need somewhere to live.

Including hands.”

He glances at the sky, judging the length of tomorrow with that same carpenter’s instinct.

“Market’s busiest early,” he says. “If you’re going to fight half the village for one decent

strip of leather, best you do it when it’s still on the table.”

There’s a pause long enough to feel like a test, then he nods once.

“Come after the rush,” he decides. “Not so late the sun’s past its climb, not so early I’m still

finishing breakfast. If you walk in looking like you’ve been haggling and not sleeping, I’ll

consider that acceptable payment for being late.”

Sef shifts his grip on the tools and grins.

“Means you’ll have to work twice as hard once you do get here,” he puts in, more teasing

than warning.

Tasho grunts his agreement.

“Leather first,” he says. “Roof second. But roof still gets done.”

He gives you one last, weighing look—an unspoken don’t make me regret this that

somehow comes out more like I’m betting you won’t—then turns down the path again.

“Rest your hands while you can,” he throws back over his shoulder. “Tomorrow they earn

that belt.”

Sef gives you a small, companionable nod before following, the two of them shrinking

slowly down the lane between houses and terraces, conversation already turning toward

timber deliveries and whether the next job will involve more ladders or more crawling

under floors.

You’re left with:

The feel of sweat cooling on your neck in the breeze off the falls.

The faint ache in your shoulders that promises to be worse tonight and better next

week.

Permission secured—for both the sagging beam and the leather hunt.

The afternoon ahead is still yours:

Mushrooms waiting at the inn and a promised meeting with Mellie somewhere

between pumpkins and plums.

A goddess statue on the hill, and a granddaughter who wouldn’t blink if you asked

her about something as basic—and important—as teeth.

A village that, slowly, is starting to treat you less like a stranger dropped from

nowhere and more like someone expected to show up again tomorrow.

I call after Tasho and Sef as they walk away. "Thank you s-- " I stop myself and correct halfway through the word 'sir',

"Tasho!"

Left to my own devices for the rest of the day, I don't waste any time making my way to Impa's again to find Paya. I become aware that I actually have a lot I'm trying to cram into the afternoon and evening. I can think of another question or two I should ask after other than just what to do about teeth, and I'm aware that there's no knowing where questions might snowball to. I'd have to try and be cognizant of the time.

Thought for 10s

Kakariko – Impa’s house

Day 5, mid-afternoon • Late spring • Warm sun, cool shade under the great tree

The climb back up toward Impa’s house feels a little shorter today. Habit is starting to map

the village into your bones: the kink in the path near the potter’s place, the stone that

always wobbles slightly near the cucco pen, the way the wind shifts as you get closer to

the falls.

By the time you crest the last rise, the great cherry tree above Impa’s house is moving

lazily in the breeze, leaves whispering more than rustling. The petals now are fewer than

when you first arrived, but enough still drift now and then to give the steps a soft,

scattered blush.

Cado is on duty today at the lower gate—armor neat, posture attentive but not rigid. He

spots you as you approach and gives that slight, precise nod of his.

“Zeth,” he says, in that pleasantly even tone. “Good afternoon. You’re just in time to miss

the hottest part of the day on the roof, I imagine.”

His eyes flick briefly to your hands, your stance, as if confirming you’ve come back in one

piece.

“Lady Impa is taking her rest,” he adds. “But Paya is about. If you have… every-day

matters,” a hint of knowing humor there, “she is well-suited to them.”

He turns his head toward the house and raises his voice just enough.

“Paya. You have a visitor.”

There’s a brief shuffle from inside—quick footsteps, the soft thunk of something set down

in a hurry—and then Paya appears in the doorway.

She’s in a simple working kimono today, sleeves tied back a bit, a faint dusting of flour or

starch on one forearm like she’d been in the middle of some chore. Her hair is pinned up

but already loosening in wisps around her face.

At the sight of you, she freezes for a half-second, then musters her courage and steps fully

out, hands nervously smoothing the front of her clothes.

“Zeth!” she says, voice wobbling just a little on the name before steadying. “G–good

afternoon. You, um… you look…”

Her eyes do a quick head-to-toe sweep and then jump away, cheeks pinkening.

“…well,” she finishes, clearly discarding three other adjectives on the way.

She glances over at Cado, who gives her a small, reassuring nod, then back to you.

“If you’ve come to see Grandmother, she’s… resting,” Paya says, confirming what Cado

already told you. “But she said you may… stop by… on your own business, when needed.”

She shifts the weight on her feet, then gestures a little awkwardly toward the side of the

house, where there’s a narrow strip of shade and a low bench just out of the main path.

“If it is something I can help with,” she offers, “we can talk there. So we don’t block the

steps.”

Cado is already back to scanning the path, clearly content that you’re here on legitimate

business.

Paya leads the way the short distance to the side bench, then hovers rather than sits until

you do—only settling once she’s certain she’s not overstepping. From here, you can see:

The curve of the valley below, layered roofs and terraces stepping away into green.

The goddess statue’s little pond just visible downslope, glinting through the leaves.

A thin line of steam from someone’s cooking fire, flattening out in the mild afternoon

air.

Up close, you notice Paya’s been working: a faint dampness at her temples, the smell of

starch and soap, and that kind of focused alertness of someone halfway through a chore

who doesn’t mind being interrupted but is aware there’s more to do.

She folds her hands in her lap, then unfolds them again, clearly bracing herself for

whatever you’re about to land on her with.

“So, um…” she begins, taking a small breath. “Grandmother said you might have questions.

About… things that are normal to us. That are not… normal… to you.”

She tries for a reassuring smile; it comes out a little shy but honest.

“I will not laugh,” she says, very seriously. “Unless you… want me to.”

Her eyes flick to your face, curious and earnest.

“What did you wish to ask?”

I take my seat graciously and wait for her to join me. I never fully understood Paya's excessive nervousness and strange brand of shyness. In the 'before times' I just chocked it up to being a Japanese trope or stereotype I didn't really know. But as a real person, in the flesh...well, I still didn't understand, but now it felt appropriate that I didn't understand. I didn't actually know much about her at all.

But I don't waste my time wandering or staring, instead getting to the questions at hand. I chuckle slightly nervously. "You laugh or don't laugh as you want. I'm not your keeper and I'm not someone you have to try and impress. I'm just a lonely idiot who knows things he shouldn't. To be honest, I'm a little embarrassed to even ask some of these questions." I close my mouth for a moment and run my tongue over my teeth again.

"So...right..." I place my hands palms down on the low table, thoughtfully. Then finally I give up and just blurt out the question in the bluntest way possible. "How do people clean their teeth here? Where I come from we literally have a special kind of...well I guess you'd call it soap, but it doesn't taste bad or anything because it's made for mouths--and we put it on a brush and scrub our teeth. I don't...really see evidence of people doing that here, but obviously people still keep their teeth in good shape. Have I just missed something very obvious? I'm starting to feel a little gross."

Day 5 • Mid-afternoon • Side of Impa’s house • Warm shade, faint plum blossom on the

breeze

Paya listens, hands folded tight in her lap at first. When you finally get the question out,

her eyes widen—and then, to your surprise, some of the tension leaks out of her

shoulders.

“That is all?” she says, almost in a whisper of relief. “Teeth?”

She clamps her lips together a second later, as if worried she sounded rude, and shakes

her head quickly.

“Um. I do not mean it is not important. It is important. Grandmother says if you live long

enough, your teeth will tell everyone whether you respected your own body.”

She tilts her head, studying your mouth with sudden, clinical curiosity—pure healer’s

granddaughter for a heartbeat—then blushes and drags her gaze back up.

“In Kakariko,” she starts carefully, “we do not have a special… mouth soap. Some of the

travelers from Hateno bring little brushes now, for scrubbing. I have seen them. But most

people still do it the old way.”

She ticks them off on her fingers, one by one.

“In the mornings, many people chew a branch first,” she says. “A thin one. From certain

trees—willow, or a kind of shrub that grows near the river. You chew the end until it

softens, then you rub it along the teeth. It… cleans and makes the mouth feel fresh.”

She mimes it with her fingers: a little stick, one end frayed to a soft brush.

“After meals, some people use salt,” she continues. “Or a powder. Salt mixed with a little

crushed charcoal or ash from clean wood. You wet your fingers or a scrap of cloth, press it

into the powder, and rub the teeth and gums. Then rinse very well.”

Her nose wrinkles faintly at charcoal, which tells you exactly how that tastes.

“For… special care,” she adds, “the apothecary in Hateno makes powders with herbs. Mint,

sometimes, or shiso.” She smiles, small but genuine. “They make your breath very pleasant.

But those are more expensive.”

She glances down at her own hands, flexing them slightly.

“I use a cloth and powder most days,” she admits. “Grandmother does too. She says if she

can still bite into a radish at her age, it means the gods are not finished with her yet.”

There’s a spark of pride in that.

Then, more quietly, she says, “If you… would like, I can make a little for you. Salt and

charcoal and some dried leaf. It does not taste like your mouth soap, I am sure, but it is

better than nothing. And then, when the Hateno merchants come again, you could ask

them about the little brushes. They call them… hm.” She frowns, searching for the word.

“Tsume-fude. Nail brushes. But some people use them for teeth instead.”

She looks back up, expression earnest.

“You are not… strange… for not knowing,” she says. “You came from ‘very far away.’

Grandmother told me. If you ask about these things, people will only think you were raised

differently, not that you are… wrong.” A tiny pause. “As long as you do not ask the aunties

while they are chewing.”

Her mouth quirks; that was almost a joke.

She smooths her skirt again, then ventures, a little more confident now that she’s survived

Question One:

“You said you had… questions. Plural.” Her eyes are curious, a little worried, but open. “If

the next ones are about… baths… or nails… I can help. If they are about the future and

calamities, I will run to get Grandmother.”

Her gaze settles on you, waiting, the afternoon light picking out the faint constellation of

freckles across her nose you hadn’t noticed before.

I feel my shoulders relax a little at Paya's mild reaction. She was actually far more composed than I expected her to be, and it makes me feel better in turn. "I, yes, I would be, so grateful if I could get some of that powder from you. Of course, if you had the ability to show me *how* to make it, that would be so much the better." I smile, without showing teeth, of course. "'Give a man a fish, teach a man to fish,' right?"

At the mention of 'the big questions' I shake my head. "No, nothing about the future or calamities. The less said about those things the better. That is something that I think everybody can agree on. No, I was just curious about working habits."

I shift my weight a bit, relieving a slight ache in my ankle from crawling around rafters and then sitting on it. "So, again, where I come from--" I stop and shake my head. This constant abstraction was getting annoying. There were certain things that would not have any meaning to people here aside from what meaning I give them. "Let's just call that place 'Kentucky,' for simplicity's sake. In Kentucky, we have this concept of a week being divided into 'weekdays'," I put my hands parallel to each other to the left side of the table to indicate one category, "and 'weekends.'" I move my parallel hands to the right side of the table indicate a separate group. "Weekdays are also sometimes referred to as 'workdays' and weekends..." I pause and blink slowly, trying to explain something I myself had never really taken the time to consider for myself. "...well weekends are just called weekends. But as you might assume, those days are days people typically

don't work. They can rest or catch up on things they need to get done or just enjoy themselves. Not everybody's weekdays and weekends are the same days of the week, so most days you can always find somebody working, unless it's a holiday or something like that.

"I know in other parts of the world that aren't Kentucky, but are closer and more similar to it than Hyrule, the culture is a little different and they don't really do things the same way. Some people work 5 days, have 2 off. Others might work 4 days and have 3 off. Other places work every day and just take off when they have to." I pause there, lowering my voice slightly to indicate a personal opinion, "Which, personally, sounds awful to me." I look up to meet her eyes. "But you get used to what you're raised with, I suppose. I guess what I'm wondering is how things like that are handled here."

Thought for 6s

Impa’s house – side bench

Day 5, mid-afternoon • Late spring • Warm shade, resin and starch on the air

Paya brightens visibly when you ask to learn rather than just receive. That seems to hit

some switch in her.

“Yes,” she says, nodding quickly. “Fish and… teaching. I understand.”

She pushes herself up from the bench in a little rush of decision.

“Wait here a moment,” she adds. “I will get the things.”

She vanishes inside. You hear quiet movement—drawers, a cabinet, the tiniest clink of

ceramic on wood. After a short pause she returns with:

A small glazed bowl, pale blue, no bigger than both your hands cupped together.

A pinch pot of coarse salt.

A little folded paper packet that leaves a faint black smudge on her fingertips—

charcoal powder.

A tiny bundle of dried leaves tied with thread.

She settles beside you again, sets the things on the low table, and breathes once, like she’s

switching into “instruction mode.”

“Salt first,” she says.

She taps a modest pinch into the bowl. The grains catch the light.

“Then charcoal. Clean charcoal only—burned wood from a cooking fire, not coal, not

anything with oils or resins.”

She adds less charcoal than salt—enough to grey the mix but not blacken it fully—then

crumbles a few specks of the dried leaf between her fingers over the top. A faint, fresh

scent lifts: something between mint and shiso.

“This is for taste,” she explains, “and for breath. The herbs can change. Mint if you have it.

Shiso. Sometimes sage.”

She mixes it with the tip of her finger, grinding salt and charcoal together until you have a

fine, mottled powder.

“For use,” she says, “you wet a cloth—clean, soft—or your fingers. Press into the powder,

like this…”

She dampens a fingertip with a bit of water from a small gourd she brought, taps it into

the powder so it clings in a thin coat.

“Then you rub the teeth,” she says, touching her own front teeth lightly with the knuckle of

her other hand to illustrate rather than actually rubbing charcoal on them in front of you.

“Front, back, along the gums. Not too hard. Just enough that it feels like sand on stone.

Then you rinse very well. Twice, if you can.”

She nudges the bowl slightly toward you.

“This will last you a few days,” she says. “Longer, if you are careful. If you keep it dry, it will

not spoil. If it clumps or smells wrong, you throw it away and make new.”

She folds the rest of the dry herb bundle back into its little paper.

“You can ask at the shops for good salt and clean charcoal,” she adds. “The herbs you can

gather, if you learn them—or buy a little at the apothecary.”

She considers a moment, then smiles, small but pleased.

“If you would like, when the Hateno traders next come, I can show you the little brushes,”

she says. “Then you can decide which way your teeth prefer.”

When you pivot to “Kentucky” and weeks and weekends, she sits very still, following your

hand gestures like she’s trying to memorize a diagram.

“Ke–n–ta–ki,” she repeats quietly once, filing the word away.

She listens to the explanation of workdays and off-days with a frown of concentration, lips

moving silently as she maps it out in her own terms.

When you finish, she nods slowly.

“In Hyrule…” she begins, choosing her words, “we do not cut the week so sharply.”

She lifts one finger.

“There is a week,” she says. “Seven days. We name them after the gods and the lights in

the sky—Sun-day, Moon-day, and so on.” A faint, apologetic shrug. “But most people do

not say those names except when counting time. They say: ‘three days from now,’ or ‘the

day before last.’”

Another finger.

“Work depends on the kind of life,” she continues. “Farmers work when the field demands.

There is no true ‘rest day’ in planting or harvest. But on days of heavy temple observance

—new moon, full moon, certain festivals—they do lighter tasks near home, if they can.”

She glances down toward the terraces.

“In Kakariko, it is much the same,” she says. “The old ones and the very young rest more.

The valley keeps moving. But on marketdays…” She makes a small circling motion with her

hand. “Many people change their work. Some sell instead of sow. Some buy instead of

mend. Some—forgive me—stand in the square and talk all day and call it ‘business.’”

There’s that tiny flash of dry humor again.

“For craftsmen—like Tasho and the others—” she goes on, “they decide their own rhythm.

Some take one day in the week to mend tools, sharpen blades, rest their backs. Some work

six days and call the seventh ‘lazy,’ even if they are still fetching water and fixing fences.”

She looks back up at you, expression open, thoughtful.

“We do not have a word like your ‘weekend,’” she says. “But we have… pockets. Days

where the village agrees, quietly, that it is better not to push too hard unless there is

need.”

Her gaze softens.

“After the Calamity ended, we had many seasons where every day felt like workday and

restday together,” she adds. “Rebuilding is like that. You fix what is broken, and then you

sit with your neighbors so you remember why it was worth fixing.”

She seems to realize she’s strayed close to heavier ground and pulls herself back a little.

“For you,” she says, “if you wish to rest one day in seven, no one will think it strange. If you

wish to work every day until your hands complain, no one will stop you—only scold you

when you drop a beam on your foot.”

She tilts her head, shy curiosity returning.

“Does that… answer what you hoped to know?” she asks. “Or is there a part of ‘weekend’

that I have not understood?”

The little bowl of tooth powder sits between you on the table, faint herb-scent rising. The

afternoon light has softened a touch, shadows beginning to stretch—but not yet long

enough to call the day done.

I absorb the knowledge about the tooth cleaning powder greedily. I feel grateful that I have some plant knowledge and could easily identify mint and sage in the wild. Or at least, I could at home. Surely they aren't that different here. Shiso, on the other hand...that one is new to me. I accept the little paperfull of powder happily, and both thank her and take her up on her offer of being shown the 'little brushes from Hateno' if they become available.

I'm amused at her pronunciation of 'Kentucky' as 'Ke-en- ta-ki', but in an endearing way, and I try to make it apparent by my facial expression that I'm not disappointed or mocking her. I like it. In my own mind, I can believe a 'Ke'entaki' could exist in the Hyrule world. Not so much Kentucky.

"No, you seem to understand perfectly. And your answer helps me understand too. That helps me put things into perspective very well." I look at her for a second, but not long enough to make her feel uncomfortable. In the game, she was easy to think of as pathetic or to mock. But in this context, I would have been ashamed to think such things, even if she did have some shy and timid quirks. "You're good at your job, Paya. Thank you."

Impa’s house – side bench

Day 5, mid–afternoon • Late spring • Soft breeze, distant falls

Paya watches your face carefully as you take the powder, like she’s bracing for some sign

she’s done it wrong. When she sees only relief and interest, her shoulders loosen.

Your thanks land; your praise does more.

At “you’re good at your job,” her eyes go round, and for a heartbeat she looks like you’ve

just hit her with a blunt, harmless spell.

“M–my…?” She glances back toward the house, as if Impa might appear in the doorway to

confirm you’re talking about the right person. Then color floods her cheeks.

“I… I only try to do what Grandmother asks,” she says, voice small but warm. “If that helps

you, then… I am glad.”

She folds her hands together, trying to turn the fluster into something like composure.

“You should rinse with that powder tonight,” she adds, slipping back into practical mode.

“Gently at first. Your mouth will tell you quickly if it does not like it. And if it does… then

you can make more whenever you need.”

She hesitates, then reaches for a scrap of paper and a short, worn brush lying near the

door. With quick, neat strokes she writes a few Hylian characters—simple enough that

even your still-adjusting mind parses them easily:

Salt

Charcoal

Leaf

Next to each, a tiny symbol: a little mountain of granules, a blackened twig, a stylized leaf.

She folds it and offers it to you.

“In case you forget the order,” she says. “Or if someone else must mix it for you.”

From the front of the house, Cado’s voice carries softly up the steps as he exchanges a few

words with a passerby. The sun has slipped a little further west; the shade beside the

house is beginning to creep outward.

Paya glances at the light, then back to you.

“You still have some day left,” she says, more confident now that the worst of your

embarrassment has been survived. “If you mean to see the fields, or the shops, the aunties

will be out before long. They talk more when they are tired,” she adds, almost

conspiratorially. “It is a good time to listen.”

She stands and gives you a small, formal bow—far less wobbly than your first day here.

“If you have more… Kentak–… Kentucky questions,” she corrects herself carefully, “you may

ask again. Grandmother says I must learn as much from you as you do from us.”

Her smile this time is tiny but real.

Cado nods you a courteous farewell as you leave the shade of the house. From here,

Kakariko spills down the hill in layers of sun and shadow:

The plum orchard’s crowns catching the light.

A hint of orange where pumpkins sit fat under their leaves.

The roof you’ve been helping to raise, ribs of new wood bright against older beams.

The paper packet of tooth powder weighs almost nothing in your hand. The rest of the

afternoon tugs at you in several directions at once: terraces and Mellie, Enchanted’s

complaining beam, the inn and its waiting basket of mushrooms—and, somewhere under

all of it, the slow, steady work of turning “stranger dropped from nowhere” into “person

who belongs on people’s lips when they say each other’s names.”

I make my way back to the inn slightly slower, being observant of the village as I go. Paya's comment about the aunties coming out and it being a good time to listen almost seems like both a hint and a dare that I should be paying more attention to them. I've been struck a number of times, even before I arrived in Kakariko by Harlin's statements, that these alleged gossipy aunties seem to be such a big deal here.

Thought for 8s

Kakariko – upper paths down toward the inn

Day 5, late afternoon • Late spring • Sun sliding west, village exhaling

You take your time descending from Impa’s house, letting your pace match the place

instead of your to-do list.

The village is in that shift between “working” and “winding down”:

Wash flaps quietly on lines between houses.

Smoke from cooking fires has thickened, carrying soy and miso and a hint of grilled

fish.

Children’s voices rise and fall like birds, then get shushed when they get too close to

the steeper slopes.

And the aunties are, as advertised, out.

You notice them now in a way you hadn’t before:

Two older women on a porch near the plum orchard, rolling yarn into balls, hands

moving without looking.

Another trio on low stools by a shared water trough, washing greens and talking, talk

doing most of the work.

One seated on her front step, shelling peas into a bowl while her eyes do a slow

patrol of the lane.

You don’t need to loiter to hear them; the breeze and the natural amplification of stone

carry enough.

“…—I saw him on the roof with Tasho’s crew. Proper work, that…”

“…Enchanted’s stock is less likely to fall on our heads now, if what my niece says about the

new pile is true…”

“…Harlin’s strays usually move on. This one keeps buying porridge and coming back

upright. That says something.”

No one says your name exactly, but “the carpenter from the ruins,” “the tall one at the

inn,” “Mellie’s Rinna was talking about him, you know” all float past in fragments as you

walk.

Eyes flick to you, to the gloves at your belt, to the easier way you navigate the stone steps

now compared to the first day. You get:

A few small nods from people you’ve seen but not really met.

One assessing squint from an auntie with a blue headscarf, like she’s measuring you

for either a scolding or a favor depending on which way you lean.

A thin, surprisingly approving “hn” from an older man sitting on a low wall, pipe unlit

but habitual in his hand, when he notices the dust on your clothes and the lack of

slouch in your shoulders.

Nobody stops you. Nobody hails you over. But you’re no longer invisible. You’re a topic.

By the time you reach the lower terrace where the inn sits, the light has turned honey-

colored. The signboard for the Shuteye sways gently; the smell of rice and barley tea is

unmistakable.

Through the open front, you can see:

Ollie behind the counter, mid-conversation with a traveler you don’t recognize.

Your borrowed basket from earlier today, freshly empty and leaned against the wall

behind him.

A couple of regulars already settled on floor cushions with early tea, talking low about

tomorrow’s market—snatches of “leather,” “spice seller,” “if he’s not sold out by noon,

he’s dead.”

The day still has some stretch left in it, but the village is clearly beginning the shift from

labor to food, from food to talk.

You’re at the threshold of the inn, the warmth and light spilling across your boots, with a

head full of new information, a paper of tooth powder in your pocket, and a mental list

that includes at least one Mellie, one beam, one belt, and maybe a pot or two of tea.

*/ Your last response is very good, but revise it to acknowledge that the player does not yet have a belt; it is a goal being worked to at the moment. /*

Kakariko – upper paths down toward the inn

Day 5, late afternoon • Late spring • Sun sliding west, village exhaling

You take your time descending from Impa’s house, letting your pace match the place

instead of your to-do list.

The village is in that shift between “working” and “winding down”:

Wash flaps quietly on lines between houses.

Smoke from cooking fires has thickened, carrying soy and miso and a hint of grilled

fish.

Children’s voices rise and fall like birds, then get shushed when they get too close to

the steeper slopes.

And the aunties are, as advertised, out.

You notice them now in a way you hadn’t before:

Two older women on a porch near the plum orchard, rolling yarn into balls, hands

moving without looking.

Another trio on low stools by a shared water trough, washing greens and talking, talk

doing most of the work.

One seated on her front step, shelling peas into a bowl while her eyes do a slow

patrol of the lane.

You don’t need to loiter to hear them; the breeze and the natural amplification of stone

carry enough.

“…—I saw him on the roof with Tasho’s crew. Proper work, that…”

“…Enchanted’s stock is less likely to fall on our heads now, if what my niece says about the

new pile is true…”

“…Harlin’s strays usually move on. This one keeps buying porridge and coming back

upright. That says something.”

No one says your name exactly, but “the carpenter from the ruins,” “the tall one at the

inn,” “Mellie’s Rinna was talking about him, you know” all float past in fragments as you

walk.

Eyes flick to you, to the gloves tucked into your waistband where a belt really ought to be,

to the easier way you navigate the stone steps now compared to the first day. You get:

A few small nods from people you’ve seen but not really met.

One assessing squint from an auntie with a blue headscarf, like she’s measuring you

for either a scolding or a favor depending on which way you lean.

A thin, surprisingly approving “hn” from an older man sitting on a low wall, pipe unlit

but habitual in his hand, when he notices the dust on your clothes and the lack of

slouch in your shoulders.

Nobody stops you. Nobody hails you over. But you’re no longer invisible. You’re a topic.

By the time you reach the lower terrace where the inn sits, the light has turned honey-

colored. The signboard for the Shuteye sways gently; the smell of rice and barley tea is

unmistakable.

Through the open front, you can see:

Ollie behind the counter, mid-conversation with a traveler you don’t recognize.

Your borrowed basket from earlier today, freshly empty and leaned against the wall

behind him.

A couple of regulars already settled on floor cushions with early tea, talking low about

tomorrow’s market—snatches of “leather,” “spice seller,” “if he’s not sold out by noon,

he’s dead.”

The day still has some stretch left in it, but the village is clearly beginning the shift from

labor to food, from food to talk.

You’re at the threshold of the inn, the warmth and light spilling across your boots, with a

head full of new information, a paper of tooth powder in your pocket, and a mental list
