that includes at least one Mellie, one beam, one future belt, and maybe a pot or two of

tea.

I try to mentally file away all the little fragments I hear, but in the end decide that really, it only matters to use them as a barometer of my 'approval rating' by the village. They could be saying negative things, about how I'm basically homeless, speculation about why I keep going to the

chieftain's house, so on and so forth. But they aren't. They seem to be focusing on the positive, and that makes me feel good inside. Like I'm passing Impa's test. The small snippet I catch about "'Millie's Rinna was talking about him, you know,'" does ring in my head louder than most of the comments, and I have to mentally scold myself. It was a foolish thing to continue getting more attached to her. But I was doing it anyways.

As I approach the entrance to the Shuteye Inn, I linger, looking around at the village, but paying less attention to it than to my thoughts. It couldn't really be a bad thing to get to know Rinna better, though, could it? Surely nobody expected me to be friendless, and while I had no problem being friends--even close, tight friends--with people younger or older than me, like Sef or Tasho, it was also a nice thing to be friends with someone who was genuinely my own peer in age. There didn't seem to be many people around the village close to my own age, I'd noticed; Rinna was somewhat unusual that way. Coincidence, perhaps, but I had no way of knowing. Ollie seemed to be not much younger than me, but I didn't know his age. Harlin was actually my age, and Mera was close, but they weren't here anymore, so they didn't count. Everybody else I'd encountered so far was either noticeably younger or older than me. Paya, Claree, Lasli, Sef--they all seemed at least 10 years younger than me, maybe a little less. Tasho, Dorian, Cado, Impa--all older. I was craving someone to make deeper conversation with other than "Yes I do need a hot bath" or "I know how to use a saw". And that seemed fair to me.

On the other hand...I'm not blind to my own feelings. Or at least, I don't think I am. Was I simply using my need for comradery as a means to justify indulging my obvious infatuation with Rinna? I don't even know the answer. Regardless, I would need to be careful, both with my actions and with my speech.

I enter the inn, catching bits of conversation about

tomorrow's marketday, and wait at the counter for Ollie to finish speaking with this other traveler, giving the traveler a discreet look-over as I wait.

Thought for 10s

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, late afternoon tipping toward evening • Late spring • Lanterns just being lit

The inn is in that comfortable in–between: not yet crowded, but no longer empty.

Inside:

The fire is banked low but steady, throwing a soft orange into the room.

A couple of regulars are already installed on cushions near the far wall, cups of barley

tea in hand, trading stories about prices, pumpkins, and whose cousin married badly.

The smell tonight is rice and something stewed long with miso and greens, getting

thicker as the light outside thins.

At the counter, Ollie is finishing with a traveler.

The man is Hylian, early middle age, with a lean, wind-browned face and crow’s-feet that

look like they were carved by squinting at long roads rather than laughing. His hair is tied

back with a faded red cord; the outer robe he wears is travel-stained but well-kept,

patterned with a subtle weave of little diamond shapes. A sturdy pack leans against his

stool, and beside it:

A wrapped bundle that looks like it could be tools.

A narrow case long enough for rolled oilcloth, or perhaps leather strips.

You only catch the tail end of the conversation:

“…if the weather holds, I’ll come in with the rest at sunrise,” the traveler is saying. “If not,

you’ll get my cousin instead, and I’ll be stuck knee-deep in a ditch full of someone else’s

wheels.”

Ollie snorts softly, that half-laugh he does when he sympathizes but can’t fix it.

“Let the ditch have the cousin, then,” he says. “Kakariko will fight over who gets your work

as it is.”

The traveler slides a few rupees across the counter, accepts a small wooden chit in

exchange—room token, by the look of it—and tucks it away. As he turns to step down

from the stool, his gaze brushes over you: a quick, measuring merchant’s look, taking in

your height, your hands, the dust in the seams of your clothes.

There’s no malice in it, just professional assessment. He gives you a brief nod—as one

working traveler to another—and moves off toward the back, where the guest rooms are.

Up close, you noticed two things:

His pack smelled faintly of oiled leather and tannin.

The case at his side had a pattern on the strap—tiny stamped crescents—that

matches one of the belts you saw on a villager yesterday.

Ollie follows the man with his eyes until he’s out of sight, then exhales and wipes his hands

on a cloth, attention sliding easily over to you.

“You timed it just right again,” he says, mouth quirking. “In before the rush, after the first

pot’s stopped sulking.”

His gaze flicks automatically to your face, to your hands, noting you’ve come back from

the hill without obvious injury and with the particular tired–but–straight posture of a day

that used most of your strength but not all of your hope.

He nods once, as if checking off a box only he can see, then gestures toward the main

room.

“Same as before—there’ll be stew and rice if you’re staying in,” he says. “Tea’s already

started. You can wash up out back if you want to scare less soup off your spoon.”

Behind him, the empty basket you used for mushrooms earlier leans against the wall,

newly clean and dry. On a shelf just above it, something else catches your eye: a pair of

small ceramic bowls and a tiny lidded jar with a faint, familiar black smudge at the rim.

Someone’s been grinding charcoal recently.

Once Ollie’s finished the practicalities—room, food, the general state of the day—he leans

lightly on the counter.

“And,” he adds, glancing in the direction the traveler went, “seems tomorrow’s market will

have at least one craftsman whose work half the valley keeps under their tunics.”

There’s the barest hint of amusement as his eyes drop, just for a heartbeat, to where your

gloves are still tucked into your waistband for lack of an actual belt.

He doesn’t say any more than that; he doesn’t have to. The inn hums softly around you—

voices, clink of cups, the low burble of the stewpot—as the evening begins to properly

take shape, leaving you to decide what to do, and who to talk to, next.

I make a mental note of the man's appearance so I know who to look for near the pond tomorrow. "Duly noted," I say about the leatherworker before turning my attention fully to Ollie. "So, I may have overextended myself a bit, but I'll let you tell me if that's true or not. I was hoping to get cleaned up, sure enough, but also deliver my leftover mushroom haul *and* take you up on your onigiri class, if it's still on the table." I look at the lengthening shadows outside the inn. "Think I have enough time to accomplish all that or have I done myself in?"

Thought for 8s

Shuteye Inn – common room / back stoop

Day 5, late afternoon sliding into evening • Late spring

Ollie glances toward the door, gauging the light the way you’ve seen farmers judge

weather. Then he looks back at you, the corner of his mouth tugging up.

“You?” he says. “You’ve been hauling beams and chasing mushrooms for two days and still

walk in here upright. You’ll live.”

He lifts a hand, ticking your list off on his fingers.

“Quick rinse, yes. It’s a warm evening; you’ll dry before the rice cools. Mushrooms—

Mother will be annoyed if you don’t let her thank you properly. And onigiri class…” His

eyes flick toward the back, where pots clink softly. “She’s just washed the rice. Perfect time.

If we wait any longer, you’ll be learning how to eat them instead of how to make them.”

He ducks beneath the counter, comes up with:

A smaller basket, lined with a clean cloth, already holding the portion of mushrooms

you’d set aside. The razorshrooms glint faintly orange in the indoor light; the brown

caps sit solid and honest beside them.

“Here,” he says, passing it across. “These are the ones we didn’t need. You can take them

up to Mellie on your way back from washing. She’s at the terraces; you’ll hear her before

you see her. Likes to tell the pumpkins what she thinks of them.”

There’s fondness in his tone that confirms your guess from Rinna’s stories: that Mellie.

He gestures with his chin toward the side door.

“Wash trough’s out back,” he says. “Same as before—there’s a ladle. Try not to flood the

whole yard. When you come back, bring the basket into the kitchen instead of the counter.

Mother will have you shaping rice before you can say ‘too many promises.’”

Out back, the air is cooler, touched by damp stone and the faint green of moss. The wash

trough sits under the eaves: a long, shallow stone basin catching water from a bamboo

spout, its surface rippling steadily.

You set your things safely away from splash reach, roll up your sleeves, and start in:

Cold water over face and neck, chasing off the day’s sweat and sawdust.

Forearms and hands scrubbed clean, cedar grit and charcoal smudges swirling away

downstream.

The simple act of splashing clean water on skin that still remembers eczema and chronic

ache from another life feels almost indecently luxurious.

By the time you pat your face dry on your sleeves, the sky has shifted another shade

toward evening, but there’s still plenty of light. Your stomach is starting to send up small,

hopeful signals at the smell of rice steaming inside.

Basket in hand, you circle back through the lane and start up toward the terraces.

The pumpkin fields sit on their own broad ledge, just above the plum trees. As you

approach, you hear her before you see her, just as Ollie promised:

“…no, you’re not getting more water until you stop sulking and stand up straight,” a

woman’s voice is saying, dry as old bark. “I raised better squash than that in the bad years.

Don’t you dare shame me now, when the sun’s actually doing its job.”

You crest the last rise and see her:

Mellie is older than Rinna by several decades, but you can see the line between them.

Strong shoulders under a faded indigo work kimono, sleeves tied back with a cord. Hair

streaked white and black, piled up and pinned with what looks suspiciously like an old

hairpin repurposed from a tool. Her hands—like the green-stained woman in the inn—

carry their own pigment: hints of earth and leaf, ground in where no washing ever fully

removes it.

She rests a hand on her hip, glaring at a particularly lazy pumpkin vine as if daring it to

misbehave further. Then she notices you at the edge of the terrace.

Her eyes flick to the basket, then your face, taking your measure in one long, unimpressed

sweep the way only someone’s mother can.

“Well,” she says, voice rough but not unkind. “You’re taller than Rinna made you sound. I

suppose that’s not a crime.”

Her gaze drops again to the mushrooms, and now there is no mistaking the interest.

“Those had better be as good as the gossip says,” she adds, wiping her hands on her

apron as she steps toward you. “Come on then. Show me what the forest gave you, before

the light goes properly stupid on us.”

I busy myself at my tasks, making sure I don't run out of time. Heading up the hill, I worry about not having ever actually gotten clear directions to Mellie, Olkin and Rinna's home, and then breath a tiny sigh of relief when Mellie

herself makes it clear where I needed to be before I had to start knocking on doors.

"Good evening, ma'am," I offer her the basket. "Hope you can make some use of them. Rinna said you might." I watch her as she investigates the availability, wondering to myself if Mellie counts as one of the 'aunties' in the village or not.

Thought for 10s

Pumpkin terraces above Kakariko

Day 5, early evening • Late spring • Air cooling, stones still warm

Mellie takes the basket from you with the air of someone accepting tribute on behalf of

the soil itself.

She crouches beside a flat stone and tips the contents out into a neat little spread. Her

fingers move quick and sure, turning caps, checking stems, giving one or two a decisive

thumbnail press.

“Mm,” she grunts after a moment. “Forest didn’t cheat you.”

She taps one of the orangey razorshrooms with a knuckle.

“These’ll wake a sleepy stew,” she says. “Or put hair on someone’s chest who doesn’t

deserve it. Good color, no rot. You cut them proper, too.”

She glances up at you briefly, then snorts.

“And you didn’t grab the ones crawling with chu spit just to show off. Better judgment

than some pups I’ve sent up there.”

Her hands separate the haul into two casual piles without really looking: one for drying,

one for immediate use. A few of the best brown caps she nudges aside, almost absent-

mindedly, into their own little group.

“For your rice lessons,” she says, as if it is obvious. “No point teaching you if you don’t get

to taste your own work.”

At your mention of Rinna, Mellie’s mouth does a funny little thing—half smirk, half sigh.

“She says all sorts of things,” Mellie mutters, but there’s no heat in it. “Mostly about

beams, roofs, and whether you remember to eat when you’re busy. If she told you I’d

make use of shrooms, she was at least right about that.”

She dusts off her palms, straightens up with a small, habitual groan, then waves one hand

toward the village below.

“Go on, then,” she says. “Before my son talks your ears off about every way you can ruin

rice if you don’t listen to his mother.”

Her eyes narrow just a fraction, weighing you the way the aunties weighed you on the

steps.

“You keep working proper for Tasho and not picking fights with stones or chus,” she adds,

“and this village will have more to say about you than ‘that stray Harlin dragged in.’ Most

of it might even be decent.”

It is, in its way, a blessing.

She scoops the mushrooms back into the basket with quick efficiency, keeps most, and

presses a small, folded cloth parcel into your hand—lighter than it looks.

“For you,” she says. “Don’t open it in the dirt. And don’t say ‘thank you’ so loudly the

pumpkins hear; they’ll get ideas.”

With that, she turns back to her vines, already mid-lecture again, scolding a leaf that has

dared flop the wrong way.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen and common room

Day 5, evening proper • Lanterns bright, sky deepening blue

Back at the inn, the warmth of the kitchen hits you first: steam, woodsmoke, and the

comforting, starchy smell of rice.

Ollie’s mother has the rice cooling in a wide wooden tub, each grain glistening. The

remaining mushrooms have been cleaned and sliced; a small bowl of salt sits nearby,

along with squares of toasted seaweed and a little dish of sesame.

She doesn’t waste time. Hands washed again, she shows you:

How to wet your palms so the rice won’t cling like a barnacle.

How much salt is enough salt and when it becomes “you’ve made a rock.”

How to tuck a bit of mushroom into the center and fold the rice around it, pressing

gently until it holds together.

Her hands move with the easy speed of long practice, shaping neat little triangles in three

motions. Yours are slower, a bit uneven at first, but they hold. After the third or fourth, the

motions begin to feel familiar in the way the pull-saw did once your brain finally mapped it

to something you knew.

She grunts approvingly when you adjust your touch without being told.

“Good,” she says. “You listen with your fingers.”

By the time you’re done, a small plate of your work sits to one side—some with

razorshroom tucked inside, some with the milder browns. She claims a couple

immediately, sets another few aside with a curt, “for Mellie,” and consigns the rest to the

common pot of village fortune.

Later, in the main room, a bowl of stew and a mound of rice find their way to you as usual

—only tonight there’s also one of your own onigiri on the rim of your plate, seaweed band

glinting dark against the white.

The first bite is all texture at once: the give of the rice, the slight chew of the mushroom,

the spark of salt and sesame. Simple, but not plain.

At the next low table over, one of the regulars takes a cautious bite of an extra rice ball

from a shared plate, eyebrows going up.

“This from the kitchen tonight?” he asks Ollie, half to himself.

Ollie, passing with a fresh pot of tea, only says, “Partly,” with a little sideways flick of his

eyes in your direction.

The murmur of conversation rises and falls around you: market gossip, field yields,

arguments about whether tomorrow will bring rain. The traveler from earlier sits near the

wall, methodically oiling a strap, his narrow case close by. You catch the faint, familiar tang

of leather again.

Between the food, the heat of the room, and the slow ebb of the day’s work from your

muscles, the inn feels less like a place you’re merely allowed to be and more like a place

that will remember you when you walk through the door.

Outside, Kakariko’s lanterns glow like little low stars along the terraces. Inside, your bowl

empties, your onigiri disappears in satisfying bites, and the evening stretches ahead—

room upstairs, ink and paper if you want them, and the promise of a busy morning at the

pond where leather meets coin.

*/ Please revise the last response to end as Mellie "turns back to her vines", so as to give the player more opportunity to interact with the scene before moving on. /*

Pumpkin terraces above Kakariko

Day 5, early evening • Late spring • Air cooling, stones still warm

Mellie takes the basket from you with the air of someone accepting tribute on behalf of

the soil itself.

She crouches beside a flat stone and tips the contents out into a neat little spread. Her

fingers move quick and sure, turning caps, checking stems, giving one or two a decisive

thumbnail press.

“Mm,” she grunts after a moment. “Forest didn’t cheat you.”

She taps one of the orangey razorshrooms with a knuckle.

“These’ll wake a sleepy stew,” she says. “Or put hair on someone’s chest who doesn’t

deserve it. Good color, no rot. You cut them proper, too.”

She glances up at you briefly, then snorts.

“And you didn’t grab the ones crawling with chu spit just to show off. Better judgment

than some pups I’ve sent up there.”

Her hands separate the haul into two casual piles without really looking: one for drying,

one for immediate use. A few of the best brown caps she nudges aside, almost absent-

mindedly, into their own little group.

“For your rice lessons,” she says, as if it is obvious. “No point teaching you if you don’t get

to taste your own work.”

At your mention of Rinna, Mellie’s mouth does a funny little thing—half smirk, half sigh.

“She says all sorts of things,” Mellie mutters, but there’s no heat in it. “Mostly about

beams, roofs, and whether you remember to eat when you’re busy. If she told you I’d

make use of shrooms, she was at least right about that.”

She dusts off her palms, straightens up with a small, habitual groan, then waves one hand

toward the village below.

“Go on, then,” she says. “Before my son talks your ears off about every way you can ruin

rice if you don’t listen to his mother.”

Her eyes narrow just a fraction, weighing you the way the aunties weighed you on the

steps.

“You keep working proper for Tasho and not picking fights with stones or chus,” she adds,

“and this village will have more to say about you than ‘that stray Harlin dragged in.’ Most

of it might even be decent.”

It is, in its way, a blessing.

She scoops the mushrooms back into the basket with quick efficiency, keeps most, and

presses a small, folded cloth parcel into your hand—lighter than it looks.

“For you,” she says. “Don’t open it in the dirt. And don’t say ‘thank you’ so loudly the

pumpkins hear; they’ll get ideas.”

With that, she turns back to her vines, already mid-lecture again, scolding a leaf that has

dared flop the wrong way.

I accept Mellie's cloth parcel with a quiet thanks and take a tiny peek at its contents before I go anywhere.

The pumpkin terraces – by Mellie’s plot

Day 5, early evening • Late spring

The cloth parcel is rough-woven, tied with a simple twist of thread. When you ease the

knot loose and peel it back just enough to peek inside, a warm, savory smell puffs up at

you.

Inside, nested in the cloth, is a smaller fold of paper holding:

A little drift of coarse, pale seasoning salt flecked with green and dark specks—dried

herbs and maybe a hint of toasted seed. It smells of shiso and something nutty, like

sesame, with a ghost of smoke. Exactly the kind of thing that would vanish into the

dirt forever if you dropped it.

It is not much in quantity, but it is concentrated—meant to be pinched between fingers

and scattered over hot rice or tucked into the palm when shaping onigiri. A “make this

taste like you live here” sort of gift.

Behind you, Mellie’s voice resumes its scolding:

“No, you don’t get any,” she tells a particularly fat pumpkin with a split leaf. “You had

plenty of ash already. You’ll get salt when you’re on a plate, same as everyone else.”

The evening light is slipping more golden across the terraces. Below, you can see the glow

of the inn’s lanterns beginning to sharpen against the deepening blue.

I make sure the package is closed securely and handle it with care as I walk. First over to Mellie again as she scolds the pumpkins. I find her speaking to the gourds rather silly, but there are worse things to be silly about, so I keep my thoughts to myself.

"I've grown a lot of plants, but never pumpkins. Do they treat you well most of the time, or are they little bratty princesses?" I ask, giving the plants some personality in a way that I've done many times before when I've been irritated at a plant for not responding well to treatment, and a way I think Mellie would approve of.

Pumpkin terraces above Kakariko

Day 5, early evening • Late spring • Light going honey-gold

Mellie is mid-harangue with a particularly droopy vine when you speak; she breaks off,

squints at you, then at the pumpkins, then back at you.

“Bratty princesses?” she snorts. “These ones wish they were that lucky.”

She plants a hand on her hip and gestures with the other at the nearest hill of gourds.

“Pumpkins are like big children with hollow heads,” she says. “Feed them right, keep the

weeds off, and they’ll act like they did all the work themselves. Turn your back, they drink

too much water, split their skins, and blame the weather.”

One of the fruits nearest you has a shallow scar down its side where something once

scraped it. Mellie nudges it with her toe, not unkindly.

“But they’re also sweet when they behave,” she concedes. “And they keep. That counts for

more than beauty when winter thinks it’s clever.”

Her gaze flicks briefly to the cloth parcel you’ve re-tied, then back to your face.

“You keep that dry and only use a little at a time,” she says. “Good food doesn’t need to be

shouted at from the spice jar.”

Then, with a small, surprisingly warm grunt:

“And if those rice balls of yours tomorrow don’t taste terrible, bring one up here after

you’ve eaten your own. These spoiled lumps—” she pats a pumpkin, “—can listen to me

brag for once.”

She dismisses you with a little flap of her hand, but there’s no sting in it. Her attention is

already sliding back to the vines, fingers checking a leaf’s underside for pests as she

resumes in a tone halfway between scold and lullaby.

“Stand up straight… leaves like that won’t catch enough light… no sulking, you’re not

cabbages…”

The terrace path down toward the inn is open behind you, the parcel safe in your hand,

the smell of rice and woodsmoke just beginning to drift up the slope.

I smile wryly at the older woman, as if she's let me in on a secret without actually telling me. "Oh I see, you want me to practice with these on Ollie and then show me the *real* way to do it later, huh?"

Pumpkin terraces above Kakariko

Day 5, early evening • Late spring

Mellie barks out a short laugh, sharp as a snapped twig.

“Hah. If you ruin his rice once, he’ll never let you forget it,” she says. “Good practice.”

She straightens up again, giving you an assessing look, amusement tucked into the lines at

the corners of her eyes.

“Besides,” she adds, “if you can follow his fussing and still make something worth eating,

then maybe you’re worth teaching properly. Saves me the trouble of wasting good grain

on someone who can’t listen.”

She tips her chin toward the parcel in your hand.

“That mix is how I do it when I’m too tired to pretend I’m fancy,” she says. “Pinch in the

palm, not the fist. Taste as you go. And don’t tell Ollie I gave you the ‘real’ way unless you

want him under my feet in the kitchen for three days trying to steal the recipe.”

She turns back to her vines, conversation clearly over on her end, and resumes muttering

to the pumpkins as she works.

“Up, up… sun’s still out, you lazy things… don’t make me compare you to last year’s lot…”

The path back down toward the village is open, lanterns just starting to glow below, the

smell of rice and stew drifting faintly up on the cooling air.

I glance at the home nearby, momentarily disappointed I couldn't stay this night to see Rinna or meet Olkin. "Thank you again ma'am. Please give me greetings to the family. Hopefully I'll see you again soon."

After the farewell, I make my way as quickly as I can back to the inn without risking spilling the herbed salt, and eager to finally properly meet Ollie's mother for more than a passing greeting, and maybe learn a thing or two about onigiri.

Thought for 13s

Shuteye Inn – lane, then kitchen

Day 5, early evening tipping toward full night • Late spring • Lanterns lit

You pick your way down the terrace paths a little faster than is strictly wise, one hand

automatically guarding the little parcel at your belt as if a misstep might jostle the flavor

out of it. The village is shifting into evening mode: doors sliding shut, cooking smells

thickening, a couple of kids being shooed inside by an aunt with a broom.

By the time you reach the inn, the lanterns out front are glowing steady and warm. Inside,

the common room is already humming more than it was: low conversations, a pot clinking,

someone laughing too loud at their own joke.

Ollie is mid-pour at a table, topping up cups of barley tea. He spots you over a patron’s

shoulder and jerks his head toward the back, the universal sign for kitchen, now.

“Through there,” he says as he passes by you, just loud enough. “If she throws you out, it

won’t be for lack of mushrooms.”

The kitchen is smaller than you might expect, but densely alive:

A wide wooden tub of rice sits on a low stand, steam just barely lifting from the

glossy grains.

Beside it, a bowl of sliced mushrooms—some razorshroom slivers, some rounder

brown caps—waits like punctuation.

Little dishes hold salt, toasted sesame, and thin strips of dark seaweed.

At the center of all this is Ollie’s mother.

You’ve glimpsed her before in passing, but up close she resolves into specifics: mid-fifties

maybe, compact and strong, hair rolled into a knot under a simple dark kerchief. Her

sleeves are tied back; forearms dusted faintly with rice starch and the ghost of charcoal.

Her eyes are the same brown as Ollie’s, but where his are anxious, hers are sharp and

steady, taking in everything at once.

She doesn’t start with a greeting.

“Hands,” she says instead, nodding at a shallow basin by the door. “Wash. Elbows too, if

you’ve been wrestling rafters again.”

Once you’ve done as told and come back, she gives you a brief, appraising nod, then

gestures you closer to the tub of rice.

“You brought good mushrooms,” she says. “Mellie said so. That saves us time.”

She picks up a small bowl of water and dips her fingers, shaking off the excess.

“Onigiri is simple,” she says. “Which is why most people do it badly. Watch.”

In quick, efficient motions she shows you:

Wet fingers, then palms.

A small pinch of salt, rubbed between her hands until it’s just a sheen.

A scoop of rice into one palm, pressed lightly so it holds together but doesn’t

compact into a brick.

Two pieces of mushroom tucked into the center.

Then a series of gentle, practiced presses—turning the mound between her hands

until it becomes a neat little triangle, edges firm, surface still soft.

She sets the finished rice ball on a waiting plate, then looks at you.

“Your turn,” she says. “Water there. Salt here. Don’t crush it. You’re shaping food, not

punishing it.”

Her tone isn’t unkind; it has the same rough fondness Mellie used on her pumpkins.

As you step up beside her, you can feel the heat of the rice on your skin even before you

touch it, and the aroma of mushroom, steam, and toasted seaweed folds around you in a

way that makes the whole day’s work feel suddenly very far behind and very worth it.

Ollie appears briefly in the doorway, leans on the frame long enough to smirk at the sight

of you drafted into kitchen duty, then vanishes back into the murmur of the common

room.

At your elbow, the tub of rice waits. Ollie’s mother nods once toward it, eyes on your

hands.

“Go on,” she says. “Show me you can listen with your fingers as well as your ears.”

I allow myself to swept along quickly into the workflow, realising I must be pushing things on time, since I didnt even have a chance to ask Ollie's mother her name. I do my best to observe her directions, but hesitate before leaping into the task, indicating the herbed salt Mellie had

given me. "I was told to try using this salt when cooking with you tonight, ma'am. Is that alright?"

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lanternlight, steam and woodsmoke

Ollie’s mother’s eyes flick to the little parcel like a hawk spotting a mouse. Not alarm—

interest. Then her gaze snaps back to your face.

“Mellie,” she says, with the kind of tone that tells you she could mean a person or a

weather event.

She holds out her hand—palm up, steady. Not grabbing, not demanding. Just: let me see

it.

When you offer it, she doesn’t open it like a thief; she opens it like a cook. A careful pinch

between thumb and forefinger, a tiny rub, then she brings it close enough to smell without

actually burying her nose in it.

A brief pause. Her mouth twitches.

“That old fox,” she mutters, and there’s affection buried under the grumble.

Then, finally, she answers your question.

“It’s fine,” she says. “But not for everything. Use my salt first so you learn what ‘normal’

tastes like. Then we’ll do one with Mellie’s mix and you’ll feel the difference.”

She reties the parcel neatly—better than it was tied before—and sets it just out of splash

range, beside the seaweed.

“And stop calling me ‘ma’am’ like I’m a traveling magistrate,” she adds, brisk and practical.

“I’m Sana. Ollie’s mother. If you burn the rice, you’ll be ‘that tall fool’ for the rest of the

week.”

She nods toward the water bowl again.

“Hands wet. Light salt. Scoop. Mushroom. Shape.” Her eyes drop to your fingers. “Now.

Your turn.”

I bob my head submissively to the direction and do as Sana asks. My initial attempt looks lumpy with oddly pointy tips, mushroom peeking out in a way it ought not, and I frown at my work. Setting it aside with some trepidation, lest Sana jump on me to fix it too quickly, I take a different tack with the next one. Adopting the samw mindset as I had with the carpentry, I try to adapt sinilar experiences I do have to the new tasks at hand. Ultimately I decide that this isn't very different from crafting pierogi with my grandma. Both required you to prep your workstation and hands to avoid things sticking where they should, both involved discernment when adding a filling, both required you to keep an eye out to avoid messing up one step of the process while you were trying to focus on another, and both required a little finesse to shape your product properly. These were all thing I at least had some experience doing, even if I was no expert.

My second rice ball, while no means as pleasant as Sana's, is at least something I can feel good about in its effort and not shrink from.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

Sana watches your first attempt with the same expression Tasho wears when someone cuts

a hair off-square: not angry, not impressed, just collecting data.

She doesn’t pounce. That alone is a kind of mercy.

“Mushroom’s trying to escape,” she remarks dryly, as if you’ve made a social faux pas at a

dinner party. “Don’t give it a doorway.”

When you set it aside and start again, her eyes stay on your hands—your palms, your

pressure, the way you turn the rice. The kitchen noise fades into a background hum: faint

clink of bowls, the soft shhh of rice shifting in the tub, the kettle’s low breath.

Your second onigiri earns a small, almost invisible nod.

“Better,” Sana says. “You stopped fighting it.”

She reaches over without taking it from you and taps one corner lightly with a fingertip.

“Still too sharp. You’re making a weapon. Round it. The triangle is a suggestion, not a

knife.”

Then, as if you’ve unlocked the correct puzzle box in her head, she adds:

“Most people crush the rice because they’re scared it won’t hold. Don’t be scared. Be

consistent.”

She gestures toward your first lumpy one.

“That one,” she says, “we’ll eat anyway. Ugly food teaches humility.”

Ollie slips in again, grabs a tray of bowls, and pauses long enough to peek at the “weapon”

onigiri.

“…That one’s yours,” he says to no one in particular, then vanishes before Sana can throw a

spoon at him.

Sana slides the mushroom bowl closer and nudges the salt dish toward you.

“Again,” she says. “Same steps. Same touch. This time, when you tuck the mushroom in,

pretend you’re hiding it from a gossip auntie. Secure, quiet, no bulges.”

Your hands hover over the rice tub, steam warming your knuckles. Sana stands just close

enough that you can feel her attention like heat off a stove, waiting to see if the third one

becomes dinner… or another lesson.

I try to think of a witty retort to Ollie's teasing, but I fail to do so before he's gone again.

Under Sana's eye I make a third attempt, tapping, patting and pinching the little blob likw it was a baby with a seaweed diaper.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

Sana makes a sound that is almost a laugh when you start “tapping and patting” like

you’re burping an infant.

“You’re not wrong,” she says, and there’s the faintest curl at one corner of her mouth. “But

if you bounce it too much, it’ll start crying.”

She points with two fingers—precise, like she’s aligning a join.

“Less pinching. More pressing. Flat of the fingers. Gentle turns. You want the rice to

remember the shape, not fear you.”

Your third one comes together slower, but steadier. The mushroom stays put this time—no

little brown edge peeking out to betray you. The corners aren’t Sana-sharp, but they aren’t

jagged, either. It looks… like food. Proudly, undeniably edible.

Sana nods once, satisfied.

“There,” she says. “That one can sit on a plate without embarrassing the house.”

She reaches for the little parcel Mellie sent, loosens it, and pinches a tiny amount of the

herbed salt into her palm. She rubs her hands together, then—before you can overthink it

—she gestures you closer.

“Make one more,” she says. “Same as that last one. Then we’ll do the ‘real’ mix.”

The tub of rice steams between you. Sana’s hands hover near the water bowl, ready to

correct you only if you wander off-course. In the common room beyond the kitchen door,

voices swell and fall—someone arriving, someone laughing, a chair scraping.

Sana’s gaze stays on your hands.

“Go on,” she says. “Fourth one. Show me it wasn’t luck.”

I twitch my nose in silent defiance of failure and go at the process a fourth time, as instructed. "No such thing as luck," I say to nobody in particular.

The promotion to Mellie's salt blend fills me with a degree of confidence, since I figure Sana would not have moved me on if I wasn't doing something right, and I push myself to make one as perfect as I can. Sana reminds me of Tasho in that she isn't necessarily pressuring me to be speedy so much as precise, and I try to push the pressure on myself not to waster her time away from my mind.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

Sana’s eyes flick up at your “no such thing as luck,” and she gives you a look that says: fine,

philosopher—prove it with your hands.

You wet your fingers, shake off the excess, and the fourth onigiri starts the same way the

third did—quiet, deliberate. Scoop. Nest. Hide the mushroom like it’s contraband. Press

with the flats, turn with patience.

It comes out cleaner. Not perfect—Sana’s hands have decades baked into them—but the

edges are even, the surface isn’t bruised, and nothing threatens to escape.

Sana nods once. That’s her version of applause.

“Good,” she says. “Now the fancy salt.”

She pinches a whisper of Mellie’s blend into her palm, rubs it between her hands until it’s a

film, and then—very deliberately—she doesn’t hand it to you. She holds her palm out,

waiting for you to mirror her, to copy the amount. A teacher’s trick: you learn the scale by

seeing it.

The herbed salt is fragrant up close—shiso-green brightness, toasted nuttiness, the faint

smoke again.

“Too much and it tastes like you fell into a spice sack,” Sana says. “Too little and it’s a

rumor.”

She gestures at the rice tub with her chin.

“Make one,” she says. “Same way. This time, don’t chase perfection. Chase consistency.

Perfection is for people who don’t cook when they’re tired.”

The kitchen feels smaller in a good way—steam on your forearms, warm lanternlight on

the wood, Sana’s focus like a steady weight. In the common room, someone calls Ollie’s

name; he answers, distant and harried.

Sana stays with you, eyes on your hands, waiting for the next onigiri to take shape under

Mellie’s salt.

*Do better, but don't chase perfection, right,* I think to myself. The direction feels like mixed signals to me, but I don't let on and do my best to follow the direction.

Wet hands, pinch of Mellie's blend, rub it in, scoop of rice, pack it, mould it.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

The “mixed signals” resolve the moment your hands start moving.

Mellie’s blend—just that thin film on your palms—behaves differently than plain salt. It

grips the outer grains ever so slightly, like it wants to stay with the rice instead of vanishing

into it. The scent rises as you work: shiso-bright and toasted, the faintest smoky edge.

Sana watches without correcting you, which is its own kind of pressure.

When you tuck the mushroom in and fold the rice over it, you catch yourself about to

squeeze harder—about to chase “perfect”—and you ease off instead. Press, turn, press,

turn. Let the shape settle into itself.

The onigiri that comes out of your hands is… solid. Neat enough. Corners present but not

sharp. No mushroom betrayal. The surface has a faint, speckled sheen from the herbed

salt.

Sana leans in, takes it between finger and thumb for half a heartbeat—testing firmness the

way a carpenter tests a joint—then sets it back down.

“There,” she says. “That one tastes like someone lives in Kakariko.”

She reaches for a strip of seaweed and wraps it around the base of the triangle with quick

surety, like tying off a bundle.

“Seaweed’s the handle,” she adds, practical as ever. “Keeps your fingers clean. Also makes

people think you know what you’re doing.”

From the doorway, Ollie reappears, eyebrows lifting at the sight of a properly wrapped

one.

“…Oh,” he says, impressed despite himself. “You’re learning.”

Sana doesn’t look up. “Of course he’s learning,” she says. “He’s tall. If he didn’t learn, he’d

have to fall over to reach the idea.”

She nudges the plate slightly toward you—your finished ones, including the ugly first

“weapon,” now wrapped and lined up like a little edible report card.

“Eat one,” Sana says. “Not the best one. Eat the honest one. Then tell me what you notice.”

I laugh just a little at Sana's wry comment. "Oh gosh, I must be accepted now, the tall jokes are starting."

I take my ugly first attempt and inhale shirt and short, like

I'm bracing myself—for good or bad I don't know—and take a bit to see what it is like.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

Sana’s eyes narrow with satisfaction at your choice.

“Good,” she says. “Ugly first. That’s character.”

You bite in.

The outer rice is warm and plain, faintly salted—simple comfort. Then the mushrooms hit:

earthy, a little chewy, their flavor deeper than you expect from something you picked out

of a forest an hour ago. The seaweed—if your ugly one has any—adds that briny snap and

a whisper of smoke.

But the ugly one has problems you can taste as clearly as you can see: the rice is a little

too tight in spots, almost past “firm” into “pressed,” and the filling isn’t centered, so one

bite is mostly rice and the next is mushroom-heavy.

Sana watches your face like she’s reading a gauge.

“Too tight,” she says, before you even have to speak it aloud. “And your mushroom’s off to

one side. Your tongue knows what your hands did.”

She reaches over, taps your third and fourth ones on the plate. “Those are closer. Even

bites. Even pressure. That’s what I mean by consistency.”

Ollie hovers in the doorway again, arms full of bowls, and can’t help himself.

“If you survive Mother’s kitchen, you can survive anything,” he mutters, then ducks out like

a man escaping a weather system.

Sana ignores him with professional ease and nods toward the better-wrapped onigiri—the

one with Mellie’s herbed salt.

“Now,” she says, “take a bite of that one. Not the whole thing. One bite. Tell me what

changes.”

The taste is, obviously, inconsistent, but I already get a hint of the experience I've always wondered about, and it doesn't disappoint me. The rice, the salt, yesterday's mushrooms—I enjoy it. I don't enjoy the seaweed. I've never liked seaweed and I'd be surprised if I ever did, but I eat it respectfully nonetheless, and refuse to allow my face to betray the fact.

If that was the ugly, my mouth waters at the idea of trying the next one as Sana directs. It could only be better.

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

Sana clocks the tiny micro-movements in your face the way carpenters clock a board that’s

almost square. She doesn’t call you out—doesn’t even look at the seaweed directly—just

files it away.

“You don’t have to love the wrap,” she says, matter-of-fact. “It’s a tool. Some people eat

the tool. Some don’t.”

She reaches over and peels a strip of seaweed off one of the better ones with two quick

motions, then sets the onigiri back down bare on the plate.

“There. No excuses now.”

Her finger taps the herbed-salt one you made—your “Mellie mix” attempt.

“One bite,” she repeats. “Then tell me what you notice about salt when it’s not just salt.”

The kitchen’s warmth sits on your skin like a blanket. Somewhere in the common room a

chair scrapes and a voice rises in a half-laugh. Sana’s attention stays where it’s always

been: on the simple alchemy of hands, rice, and how honest you’re willing to be about

what you taste.

I take my bite while mentally berating my face for betraying me so, and I feel my ears warm just the smallest bit. The Mellie Salt onigiri is simply delectable, especially without the seaweed. Earthy, botanical, not overly salty but enough to be comforting and jazz up the white rice. I eat the bite slowly, thinking about it so I can answer Sana with intelligently. "Salt-when-it's-not-just-salt...is..." I think of how to parse my thoughts, and decide to lock on to Sheikah penchant for proverbs, metaphors and similes. "...is like a beam in a house. But's not a flashy finish and people might not think about it, but without it the house falls down, and it never needs the extra attention anyways. It just needs to be *right* the *first time*."

Shuteye Inn – kitchen

Day 5, evening • Late spring

Sana holds your gaze for a beat, like she’s deciding whether that metaphor deserves to

live.

Then she gives a single, decisive nod.

“Mm,” she says. “That’ll do.”

Not praise exactly—more like you just set a joint properly and she can stop worrying

about it.

She slides the little parcel of Mellie’s blend a hair closer to you on the counter, not giving

it away, just… acknowledging it belongs in your orbit now.

“Salt is structure,” she agrees. “And seasoning is memory. People forget the rice. They

remember how it made them feel.”

She reaches for one of the plain ones—your fourth—breaks a corner off with her fingers,

and tastes it, as if verifying the lesson from the inside.

“Your hands were calmer on the Mellie one,” she says. “You stopped trying to force it into

being perfect. You let the steps do their work.”

A kettle ticks softly as it settles. Sana sets the bitten corner down, then wipes her fingers

on a cloth with a neat snap.

“Two things,” she says, and now she’s in “teacher mode,” blunt and practical:

“First: if you hate seaweed, don’t waste it. Wrap only for travelers who want the handle. For

yourself, carry a cloth. Same job, less chewing on the ocean.”

“Second: tomorrow is market day. If you’re buying a belt, get one wide enough to carry

weight without cutting you. If you’re staying in Kakariko a while, you’ll end up hanging half

your life from it.”

She glances toward the doorway where the common room noise swells again.

“And before you go making friends with every pretty craftswoman in the village,” she adds,

dry as dust, “learn to feed yourself. Hungry men make dumb choices.”

She doesn’t say Rinna’s name. She doesn’t need to.

Sana nudges the plate toward you again—your better onigiri lined up, one now

unwrapped and shining with the herbed salt.

“You’ve earned dinner,” she says. “Eat. Then get out of my kitchen before Ollie decides

you’re his new help.”

I smile broadly and satisfied as Sana wraps up my lesson, and already begin thinking about how at least one of these is going to be lunch tomorrow, but then my smile drops at her allusion to Rinna. I'm not sure if my face flushes completely red or drains completely white, but

either way I didn't have a chance of controlling it this time.

"Oh, I didn't—I mean I don't intend—It's not..." Although I had realised the power weilded by the 'gossip aunties' in terms of information, I hadn't fully grasped it, and had been thinking about asking Ollie, Paya or Rinna why everyone in Kakariko was so seemingly obsessed with them. But now the realisation hit me like a brick to the face. If Sana was saying that to me then the aunties knew, and if they knew, everybody knew. I was instantly sure Impa intended for me to feel this feeling of dread at information being weilded against me. For now, I was starting to ramble, and decided I needed to clamp my mouth shut before it did any more damage. I bowed my head and started collecting my two and a half remaining rice balls. "Yes ma—Yes Ms Sana," I say and rush out of the kitchen and up to my room.

Shuteye Inn – hallway and room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lanternlight, quiet boards underfoot

Sana doesn’t follow you. She doesn’t need to. Her voice floats after you like the last scrape

of a knife on a cutting board—final, not unkind.

“Eat. Sleep. Don’t invent tragedies.”

Upstairs, the inn’s hallway feels suddenly narrower, like it knows what your face did.

Your room is mercifully still: the futon neat, the chest waiting, the lantern’s warm pool of

light. Outside the papered window, Kakariko murmurs—water over stone, a distant door

closing, someone laughing far away like the village is an organism and you’re a new itch

on its skin.

You set the onigiri down—three neat triangles and the ugly “weapon,” now looking less

like a failure and more like proof you started somewhere. The herbed-salt one smells

bright and earthy even in the quiet.

A faint thump of footsteps passes in the hall. A soft voice—two women, maybe—drifts by,

too low to make out, but you feel the shape of it: talk that isn’t meant for you but is about

you.

The room holds its breath with you.

Your beltless waist is a blunt reminder of how much of your life right now is improvised: no

scabbard, no pack, no spare clothes, no privacy from a village that treats gossip like

weather.

And yet: you have a room. You have food you made with your own hands. You have

tomorrow’s market day waiting like a clean page.

The lantern flickers once, steadying.

What do you do with the rest of the evening—eat and try to sleep, write more notes, or go

back downstairs and face the common room noise on purpose?

I place the results of my kitchen education on the small stand near the lantern that lights the room, taking stock. I had finished the Ugly Ball, and the nicest, Mellie-salt blend-infused one was half-eaten between the taste- testing Sana and myself had performed. I wraped them gently in the cloth that had been leftover from Mellie's salt, and decided to save them for later. I could probably make at least two lunches with them if I wasn't a glutton.

As for the rest of the night...I wasn't starving but I wasn't entirely full either, and my experiments with salt levels had me desiring a drink. I could go back downstairs and have some of whatever the other pateons were having, maybe also some tea, per my developing habit. It was already paid for afterall, and I couldn't be letting rupees go to waste.

Sana's blunt reminder that I was still being judged by the community weighed heavy on my mind, making me hesitate. But I recalled what Dorian had said a couple days

ago when I'd gone to check in with Impa. He said that showing my face and not needing to be reminded to come back was not the sign of a coward. If it wasn't the sign of a coward, then Dorian must have meant it was an action worth approval. The logical conclusion being that facing a problem and not hiding from it was something Kakariko, as a community, wanted to see in a person.

*Besides,* I think to myself. *Believing that everybody is only talking about you is a horribly selfish thought. This village does not revolve around you.*

So I get up, and just in case I decide to change up my plans for the night, I get a handful of rupees from my small but growing stash. Satisfied, I take myself downstairs to Ollie's counter. If people talk about me, then they would do it whether I'm in the room or not. And if they don't talk about me...well then I have nothing to worry about.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamplight, stew-and-woodsmoke air

Downstairs is warmer in every sense: lamps throwing honey-colored pools across the

floorboards, the low roar of small conversations, bowls clinking, someone laughing with

their whole chest.

Ollie’s at the counter doing his usual frantic ballet—stacking cups, taking coins, answering

a question from a traveler with a pack that looks like it’s been to three different climates

and disliked all of them.

A few heads turn when you enter. Not staring, not hostile—more that quick village reflex

of taking the measure of a new moving thing. Then most eyes slide away again. The room

goes back to being itself.

Near one wall, two older women sit with their knees tucked in, cups steaming in their

hands. Their hair is streaked gray, their clothes neat in that practical Kakariko way, and

they talk with the confidence of people who’ve never once asked permission to have an

opinion. When you come into view, one of them pauses midsentence—just long enough

to glance at you—then continues as if you’re a passing breeze.

Ollie spots you and lifts his chin in greeting, relief flickering across his face like you’re a

familiar problem he knows how to solve.

“You look… less like a roof tried to eat you,” he says, voice pitched low enough to be

friendly, not broadcast. “Tea? Or something stronger? We’ve got rice beer tonight—mild.

Also hot barley again, if you’re staying loyal.”

The traveler at the counter finishes and steps aside, making space. Ollie’s hands hover over

cups, waiting for your choice.

Behind you, the aunties’ conversation swells for a moment, and you catch a fragment—

more tone than words: amused, approving, and sharp around the edges like a blade that’s

been used a long time and kept that way.

You’re here. You didn’t hide. The inn didn’t swallow you.

What do you ask Ollie for?

I smile politely at Ollie. It is not an insincere smile, but I know it lacks the full effect of a real one. "Everybody seems genuinely concerned about that roof getting the best of me. Guess I must be doing well if it hasn't. I'd like a light portion of whatever you have going tonight. Just need to top off my kitchen efforts with your mother; not trying to be a glutton. And I would be thrilled to try a rice beer. I don't think I've ever tried one."

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamplight, rainless air, river-hush outside

Ollie’s shoulders drop a fraction—like your order is something he can do in his sleep,

which is… probably true.

“Light portion, rice beer,” he repeats, already reaching under the counter. “And

congratulations: you are about to drink something that tastes like a polite argument

between grain and water.”

He sets a small bowl for you—less than last night, still hearty—and a cup with pale, cloudy

rice beer that catches the lamplight. It smells faintly sweet and yeasty, like warm bread

decided to become mischievous.

“You’ll want to sip,” Ollie adds, not lecturing—just… practical. “It’s gentle, but it sneaks up

if you treat it like tea.”

As you take your place, you feel the room’s little currents. People glance and then return

to their meals. No dramatic hush. No tribunal.

The two older women—the aunties, unmistakably—continue their conversation at a steady

pace. One of them finally angles her body a touch more toward you without turning fully,

as if making sure you can hear the existence of their talk but not the details. They are

performing community, not espionage.

A young traveler at the next table nudges his companion and murmurs something with a

grin, and the companion shushes him with an elbow—more playful than scolding.

Your bowl steams. The rice beer’s surface trembles slightly when you set it down.

You’ve earned the right to exist in this room without flinching.

Do you take the first sip of the rice beer, or do you eat a bite first?

I try the rice beer immediately.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamplight

The first sip is… gentler than your brain expected.

It’s lightly sweet up front, like watered-down rice pudding without the dairy, then a soft

fizz of fermentation—more alive than carbonated. The finish has a faint tang, a whisper of

bread-yeast and something almost floral that might just be your mind filling in gaps

because you want it to be magical.

It warms your throat on the way down in a slow, friendly way. Not a burn. More like the

memory of a hearth.

Ollie watches from behind the counter with the expression of a man waiting to see if you

spit it out. When you don’t, he relaxes and goes back to his cups.

One of the aunties laughs—quiet, satisfied—at something you can’t quite hear. The sound

lands like a coin in a bowl: small, clear, meaningful even without context.

Your stew waits. Steam curls up. The common room hum wraps around you.

On your next breath you notice something else: the smell of cedar still clinging to you

under the inn’s warmth, now mixed with clean skin from the bath. It’s the first time since

Gatepost that you’ve smelled like your day instead of just the road.

What do you do next—another sip, or dig into the food?

I'm not sure what I expected from the rice beer. It is good, but surprising. I thought I might be comparing it to a Japanese barley malt beer I had tried a few times and liked (called Ichiban), but the rice beer bears little resemblance to it. It is good in its own, unique way.

I understand Ollie's warning about not drinking it too quickly also. Its gentle flavour could be deceptive, making it easy to imbibe too much too quickly. And so I enjoy sips of it between spoonfuls of stew, until both are finished. I wait politely once I have as Ollie bundles around from task to task, until it seems like he's ready to slow down a bit.

"Hey," I ask as he comwa back to get my bowl and cup. "People seem to think that working on a roof for Tasho is a tough job, but I don't think I've seen you rest since I got here. How do you keep that up?"

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamplight, low chatter

Ollie takes your bowl and cup like he’s done it a thousand times—which, honestly, he has.

He stacks them, wipes a spot that was already clean, then realizes you’re not asking for

anything urgent.

That alone makes him pause.

He glances around the room—quick inventory of who needs what, who’s about to need

what—and only then leans his forearms on the counter like a man pretending he knows

how to stop moving.

“I don’t,” he says, and the honesty lands with a little thud. “Not really.”

Then, with a half-smile that’s more tired than jokey:

“People say roofs are tough because if you mess up, you fall. In here, if I mess up, everyone

remembers.” He flicks his eyes toward the aunties without pointing. “That’s a different kind

of falling.”

A kettle ticks somewhere. Someone laughs. The room keeps being warm.

Ollie rubs the back of his neck, then gives you the practical version:

“I do it because Sana does not slow down. And because travelers don’t care if your day

was hard—they care if they can sleep, eat, and not get cheated.” He shrugs. “And

because… it’s ours. If the inn runs well, Kakariko runs a little better.”

He studies you for a moment, then adds, quieter:

“You’re doing that thing where you act like you’re asking about me, but you’re actually

asking how people here live at this pace. You’re not wrong to ask. Just… don’t let it chew

you up.”

Behind him, Sana’s voice cuts in from the kitchen doorway—dry, blunt, perfectly aimed.

“He’s young. That’s how,” she says, and vanishes again like a ghost that smells faintly of

rice.

Ollie exhales, a little embarrassed, a little amused.

“If you want the real answer,” he says, “it’s habits. Routine. And the village watching. Most

people don’t fall apart when they’re being seen.”

His eyes dart to your hands—gloves, calluses healing, the posture of someone learning

where he fits.

“You’re adjusting faster than you think,” he adds. “Market day tomorrow will help. People

get distracted by bargains. Less time to talk about you.”

He straightens, already half pulled back into motion by the room’s needs.

“You staying in tonight, or going for a walk before bed?”

I bristle only a tiny bit as Sana enters the conversetion, but force myself to relax and instead raise my brow thoughtfully at the suggestion. "A walk does sound nice, regardless of aching feet." I look at the gathering of inn patrons that's starting to thin slightly.

"But I think I'll just stay here. I honestly was just curious about you hold up," I say to Ollie. "I can be curious about more than one thing at once."

If neither Ollie nor Sana seem to object, I decide to simply sit at the counter as the crowd continues to dwindle.

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamplight thinning into quiet

Ollie’s mouth twitches like he’s trying not to grin.

“Fair,” he says, and it comes out warmer than the word deserves. “Curious is… kind of your

thing.”

He doesn’t object to you staying at the counter. If anything, your presence seems to

register as useful—not in a labor way, but in a “someone is here who isn’t demanding

anything” way. For an innkeeper, that’s basically a vacation.

The crowd thins in layers. A pair of villagers stand, bow to Sana’s motherly glare from the

kitchen, and drift out into the night. A traveler pays in small, careful rupees and leaves with

a soft clink of gear. The aunties linger the longest—of course they do—then finally rise in

unison, cups empty, and sweep past the counter with the authority of weather systems.

One of them—short, broad-shouldered, hair pinned up with a carved wooden comb—

gives you a look that is neither friendly nor unfriendly. It’s evaluative, like you’re a board

they might buy. Then she nods once, tiny as a coin drop, and they’re gone.

Ollie watches them go, then looks back at you and exhales.

“They liked your onigiri attempt,” he says, as if reporting the barometric pressure. “Not the

shape. The trying.”

From the kitchen doorway, Sana’s voice comes again, quieter this time, not aimed like a

dart—more like a note placed on a table:

“And they liked that you didn’t sulk about the seaweed.”

You can’t see her face, but you can hear the almost-smile in it before she disappears again.

The inn settles into late-night mode: fewer voices, more creaks of wood, the soft hiss of a

kettle being topped off for whoever’s still awake.

Ollie rests his hands on the counter, finally still.

“So,” he says, low and casual, “tomorrow’s market. You going early for that belt, or are you

letting the aunties choose your fate by rumor and coincidence?”

I warm at Ollie's comment that 'curious is my thing'. If I was to be known as anything, then I could do a lot worse than the 'guy who likes to know things'. To me it feels like a reminder that I am still myself, since that's basically how I was known before coming to Hyrule anyways. Harlin had seemed to recognise that too. I also take solace in the approval of my onigiri attempt, which had been something I'd purely wanted to do for myself anyways. Finally something that felt like a win-win.

"Oh I'll definitely be going early for the belt," I respond to Ollie's question. I rub the tip of my ear thoughtfully. I carch myself doing it again, but this time I don't bother stopping myself, giving in to the quirk and not caring what it might say about me. "You know, where I came from, we don't really have this concept of 'gossip aunties'...but I think every community does have them, whether the community realises it or not. Kakariko has a one-up on most of the world in that regard I think. And, actually, now that I look back on it, I think my grandma may have been one of them, even if none of us knew it."

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamplight, last bowls cleared

Ollie’s eyes brighten at that—like you’ve handed him a familiar shape he knows where to

put.

“Everyone’s got them,” he agrees, scrubbing a cup that’s already clean because his hands

don’t know what to do with peace. “Some places pretend they don’t. That just means the

gossip has better camouflage.”

He follows your ear-rub with a quick glance—notes it, doesn’t comment. His voice stays

easy.

“Kakariko’s aunties aren’t… malicious, most days. They’re like… village memory with

opinions. If you’re kind, and you pull your weight, they’ll make you real here faster than

any ceremony.”

From the kitchen, Sana makes a small sound—half snort, half laugh.

“They also bite,” she adds, like she’s reminding Ollie not to romanticize them. “But only

when something deserves biting.”

A moment later, she steps out just far enough to set a little wrapped bundle on the

counter—paper and cloth tied tight, the size of a fist. It smells faintly of toasted grain and

something herbal.

“Take this,” she says, not asking. “For tomorrow. You’ll be early, you’ll be hungry, and I do

not need you fainting dramatically near my doorway.”

Ollie opens his mouth to tease you about dramatic fainting, thinks better of it, and just

nods like this is normal.

Sana’s eyes flick to your hands—calluses, healing blisters, gloves tucked nearby—and then

to your face.

“And,” she says, voice flatter, “market day has pickpockets sometimes. Not often. But

sometimes. Keep your rupees close. You still don’t have a belt, which means you still look

like a man carrying money in his pockets like the world is gentle.”

She vanishes back into the kitchen again, leaving the bundle and the advice behind like a

thrown knife that lands handle-first.

Ollie taps the bundle lightly toward you.

“She likes you,” he says, as if this is an objective fact like the weather. “That was her being

nice.”

The inn is quiet enough now that you can hear the creek outside, and somewhere up the

hill a night insect starts its steady, metallic song.

Do you take Sana’s bundle and head up to bed, or do you linger a little longer—maybe

ask Ollie what to look for in a good belt from the leatherworker tomorrow?

I take the little bundle with a surprised expression. "O-oh, thank you Ms Sana." I take a quick peek as she warns me about pickpockets. "I appreciate the warning," I say genuinely. It had never occurred to me that a pickpocket might dare lurk around Kakariko with its aunties' eyes and Dorian and Cado around.

As she leaves, I return my attention to Ollie, but dawdling about resuming conversation until I'm certain Sana is out of earshot. Even then I keep my tone a bit quieter than before. "She got me pretty good earlier," I admit to him. "I didn't handle it well either. There's an expression where I come from, maybe you have it here, maybe you don't: I have egg all over my face." I pick at something nonexistent on the counter as Ollie listens. "So I guess I'm an easy book to read then, huh?"

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Nearly empty, kettle-sighs

Ollie watches you lower your voice like he understands the instinct. His own drops with it.

“She did,” he says, and there’s no judgment in it—just recognition. “Sana doesn’t poke.

She… taps the nail with a hammer and calls it ‘guidance.’”

He sets another cup aside and finally leans in a little, elbows on the counter again. The

bundle in your hands gives off a warm, comforting smell—grain, herbs, maybe a little

pickled sharpness hiding in there.

At your “egg on my face,” he blinks once, then a small grin breaks through.

“We don’t say that,” he admits. “But I get it.”

Then he tilts his head, considering your last line.

“Easy book?” he repeats. “Mm. Not easy. Just… honest.” He rolls the word around like he’s

checking it for splinters. “Honest people show seams. That’s all.”

He glances toward the kitchen doorway, like Sana might reappear just to critique the

conversation. When she doesn’t, he continues.

“You came in here new, working hard, asking questions, looking like you’re trying not to

step on toes you can’t see. Then you meet Sana—who can smell embarrassment like

smoke—and you reacted like a person who’s used to… keeping things private.”

His eyes flick to your ear-rubbing again, but still he doesn’t call it out. Just notes it.

“So yes,” he says, softer, “you’re readable. But so is everyone. The aunties read people

because it’s how they keep the village from rotting in secrets. Sana reads people because

she’s had to run a kitchen through bad years.”

He pauses, then adds with a small shrug:

“If you were unreadable, that would be worse.”

A little silence settles between you—comfortable enough to hear the inn’s wood cooling

and shifting.

Ollie nods toward the bundle in your hands.

“That’s her way of saying: ‘You embarrassed yourself, but you’re still welcome. Eat. Try

again tomorrow.’”

He straightens, the motion of work tugging him back into his role, but his tone stays

friendly.

“You heading up now? Market morning comes fast.”

I accept his comments thoughtfully, ruminating on them as they come. My time in Kakariko thus far had been brief, but already felt like a small rollercoaster. Ride wasn't over

yet, but that was okay. It is possible I needed the humbling.

I take his cue that maybe I shouldn't continue dawdling, and realise Ollie probably wants to sleep as well. An innkeeper always had to beat his guests to waking. "Thanks," I day as I get up with his mother's gift. "I know it's your job to be *friendly*, but it makes me feel better that you choose to be *a friend*. God knows I need one." I blink stupidly once and then correct myself. "Goddess." I look at Ollie hoping the slip means nothing to him. "You know what I mean. Have a good night."

Shuteye Inn – common room

Day 5, evening • Late spring • Lamps low, last warmth clinging

Ollie’s expression softens at the friend part—like you’ve handed him something fragile and

he’s deciding where to set it so it won’t break.

“Yeah,” he says quietly. “I know what you mean.”

At your “God—” then “Goddess,” he doesn’t flinch. If anything, he looks more amused

than alarmed, the way people look when they catch a traveler using a strange word for

something ordinary.

He lifts one shoulder in a tiny shrug. “People swear weirdly when they’re tired. Sana once

said ‘Hylia’s kneecaps’ when the rice burned.”

That earns the faintest hint of a grin.

“Good night,” he adds, more firmly, like a blessing he’s decided you’re allowed to have.

“Eat that bundle in the morning if you wake up hollow. And keep your rupees close

tomorrow.”

He reaches under the counter and sets a small folded scrap of paper beside you—thicker

than normal, with a crude charcoal mark on it: a simple symbol you recognize as the kind

of quick “shop note” people pass around.

“Leatherworker’s name is Vako,” he murmurs, tapping it once. “If you get there early, just

say you’re the tall carpenter from Tasho’s crew who needs a belt that won’t quit. He’ll

pretend not to care. He’ll care.”

He pulls his hand back, already turning to something that needs wiping.

Upstairs, the inn’s hallway waits—quiet, dim, safe.

I take the slip of paper with thanks and head up to my room. *Vako,* I think to myself, trying to sync the name with the man I'd seen earlier and who was currently somewhere else on the premises, probably asleep. I decide it is a fun name to say, and imagine an anthropomorphic moose named Bullwinkle in mind's eye: *Hey Vako, watch me pull a rabbit out of my hat!*

I chuckle at my own private joke as I enter my room, tucking Ollie's paper with Vako's mark on it with my own list of items I'd like to procure. Then I realise I'd forgotten somwthing earlier and dig around in my pocket until I find Paya's recipe for tooth cleaning powder, now rumpled from having been left in my pocket.

"Crap," I fret to myself as I try to smooth and flatten the paper on the edge of the lantern stand. It was still easily legible, but I decide I can never let Paya see it this way.

With that reminder, I pull out her little gift from the chest and unfold the clothy paper gently. The prize inside: Paya's powder that promised to make me feel a little cleaner, a little better. Realising I have neither cloth nor water, I grab a provided towel from the edge of the futon and sneak downstairs again, stealing outside to the water barrel and dampening the towel before heading back the way I came. Gratefully, since I let him ho, Ollie seems temporarily occupied elsewhere in the building and I don't have to

make any explanations, though I can still hear the telltale sounds of either him or Sana doing something in the background.

Back upstairs in my room I tenderly dip the edge of the cloth in Paya's mixture and then emulate what she demonstrated. The experience is...bizarre to my untrained mouth, and while the taste of the charcoal isn't gag- inducing—it was actually far less abrasive than I expected it to be—it isn't exactly good either. Fortunately the salt and shiso do their job and make the solution taste more like an odd food than a utility. After doing my best I glide my tongue around my teeth again and can tell the gritty salt had done its job: my teeth don't feel like they've been scrubbed with flourinated minty toothpaste, but they do feel cleaner. Mostly. There was still some grit and residue from the powder. I hadn't brought anything to rinse with. 'Rinse immediately,' Paya had said.

So back downstairs I go. I can't avoid passing by Ollie this time as he attends to whatever finishing up duties around the common space he has to do.

"Just forgot some water," I say briefly, excusing myself to the rear of the building again to rinse my mouth. Having done so, I feel my teeth again and click them together. It would take some getting used to, but it was infinitely better than having a dirty mouth and rotten teeth. I would have given them an inspection in the reflection of the water left in the tub, but it was too dark to really see much in the water now, even with the tinges of lantern light around. So I turn around and head back up to my room for hopefully the last time tonight, giving Ollie one last "good night" as I do.

Updated saved memory

Thought for 18s

Shuteye Inn — upstairs room, then hall and yard

Day 5, late evening • Late spring • Air cooling, lanterns low

Up in your room, the little rituals start stacking into something that almost resembles a

life: Vako’s marked slip tucked with your notes, Paya’s rumpled paper coaxed flat again

with careful fingers. The lantern light makes the fibers of the page look like tiny veins.

The tooth powder is… weirdly medieval in practice, but it works. Charcoal has that dry,

earthy bite—more campfire than medicine—and the salt-shiso edge keeps it from feeling

like you’re licking a hearth. Your mouth doesn’t feel mint-fresh, but it does feel less like

you’ve been living out of a pocket for a week. Good enough to be a small victory.

Downstairs, the inn is quieter now—chairs nudged back under tables, the smell of rice and

broth lingering in the wood. Ollie’s still moving like an exhausted metronome behind the

counter. He glances up as you pass, and if he notices anything odd about your mouth, he’s

kind enough to pretend he does not.

Outside, the water barrel’s staves are cool and damp under your hand. The night air carries

wet earth and cedar and the soft hush of Kakariko settling in. You rinse, spit, rinse again—

until the grit is gone and your tongue stops complaining.

When you come back in, Ollie gives you a tired little nod over his shoulder—no questions,

just that quiet “yeah, go on” that busy people give other busy people.

Back upstairs, your room feels warmer by comparison. The futon waits. Your tools-and-

treasures are exactly what you can carry: a few rupees, a marked slip that says Vako, and

the knowledge that market morning comes fast.

I hang the towel on the peg in the room that still has no cloak or pack to hang from it and lay down on the futon. My typical evening ruminations begin to surface as I unwind.

My thoughts mostly gravitate to the marketday tomorrow. I'm no master haggler, but I think I'm pretty good at

working my way around a deal. I've always perceived that there are essentially two types of business people in the world: those who are proud of their craft and need money, and those who are proud of how much money they can make and need their craft to make it. There are, of course, subcategories within those two and both good bad people in either, but regardless, there was one tactic I always felt worked pretty well on both. Be friendly, and let them believe that being friensly is your primary goal. The good people or those who value craft over cash will enjoy having a friend that they can speak intelligibly with, and reciprocate. The bad people or those who value money over craft will think just think you're a chump they can take advantage of, and when you throw them a hardball or walk away it can throw them off balance and make it harder for them to call your bluff. It isn't a foolproof method, and in fact I've been told before that it is a foolish method. But it's seen me through life well enough so far.

I make a mental note to bring my written list with me and to keep my eyes open to the entire market and not solely on Vako's wares. If there's anything else on my list that happens to be available and affordable—or hey, even something not on my list but that may strike me as useful —I want to notice it. The belt has priority, which is why I wanted to get there early, but after work there would surely still be some selling going on. It would be heavily picked over, and it's possible some items may disappear, but late day shopping for leftovers would carry the advantage of merchants not wanting to pack wares and carry them again when they might still be able to sell it for profit, even if slightly less profit.

Aside from the marketday, I also find myself thinking about what to do when I'm inevitably summoned to Impa again at the end of my "trial period". I think back over the past couple days. If my recollection is correct, I was about halfway through my mandated stay. Four days to go.

I'm not sure exactly what Impa will say, what she will ask,

or if I will pass her judgement and be allowed to come and go as I please from Kakariko. A lot could still happen in four days. But if she asks me what my intentions are if I leave Kakariko, what would I say?

Was I even in Hyrule for a reason? Did something or someone purpisefully bring me here? Did something or someone accidentally bring me here? Was there no agent at all and simply some glitch in reality? Maybe something entirely I couldn't even imagine? I don't know, and I don't even know how I'd find out. But there was one thing I was sure of: if I was in this world now, I wanted it to belong tocme as much as I belonged to it. My mere existance here had already caused people to think about things differently, so any future I believed could come about was already out the metapborical window. It'a possible not everybody would agree with that sentiment, but that just meant the sentiment stayed with me.

I may not have my own home, my own tools, or even my original species, but I still had my own mind. And that couldn't be taken away from me.

I allow that to be my final thought before trying—and succeeding—to get to sleep.

Shuteye Inn — your room

Day 5, late night • Late spring • Clear, cool air outside, lanternlight inside

Sleep comes clean and quick.

Kakariko Village — market pond

Day 6, early morning • Late spring • Pale sun, cool mist off the stream

The inn stirs before it sounds like it’s stirring. Floorboards whisper. A kettle ticks.

Somewhere outside, a rooster in someone’s yard tries to convince the entire valley that

dawn is his personal achievement.

By the time you’re down and out, the village is in that half-awake mode where everything

feels softer at the edges: blue smoke from cookfires, damp earth underfoot, and the faint

sweet bite of plum blossoms lingering around the orchards.

The market’s heart is the pond. You hear it before you see it—voices in low, practical

tones; the clink of pottery; the dry rasp of rope being tugged tight. A few stalls are already

up: woven baskets stacked like honeycomb, bundles of herbs tied with twine, a fishmonger

with a shallow tray of river catch that still smells like cold water.

And near the pond, a man is setting up leather like it’s a careful ritual, not a hustle.

Vako.

He’s lean and weathered, probably late 40s or 50s, with forearms like cured wood and

fingers stained darker at the nails—oil, dye, and time. His hair is pulled back with a strip of

leather, and his beard is trimmed short enough not to get in the way of work. The stall
