itself is simple: a low table, a rack, and a handful of hanging straps that sway slightly when

he moves. No flashy signs. No shouting.

He looks up as you approach—eyes quick, assessing, not unfriendly. His gaze slides once

over your hands, your posture, the way you carry yourself. Like he’s checking whether you

use things or just own them.

“Morning,” he says, voice rough but even. “You’re early. Either you want something

specific… or you’re trying to beat the aunties.”

A few steps away, two older women absolutely pretend they didn’t hear that, while

definitely hearing it.

On Vako’s rack: belts of different widths and thicknesses, some plain, some stamped with

simple Sheikah motifs, some clearly meant for tool weight—reinforced holes, heavier

buckles, extra stitching at stress points. One or two small pouches hang beside them, and

a narrow looped frog that looks like it would hold a short blade or tool handle.

He rests one hand on the table. “So. What are you after?”

When I wake in the morning I waste no time getting a move on, grabbing Sana's pre-prepared breakfast, and, after thinking about her warning about pickpockets, I take my entire little bag of rupees rather than stuffing my pockets with currency. I might look silly carrying a bag of money around, but as long as the bag is in *my* hand it can'tbe in someone else's.

I eat awkwardly as I walk to the market space, moneybag in the cradle of my arm, securely pressed against my body until I finish eating. The cloth that had been around the food gets tucked into my waistband and I return my moneybag securely to my two hands.

I smile broadly as Vako greets me. "Early bird gets the worm, so they say," I quip in response. "It is a good morning though." I gesture about myself, indicating a notable lack of something. "Go ahead and guess," I say in regards to him saying I might be after something specific. "I'm afraid I'm just a poor boy and probably can't do much to help your financial enterprise, but I have it on good authority," I recall Rinna's initial recommendation, "that you might have something...'pre-owned' but still tough you mught be willing to let go of a little more gently."

I straighten my back, partially because I needed to stretch my back, but also partially to make sure I'm standing at my full height.

Thought for 11s

Kakariko Village — market pond

Day 6, early morning • Late spring • Cool air, brightening sun

Vako’s eyes flick down to the little bag of rupees in your hands, then back up to your face

with a faint, knowing crease at one corner of his mouth—like he’s filing you under

“earnest, not stupid… probably.”

“Pre-owned,” he repeats, tasting the phrase like it’s a spice he doesn’t use often. “A

traveler word.”

He shifts his weight, boots soft on packed dirt, and hooks two fingers under a hanging

strap to still it. The leather creaks—old-saddle creak, well-oiled, not cracked.

“Good authority, huh?” His gaze flicks sideways, just barely, toward the direction of the

village proper—where gossip has a postal route and a delivery schedule. “Right.”

He steps closer to the rack and starts sorting with practiced speed. “I’ve got used and I’ve

got ruined. Folks confuse those.” He lifts three belts down and lays them on the table in a

neat row.

The first is plain and honest: wide, dark brown, softened by time. The holes are stretched a

little, but not torn. A work belt, the kind that’s been sweated into and lived in. The buckle

is simple iron, slightly dulled.

The second is narrower, lighter, better for keeping pants where they belong than carrying

anything heavy. It’s stamped with a subtle Sheikah chevron pattern—decorative, but not

flashy.

The third is the “serious” one: thick, reinforced, with double stitching and a buckle that

looks like it could survive being dropped off a cliff. There’s a repaired section—clean work

—where a slice once started to run and someone stopped it before it became a failure.

Vako taps each in turn with a knuckle.

“This one is comfortable and tough. Someone outgrew it. Not their waist—” his eyes flick

up to your height with a dry little huff, “—their life.”

“This one is for looking like you belong in a village. Doesn’t do much besides hold cloth.”

“This one will hold tools, a pouch, maybe a small sheath loop… and it won’t roll over on

you when you actually move.”

He leans an elbow on the table, and his eyes go to your hands again—blisters healing, the

way you’re holding that bag tight like it’s a newborn.

“Before we talk price, we talk fit,” he says. “Put your money away. Market’s full of eyes.

Some are just older women with opinions. Some are hands.”

He slides the plain work belt toward you first, like he’s making a point. “Try that. Tell me if

it sits right on you.”

I wrinkle my nose. "I'm afraid I'm entirely at your disposal about whether I *can* put my money away," I say. Before I take the first belt I stick out a hand to shake in greeting, more confident in its acceptance from the traveling Hylian merchant than from the Sheikah residents. "Name's Zeth, by the way. You're Vako, right? I saw you at the Inn yesterday. Ollie gave me your name."

Kakariko Village — market pond

Day 6, early morning • Late spring • Cool air, brightening sun

Vako looks at your offered hand like he’s weighing whether you’re about to sell him

something, swear an oath, or start a fistfight with tradition.

Then he takes it.

His grip is firm and quick—merchant handshake, not a village “nice to meet you, let’s be

friends” handshake. Calluses, too. Leatherworker hands, no question.

“Zeth,” he repeats, committing it to memory the way someone commits a price list. “Vako.

Yeah.”

At the mention of Ollie, his eyes flick up toward the inn for half a heartbeat, then back

down to the rupee bag you’re still clutching.

“Ollie’s got a mouth like a cooking pot,” he says mildly. “Always simmering.”

He angles his head, voice dropping a notch—not secretive, just practical. “About your

money: away doesn’t mean gone. It means not advertising. Right now you’re ringing a

dinner bell.”

He glances past you—subtle, casual—at the slow churn of the market: aunties prowling

like friendly sharks, kids darting, a couple travelers that don’t quite match the village’s

rhythm.

“You don’t have a belt yet,” he adds, nodding at the obvious problem. “So no pouch to

hang. But you’ve got cloth and you’ve got hands.”

He slides the plain, wide work belt closer, then lifts it and holds it out so you can take it.

The leather bends easily, the buckle clinks softly.

“Try it on. We’ll talk price after it sits on you. And while you do—” his gaze flicks to the

rupee bag again “—decide whether you’re keeping that in your hands, or tucking it where

someone would have to fight you to get it.”

He waits, belt offered, eyes steady—watching your face more than your hands, like he’s

gauging whether you’re the kind of person who freezes under pressure or gets sharper.

"Yes. Right." Still completely mystified as to what the merchant would actually have me do with the bag of money, I finally simply shove it in a pocket just as I did not want to do and make a mental note that I will not allow myself to be distracted from it. Then I take the offered belt and try it on, unwilling to concede any more control of the conversation.

The belt fits well, and, not being new, didn't seem to want any wearing. I give it some practice tugs here and there, try it a notch looser, a notch tighter. It is simple and serviceable. Not much else I can think of for it, and that's okay. I hand it back to Vako.

"We'll spare the trouble on the second belt. It's a nice piece but I don't need anything flashy. I need practical. Let's see number three there."

Thought for 14s

Kakariko Village — market pond

Day 6, early morning • Late spring • Cool air, brightening sun

Vako’s eyes flick—just once—to the pocket you stuff the rupee bag into. Not disapproval

exactly. More like watching someone set down a lit candle near dry straw.

He takes the first belt back without comment, gives it a quick flex between his hands, and

hooks it over his display rail again.

“Practical,” he echoes, and reaches for belt number three.

This one’s still plain, but it’s built—slightly thicker hide, edges burnished smooth so it

won’t chew your clothes to ribbons, and the buckle is iron-dark with a little pitting that

says “years of sweat and rain” rather than “cheap.” There’s an extra keeper loop, too—

someone cared enough to add it so the tail doesn’t flap.

He holds it out.

“This one won’t roll on you when you move,” he says. “And it’ll take a sheath loop when

you finally get one.”

As you test it, the market noise eddies around you: the papery rustle of cloth rolls, the soft

clink of pottery, a kid’s muffled giggle getting instantly shushed, and two aunties nearby

pretending they are definitely not listening while they absolutely listen.

Vako watches the belt on you, then taps two fingers lightly on the buckle.

“Twenty-four rupees,” he says. “And if you buy it, you hand me that money after you’ve

moved it somewhere smarter than a pocket. Because pockets are where quick hands go

fishing.”

I try on belt number three and, unsurprisingly, it is perfect for my needs. I let my hand thoughtfully feel the unshaved whiskers on my chin and lip regardless.

I take belt number three off again and let my hands peruse it some more, imagining it as part of my everyday gear. After a few seconds of doing so, I put it back around my waist and look Vako in the eyes. Not in a challenging way, but merely to make a confident business connection with the man. Contrary to my musing the previous night, Vako, while a pleasant enough person, was not here to be chummy. He wanted straight talk. He was like Harlin that way. I do have one thing strongly in my corner though: everybody in Kakariko already had a *used* belt. If they wanted a belt from Vako, they'd be buying new. This is a good belt, but if Vako didn't sell it to me, he'd be hardprwssed to find another buyer in Kakariko, and he would know that.

"So here's how it is," I say plainly, "I don't want to waste your time and I don't think you want your time wasted. You know this is the belt I both want and need, but I know I'm also probably the only one in this village that will go for it. I can offer you 20 rupees even. If that's not good enough, then I'll just have to walk away disappointed, but you'll have to find a buyer in a different valley."

I stick out my hand again, asking to make the deal real.

Kakariko Village — market pond

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

Vako doesn’t take your hand.

Not as an insult—more like it simply isn’t part of how he does this. His gaze stays on your

face for a beat, then drops to the belt, then—again—to the pocket with the rupee bag like

that pocket has personally offended him.

Up close, he’s lean and ropy, sun-browned and wind-dried, with a narrow face and a short,

uneven stubble that looks like it’s lost a few arguments with a razor. One ear has a small

notch in it, old healed damage. His hands are the real tell: scarred knuckles, nails cut short,

fingertips stained dark from leather oil and metal.

“Straight talk. Good,” he says, tone even. “But you’re wrong about one thing.”

He taps the belt—your belt—right where the strap meets the buckle.

“I can sell used to travelers. Always can. The village isn’t my only buyer.”

Then he finally looks you in the eye again—calm, not hostile, just merchant.

“Twenty doesn’t buy this. Twenty buys you one that twists and bites and you curse me a

week later.” He pauses, letting the market sounds fill the space: cloth flapping, a pot

clinking, the soft hush of water at the pond. Somewhere behind you, an auntie’s voice

murmurs something that sounds suspiciously like, “Tall one’s got spine today.”

Vako holds up two fingers.

“Twenty-two. Final.” A tiny nod toward your pocket. “And you don’t pay me until your

money is somewhere smarter than that. I’m not having some quick little rat-finger lift you

and then you glare at me like I did it.”

He keeps his hand on the belt a moment—just enough contact to remind you he can take

it back off your waist as easily as you put it on.

The belt sits right. Feels right. Smells faintly of oiled hide and sun.

Vako waits, expression unreadable, the market’s eyes prickling at your back.

I smile again, not willing to let Vako's merchant-trained stiffness get me down, and not embarrassed to admit it. "Twenty-two will do fine."

The belt has a squarish pocket on one side that reminds me of an antique leather ammo pocket. I'm not sure what it's original purpose was, but it is for now, my vault. I unwind a thread of tough sinew from around the button keeping the pouch closed, and after picking out 4 blue rupees and 2 green rupees, I place the bag with the rwsr of my funds in the belt pouch and secure it with the sinew thread.

The 22 rupees go to Vako's hand, which by my own custom I still want to shake, but I accept that I won't this day.

"You value your craft," I say. "It is good."

Kakariko Village — market pond

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

Vako takes the rupees without ceremony—just a clean, efficient scoop into his palm,

thumb counting by feel like the numbers live in his bones. The coins click once, then

vanish into a stitched inner pocket of his own satchel.

When you slide your moneybag into that squarish belt pouch and cinch it shut with the

sinew thread, you feel a tiny, immediate shift in your whole posture—like your center of

gravity just got less anxious. The belt sits right. The pouch lies flat against your hip. No

jingling temptation. No pocket-magnet for “rat-fingers.”

Vako watches the movement, and for the first time his mouth twitches—almost a smile,

but he refuses to give it the full oxygen.

“Good,” he says, and this time it isn’t about the sale. “Now you look like someone who

intends to keep living.”

At your last words—You value your craft. It is good.—his eyes flick briefly to your hands.

Work hands. Healing blisters. Fingerless gloves. He nods once, small and sharp, like a

carpenter checking plumb.

“Craft is what’s left when charm runs out,” he replies. Then, with the faintest tilt of his chin,

he adds, “But charm helps.”

Around you, the market is properly awake now: water murmuring at the pond edge, soft

sandals on packed earth, a few travelers’ voices mixed in with the village cadence. A

woman near a produce mat is arranging glossy cucumbers in obsessive lines. Someone’s

selling bundles of greens that smell like crushed mint and something darker—sage,

maybe. Farther down, you catch a flash of dyed cloth, and the faint metallic clink of a tool

roll being unfastened.

And then—because Kakariko is Kakariko—two aunties drift past behind you like they’re

just happening to be walking the exact same route at the exact same speed.

“…told you he’d get one that fits,” one murmurs, not quite whispering.

“…if he’s smart, he’ll buy a sheath next,” the other answers, like you’re a weather report.

Vako turns slightly, reclaiming his stall from the moment. He’s already reaching for the

next customer with a glance that says move along, tall man, the world spins.

You’ve got the belt. Your money is finally secured. The morning’s still young—but work

with Tasho will not wait forever, and the market won’t either. Your move.

I reach into my pocket and pull out my list, written in my now secret little code. I can't keep browsing the market, not really, since Tasho had made it clear he would prefer that I be present when he inspected the beam at Enchanted before we got to work proper back on the roof. But per my plan from my futon-thoughts last night, I make sure I review my list and keep an eye out for anything available in the market that I might try coming back for later in thr day after work. Naturally, I want to make a note of anything that might be useful, really, whether it is on the list or not, and I start making my way to Enchanted and Tasho with my eyes wide open to what's on offer.

Thought for 12s

Kakariko Village — market lane to Enchanted

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

Your list feels almost comically illegal in your hand—those clunky English strokes on

calligraphy paper, your own private little “I’m still me” artifact. You don’t have time to shop

properly, but you do have time to hunt with your eyes.

As you peel away from Vako’s pond-side stall and flow into the market lane, you clock the

whole place like a jobsite walk-through:

A vendor with a reed mat full of hats—those curved, rain-shedding Kakariko styles and a

few wide, flatter straw caps. The straw ones look like they’d actually fit your head without

perching there like a snack plate. A little sign-board shows prices in neat Sheikah script.

A traveling cloth seller with simple cloaks—undyed wool and a couple darker ones that

look sturdier, less “festival” and more “rain doesn’t get a vote.” The hems are reinforced

with tight stitching. Practical.

A wiry old man with a bundle of cordage and belts of woven hemp—not what you need

now that you’ve got leather, but you file it away anyway. Cord is cord, and cord is life.

A young merchant kneeling beside a wooden crate of secondhand odds: a dinged

cooking pot, a cracked lantern globe, two battered satchels with patched straps, and—

your eyes snag hard—what looks like a knife sheath and a couple short scabbards sized

for something like a traveler’s sword. The leather is dry but not dead.

Near the edge of the square, a woman with green-stained fingers (same one you’ve seen

around the inn breakfasts) is selling bundles of herbs—mint, sage, and something that

might be shiso if you squint and believe in yourself. The smell punches through the market

air like a clean thought.

You don’t stop. You bookmark with your brain: hat-mat, cloak-table, secondhand-crate,

herb-bundles. Come back later, when time isn’t breathing down your neck.

And—because Sana’s warning now lives rent-free in your skull—you notice a boy lingering

too close to your hip as you pass. Not doing anything obvious. Just… drifting. The moment

your hand settles near the belt pouch, he “remembers” somewhere else to be and slides

away into the crowd.

Enchanted is only a short walk downhill, but the mood shifts as you leave the chatter

behind. The shop’s front looks tidy and inviting… and then you catch the interior line of

that sagging beam again through the doorway, like a smile with a tired tooth.

Out front, Tasho is already there—compact and solid, hair tied back, beard shot with gray,

his tool roll laid open like a surgeon’s kit. Sef stands nearby with his usual quiet alertness,

lean and long-limbed, eyes following everything. Rinna’s not with them right this second.

Claree is just inside the threshold, posture polite but tight around the shoulders—trying

not to look worried and failing in a very responsible way. Lasli hovers a step back from her

sister, hands folded, watching Tasho with the same intensity she watched your work: like

she’s trying to learn by pure attention.

Tasho’s gaze lifts to you—no smile, but not unfriendly either.

He taps two knuckles against the beam post, listening to the wood like it might answer.

“All right,” he says, voice level. “Show me what you noticed.”

I notice Lasli's attentiveness but moreso Claree's tightly wound body language. "Relax," I tell her as I guide Tasho through the shop. "You already know it's not going to fall on you."

Arriving at the beam in question, I give it a few solid thunks with my fist to bring Tasho's attention to it. "There's a seam forming in the beam itself, but it's more 'character' than concern. The real issue..." I slide over to far end where the mortise meets the sorry tenon. "Is here. Not sure if the original work was a little sloppy or maybe it was perfect but age and elements got it. Either way, what is sloppy is somebody else's previous repair attempt."

I move slightly out of the way so that Tasho can start giving it his professional examination, but hunch down to step under the beam and stand on the other side. "I think I'm the only one in the village that it's a danger to," I explain, imagining clocking my head on it if I didn't watch out. "To everyone else it's probably just an annoyance, but Inpromised Claree and Lasli I'd see if there was something I could do about it. On my own time, of course."

Thought for 15s

Kakariko Village — Enchanted

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

Inside the shop the air is a familiar cocktail: cloth-dust, faint dye, cedar from the shelving,

and that clean, cool undertone of stone that never quite warms up. The “beam problem”

looks worse from indoors—less dramatic, more persistent, like a tired shoulder that keeps

slipping out of place.

Tasho doesn’t rush. He does that carpenter thing where his whole face turns into a level

and a measuring tape.

He steps in close to the joint you indicated, runs two fingers along the shoulder line, then

sets his thumb at the seam and pushes—testing for the smallest give. From his roll he

produces a thin sliver of wood (not quite a shim, more like a feeler gauge made by

someone who refuses to admit metal is superior). He slides it into the gap where the tenon

meets the mortise.

It goes in farther than it should.

A quiet, annoyed sound leaves his nose. Not a grunt—more like a “yep, there it is.”

He leans, sighting along the beam, then checks the post beneath with his palm: feeling for

twist, for the tell of a joint that’s been “fixed” by whoever owned a hammer and optimism.

And then he finds it: the old repair.

A little wedge of soft wood jammed in at a bad angle, crushed fibers around it like

bruising. Someone tried to stop movement by forcing it… and they forced it against the

wrong surface, so the joint deformed instead of tightening.

Tasho taps the bad shim with his chisel and it shifts with a sad little creak.

“Not going to fall today,” he says, voice flat and sure. He points with the chisel tip. “But it

will keep loosening. Every season change, every time the shop fills with damp air. That gap

will get ideas.”

He gestures you closer—not into danger, just close enough to see what he sees.

“The beam’s fine. The joint isn’t.” He presses the tenon shoulder again; it flexes the tiniest

amount. “This wants to be tight wood on tight wood. Instead it’s wood on air… and

someone’s old mistake.”

Then he lays out the fix like it’s the most ordinary thing in the world:

Prop the beam (a temporary post, snugged up) to take the load.

Pull the bad shim, clean the crushed area.

Pack the joint properly with a hard shim cut to match the grain direction, not

crosswise.

Wedge and peg—a hardwood wedge to lock it, and a wooden pin (a tight

dowel/peg) to stop future drift.

Not flashy. Just correct. The kind of repair that makes a house stop making that one

annoying sound in the night.

Claree’s shoulders ease about half an inch. Lasli’s eyes stay on Tasho’s hands like they’re

the lesson.

Tasho finally looks at you, expression unreadable but not unkind. He gives the beam one

last firm push—confirming his own confidence.

“You can help,” he says, nodding toward the scrap pile by the door. “If you want that

promise to mean something, you cut me two wedges and a packing shim. Cedar for the

pack, hardwood for the wedge. Clean. No splinters. No ‘close enough.’”

He turns slightly, already half back to the joint—waiting to see whether you step toward

the scrap and tools, or decide this stays his job.

I look at him for half a second before responding, with a look that must have said, 'oh, you mean right now.' I made my way quickly back to the entrance, where Sef was still standing, talking to Lasli. It made sense now why Sef was there at all: Tasho must have told him to bring these various wood scraps and tools. I was surprised though that Tasho seemed so ready to jump on this himself. I had expected some words of advice and then to do the job on my own. Tasho, apparently, had other ideas. Who was I to get in his way?

I tell Sef what Tasho said and he helps me pick out the best candidates from the wood scraps, and then I start making the cuts. The days working on the roof have brought my previous work experience in line with the style of work being done by Tasho's crew and I when I finish the cuts, I have confidence that they will meet Tasho's expectations. I leave Sef to continue chatting with Lasli, somewhat pleased that the younger man seems to get a break, and bring Tasho what he requested. I also bring along a mallet, sure that we would need a way to help wedge the prop in place to lift the beam.

Kakariko Village — Enchanted

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

Sef’s been loitering like a man who absolutely planned to be useful but also wouldn’t mind

if the universe forgot he existed for ten minutes. Up close, in good light, he’s all wiry limbs

and work-hardened hands, dark hair tied back with a strip of cloth, and a face that still has

a bit of boy in it when he smiles—right up until you see the little nicks along his knuckles

from tools he’s not quite finished learning to respect.

Lasli stands with him near the entry, posture careful the way people get when they’re

trying not to “hover,” but still hovering. Her sleeves are rolled just enough to keep them

clear, and her eyes keep darting from your hands to Tasho’s back like she’s watching an

herb surgeon prep a patient.

With Sef’s help you pick through the scraps: cedar with straight grain for the packing shim,

and a harder piece—dense, pale, and stubborn—for the wedge. Your saw strokes are

cleaner now, more pull than fight, and when you bring the pieces back the edges look like

they belong to someone who has stopped negotiating with the tool.

Tasho accepts them without praise—just the smallest nod that means yes, this won’t

embarrass me.

He takes the mallet from you, weighs it once, then sets it aside where he can grab it

without looking.

“Good,” he says.

He moves like he’s done this repair a hundred times in houses where people cook under

the beam they’re trusting with their lives.

First he has Sef drag over a short post—something like a stout length of timber with a flat

top and a foot that won’t skate. He sets it under the sagging end and sights it again, then

takes your cedar shim and slides it into the gap, testing, removing, shaving a whisper-thin

curl off with his chisel, re-fitting. The shop goes quiet in that way a room does when

someone competent starts doing delicate work.

Then he hooks the old, bad wedge with the chisel tip and draws it out.

It comes free with a tiny snap of crushed fibers releasing. The beam settles a fraction—

barely perceptible, but you feel it more than see it, like a breath exhaled.

Claree flinches anyway.

Tasho doesn’t even look at her. He just says, calm as rain: “That’s why we prop.”

He seats the post under the beam, then takes the mallet and gives the base a couple of

controlled taps—thunk… thunk—until the post kisses the beam tight enough that the slack

is gone. Not lifting it dramatically, just taking the load so the joint can be corrected

without the building “remembering” the wrong shape.

He cleans the mortise shoulder with the chisel—scraping out fuzz and old crushed wood

until the surfaces are honest again—then slides your cedar packing shim into place.

It fits like it belongs there.

Now he takes the hardwood wedge you cut, lines it up with the grain the right way (so it

tightens rather than splits), and starts it with a firm push of his thumb. It resists—good

hardwood always does.

Tasho glances at you for the first time since he began, and his eyes flick to the mallet.

“Your hit,” he says, and positions the wedge with two fingers. “Straight. Not hard. Let the

wood tell you when it’s seated.”

I roll my shoulders and take the mallet. The mallet is not the hammer I'm accustomed to from before, but this job right here, unlike the creation of the roof from scratch, is a job I'd effectively done a hundred times, and I'm pleased to show Tasho that in this at least, I know just how to do it.

*Thok* after *thok* the wedge does just as it was designed to do, and gradually, the funky twist the beam had begun to learn from the sloppy patch job start to align, and the sag starts to shrink...and then finally disappear.

I nod to Tasho and hide my smile for now. I don't want him to think I'm cocky. I also don't want him to think of me like a little boy seeking his father's approval. He's the master craftsman, so I let him make the judgement call.

Kakariko Village — Enchanted

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

The mallet feels different than your old world’s hammers—less metal certainty, more

wooden persuasion—but the language is the same.

You set your stance, breathe once, and let the first tap land.

Thok.

The wedge slides a hair, the sound bright and clean. Tasho’s fingers stay close, not in the

way, just there—ready to correct if the wedge tries to wander.

Thok… thok…

Each strike is measured. Not harder—just truer. The wedge sinks, the shim compresses into

a firm, obedient fit, and the beam answers the way old timber does when you stop lying to

it: it shifts with a reluctant grace, easing out of the twist it had been forced to “learn.”

There’s a tiny complaint—a creak like a knuckle popping—and then the sag you’d been

ducking under becomes… less. The line of the beam straightens until it looks like it

belongs in the room again, not like a tired shoulder slumping.

Tasho lifts a hand.

You stop instantly, mallet hovering.

He leans in, presses two fingers to the joint, then runs a thumb along the contact point

where mortise meets tenon. He does it like a man reading braille—feeling for truth more

than looking for it.

Sef, who has been pretending he’s not watching, lets out a slow breath like he’s been

holding it since you started.

Claree’s posture loosens by degrees. Lasli’s eyes widen just slightly, then she blinks and

looks away like she caught herself staring.

Tasho steps back half a pace and finally gives you something that, for him, is practically a

standing ovation: a single, decisive nod.

“That’ll hold,” he says. Then, after the smallest pause—barely a heartbeat—he adds, “Good

hand.”

He sets his palm against the post once, checking that it’s snug and not going to walk, then

looks toward Claree.

“Leave the prop for today,” he says, tone flat but not unkind. “Let it sit. The wood will settle

to the new truth. Tomorrow, if it’s still quiet, you can pull it.”

Claree exhales, a sound half relief, half offense at how simple it suddenly seems. “So… it’s

— it’s fixed?”

“It’s mended,” Tasho corrects. “Fixed is what you say when you pretend age doesn’t exist.”

He turns back to you and Sef, already shifting into work-mode again, the moment of

evaluation done and filed away like a tool returned to its hook.

“Pack up. Roof isn’t waiting.”

I lean in to Claree as Sef and I pack up the scraps and tools, "I'll try and make time sometime tomorrow afternoon to come and check on it, remove it if it stays quiet. Keep an ear on it though so I know if I'm good to do it when I come back." Tasho and Sef move out quickly and I hurry after them.

"If I'm not back tomorrow afternoon though, don't worry," I say over my shoulder. "I won't forget about it!"

I jog a few steps to catch up and keep pace with Tasho and Sef as we head back to the roof that needs finishing.

Kakariko Village — Path back to the roof

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

Claree’s eyes flick to you as you lean in—still a little tight around the edges, but not knife-

blade tense anymore. The shop feels different with the beam no longer nagging at the

room like a bad tooth.

Behind you, Sef gathers the scraps with quick, practiced motions—slight, wiry, dark hair

tied back, the kind of young man who looks perpetually one good meal away from

becoming “broad-shouldered.” He keeps stealing glances at the repair like he expects it to

misbehave the second nobody’s looking.

Tasho doesn’t linger. He’s already outside, long-legged stride eating up the path, his work

coat swinging with each step. From behind, he has that older-craftsman silhouette: straight

back, compact strength, no wasted movement.

You jog to catch them, and the village slides by in soft morning sound—distant water over

stone, birds, the faint clack of someone setting out market wares.

Tasho doesn’t look back, but he does speak, voice pitched so you and Sef can hear without

making a performance of it.

“Beam’s done for now,” he says. “Roof’s still hungry.”

Sef gives you a quick sideways look—half impressed, half don’t get comfortable—then

lengthens his stride to match Tasho’s pace.

By the time you reach the worksite, the half-finished roofline is waiting like a problem that

never slept: cedar scent sharp in the morning air, bundled rafters laid out, rope coils, and

the last span of exposed frame catching the light.

Tasho stops at the base of the scaffold and finally turns, eyes doing that quick inventory

thing—tools, posture, readiness—like he’s counting inventory without numbers.

He points once, precise.

“Sef—bring the line and pegs up. I want the next run set before the sun’s high.”

Then his gaze lands on you. Not stern, not warm—just direct. The “Good hand” from

earlier is still there in the background, but it doesn’t buy you softness; it buys you

expectation.

“Zeth—up with me. We’re fitting the next rafter pair. You’ll hold and seat. I’ll mark and

check.”

He steps onto the first rung like it’s a sentence he’s spoken a thousand times.

The roof waits above—quiet, high, and ready to punish sloppy feet.

(Your move.)

I put the mallet I'd been carrying with some delight in a loop on my new belt, where it hangs the way it should. It's on the left side--I'm accustomed to my hammer loop being on the right side of my carpenter's cargo pants in 'the before times', but it's a minor alteration and feels far more right than wrong. Then I follow Tasho up the scaffolding, looking around as I ascend, still not seeing Rinna anywhere. I had sort of expected her to be here waiting on us, or something.

"No Rinna today?" I ask as I get into position to start work. "Do her and the folks have a stall on marketday?"

Kakariko Village — Rooftop worksite

Day 6, early morning • Late spring

The new belt takes the mallet like it was born for it—leather creaks once, settles, and the

weight sits right against your hip. The loop’s a little different than your old “before times”

setup, but it doesn’t fight you. It just…belongs.

Up the scaffolding you go.

The cedar smell is stronger up here, sun warming the fresh-cut faces of rafters. Below,

Kakariko is already in motion—distant voices, the occasional clink of set-down baskets,

and the soft buzz that says market day without anyone needing to announce it. A breeze

slides through the half-framed roofline and catches loose wood shavings, sending them

skittering like tiny beetles.

Tasho is already a few rungs above you, moving like the scaffold is just another floor he’s

walked his whole life. Up close his age reads clearer: not old, but seasoned—sun-browned

skin, a few deep lines at the eyes, and hands that look permanently “work-ready,” knuckles

a little thickened from years of persuading wood into agreement.

Sef climbs behind with the line and pegs, breathing steady, careful with his footing.

When you ask about Rinna, Tasho doesn’t stop climbing. He answers like he’s filing it

under useful information.

“Market morning,” he says. “Mellie sells. Rinna helps her set up and watch the stall early.”

He reaches the work level, steps off, then glances down at you for the first time since the

question—brief, measuring.

“She’ll be here after. Or she’ll come when she can. Work doesn’t stop because someone’s

got family duties.”

Sef, halfway up, adds quietly—almost like he’s confirming the obvious. “Rinna doesn’t skip.

If she’s not here, it’s because she’s doing something that has to be done.”

Tasho plants a hand on the rafter stock and points to the next pair laid out.

“Positions,” he says. “You hold and seat like I told you. Eyes on the edge. Wind’ll try to

make a liar out of your balance.”

He starts checking the rafter ends—thumb over grain, quick look down the length, then a

small, precise mark with charcoal. Efficient. Unshowy.

Sef finishes climbing and sets the line and pegs within reach, then backs out of the way,

waiting for the call.

Tasho lifts the first rafter end, bracing it against his shoulder like it weighs nothing. He

angles it toward you, ready to feed it into place.

“Hands ready,” he says. “On my count.”

He looks at you—expectant, steady—then nods once toward the join point.

“One… two…”

The explanation makes sense to me. Mellie would sometimes have plums, Olkin would always have pumpkins. More or less, anyways.

But for now I didn't want to keep Tasho waiting, and it comforted me to know that people other than me need to do things apart from work sometimes. On Tasho's count I swing into the work rhythm of the morning until the next noteworthy thing comes my way.

Thought for 14s

Kakariko Village — Rooftop worksite

Day 6, morning • Late spring

The morning becomes a simple machine.

Tasho counts, you brace and seat, Sef feeds pegs and line where they’re needed—no

wasted motion, no chatter that isn’t attached to the work. Cedar dust clings to sweat at

your forearms. The new belt earns its keep fast: the mallet rides your hip instead of your

hand, and every time it knocks lightly against the leather loop it’s a tiny reminder that

you’re not improvising everything anymore.

Below, the village’s market-day hum thickens as the sun climbs—voices clustering, baskets

set down, the occasional laugh, and that warm smell of cooked rice drifting up in teasing

little waves. Somewhere down the slope, someone’s calling out prices like it’s a song

they’ve sung a hundred times.

Up here, it’s rafters, pegs, alignment, repeat.

Tasho checks each piece like he’s listening for lies in the grain. When something’s even

slightly off, he doesn’t scold—he just makes you redo it until it’s right, the same calm,

relentless standard every time. Sef stays quiet, but you catch him watching the join lines

with a seriousness that makes him look older than he did a week ago.

Then the wind shifts.

It’s not a gentle breeze this time—it comes in quick and sideways, a little stronger than it’s

been all morning. The loose shavings skitter. The edge of the rafter you’re holding twitches

under your hands, trying to lift and yaw away from the seat.

Tasho’s head snaps up instantly.

“Hold!” he barks—sharp, immediate.

The gust catches again, and for half a heartbeat the rafter feels like it wants to lever itself

out of position. If it pops free, it won’t just waste time—it could swing, slam, or slide, and

the scaffold suddenly feels much narrower than it did a second ago.

Your hands are on the wood. The rafter is moving.

A little flutter of unease, bordering fear plays around my chest, but I don't let it get the better of me. Tasho said 'hold', so he clearly expected me to keep a calm head and hold the line, not panic. I hadn't expected what seemed like such a minor breeze to catch the relatively heavy beam, but it wasn't out of control. I assess the way the beam is wanting to lever out of position, dragged by the wind. I could throw my weight on it. I'm a large man and in a lesser wind, that may have been enough, but this wind had already proven I probably couldn't fight it. So I don't try, not wanting to get myself maimed or killed.

Instead, I whip out a wooden shim and the mallet. I couldn't fight the wind, but the laws of physics could. If I wedged the shim into the gap in the beam's intended mortise, then the wind would have to be far stronger to make it move. It wouldn't necessarily help the beam look any prettier, but it might save the project and a limb at the same time, and nobody would be able to see the results of the effort when the house was done anyways.

The rafter bucks again—more like a stubborn animal than a piece of lumber—and that’s

the moment you commit to “let physics do the punching.”

The shim flashes into your hand. You drop your center of gravity, keep your knees bent

against the scaffold’s faint wobble, and slide the wedge toward the hungry gap of the

joint. The wind worries at the board like a dog at a bone, but you don’t try to out-muscle it

—you just aim.

Thok.

The first mallet strike seats the shim shallow. The rafter still twitches, but now it’s twitching

against something.

A second gust hits, sharper, and you feel the whole assembly try to “walk” a fraction—then

the wedge bites harder.

Thok. Thok.

The shim drives home with that satisfying, ugly honesty of wood locking wood. The rafter’s

motion goes from “about to lever” to “angry vibration.” Still alive. Not free.

Tasho’s eyes are on your hands the whole time—hawk-still. His jaw tightens, then loosens

by a hair when the rafter stops trying to escape.

“Good,” he says—one word, but it lands like a stamp of approval.

Sef, a half-step behind Tasho, moves fast now that the worst is contained. He grabs the

nearest coil of line and braces it with his boot so it doesn’t unspool into chaos, eyes

flicking between the rafter, the peg pouch, and Tasho’s face like he’s waiting for a signal.

Another gust runs over the roof like a hand raking across strings. The rafter hums but stays

seated.

Tasho leans in, voice low but firm—meant to carry over wind without turning into panic.

“We lash it now, temporary. Two turns and a bite. Then we finish the seat clean once this

dies down.”

He reaches for the line Sef has ready, then pauses—watching the shim, the joint, and the

way your mallet’s hanging on that new belt loop.

The rafter is held for the moment… but you can feel how close that was. The wind hasn’t

finished arguing with the roof yet.

I do as Tasho says and help him and Sef lash the beam in place, then scramble down from the scaffolding with Tasho, following his lead as he stands clear and reassesses the situation.

I look at Sef, who mirrors my feeling of sudden relief after a tense situation. I feel a sudden a moment of identification with Sef that I hadn't up to this point, even though he hadn't been up on the scaffold with me and Tasho, like I was seeing myself a decade ago.

"Well," I say, popping my neck as I roll it around and loosen its tense muscles, "that's a new page in my book."

Tasho doesn’t answer right away. He steps out from the scaffold’s shadow to where he can

read the roofline cleanly, head tilted, eyes narrowed—not at you, not at Sef, but at the

geometry of the whole mess. The wind combs through the cedars above the lane and

makes the loose ends of line flutter like nervous tails.

The lashings hold. The shim you drove is still seated. The rafter is no longer trying to

become a flying lesson.

Sef lets out a breath that sounds like he’s been holding it since before you even grabbed

the mallet. His cheeks are a little pink—part exertion, part the delayed “oh wow that

could’ve gone worse.” He gives you a quick, sideways look that’s half respect, half “I’m

glad you were the one up there.”

Tasho finally speaks, voice dry as sawdust, like he’s commenting on weather and not near-

misses.

“Good page. Keep it. Wind teaches faster than any master does.”

Then he looks directly at you—measuring, not unkind.

“You did not fight it. You anchored it. That is the difference between a worker and a

survivor.”

He turns his gaze back to the roof. Another gust rolls through, but weaker this time—more

bluster than bite. The rafter shivers, the lashings creak, and then everything settles again.

Sef shifts his weight and fiddles with the end of the rope like he wants to do something

with his hands to burn off the leftover adrenaline. He clears his throat.

“Marketday winds,” he mutters, as if that explains the universe. “Always show up when

you’re holding something expensive.”

Tasho gives a short nod toward the scaffold, then toward the ground-level tools.

“We wait five breaths. If it steadies, we go back up and work smaller pieces. No hero

beams. No long carries. We do not give the wind a handle.”

He starts organizing the next steps without fuss—moving a coil here, shifting the saw

horse there—quiet competence trying to pin the day back down.

Day 4 in Hyrule is turning into the kind of day that makes you earn your lunch.

Tasho’s eyes flick once more to the lashings—satisfied, for now.

“Water,” he says, and jerks his chin toward the shade. “Then we decide. You are still intact.

That is success.”

*/The previous response is good, but please revise it to reflect that this is late morning of Day 6, not Day 4. Resume using the "location • time • weather • season (one clean line)" Scene Header as instructed in rules for this simulation as you have been in previous scenes. /*

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Late morning, Day 6 • Gusty, capricious wind

with sudden stronger gusts • Spring

Tasho doesn’t answer right away. He steps out from the scaffold’s shadow to where he can

read the roofline cleanly, head tilted, eyes narrowed—not at you, not at Sef, but at the

geometry of the whole mess. The wind combs through the cedars above the lane and

makes loose rope-ends twitch like nervous tails.

The lashings hold. The shim you drove is still seated. The rafter is no longer trying to

become a flying lesson.

Sef lets out a breath that sounds like he’s been holding it since before you even grabbed

the mallet. His cheeks are a little pink—part exertion, part the delayed “that could’ve gone

worse.” He gives you a quick sideways look: half respect, half “glad it was you up there.”

Tasho finally speaks, voice dry as sawdust, like he’s commenting on weather and not near-

misses.

“Good page. Keep it. Wind teaches faster than any master does.”

Then his eyes settle on you—measuring, not unkind.

“You did not fight it. You anchored it. That is the difference between a worker and a

survivor.”

Another gust rolls through—still sharp, but weaker than the one that tried to lever the

beam out of place. The rafter shivers; the lashings creak; then everything settles again.

Sef shifts his weight and fusses with the rope like he needs his hands busy to bleed off the

leftover adrenaline. He clears his throat.

“Marketday winds,” he mutters, like that explains the universe. “Always show up when

you’re holding something expensive.”

Tasho gives a short nod toward the scaffold, then toward the ground-level tools.

“We wait five breaths. If it steadies, we go back up and work smaller pieces. No hero

beams. No long carries. We do not give the wind a handle.”

He starts resetting the site with quiet competence—coil here, wedge there—pinning the

morning back down the way you pin a board before cutting it.

“Water,” he says, and jerks his chin toward the shade. “Then we decide.”

Sef and I get some water for ourselves, but after I take a drink I dip the ladel back in and bring up some more, taking it to Tasho and offering it.

"You okay?" I ask simply and without any ulterior motive. I just want to be sure, while also giving Tasho a chance to have an extra breather after the close call if he needs it.

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Late morning, Day 6 • Gusty wind easing in

pulses • Spring

Tasho takes the water without making a production of it—just a steady, work-worn hand

accepting what’s offered. Up close, the man looks like he’s been carved by weather and

repetition: compact, dense muscle under sun-browned skin, forearms corded with old

strength; a few pale scars that don’t need explaining; hair tied back in a practical knot with

a strip of cloth that’s seen better days. His eyes stay alert even while he drinks, like part of

him is still listening to the wind argue with the rafters.

He swallows, then exhales through his nose.

“I am fine,” he says, plain and honest.

Then, after a beat—because he’s not just a foreman, he’s responsible—his gaze flicks over

you and then to Sef, checking for the same answer in your faces without asking it directly.

“That gust was rude,” he adds, almost deadpan, like the wind has manners it keeps

forgetting. “But it did not take anything from us.”

Sef—leaner, younger, with that wiry “still growing into himself” build—stands a little

straighter at that, like hearing it said out loud lets his ribs unclench. He wipes his mouth

with the back of his wrist and glances toward the lashings again, distrustful of the sky on

principle.

Tasho hands the ladle back.

“Good to ask,” he says—no praise-speech, just acknowledgement. “Do it again when it

matters.”

Another breeze runs its fingers along the roof edge. The lashed beam gives a small

complaint—wood and rope talking—but it holds. Tasho watches it like a hawk watching a

mousehole.

He lifts his chin toward the scaffold.

“Five breaths like I said,” he tells both of you, voice back in the rhythm of command. “If the

wind behaves, we work small. If it does not…” He taps two fingers lightly against his

temple. “We work smart instead.”

He pauses, eyes narrowing up at the sky as if deciding whether it deserves trust.

“Your call,” he says, not to the wind—to you and Sef. “Does it feel steady enough to climb

again, or do we stay down and cut more pieces until it settles?”

Sef and I exchange a look at each other. I try to make my eyes ask Sef if he's ever had Tasho ask him such a question, but of course I can't. Sef's own expression is simply blank.

I turn my attention back to Tasho. "Well I'm not sure...I don't really have experience judging that kimd of thing. I guess, so long as we're still making progress, we could keep our feet on the ground and cut, just to be safe. We

can always keep our eye on it while we cut and reassess later."

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Late morning, Day 6 • Gusts on and off, cooler

in the shade • Spring

Tasho studies you for a moment—not suspicious, just weighing the sense of what you said.

Then he gives a single, sharp nod like a nail set true.

“Good,” he says. “That is judgment. Not pride.”

Sef’s shoulders drop a fraction, relief hiding under the motion like a shy animal. He glances

at the lashed beam again, then back to Tasho, as if confirming the decision didn’t just

happen to him.

Tasho steps closer to the scaffold and gives the rope lashings a firm tug with both hands—

testing, listening. The beam holds with a dull, wooden stubbornness. Another gust noses

the roofline and the ropes creak, but nothing shifts.

“Wind is not finished talking,” Tasho mutters, half to himself.

He looks at you and Sef again—eyes steady, voice back to that calm foreman cadence.

“We stay down. We cut and fit what we can from the ground. When the air calms, we

climb. If it does not, we still leave this house better than we found it.”

He gestures toward the sawhorses and the stack of timber like a general pointing at a

map.

“Sef—measure and mark the next set. Zeth—cut clean. Do not chase speed.” His gaze

flicks to your belt and the mallet loop with a brief approval that he doesn’t verbalize. “And

keep your ears open. The roof will tell you when it is ready.”

Sef moves first, grabbing the measuring line and chalk with that “trying-to-look-older-

than-I-feel” stiffness. He hesitates just long enough to shoot you a quick look—something

like thanks for saying it out loud—then ducks into the work.

Tasho stays near the scaffold a moment longer, watching the treetops sway and listening

to the ropes complain. Then he turns back toward the timber pile, already thinking three

steps ahead.

You’ve got the saw station in front of you, fresh marks about to go down, and the wind still

occasionally flexing its fingers over the roofline.

As we get back into the swing of things, all three of us keep an eye on the weather to see if the wind will safely allow us back on the roof or not.

Though Tasho clearly does not want to lose time—roof still needed to be done before the weather really messed things up—but the need for speed obviously lessens as we get unevenly prepared with rafters on the ground without setting them.

I work mostly without chit-chat; Tasho never seems to mind when Sef, Rinna or myself talk as we work, but he himself doesn't join in much, and while in his immediate vicinity idle conversation tends to taper off some. An occasional joking tease here or genuine small question there. I find myself wondering when or if Rinna will show up today, busy helping her parents as she is. The stupid boy part of my brain disappointed she missed the 'excitement' of the near miss, but the responsible man part is glad she did, since it would have just meant another set of limbs to worry about being damaged.

Thought for 12s

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Late morning sliding toward noon, Day 6 •

Gusts easing, still twitchy • Spring

With everyone grounded, the work gets into that familiar carpentry trance: measure →

mark → cut → test-fit → adjust. The wind keeps trying to “participate” like a bored

spectator, ruffling loose curls of cedar shavings and occasionally thumping the lashed

beam hard enough to make the ropes complain—eeerk—but it’s no longer yanking at

everything like it wants to tear the roof off and wear it as a hat.

Tasho stays spare with words. Not unfriendly—just…focused, like he’s listening to the

building’s bones more than to people. Up close, his hands look like old leather and knotty

rootwood—thick fingers, crescent scars, nailbeds permanently stained by pitch and work.

When he checks a cut, it’s with a thumb sweep and a small tilt of the head, like he can hear

whether a joint is honest.

Sef, meanwhile, is all quick motion and careful respect—dark hair tied back messily, cheeks

still boyish under the dust, eyes darting between your saw stroke and Tasho’s face like he’s

trying to learn two lessons at once. He talks less today too, not because he’s scared, but

because the air has taught everyone a little humility.

Time passes in clean, useful chunks.

Then—somewhere around when the light starts to go whiter and more vertical—the wind

finally lets go for more than a minute at a time.

Tasho pauses mid-step, eyes on the treetops beyond the eaves. Another long beat. He

walks to the lashings and puts both hands on the rope again, testing. The beam holds

steady. No sideways urge. No sudden shudder.

“Now,” he says, quiet and firm.

He points up with his chin—no drama. Just the next step.

Before anyone climbs, there’s a soft scuff of boots on packed earth from the lane: Rinna

appears at the edge of the yard like she’s been moving fast but trying not to look like

she’s been running. Taller than most villagers, built compact and strong—sun-browned

skin, freckles across her nose and upper cheeks, hair pulled back in a practical tie that still

manages to look rebellious. The faint scar you’d noticed earlier catches the light when she

turns her head.

She carries a small bundle and a water gourd, breath steadying as she arrives.

“Hey—” she starts, then stops herself like she’s remembering she’s on Tasho-time. Her eyes

flick up to the scaffold and the lashed beam, then back down to the three of you. “Wind

behaving?”

Tasho answers her with a single nod and a brief gesture toward the ground station, as if to

say good, set it there. No rebuke. Just direction.

Rinna sets the water down where it’s easy to reach, then steps back out of the way with

that practiced “I’m here but not in anyone’s workspace” posture. She watches you, Sef, and

Tasho like someone counting hands and feet without meaning to.

Tasho looks to you and Sef. His voice stays even.

“We set one rafter. Slow. If the wind returns, we come down. If it stays quiet, we set the

next.”

He gives the scaffold a hard, deliberate look—as if daring it to disagree—then starts

toward the first rung.

Sef’s eyes go up, then to you, then up again.

Tasho is about to climb.

Do you go up with him to set the first rafter now that the gusts have eased, or do you call

for one more minute to watch the air and keep cutting on the ground?

*/The player doesn't need to be prompted with questions unless there is an extreme sense of urgency and an obvious, exclusive dichotomy of choices./*

I wave to Rinna with a smile. "Glad you made it." I trust Tasho's wealth of experience over my own and begin following him up the scaffolding again. "Yeah you missed all the excitment," I say sarcastically. "It was almost bad for a minute."

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Late morning, Day 6 • Gusts easing, intermittent

• Spring

Rinna catches your wave and smile with a quick, bright return—half grin, half “I’m trying

not to distract the crew.” She tucks a loose strand of hair back under her tie and looks up

at the scaffold again when you mention the “almost bad” moment.

“Almost bad?” she murmurs, sarcasm meeting sarcasm. “That’s the kind that takes fingers.

Or pride.”

Tasho doesn’t comment. He just starts climbing with the same steady, economical rhythm

he always has—boots finding the worn rungs like they’ve got memory. The scaffold gives a

low wooden creak under his weight, then under yours as you follow. Cedar dust clings to

everything: hands, sleeves, the grain of the planks. Up here, the wind feels closer—less like

“weather” and more like a living thing testing boundaries.

Sef stays below for the moment, doing exactly what Tasho had arranged: he positions

himself at the ground station with eyes on the lashings and the beam, ready to feed up a

tool or shout warning if the air turns nasty again.

Tasho reaches the working platform and plants his stance wide. He taps the lashed beam

with his knuckles—tok, tok—then glances to the treetops beyond the roofline. The leaves

are moving, but not lunging. Not yet.

He motions you in with two fingers: close, on his inside, where your weight helps rather

than fights. Then he points to the rafter waiting to be set—its end already marked, its face

planed clean enough that the cedar’s pale stripes look almost silky even under dust.

“Hands here,” he says, indicating the safe grip points—away from pinch zones. “We lift

together. We seat it. No wrestling.”

Above you, the lashed beam gives a small, impatient groan in the rope—like it remembers

the earlier gust and is daring the wind to try again.

On the ground, Rinna has gone still. Not panicked—just watchful. Her arms fold loosely,

and her eyes track your hands the way a craftsperson tracks a blade: not judging, just

calculating risk.

Tasho takes a breath through his nose, then gives the smallest nod—now.

The rafter’s weight comes alive the instant you commit. Cedar is light compared to oak,

but awkward weight is its own animal, and the wind chooses that moment to brush the

roofline—just a nudge, like a fingertip on the edge of balance.

Tasho holds the cadence steady, voice low and precise. “Up. In. Seat.”

The rafter rises. The joint approaches. The whole world narrows to grain, angle, pressure,

and the tiny language of wood telling you whether it wants to fit—or fight.

You’re on the lip of that next crucial second: the seat is close enough to commit, or close

enough to slip if the breeze decides to get clever again.

The wind seems to behave itself for now, and Tasho and I fall into a steady pattern. Not exactly relaxed enough to be mindless in its repetition, but less nerve-fraying than the wind had made the rest of the morning.

Below us, Rinna finds her place in the workflow alongside Sef, and we start making good time as we pass noontime, setting the rafters Sef, Tasho and myself had prepared on the ground.

The rest of the workday passes, thankfully, without further incident.

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Afternoon, Day 6 • Wind calmed; cool, steady

air • Spring

By the time the sun tips past noon, the roof stops feeling like a dare and starts feeling like

a project again.

Tasho’s pace never turns casual, but it does become predictable—the best kind of mercy

on a roof. Lift, seat, check. Lift, seat, check. The cedar rafters go in like teeth in a comb,

each one tightening the structure a little more, each one making the whole thing less

vulnerable to the sky’s moods.

Below, Rinna slides into the work with Sef like she never left it. Not loud, not showy—just

competent. She calls measurements up when needed, keeps the next piece ready before

you have to ask, and once or twice you catch her palm resting on a rafter-end as if she’s

listening through the wood for what it wants.

Late afternoon brings that familiar rhythm of finishing: fewer big motions, more little ones

—trimming, aligning, tightening lashings, checking that nothing’s drifting out of true.

Tasho does his last walk of the line, eyes narrow, fingers occasionally touching a joint the

way Sana taps an onigiri to judge its shape—quiet, decisive, impossible to fake.

Finally he stops, looks down the slope toward the village, then up at the roofline one more

time.

“That’s enough for today,” he says. Not praise. Not dismissal. Just the verdict.

On the ground, Sef exhales like he’d been holding a breath since morning. Rinna wipes her

brow with the back of her wrist, leaving a faint smear of dust and sweat, and gives you a

look that lands somewhere between relief and “don’t ever scare me like that again,” even if

she doesn’t say it.

You climb down with the day’s tiredness in your bones—the good kind, earned and

complete. The village sounds drift up to meet you: distant conversation, a bird calling from

the trees near the shrine trail, the soft thump of someone closing shutters for the evening.

Tasho gathers the tools with the same care he uses on beams. As he does, he glances at

you—brief, measuring.

“You kept your head,” he says, and then he’s already turning the thought into the next

practical thing. “Tomorrow we finish the last of it—if the sky stays polite.”

Rinna and Sef start bundling scraps and offcuts. The day is done, and for once, it ends

without any new debts to fear—just the simple, quiet fact of work completed and a roof

that will not betray its people the next time the wind comes sniffing around.

I clamber down without delay at Tasho's call, sorting some tools while Sef and Rinna gather scraps and offcuts. My stomach growls as it has been since noon—in my urgency to get my belt this morning I had forgotten to bring my lunch. Not that it seemed to matter anyways, since it seemed Tasho had judged it wise to make this another 'work-through-midday-but-end-earlier' day.

I think back on the other items I had spied walking through the market stalls this morning and wondered if any of them were still available.

As Sef and Rinna finished their bit of cleanup, I pass the organised tool bundle to Sef. The mallet, still hanging from the loop on my belt, is last, and I remove it then toss it, spinning, in the air before I catch it by the handle again. A little show-offy? Maybe. But I'm still happy about the belt and I don't think anybody would hold that against me.

"You headed back to the market, Rinna?" I ask, genuinely curious if she would also be helping her parents finish the day as she had helped them start it.

Thought for 14s

Kakariko Village (residential roof jobsite) • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Wind mostly settled;

cool gusts come and go • Spring

Tasho’s “enough for today” has the weight of a nail finally set flush—final, no argument.

The three of them move into cleanup like it’s just the next phase of the craft: nothing

wasted, nothing left to snag a toe or disappear into the weeds.

Sef accepts the bundled tools from you with both hands, giving the bundle a quick,

practiced check—more habit than distrust—then nods once.

When the mallet comes free of your new belt loop and you give it that quick little spin-

toss, it draws attention the way a snapped string does: not loud, but everyone notices.

Sef’s face does a tiny twitch like he’s deciding whether to scold you or laugh. He lands on

neither; he just exhales through his nose and says, dry as sawdust, “If you drop it and it

takes a foot, I’m not carrying you to Sana.”

Rinna, meanwhile, watches the mallet’s rotation with a carpenter’s eye—tracking its center

of mass without thinking about it—then your catch. One corner of her mouth lifts, and she

gives you a look that says, All right. Don’t get cute on a roof, but without the heat behind it.

At your question, she wipes her hands on her trousers and glances down the slope toward

where the market noise floats up between the houses—muffled voices, a call from a

vendor, the clink of something wooden being packed.

“Yeah,” she says. “I’m headed back. Ma’ll want help packing up, and Da’ll pretend he

doesn’t, but he’ll be happier for the extra hands.” Her eyes flick to your belt—quick,

assessing—and she adds, “Looks like you got what you needed.”

Then, a half-beat later, she tilts her head toward the village center, like she’s offering

information without making it a big deal. “Market’ll thin fast once the shadows get long. If

you’re hunting anything else, now’s the time—before the travelers start tying down their

loads and thinking about the road.”

Tasho is already shouldering his own tools like the day is a finished sentence. He doesn’t

bark orders, but his posture makes it clear: the crew’s dispersing, and the village evening is

about to begin whether you’re ready for it or not.

I pat the belt with contentment. "I did indeed. Mind if I walk with you for a minute?" I ask, seeing a possible opportunity for some friendly conversation about something beyond work for a change.

Kakariko Village (roof jobsite, hillside) • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Wind calmed, occasional

cool gusts • Spring

Rinna’s gaze flicks to your hand patting the belt, then back to your face. Up close in

daylight she has that sun-browned, work-season skin and a scatter of freckles across her

nose and cheeks that the morning’s dust never fully hides; her hair’s tied back in a

practical knot, and the old scar you asked about earlier sits pale against the tan like a thin

brushstroke.

She shifts the bundle of offcuts she’s carrying to sit better against her hip and gives you a

small, uncomplicated nod.

“Yeah. Walk.” Simple as that—no ceremony, no weirdness.

Tasho and Sef peel off their own directions without needing to announce it. Tasho heads

with that steady, unhurried stride of someone who’s decided the day is over and therefore

the day is over. Sef lingers a half-step like he might say something, then thinks better of it

and follows.

Rinna falls into an easy pace beside you down the slope. The village sounds grow louder

with each step: faint music from somewhere, a vendor calling out the last of something,

the soft clack of wooden sandals on stone. The air smells like warm wood and cooking

smoke—someone’s already started evening fires.

She glances sideways once, quick and measuring, like she’s checking whether you’re

walking with her to talk or walking with her because you don’t know where you’re going.

Then she speaks, tone casual—friendly, but not syrupy.

“Market’s smaller than it sounds from up there. By the time you get into it, it’s mostly just

people trying to finish their day.” She gives your belt another brief look. “You did all right,

though. Most folks would’ve gotten fleeced the moment they looked relieved.”

A gust tugs at the edge of her tunic and she hooks a thumb under her strap to keep the

bundle steady. “So.” She lets the word hang for a beat—an opening, not a demand—eyes

forward toward the village center where the market noise thickens.

The expectation for me to carry the conversation in the 'so' catches me slightly off-guard. I liked Rinna's straight- forward attitude and plain, engaging way of speaking, though.

"So I'm sure your mither told you about mushrooms and her herbed salt yesterday," I say. "Sana had me using it immediately. Still have some of my 'attempts' up in my room." The mention of food reminds me of my empty stomach, but I ignore it for the time being.

Thought for 10s

Kakariko Village (stone path down from the roofline) • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Clearing

after gusty wind, cool air in the shade • Spring

Rinna’s mouth quirks at the mention of her mother’s salt—half pride, half “yeah, I know

exactly what you’re talking about.”

“Mellie tells everyone about mushrooms,” she says, like it’s a law of nature. “If the Goddess

ever takes the pumpkins, she’ll keep the village alive on lectures and fungus.”

Her eyes flick down toward your midsection for a heartbeat—clocking the belt, the way it

sits, the mallet loop—then back up. “Sana had you using Mellie’s blend immediately?” A

soft, incredulous huff. “Bold. She usually makes people prove they can boil water without

burning it first.”

As you keep walking, the market noise grows: a few vendors calling out last prices, a

child’s laughter, the clink of pottery, and that warm, hungry smell of grilled things that

makes the whole village feel like it’s exhaling.

Rinna adjusts the bundle on her hip again. Up close, her hands are work-hands—callused

pads, a couple of old nicks, cedar dust still trapped in the creases despite a rinse. “Those

‘attempts’… don’t toss ’em. Even ugly ones fill a belly.” She says it plainly, not as pity—

more like practical advice she’d give anyone.

A few steps later, you pass an older woman with a basket who glances at you, then at

Rinna, then pointedly at the space between you like she’s measuring gossip with her eyes.

Rinna doesn’t react—either she doesn’t notice or she’s learned the ancient village art of

pretending not to.

“The market’ll still have something hot,” she adds, voice steady, eyes forward. “Even when

the good stuff’s gone.”

I try to be as nonchalant as possible as the older woman crosses out path. If Rinna doesn't mind, then I don't have to mind either. "Oh no chance of those going to waste," I say about my mushroom riceballs back at the inn. "I meant to bring one with me to work today, forgot it though. Even if they weren't going to be lunch they taste too good to waste."

As we walk I keep an eye out to see if any of the items I had mentally tagged that morning were still obviously available or not.

I unconsciously rub the tip of my ear a little bit, the nervous/thoughtful tick having worked its way into my subconscious deeply enough at this point I only sometimes notice it. "Hey, I don't want to make you feel like you have to hang around if you have things you need to do. It's just nice to have someone to talk with that I have some things in common with, you know?"

Kakariko Market Lane (below the roofline, toward the pond) • Late afternoon, Day 6 •

Breezy but settling; sun slanting gold between rooftops • Spring

Rinna flicks a quick look at the woman with the basket—then back to you like she’s

decided, Not worth feeding that fire.

“Good,” she says about the rice balls not going to waste. “Because wasting food is how

you get haunted. Not by spirits—by aunties.”

The market’s thinned from the morning rush, but it’s not dead. A few stalls still have their

“last of the day” energy: a potter with chipped bowls stacked in nests, a cloth-seller

shaking out a faded shawl, a guy with little bundles of cord and twine laid out like

treasure. Somewhere nearby, something’s sizzling on a little grill, and your stomach—

traitor that it is—does the most dramatic, audible commentary on it.

As you scan, you spot a couple of things that ping your mental list:

A simple woven shoulder satchel (reed or straw, with a cloth strap) hanging from a

peg—lightweight, practical-looking, not fancy.

A broad-brimmed hat—not the curved Sheikah style, more like a plain travel hat—

sun-bleached and a little misshapen, but still intact.

A stall with leather odds and ends—laces, patched gloves, small pouches—nothing as

solid as a belt like Vako’s work, but useful bits.

Rinna catches your ear-rub and doesn’t comment. When you say you don’t want her to

feel obligated, she exhales a small laugh through her nose—warm, not mocking.

“I’m not trapped,” she says. “If I wanted to ditch you, I’d already be gone. I’ve got things to

do, yeah—but walking and talking isn’t nothing. It’s… normal.”

She gestures ahead with her chin, toward a stall where the last customers are drifting away

with orange pumpkins tucked under arms like prizes. “I do need to help my parents close

up.” As you get closer, you see Olkin clearly: older, thick in the shoulders like someone

who spent decades lifting things the hard way, with a sun-browned face, a grey

moustache, and forearms like bundled rope. Mellie’s there too, fussing with a basket and

muttering at produce like it’s misbehaving on purpose.

Rinna slows just a touch, then angles toward them. “You can walk with me this far. Just—”

a quick glance around the lane, practical and sharp, “—keep your money close. Market

makes people brave.”

She steps into the edge of the stall space, raising her voice slightly—not calling attention,

just announcing herself.

Olkin looks up first. Mellie follows a beat later, eyes narrowing in that way older villagers

do when they’re deciding whether you’re trouble, useful, or both.

Rinna turns her head toward you, leaving you a clean opening to join her at the stall or

hang back a step without it looking weird.

I nod with a trepidatious little smile at Mellie and Olkin, hoping to suggest something along the lines of 'nothing funny going on here, just a guy in a market.' Then I think better of it and offer the older couple a respectful little head bow the same way I had Impa or Dorian.

"I used your salts last night...Mellie," it feels wrong not to say 'ma'am or 'mrs' or 'sir', but so far the only person who hadnt insisted that I drop the formality was Dorian, and even he seemed a little uncertain of it. Even Rinna referred to her own mother by name. "Thank you again for them. They made some excellent rice."

I look at Olkin. This is actually the first time I'd really had a chance to interact with him, and he simultaneously seemed to both meet and fail my expectations based on my game experience. Sure, he had thay sort of broad- shouldered, square look of toughness, and I could easily imagine him getting wound up over Steen's carrots, but now that I was actually looking him in the face...he didn't seem like a caraciture. It was like went from being a two- dimensional drawing to a three-dimensional form. I suppose I would find out one way or another, but just looking at him and the lines in his face...he seemed like he might actually know his way around a joke as well as an argument. Which wasn't exactly what I'd expected.

Kakariko Market Lane (Olkin & Mellie’s pumpkin stall) • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy but

calmer; warm light slanting through eaves • Spring

Mellie’s eyes flick from your bow to your face, then down—fast—to your hands and belt,

like she’s doing a whole inventory without asking. The look softens a fraction at the

mention of the salt.

“Hmph,” she says, but it’s the pleased kind of humph—the one people use when they don’t

want to hand out compliments like candy. “Good. That blend isn’t for looking pretty in a

pouch.”

She plucks a small cloth-wrapped packet from the stall basket and taps it once with a

knuckle. “And don’t call it salts. It’s seasoning. Salt is what you use when you’re lazy.”

Olkin—broad-backed, sun-browned, moustache greyed at the edges—leans forward a

little, resting a forearm on the stall rail. Up close, he’s less “caricature farmer” and more

“man who’s argued with weather for decades.” His eyes take you in with that steady,

weighing look—boots, gloves, the work-worn edges of your clothes, the new belt.

“You’re the tall one,” he says at last, voice dry as old cedar. “Rinna’s been talking.”

Rinna makes a small sound—half warning, half don’t you start—but Olkin’s mouth twitches

like he’s enjoying himself.

Mellie huffs again and starts straightening the remaining pumpkins with brisk little shoves,

as if they might roll away out of spite. “He’s been working,” she says, to Olkin more than to

you. “That’s what matters.”

Around you, the market has that end-of-day loosening: a couple of merchants counting

down stock, a traveler bargaining for cord with the intensity of someone negotiating for a

life-saving artifact, and—two stalls over—an older Sheikah woman watching the world like

it’s her personal theatre. Her gaze skims you, then shifts away like she’s already stored the

scene for later.

Olkin nods once, slow, like a door latch settling. “If you can make rice taste like something

and you show up when you say you will, you’re ahead of most.”

Rinna steps in closer to the stall, starting to gather loose twine and tuck it into a basket.

No fuss, just the quiet choreography of closing up. She glances your way—quick,

grounded—like she’s checking you’re still standing where you should be and not

wandering into trouble.

The smell of grilled food drifts past again, louder now that the wind’s eased, and your

empty stomach helpfully re-announces itself in the silence between Olkin’s words and

Mellie’s sorting.

Mellie pauses mid-pumpkin, eyes cutting sideways at you. Not unkind. Assessing.

I stand awkwardly for a few seconds. There are things I want to get from the market, actually, but at the same time the thought of simply walking up to Olkin and Mellie with their daughter and then immediately skittering off seemed wrong. I'm torn between the concern that I might miss out on something I need and the inexplicable desire within me to want to impress these people in some small way.

I decide I'd simply keep to my 'honesty is the best policy' mantra, and allow Olkin and Mellie decide for me. "I was going to see if there was anything left around the market I might need," I say honestly, "but if you need any help packing up I'm happy to help out."

Kakariko Market Lane (Olkin & Mellie’s pumpkin stall) • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breeze

easing; warm, slanting light • Spring

Mellie stops mid-shove on a pumpkin like it just mouthed off to her. She looks you over

again—belt, gloves, the “I have been on a roof all day” grit you can’t fully hide—and then

gives a small, decisive nod.

“Good,” she says. Not warm, not cold. Practical. “If you’re offering, you’re lifting.”

Olkin’s mouth twitches again, like a smile that never quite commits. “Market’s not going

anywhere in the next five minutes. Vako and the others will still be squinting at coins when

the sun’s down.”

Mellie snaps a short instruction over her shoulder to Rinna—something in that familiar

mother-daughter cadence—and Rinna immediately starts bundling twine, sliding empty

baskets into each other, moving with the efficient, no-wasted-motion rhythm of someone

who’s done this a hundred times.

Mellie jerks her chin toward a squat stack of wooden crates and a burlap sack half-full of

stems and leaves. “Those go up first. Crates stacked neat. Sack tied. Don’t dump it—those

scraps feed the goats.”

Olkin shifts his weight and points with two fingers toward a small handcart tucked behind

the stall. “And if you can manage it without snapping the axle, pull that closer. We’ll load

heavy last.”

A couple of passersby drift by—one gives you a quick look, clocking you as “the tall

outsider who works” and then moving on. No laughter, no whispers loud enough to bite.
