Just the village doing its constant, watchful breathing.

Mellie is already turning back to her pumpkins, speaking to them under her breath like

she’s arguing with stubborn children. Rinna’s hands keep moving, but her eyes flick to you

once—brief and approving, like: Alright. Show you mean it.

The stall is in that sweet spot where it’s not chaos, but it’s also not packed up yet—enough

time to help and still make a pass through the market before it thins out completely.

I catch Rinna's glance and return it with one of my own to reassure her: *Yeah, I mean it.* I easily slip into the mode of helping my grandfather in his massive garden and orchard when I was growing up.

My life before now had easily made me a little bit of a 'renaissance man', a little bit of a polymath. Once upon a time that had felt like a burden, and I'd constantly done my best to downplay my own abilities, because if people

back then considered me to be of that reputation, then they held me to what I felt like an impossible standard, and I constantly felt like I was expected to be an expert on every subject matter. People always thought of me as a very intelligent person, buy when they found out I wasn't a complete and thorough master of any given thing I had an interest in, I always felt their disappointment. It also had always felt like pulling teeth to gdt help from anybody, since they always expected me to be able to do everything myself.

Here it wasn't like that at all. Nobody expected me to be an expert. They were simply pleased that I had an interest and was competent. And I had even earned some small surprised praise when I showed I had some skill—or even was *good*—at something.

It was an extremely encouraging and upbuilding experience.

I follow Olkin and Mellie's direction, finding solace in how much of my favourite pair of grandparents they reminded me.

Kakariko Market Lane (Olkin & Mellie’s pumpkin stall) • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breeze

easing; warm, slanting light • Spring

You slide into the work like it’s an old song your hands remember.

The crates are rough-hewn cedar, scuffed at the corners, each one still smelling faintly of

earth and vine. You stack them square—corners aligned, weight centered—so they won’t

shimmy when the cart hits the uneven stone.

Behind you, Mellie keeps muttering at the pumpkins as she checks each one like a jeweler

inspecting gems. “Too pale. Too soft. You—don’t you dare bruise on me now.” She gives

one a tiny, corrective tap with two fingers. Like discipline.

Olkin watches you take the handcart’s handle and test it with a careful pull, the way you’d

test a stubborn gate. He nods once—small, approving. “That’s it. Don’t yank. Wheels don’t

like being argued with.”

Rinna works opposite you, tying the sack with quick, tight knots. When she lifts it, she

shifts her hips and uses her legs—clean form, no showboating. She catches your eye again,

just a flick, and there’s the faintest hint of amusement like she’s clocking that you know

how to move around weight and tools without making it a performance.

A couple villagers drift past. One of the older women slows, eyes you, then the neatly

stacked crates, then Mellie. She gives Mellie a knowing little “hm” and keeps walking—no

words, but the verdict lands anyway: He’s useful.

Mellie points without looking up. “Those two crates go on the cart. Then the sack. Then

the smaller baskets. Keep the pumpkins last so I can count ‘em.”

Olkin adds, dry as dust: “And don’t put the pretty ones on the bottom unless you want to

meet Mellie’s other personality.”

Mellie’s head turns just enough that you can see her smile trying not to happen. “I only

have the one personality.”

“Sure,” Olkin says, utterly unconvinced.

The stall is almost ready to roll. The market around you is thinning—merchants calling last

prices, cloth flapping, the faint clink of rupees, someone laughing near the pond.

Rinna hoists the tied sack toward you, offering it up for the cart load, and Mellie finally

turns her attention fully to you for the first time since you offered help—eyes sharp,

appraising, but not unkind.

“You said you wanted to look around,” she says. “After we’re packed, go. But first—” she

taps the cart rail with two knuckles, indicating the final step.

“Lift with your back and I’ll personally salt your stew wrong.”

Olkin snorts.

Everything’s staged for the final load: sack, baskets, crates—pumpkins waiting.

The only question left is the pace: you can finish packing briskly and still catch the market

while there’s daylight… or slow it down and linger a little longer in this oddly-

grandparental pocket of the village.

I do my best to match Rinna's pace; she was close to my age but knew her parents well, so however she worked would be good enough for me. For her part, she moves at a comfortable and unrushed pace for a fit person in their early 30s, and she doesn't seem to mind outpacing her parents. Olkin and Mellie don't seem to mind either, actually stopping to talk with another older couple who pause as they're walking by.

I lift with my legs as Mellie hopes, a lesson I learned a long time ago—one does not get to be almost 196 cm without learning to treat their back well—and start pushing the cart up the slope beside Rinna as she shoulders two large bundles.

For the moment, we are more or less alone again. There are still people around, sure, but their numbers have dwindled and we're leaving most of them behind anyways as we head to Olkin and Mellie's house.

"I like your parents," I say while keeping my eyes on the cart. "They remind me of my father's parents."

Thought for 19s

Kakariko Village • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breeze easing; light cooling as the sun drops •

Spring

The cart complains in a steady wooden groan as you angle it up the slope—wheels

bumping over stone seams, the whole thing smelling like vine-sap, dirt, and pumpkins that

have been in the sun all day. Your legs do the honest work; your back stays politely

uninvolved. Mellie would approve, even from half a hill away.

Rinna moves ahead a few steps with those bundles like they weigh less than they have any

right to—shoulders set, pace easy, no wasted motion. She doesn’t rush you, but she also

doesn’t slow down to match you in that performative way people sometimes do. It’s…

refreshing. Like she assumes you can keep up because why wouldn’t you?

Behind, Olkin and Mellie have stopped, as you noticed, to talk with another older couple.

Their voices drift faintly up the lane—soft, familiar-sounding cadence, the kind of

conversation that could be about weather, prices, someone’s aching knee, and village

politics all in the same three breaths.

When you tell Rinna you like her parents, she glances back over her shoulder—quick and

unreadable for half a beat—then her mouth quirks like she’s trying not to smile too much.

“Careful,” she says, voice light but sincere. “If Mellie decides you’re ‘family-adjacent,’ she’ll

feed you and scold you forever. That’s the whole deal.”

The evening air shifts as you climb: cooler, greener. You pass a patch of herbs someone’s

hung to dry under an eave—sharp and clean in the nose. Your hands tighten once on the

cart handle as a wheel catches, then it rolls free again, and you keep the rhythm.

Rinna slows just slightly when you draw even with her again, enough that you’re side by

side for a stretch of the lane. Her freckles stand out more in the slanted light, and there’s a

little line of sweat at her temple from the day—nothing dramatic, just proof she worked.

“Your father’s parents,” she repeats, like she’s turning the words over for their shape. Not

prying. Just…not letting it bounce off. “That sounds like they were good to you.”

Ahead, Olkin and Mellie’s place is coming into view—fences, trelliswork, the familiar mess

of a working yard that’s been kept alive by stubborn hands and routine. Rinna angles

toward the gate with her bundles, and you’re a few strides behind with the cart, at the

moment where you either roll straight in and get to unloading… or you keep the thread of

that thought about grandparents alive while you’ve got this rare pocket of quiet.

I stop at the gate as Rinna does, letting her dictate the pause in the errand.

"I *adore* my grandparents." After a half a hearbeat I add: "On that side of the family. Most of my formative years were actually spent more with them than my own parents. My parents were good parents, don't get me wrong, but times were pretty hard when I was a just a little kid, and they had to stay very busy to keep up. So I spent most of the time with grandma and grandpa." I roll my jaw to one side and stare into the middle distance for a moment, remembering them but trying not to let my feelings get the better of me.

"I miss them a lot. Grandpa had a lot of land—well, a lot relative to what I'm used to anyways—and he had retired from being an engineer. He was good at everything. I mean *everything*. I know I have a silly habit of overlooking his foibles and idolising him. Sometimes I have to stop myself from trying to measure myself to the standard he set. I could try for a hundred years and only master half the skills he had. Grandma may not have been as varied in her skills, but what she was good at she was the best at. They both came to...the country my father and I were born in after surviving a war in their home country. Grandpa wasn't a soldier though. Invaders forced him to work. They killed all four of my great-grandparents on that side..."

I refocused my attention on Rinna, bringing my eyes to hers. "But that's depressing. I'm sure that's not what you wanted."

Thought for 15s

Kakariko Village • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Wind calmer; cooling light, long shadows •

Spring

Rinna’s hands pause on the gate latch. For a second she doesn’t do the polite thing—

doesn’t fill the space with a joke, doesn’t hurry you along to “make it less awkward.” She

just…listens.

In the slanted light, you can see the fine dust stuck to the sweat at her temples, the

freckles across her nose and collarbones like someone flicked paint from a brush, and the

way her forearms hold that quiet, worked strength—corded, not showy. Her hair’s pulled

back tight and practical, a few strands escaping to cling to her cheek.

When you refocus on her, your last line lands, and she exhales through her nose—half a

huff, half a tiny laugh with no humor in it.

“That is not depressing,” she says simply. “That is true.”

She hooks the latch and swings the gate inward, then sets one of her bundles down just

long enough to look you properly in the face—eyes steady, not pitying, not prying.

“And if it’s heavy to carry, you do not make it lighter by pretending it is not there,” she

adds. The words come out like she’s repeating something she’s heard her whole life.

Village wisdom. Mellie-wisdom.

From up the yard, you hear Mellie’s voice—sharp and familiar—scolding plants like they’ve

offended her personally. Olkin’s lower rumble answers from somewhere near the trellis.

Neither sounds alarmed. Just…home.

Rinna tips her chin toward the yard. “Come on. We’ll get this put away before my mother

decides the cart is judging her.”

She lifts her bundles again and steps through. As she does, she glances back once—quick,

checking you’re following—and her tone softens by a fraction.

“And Zeth?” she says, like an afterthought, but it isn’t. “You do not need to apologize for

missing people who were good to you.”

The yard opens ahead—packed earth, trellis shadows, the smell of vines and warm gourd-

skin—while Mellie turns back to her work with the pumpkins, still muttering like they’re

stubborn children.

I give the cart a stiff shove to get it going again and follow her to where we need to start unloading.

"That's kind of you to say," I respond sincerely. "Thanks. And thanks for...not..." I think about what Sana had said to me last night, obviously carried to her via the 'village network', "...caring about what the aunties are saying." I feel my face go very red and do my best to quickly hide it by looking away and busying myself unloading the cart, maybe correctly, maybe incorrectly.

Kakariko Village • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Wind easing; cool breeze, long shadows • Spring

The cart gives a reluctant creak as you muscle it forward again. Gravel pops under the

wheels. Rinna takes the lead without making a production of it—she just starts unloading

like this is the most normal thing in the world: market, haul, home, repeat.

At your mention of the aunties, she doesn’t look shocked. She doesn’t look guilty, either.

She just gives you a sideways glance—quick as a hammer tap—and one corner of her

mouth lifts.

“They are always saying something,” she says. Not dismissive—more like…weather report.

“If they are saying your name, it means you exist. If they stop saying it, then you worry.”

She steps in close to the cart and grabs one of the heavier bundles before you can,

shouldering it with practiced ease. Up close, you catch the details you don’t see on a roof:

a thin pale scar tucked under her jawline that vanishes into her collar, a dusting of sun-

freckles across her cheeks, and the faint scent of wood resin and smoke on her clothes—

cedar and hearth.

From the pumpkin patch, Mellie straightens with an exaggerated groan like she’s doing it

at the universe. She’s sturdy in the way older farm-strong people get—weathered hands,

forearms like braided rope, hair pulled back with a cloth tie that’s seen a thousand

workdays. Her eyes flick to you, then to Rinna, then back to you again—measuring, sharp,

not unkind.

Olkin emerges from near the trellis carrying a stack of folded cloth and twine. Broad-

shouldered, square-faced, the kind of man who looks like he was built out of fence posts.

His expression is neutral until his eyes land on the belt at your waist—then you get the

tiniest “hm” of approval, like he’s checking a tool someone finally bought after borrowing

his.

Mellie wipes her hands on her apron and calls over, “You—tall one. If you are going to go

red like a cooked crab every time someone talks, you will spend your whole life

overheated.”

Rinna makes a sound that might be a laugh if it decided to become one. She drops her

bundle by the porch and starts sorting: perishables together, cloth goods together, heavier

items closest to the door.

Olkin sets down the twine, looks at the cart, then at you. “You lift like you’ve done work

before,” he says, blunt as a mallet. “Good. Put the heavy sacks there—by the step. Do not

block the door. My wife will decide the doorway is cursed.”

Mellie turns back toward the vines, already mid-grumble, but not before adding—over her

shoulder—“And if you brought more mushrooms, you give them to me, not Sana, or she

will turn them into ‘a lesson’ and you will die of embarrassment.”

I do as Olkin asks as Mellie brings up the mushrooms, grateful of her offer to simply let mushrooms be mushrooms. I enjoy learning, but maybe not every single minute of the week.

"I will," I promise her. "Did you already get to use the ones I brought yesterday?"

Kakariko Village • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Wind easing; cool breeze, long shadows • Spring

Olkin’s instructions are simple, and you follow them: heavy sacks by the step, door left

clear. The cart settles with a final complain-y creak as the last load comes off.

At your question, Mellie pauses like you’ve asked something deeply philosophical about

the nature of gourds. Then she snorts.

“Used them?” she says, and there’s a little offended pride in it. “Boy, I fed them to my

husband.”

Olkin makes a sound—half cough, half laugh—that he tries to hide by bending to tug a

knot tight. It doesn’t work. His ears go slightly pink.

Mellie continues, pleased with herself. “Sliced. Pan. A little oil, little salt. Threw in greens.

He ate like he hadn’t seen food since the Calamity.” She jabs a thumb at him without

looking. “He said ‘Mmm’ twice. That is basically poetry from that man.”

Olkin straightens and gives you a look that says do not repeat this story in public. But he

also nods, short and sincere. “They were good.”

Rinna, who’s stacking cloth bundles with efficient little taps, adds without looking up, “He

went back for more. Don’t let him pretend he didn’t.”

Mellie plants her hands on her hips and gives you a once-over again—less like suspicion

now, more like deciding where you fit in a messy pantry. “If you found more today, you

bring them here. I will trade you something useful. Not rupees. Something you will actually

use.”

She turns back toward the vines, already resuming her scolding under her breath, but the

tone has softened—like she’s grumbling at pumpkins the way some people grumble at

family.

"Ngh, the day is too short," I say, half joking, half truth. "No mushrooms to offer today. I'll try and make some time to get some more soon though." I look at Olkin, "I love mushrooms."

Looking over the goods hauled back from the market I see that they're more or less finished being put back, and realise I should probably tear myself away before anything of value still at the market was gone. I was also getting rather peckish.

"I should probably get going though," I say, patting my hands on my worn trousers. My instincts say to give Olkin a firm handshake and Mellie a hug. Not sure what would be appropriate for Rinna. But, not wanting to overstep, I offer the customary bow of the head and then a wave as I leave back down the hill.

Thought for 15s

Kakariko Village • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy and bright, wind finally behaving • Spring

Olkin gives a short, approving nod at your bow—like you just passed a quiet test you did

not know he was giving. Mellie answers with a two-finger shoo that somehow manages to

be both “go on, then” and “don’t be a stranger.” Rinna’s wave is quick, casual, and a little

amused—like she’s used to people orbiting her parents’ gravity and getting lightly yanked

into chores.

Down the hill, the village smells like sun-warmed cedar, cooking rice, and damp earth. The

market’s in its “picked over and packing up” phase: awnings coming down, baskets being

re-lidded, merchants doing that last-ditch chant for anyone with late-day luck.

A few things stand out as you drift past:

Vako is already coiling straps with practiced speed, his stall looking leaner than it did

this morning. He’s all angles and efficiency—dark hair tied back, sleeves rolled, hands

moving like he’s tied ten thousand knots in his life.

A traveling cloth-and-gear peddler—a round-faced Hylian with a sunburnt nose and

a wide straw hat—has a little spread of practical stuff: cords, simple canvas wraps, a

couple of satchels, and what looks like a plain oilcloth cloak folded into a tight

rectangle. Nothing flashy. Exactly the sort of unromantic object that becomes precious

when the sky turns nasty.

A food stall is still going, sending out a warm, savory smell that makes the stomach’s

opinion known immediately.

You end up at a small fork of foot traffic: one way back toward the inn’s warmth and food,

the other threading between the last open stalls. The gear peddler lifts two fingers in

greeting and taps a squat, sturdy-looking satchel like it’s making a case for itself—quietly,

confidently—before someone else decides they need it more than you do.

I ponder the entire encounter with Rinna, Mellie and Olkin as I meander, my gut tugging me toward the warm, savoury smell. I know it's a bad idea to shop when hungry —you end up spending money you don't mean to—but I'm not sure if I can resist.

I do resist, though, at least long enough to check on the cloak. It's plain and simple, reminding me of the Hylian Hood that link wore in Breath of the Wild, except an undyed and unadorned brown, and long enough to be a real cloak.

I detect the round-faced and sun-touched peddlar approaching and mentally brace myself. I don't know what kind of merchant this one will be, but I'm uncertain if I have the fortitude for another hardball encounter like I'd had with Vako just this morning.

Kakariko Village Market Lane • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy, cooling toward evening •

Spring

The cloak looks even more honestly useful up close. Undyed brown—like bark or well-worn

leather—with a simple hood and a longer fall than the little “capelet” some travelers wear.

The fabric isn’t fancy, but it’s tight-woven and treated: when you pinch it between thumb

and forefinger it has that faintly waxy, oilcloth resistance that says I can take a drizzle and

keep my promise.

The peddler closes the last few steps with the soft confidence of someone who’s spent a

life walking up to strangers and making it not-weird.

He’s shorter than you by a lot, round-faced as advertised, with a sunburn across his nose

and cheeks and laugh-lines that suggest he’s either friendly or dangerously practiced at

looking friendly. A broad straw hat shadows his eyes; when he lifts his chin, you catch them

—warm brown, alert. His hands are thick-fingered and stained faintly with dye and oil, the

kind of hands that tie knots and haul packs all day.

He doesn’t crowd you. He stops at a respectful distance, then taps the cloak lightly with

two knuckles like he’s knocking on a door.

“Good eye,” he says, voice easy. “That one’s for weather, not show. Keeps the chill off when

the sun drops, and it won’t drink the rain like a sponge.”

He flips one edge of the cloak so you can see the seams—tight stitching, reinforced at the

shoulders. Then he gestures to the rest of his spread: a plain canvas satchel with a wide

strap, a smaller belt-pouch, and a simple wrap that could serve as a bedroll cover.

His gaze drops—briefly, professionally—to your new belt, the mallet loop, the work-worn

boots. Not judgment. Inventory.

“I’m packing up soon,” he adds, “but I’d rather sell than carry. Cloak, satchel, or both—

what’re you actually needing tonight?”

The merchant doesn't immediately come across as pushy, and whether that's genuine or a tactic I'm not sure, but I am grateful for it. Same can be said about his admittance that he'd rather sell than carry.

"Can't lie," I say, moving over to the canvas satchel but also glancing at the basic sleeping rap and one of his broad straw hats like I see the workers in the rice paddies wearing. "I like what I see but I have to be judicious." I indicate the cloak, the satchel, the hat and the sleeping

wrap, halfway to a traveler's starter kit, "What kind of deal can you offer me if I wanted all four of these?"

Thought for 10s

Kakariko Village Market Lane • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy, cooling toward evening •

Spring

The peddler’s mouth quirks like you just spoke his native language: bundle math.

He squats on his heels, palm up, and starts counting on thick fingers—quick, practiced, not

theatrical.

“Judicious is smart,” he says, giving the satchel strap a tug so you can feel it won’t pop on

the first hard walk. “All four… here’s the honest cut.”

He taps each item in turn:

The cloak: he pinches the hem and lets it fall. “Treated cloth. Holds up. 70 rupees.”

The satchel: he thumps the side and shows the stitching at the strap anchor.

“Reinforced. Doesn’t bite the shoulder as bad. 55.”

The straw hat: he knocks it, grinning. “This one’s plain. Keeps sun off, keeps rain out

of your eyes. 25.”

The sleeping wrap: he runs a thumb along the edge where it’s double-stitched.

“Waxed enough to keep the ground damp from soaking you. 35.”

He spreads his hands. “That’s 185 if you pick at them one by one.”

Then he tips his head toward the road out of the village—toward the idea of him carrying

it all back up a hill.

“If you take the lot and save me the load, I’ll do 160. And I’ll throw in a short length of cord

—good cord, not the snapping kind—so you can lash the wrap to the satchel.”

He lets the number hang there without pressing, just watching you with that calm

merchant attention—ready to pack up or ready to make the sale clean and quick.

I rub the tip of my ear, except this time it's secretly on purpose, allowing the merchant to imagine what the 'nervous tick' could mean.

If that was a mislead, then I fold the truth in with it. 160 rupees *seemed* like an okay deal. These were all new items, unlike my used belt. It was difficult for me to really judge given my limited experience in Hyrule, but I had at least some baseline based on what I had to pay as Link in the game. If I paid that though, it would nearly bankrupt me. I don't need to let the merchant know all of that, but it would hurt to let a hint of it slip. The most effective way to bargain was to mix the exaggeration with believable truth.

"Not sure I can stretch myself quite that far to be honest..."

Thought for 12s

Kakariko Village Market Lane • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy, cooling toward evening •

Spring

The peddler watches your fingers brush that pointed ear, and he doesn’t smirk—but his

eyes do that tiny merchant flicker that says I see what you’re doing. He shifts his weight,

the canvas of his little stall creaking, and studies you like you’re a riddle he can solve with

arithmetic.

Up close he’s got that sun-baked, road-worn look: round cheeks, a leathery tan, faint

crow’s-feet from squinting into glare, and hands that are all nicks and callus. His clothes

are practical—patched vest, plain trousers, sandals that have seen too many miles.

“Mm.” He nods once, slow. “That’s fair. Four pieces is a lot of rupees at once.”

He taps the cloak again, then the satchel, like he’s re-stacking the logic.

“I can’t cut it to nothing,” he says, not defensive—just matter-of-fact. “But I can shave it.”

He holds up two fingers.

“Option one: you take all four, no cord thrown in. 155.”

Then three fingers.

“Option two: you take the important two—cloak and satchel—and you come back for the

hat and wrap when you’ve got more coin. 120 for those two. They’re the ones that actually

change your life on the road.”

He pauses, eyes briefly flicking to your belt pouch—more observation than accusation—

then back to your face.

“If you’re trying not to bleed yourself dry, that’s the cleanest way.” He leans back, letting

the breeze ruffle the cloak’s hem. “I’ll keep the hat and wrap here until dusk. After that,

they go back on my back.”

He stops talking and simply waits, hands open, giving you space to decide without

crowding you.

I hum thoughtfully. "When do you think you'll be back through here again?" I ask simply, hoping the answer is simple too.

Kakariko Village Market Lane • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy, cooling toward evening •

Spring

The peddler rolls his lower lip like he’s counting days on his teeth.

“If the roads behave?” he says. “About nine or ten days. I run a loop—Kakariko to Hateno,

then back by Dueling Peaks if the weather stays kind and nobody decides to get brave on

the road.”

He gives a small shrug, practical rather than gloomy. “Could be a week. Could be two.

Depends on rain, trouble, and how fast folks elsewhere buy me empty.”

I nod, understanding that I may not see this product again if I let it go. Then again, even if I was still in Kakariko when he came back, it may very well not be available anyways. He'd be doing his best to sell it no matter where he want. Less of a concern with the hat, since he probably had a constant supply of those anyways, but still...

I tally a few things in my head. The totals he listed off, the deals he already offered, trying to find a middle ground that might satisfy us both. "What if...instead of all four for a discount and some free cord, I take the cloak and satchel, the big items, full price at 125, but you throw in the hat for free instead of the cord. I'll try another day on the sleep wrap."

Kakariko Village Market Lane • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy, cooling toward evening •

Spring

The peddler’s eyes flick down—cloak, satchel, then to your face—like he’s weighing

whether you’re crafty or just broke and earnest (often the same animal).

“Free?” he repeats, not offended, just…merchant-proud. He tugs the brim of one of the

straw hats with two fingers.

“I can’t do free,” he says, “or I teach my own hands bad habits.”

He pauses a beat—then softens, like he’s decided he’d rather sell than pack.

“But I’ll meet you in the middle: cloak and satchel for 125, and I’ll do the hat for 5.” He

taps the stack like it’s a settled thing. “That’s cheaper than I’d give my cousin, and my

cousin’s a liar.”

He tilts his head toward the sleeping wrap. “Wrap’ll still be here in ten minutes if you

change your mind. Probably.”

I nod, satisfied. That was fair, bordering on generous. "I can swing that." I unbind the rupee pouch built into my new belt without flair or show and start picking out the necessary amount. It hurt to give away so much of what little I had, but I feel good that it is justified that these are necessary items that I can make last a long time if I treat them right, and not just some temporary indulgence.

Dropping the correct amount into the pudgy hand of the merchant, I swing the satchel over a shoulder, hang the cloak from one arm and immediately don the hat.

It occurs to me that there might be some smaller, cheaper items I may still need and may still be available. Paper, maybe a pencil, or one of those...toothbrush-by-some- name-I-forget that Paya told me about. I'm still hungry and the nearby food vendor is a strong temptation to spend on something I really ought not. I purposefully avoid that vendor and start making my way the direction of the Shuteye Inn, where I know food is already included with my paid-for room. Though it was slightly earlier than I'd normally be making back to the inn. Somehow. Oh well. If Sana or Ollie didn't have anything ready yet, I still had my rice balls which I had planned on eating today anyways. If I tried to save them too long they'd just go bad anyways.

Thought for 8s

Kakariko Village Market Lane → Shuteye Inn • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy, cooling fast •

Spring

The peddler’s pudgy hand closes around the rupees like he’s catching a fish before it slips

the net. No flourish, no blessing—just a quick nod of respect for a clean deal. Up close,

you can see the little sun-cracks at the corners of his eyes and the faint creases in his

palms from hauling canvas and cord day after day.

The satchel’s strap bites in at first—new canvas always feels a little stiff—but it sits well on

your shoulder. The cloak hangs with a satisfying weight, the kind that promises it’ll actually

do something when the air turns mean. The hat… the hat is instantly practical. Shade cuts

across your vision like a lowered brow.

As you step away, the market noise thins behind you in layers: bargaining voices, a child

laughing, the soft clink of rupees, the faint thump-thump of someone packing crates. The

food stall smells like warm rice and sizzling oil and regret for people trying to be

“responsible.” You keep moving anyway.

On the lane toward the inn, a pair of older women drift past carrying bundles—one gives

you a quick, assessing look that lands on the hat and then flicks away as if she’s already

filed you into some mental ledger. Not hostile. Just…Kakariko.

By the time the Shuteye comes into view, the sky’s taken on that spring-evening tilt—gold

going slightly copper at the edges. Inside, you catch familiar sounds through the open

front: bowls clinking, low conversation, someone moving with purpose behind the counter.

Warmth spills out with the smell of stew and toasted barley tea.

You reach the threshold with your new kit settling into place—satchel on shoulder, cloak in

the crook of your arm, hat on your head—early enough that the inn is still in that in-

between state: not quiet, not yet fully settled for the night.

Not spying any of the little things, I momentarily concede defeat and duck into the inn. Even though it’s a little early for dinner, I smell the stew and the tea, and decide that maybe it’s not too early after all. I take my newly acquired goods and head up to my room. The peg near the door finally gets a cloak to hang upon it, and the hat goes over it, hanging by its chin-strap. The satchel, at least for the moment, goes in the chest with my sword, shield and little bundle of teeth-cleaning powder. The cloth which had

until this morning been tied up as a makeshift wallet for my rupees is extracted from my new rupee belt pouch, no longer required for that purpose. I intend to fold it up and stash it in my satchel, but then think twice. If I clean it properly so it didn’t taste like sweaty hands, chest dust and money, it was still a perfectly acceptable piece of cloth. And with a perfectly acceptable piece of cloth, I wouldn’t have to borrow towel corners from the inn to clean my teeth tonight.

So for now, the cloth gets folded but placed in my pocket, not the satchel, then I head downstairs to check with Ollie about whether I actually was too early for a bite to eat or not.

Thought for 7s

Shuteye Inn, Kakariko Village • Late afternoon, Day 6 • Breezy outside, warm indoors •

Spring

Downstairs, the inn is in its “between” mood: not the full dinner rush, but no longer quiet

either. A few villagers linger with cups in hand, and the air tastes like toasted barley and

simmering broth.

Ollie’s behind the counter, sleeves rolled, doing three things at once the way innkeepers

apparently learn in the womb. Up close you catch more of him than you usually do from

across a room: early-to-mid 20s, soft-faced but tired around the eyes, dark hair that

refuses to stay neatly tied back. His hands move fast—practiced—like he’s constantly

afraid the inn will fall over if he stops.

He looks up as you approach, eyes flicking (briefly) to the new satchel strap line across

your shoulder and then away, polite enough not to stare.

Sana’s there too—half in the kitchen threshold, half in the common room—older,

compact, and sturdy in that “has lifted a lifetime of heavy pots” way. Her green-stained

hands are clean enough for food work, but the stain never really leaves. She doesn’t say

anything yet; she just watches, the way someone watches weather.

The stew pot is going. Not fully “dinner’s served,” but close—little bubbles breaking the

surface, that deep savory smell building like a promise.

Ollie speaks first, low and friendly, like he’s meeting you where you’re at without making it

a thing.

If you want stew right now, he can do a “small bowl” and tea without fuss—more of

an early plate than the full evening serving.

If you’d rather wait for proper dinner, he’ll have it ready soon, and you can sit with a

cup while the pot finishes.

He sets a cup within easy reach on the counter—empty for the moment—like he’s already

halfway to pouring.

What you do next:

Take the small bowl now and settle in at the counter.

Just take tea for the moment and wait for the full dinner serving.

Head back up briefly to stash anything else, then come down for the proper meal.

Something else.
